abstract: The avian skeletal α-actin gene was used as a template for construction of a myogenic expression vector that was utilized to direct expression of a human IGF-I cDNA in cultured muscle cells and in striated muscle of transgenic mice. The proximal promoter region, together with the first intron and 1.8 kilobases of 3'-noncoding flanking sequence of the avian skeletal α-actin gene directed high level expression of human insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) in stably transfected C<sub>2</sub>C<sub>12</sub> myoblasts and transgenic mice. Expression of the actin/IGF-I hybrid gene in C<sub>2</sub>C<sub>12</sub> muscle cells increased levels of myogenic basic helix-loop-helix factor and contractile protein mRNAs and enhanced myotube formation. Expression of the actin/IGF-I hybrid gene in mice elevated IGF-I concentrations in skeletal muscle 47-fold resulting in myofiber hypertrophy. IGF-I concentrations in serum and body weight were not increased by transgene expression, suggesting that the effects of transgene expression were localized. These results indicate that sustained overexpression of IGF-I in skeletal muscle elicits myofiber hypertrophy and provides the basis for manipulation of muscle physiology utilizing skeletal α-actin-based vectors.

The cytokine tumor necrosis factor α (TNFα) and the growth factor basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) are known to induce early response genes such as c-fos and c-jun in various cell types. Activation of AP-1, a heterodimeric complex of Fos and Jun proteins, is required for matrix metalloproteinase production and cell proliferation. However, the signaling pathways by which these two factors influence the expression and activities of AP-1 remain currently poorly characterized. Several studies have shown that cytokines induce reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, but growth factor induction of ROS has not been reported. In the present study we demonstrate that both TNFα and bFGF induce ROS production, and that this is a common signaling event involved in the stimulation of c-fos gene expression in chondrocytes. To our knowledge, this is the first report directly demonstrating ROS production upon stimulation with a growth factor. TNFα and bFGF induction of ROS production is mediated through flavonoid-containing enzymes such as NADPH oxidase. Moreover, the ROS nitric oxide is not responsible for the induction of c-fos expression by TNFα and bFGF. In addition, the inhibitory effects of antioxidants on c-fos expression may account for their protective roles against proliferative and inflammatory diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular diseases, and arthritis.

The pathologic picture in ischemic tissue injury shares features with the inflammatory response, including production of proinflammatory cytokines. Hypoxia-mediated induction of interleukin-6 (IL-6), a cytokine with anti-inflammatory properties, could set in motion mechanisms limiting inflammation in ischemia. Exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to H (pO2 ≍12–16 torr) increased transcription of IL-6, elevated levels of IL-6 mRNA, and induced elaboration of IL-6 antigen in a time-dependent manner. Exposure of mice to hypoxia increased IL-6 transcripts in the lung, and immunostaining revealed a striking increase in IL-6 antigen in pulmonary vasculature. Transfection of ECs with deletion chimeric IL-6 promoter-chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) constructs showed hypoxia-mediated 9–11-fold induction with –1200/+13, –596/+13, and –225/+13 but no induction with –111/+13. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs) using –225/–111 as the labeled probe demonstrated enhanced binding activity in nuclear extracts of hypoxic ECs and lung; the appearance of the gel shift band was prevented by excess unlabeled probe (–225/–111), and hypoxia-mediated enhancement of the band was blocked by a probe corresponding to the nuclear factor (NF)-IL-6 site (–158/–145). The hypoxia-enhanced band on EMSA displayed a supershift with antibody to CCAAT-enhancer-binding protein β (C/EBP-β), but antibody to C/EBP-α or -δ was without effect. Transfection of ECs with a construct comprising thymidine kinase promoter, –225/–111 in either the 5′ to 3′ or 3′ to 5′ orientation, and the reporter CAT showed this region to be an enhancer (≍8-fold) under hypoxia. EMSA with the NF-IL-6 probe revealed a prominent induction of binding activity with nuclear extracts from hypoxic ECs and whole lung. Constructs with –158/–145 and the CAT reporter gene showed induction when transfected into hypoxic ECs, whereas a similar construct with the NF-IL-6 motif mutationally inactivated failed to display hypoxia-induced expression. Furthermore, the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) gene, whose product contributes to ischemic pathology and contains a putative regulatory NF-IL-6 site, demonstrated enhanced binding activity for its NF-IL-6 motif and induction of TNF mRNA based on analysis of hypoxic lung. These data indicate that hypoxia induces expression of IL-6, most likely a result of hypoxic activation at the NF-IL-6 site, and suggest that other genes with regulatory NF-IL-6 sites may also be induced by a similar mechanism. In view of parallels between the pathologic picture in ischemia and that associated with inflammation (1Granger D. Am. J. Physiol. 1988; 255: H1269-H1275PubMed Google Scholar, 2Mullane K. Smith C. Pathophysiology of Severe Ischemic Myocardial Injury. Kluwer Academic Publishers, Dordrecht, The Netherlands1990: 239-267Google Scholar), recent studies have focused on ischemia-related induction of proinflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF 1The abbreviations used are: TNF, tumor necrosis factor; IL, interleukin; EC(s), endothelial cell(s); NF, nuclear factor; C/EBP, CCAAT-enhancer-binding protein; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; PCR, polymerase chain reaction; ELISA, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay(s); bp, base pair(s); CAT, chloramphenicol acetyl transferase; TK, thymidine kinase; HIF, hypoxia-inducible factor.)-α, interleukins (IL)-l and -8 by endothelial cells (ECs), and mononuclear phagocytes (3Shreeniwas R. Such cytokines induce endothelial expression of leukocyte adherence molecules, stimulate directional cell migration, and thus target polymorphonuclear leukocytes to sites of ischemic injury and lead to their activation (7Pober J. Am. J. Pathol. 1988; 133: 426-433PubMed Google Scholar). These mediators have also been shown to induce changes in vascular permeability and thrombogenicity, further contributing to vascular dysfunction. The potential pathologic significance of cytokines in ischemic settings is emphasized by the protective effect of blocking antibody to TNF in hepatic ischemia (8Colletti L. Remick D. Burtch G. Kunkel S. Strieter R. Campbell D. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 85: 1936-1943Crossref PubMed Scopus (771) Google Scholar) and antibody to IL-8 in lung ischemia (9Sekido N. Mukaida N. Harada A. Nakanishi I. Watanabe Y. Matsushima K. Nature. 1993; 365: 654-657Crossref PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar). IL-6 is a multifunctional cytokine that affects multiple cell types. The contribution of IL-6 to inflammation has been the subject of many studies. The proinflammatory cytokines TNF and IL-1 both elicit IL-6 synthesis in a range of target cells, including ECs, and stimulation by IL-6 results in expression of acute phase hepatic proteins, such as C-reactive protein and fibrinogen (10Kishimoto T. Hirano T. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1988; 6: 485-512Crossref PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar). Recent studies have addressed another facet of IL-6 activity: the role of this mediator as an anti-inflammatory agent (11Barton B. Jackson J. Infect. Immun. 1993; 6: 1496-1499Crossref Google Scholar, 12Aderka D. Le J. Vilcek J. J. Immunol. 1989; 143: 3517-3523PubMed Google Scholar, 13Schindler R. Mancilla J. Endres S. Ghorbani R. Clark S. Dinarello C. Blood. 1990; 75: 40-47Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14Tilg H. Trehu E. Atkins M. Dinarello C. Mier J. Blood. 1994; 83: 113-118Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 15Ulich T. Yin S. Guo K. Yi E. Remick D. delCastillo J. Am. J. Pathol. 1991; 138: 1097-1101PubMed Google Scholar). IL-6 suppresses the generation of IL-1 and TNF in macrophages exposed to lipopolysaccharide in culture and in mice infused with lipopolysaccharide (12Aderka D. Le J. Vilcek J. J. Immunol. 1989; 143: 3517-3523PubMed Google Scholar, 13Schindler R. Mancilla J. Endres S. Ghorbani R. Clark S. Dinarello C. Blood. 1990; 75: 40-47Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It also attentuates the inflammatory response to lipopolysaccharide administered intratracheally (15Ulich T. Yin S. Guo K. Yi E. Remick D. delCastillo J. Am. J. Pathol. 1991; 138: 1097-1101PubMed Google Scholar). The effect of IL-6 to increase production of soluble TNF and IL-1 receptors, capable of preempting these proinflammatory ligands, also supports an anti-inflammatory role for this cytokine (25Grenett H. Danley D. Strick C. Otterness I. Fuentes N. Nesbitt J. Fuller F. Gene (Amst.). 1991; 101: 267-271Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). In view of the anti-inflammatory properties of IL-6, we considered the hypothesis that hypoxia, a common denominator of ischemic microenvironments, might elicit IL-6 production in vascular cells, such as ECs and smooth muscle cells, thereby activating protective mechanisms. Our results indicate that IL-6 is induced in response to oxygen deprivation by hypoxia-mediated activation of nuclear binding activity for the nuclear factor (NF)-IL-6 motif. Activation of DNA-binding proteins, presumably in the C/EBP family, during oxygen deprivation could potentially regulate expression of other gene products relevant to ischemia, including IL-8, TNF, and granulocyte/colony-stimulating factor (8Colletti L. Remick D. Burtch G. Kunkel S. Strieter R. Campbell D. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 85: 1936-1943Crossref PubMed Scopus (771) Google Scholar, 16Akira S. Isshiki H. Sguita T. Tanabe O. Kinoshita S. Nishio Y. Nakajima T. Hirano T. Kishimoto T. EMBO J. 1990; 8: 1897-1906Crossref Scopus (1211) Google Scholar, 17Bussolino F. Wang J.-M. Defilippi P. Turrini F. Sanavio F. Edgell C.-J. Aglietta M. Arese P. Mantovani A. Nature. 1989; 337: 471-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (552) Google Scholar, 18Yong K. Cohen H. Khwaja A. Jones H. Linch D. Blood. 1991; 77: 1675-1680Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Consistent with this hypothesis, TNF transcripts were found to be elevated in hypoxic mouse lung. This indicates that activation of NF-IL-6 nuclear binding activity in hypoxic tissue has complex consequences, affecting both pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines. Human umbilical vein ECs were prepared as described (3Shreeniwas R. Koga S. Karakurum M. Pinsky D. Kaiser E. Brett J. Wolitzky B. Norton C. Plocinski J. Benjamin W. Burns D. Goldstein A. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 2333-2339Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar). For experiments, human ECs were from passages 1–3 grown in medium 199 containing endothelial cell growth supplement (Sigma), heparin (90 µg/ml; Sigma), human serum (5%; Gemini, Calabasas, CA), and fetal bovine serum (15%; Gemini). Bovine pulmonary artery ECs were harvested by scraping pulmonary artery vessel segments obtained from the abattoir, and the cells were grown to passage 2–3 using minimal essential medium containing fetal bovine serum (10%; Gemini). ECs were subjected to hypoxia by placing them in an environmental chamber (Coy Laboratory Products, Ann Arbor, MI) which provided a controlled temperature (37 °C) and atmosphere with the indicated amount of oxygen, carbon dioxide (5%) and the balance made up of nitrogen (3Shreeniwas R. Koga S. Karakurum M. Pinsky D. Kaiser E. Brett J. Wolitzky B. Norton C. Plocinski J. Benjamin W. Burns D. Goldstein A. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 2333-2339Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar). Use of this chamber for cell culture has been described previously (3Shreeniwas R. Koga S. Karakurum M. Pinsky D. Kaiser E. Brett J. Wolitzky B. Norton C. Plocinski J. Benjamin W. Burns D. Goldstein A. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 2333-2339Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar). The pH of the medium remained unchanged throughout experiments; pO2 in the medium was ≍12–15 torr (oxygen was leached continuously from the tissue culture plasticware during the course of the experiments). The glucose concentration fell by 35–50% (this degree of glucose depletion does not induce the described changes in IL-6 expression described in the studies below). Mouse ECs, generously provided by Dr. R. Auerbach (University of Wisconsin, Madison; 19), were grown in DMEM containing fetal bovine serum (10%) and penicillin/streptomycin. Cultured human smooth muscle cells were prepared from aortic segments within 12 h of explantation (20Colucci W. Brock T. Gimbrone M. Alexander R. Mol. Pharmacol. 1985; 27: 517-524PubMed Google Scholar). IL-6 expression by ECs was studied by examining induction of IL-6 transcripts, using PCR analysis and Southern blotting, changes in IL-6 transcription, using nuclear run-on analysis, and production of IL-6 antigen, using a specific ELISA. PCR analysis was performed on total RNA extracted from normoxic or hypoxic EC cultures using the acid-guanidinium thiocyanate procedure (Stratagene Inc., Torrey Pines, CA) using a reverse transcriptase-PCR kit from Perkin-Elmer and primers for IL-6 (mouse and human) and the housekeeping gene β-actin (obtained from Clontech, Palo Alto CA). Amplification by PCR was performed using the following thermocycling parameters for human EC and smooth muscle cell samples. Each cycle consisted of incubations at 94 °C for 1 min, 50 °C for 2 min, and 72 °C for 2 min for a total of 35 cycles for IL-6 and the housekeeping gene (cDNA was amplified simultaneously with primers for IL-6 and the housekeeping gene). Parameters for thermocycling on samples from mouse ECs were 95 °C for 2 min for one cycle, followed by 95 °C for 1 min and 60 °C for 1 min for 35 cycles, and 60 °C for 7 min. Products were analyzed by agarose gel electrophoresis (1%) and visualized by ethidium bromide staining under ultraviolet light, transferred to nylon membranes, and Southern hybridization was performed using 32P-labeled human or murine IL-6 cDNA (21; Clontech). The IL-6 cDNA did not contain the region included in the IL-6 primers. Nuclei were isolated, and in vitro transcription was performed as described previously (22Bartalena L. Fansetti A. Flink I.-L. Robbins J. Mol. Endocrinol. 1992; 6: 935-942Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 23Kasahana T. Mukaida N. Yamashita K. Yagisawa H. Akahoshi T. Matsushima K. Immunology. 1991; 74: 60-67PubMed Google Scholar). Labeled RNA was hybridized to linearized plasmid DNA (mouse IL-6 or β-actin) immobilized on nitrocellulose membranes for 48 h at 42 °C. Filters were washed first in 2 × SSC, 0.1% sodium dodecyl sulfate at 65 °C twice for 15 min each and then once in 0.1 × SSC, 0.1% sodium dodecyl sulfate at 65 °C for 60 min followed by air drying, and exposure to Kodak x-ray film at –70 °C. ELISA for murine IL-6 antigen elaborated into culture supernatants was performed using a kit from Biosource International (Camarillo, CA). The limit of detection in this assay is <8 pg/ml. Expression of IL-6 in the lungs of mice exposed to hypoxia was studied by PCR analysis and immunostaining. Mice (CD1) were subjected to oxygen deprivation as described previously (6Karakurum M. Shreeniwas R. Chen J. Pinsky D. Yan S.-D. Anderson M. Sunouchi K. Major J. Hamilton T. Kuwabara K. Rot A. Nowygord R. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 93: 1564-1570Crossref PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar) using a controlled environment chamber. Animals were placed in the chamber and allowed free access to food and water. The system parameters were adjusted to a final oxygen concentration of 6% oxygen with the balance of the gas mixture made up of nitrogen (6Karakurum M. Shreeniwas R. Chen J. Pinsky D. Yan S.-D. Anderson M. Sunouchi K. Major J. Hamilton T. Kuwabara K. Rot A. Nowygord R. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 93: 1564-1570Crossref PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar). At the indicated times, mice were sacrificed, and lung tissue was collected for extraction of total RNA using the acid-guanidinium method as described above. PCR utilized primers for murine IL-6, TNF-α, and for β-actin (all from Clontech) and was performed as described. For immunostaining, lung was rapidly harvested from normoxic or hypoxic animals, fixed overnight with formalin (3.5%) in phosphate-buffered saline, dehydrated, and embedded in paraffin by standard procedures (24Brett J. Schmidt A.-M. Zou Y.-S. Yan S.-D. Weidman E. Pinsky D.P. Neeper M. Przysiecki M. Shaw A. Migheli A. Stern D. Am. J. Pathol. 1993; 143: 1699-1712PubMed Google Scholar). Immunohistochemical studies used sections that were rehydrated, incubated in blocking buffer (1% bovine serum albumin and 2% normal goat serum in phosphate-buffered saline) for 30 min at 37 °C, washed in phosphate-buffered saline, exposed to affinity-purified rabbit anti-mouse IL-6 IgG (25Grenett H. Danley D. Strick C. Otterness I. Fuentes N. Nesbitt J. Fuller F. Gene (Amst.). 1991; 101: 267-271Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar), washed again, and incubated with biotinylated goat anti-rabbit immunoglobulin followed by peroxidase-conjugated avidin (Sigma). Localization of peroxidase conjugates was revealed using aminoethylcarbazole as the chromogen. Nonimmune rabbit IgG replaced the anti-IL-6 IgG for controls. Transient transfection was performed with deletion chimeric constructs of the IL-6 promoter with a chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) reporter gene including: pIC1200 (–1200/+13), pIC596 (-596/+ 13), pIC225 (-225/+13) and pIC11O (–110/+13) as described previously (21Ray A. Tatter S. May L. Sehgal P.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 6701-6705Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar, 26Ray A. Sassone-Corsi P. Sehgal P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 5537-5547Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar, 27Ray A. LaForge K. Sehgal P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 5736-5746Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). Two additional constructs, pTKCi (225/111) and pTKCi (111/225), consisting of the thymidine kinase basal promoter (pTKC; –80/+18) ligated to the indicated portion of the IL-6 promoter, as described (26Ray A. Sassone-Corsi P. Sehgal P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 5537-5547Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar). To analyze further the contribution of the NF-IL-6 site (–158/–145) to hypoxia-mediated induction of IL-6, a wild type and a series of mutationally inactivated constructs were made (termed the YSF series). The YSF series of oligonucleotides were annealed as follows.Tabled 1YSF-1 (for pYSF52)CACATTGCACAATCTGCCGGGTGTAACGTGTTAGACTTAAYSF-2 (for pYSF53)CACACTACACAATCTGCCGGGTGTGATGTGTTAGACTTAAYSF-3 (for pYSF54)CACATTGCAAACTCTGCCGGGTGTAACGTTTGAGACTTAAYSF-4 (for pYSF55)CACACTACAAACTCTGCCGGGTGTGATGTTTGAGACTTAA Open table in a new tab They contain flanking ApaI and EcoRI sites and were cloned into pGEM-7Zf(+) upstream of the thymidine kinase promoter. The CAT fragment was inserted between HindIII and BamHI sites on pGEM-7Zf(+) to give pYSF52, pYSF53, pYSF54, and pYSF55. DNA sequencing confirmed the identity of each of these constructs (see Fig. 7). These three mutations have previously been shown to render the NF-IL-6 site inactive (16Akira S. Isshiki H. Sguita T. Tanabe O. Kinoshita S. Nishio Y. Nakajima T. Hirano T. Kishimoto T. EMBO J. 1990; 8: 1897-1906Crossref Scopus (1211) Google Scholar, 28Hensel G. Meichle A. Hizenmaier K. Kronke M. Lymphokine Res. 1989; 8: 347-351PubMed Google Scholar). The calcium phosphate-mediated cotransfection procedure for adherent cells (29Sambrook J. Fritsch E. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual.2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar) was employed with the following modifications. Briefly, the day before transfection, exponentially growing cells were harvested by trypsinization, replated at a density of 1.2 × 106/100-mm dish in DMEM containing fetal bovine serum (5 and 7% for HeLa and ECs, respectively), and cultures were incubated at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2. Calcium phosphate-DNA coprecipitates were prepared by adding chimeric IL-6 promoter-reporter plasmid DNA (10–20 µg) and pSV-β-galactosidase plasmid (2–10 µg) to deionized water (0.5 ml) with CaCl2 (0.25 m), mixing with an equal volume of Hepes-buffered saline, and incubating at room temperature for 30 min. DNA-calcium phosphate coprecipitate was added dropwise to plates, and the mixture was swirled to achieve uniform mixing and returned to the incubator. For ECs, after 8–12 h of transfection, cultures were washed twice with balanced salt solution, and then the medium was changed to DMEM containing 7% fetal bovine serum. After another 28 h at 37 °C, the medium from EC cultures was aspirated, cells were washed with balanced salt solution, and one of the indicated medium changes was made for each of the following experimental conditions. For hypoxic and normoxic conditions, serum-free DMEM was added; for serum induction, DMEM with 10% fetal bovine serum as added. EC cultures were then incubated for 12 h at 37 °C with 5% CO2 in either normoxia or the hypoxia chamber. For HeLa cells, cotransfection was performed for 36 h; the change of medium was performed as described above for ECs, and cultures were then incubated at 37 °C for another 12 h in normoxia or hypoxia. After the incubation period, cell extracts were prepared by three freeze-thaw cycles, followed by heating for 10 min at 60 °C, centrifugation, and harvesting supernatant for CAT assay (Promega, Madison WI) and protein determination (Bradford assay; Bio-Rad). To control for efficiency of transfection, β-galactosidase activity (Promega) was determined in cell extracts prior to heating (this was used to normalize CAT activity in samples). EMSAs were performed using nuclear extracts prepared from normoxic or hypoxic ECs, HeLa cells, or lung tissue from animals exposed to normoxia or hypoxia for 4 h by the method of Dignam et al. (30Dignam J. Lebovitz R. Roeder R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1983; 11: 1475-1489Crossref PubMed Scopus (9160) Google Scholar). These extracts were prepared in an environment with the same ambient oxygen tension as that in the experiment. Complementary 115-bp oligonucleotides representing –225/–111 bp from the IL-6 promoter were prepared from pTKCi225/111. In other experiments, complementary oligonucleotides representing a portion of the human IL-6 (–158/–145 bp) and the human TNF (-196/-183) promoters containing a putative NF-IL-6 site (16Akira S. Isshiki H. Sguita T. Tanabe O. Kinoshita S. Nishio Y. Nakajima T. Hirano T. Kishimoto T. EMBO J. 1990; 8: 1897-1906Crossref Scopus (1211) Google Scholar, 28Hensel G. Meichle A. Hizenmaier K. Kronke M. Lymphokine Res. 1989; 8: 347-351PubMed Google Scholar, 31Akira S. Hirano T. Taga T. Kishimoto T. FASEB J. 1990; 4: 2860-2867Crossref PubMed Scopus (1155) Google Scholar) were employed. From IL-6 this included 5′-ACATTGCACAATCT-3′ (IL-6–1) and 5′-AGATTGTGCAAT-GT-3′ (IL-6–2). From TNF oligomers included 5′-AACTTTCCAAAT-CC-3′ (TNF-1) and 5′-GGATTTGGAAAGTT-3′ (TNF-2). Oliognucleotides were annealed and 5′-end labeled with [32P]ATP (3,000 Ci/mmol) with T4 polynucleotide kinase using standard procedures (29Sambrook J. Fritsch E. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual.2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). Binding reactions were performed by preincubating nuclear extract protein (1–5 µg) in 20 mM Hepes, pH 7.9, 60 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 0.1 m EDTA, 10% glycerol, 0.5 mM dithiothreitoln 2 µg poly(dI-dC) at room temperature for 10 min, followed by the addition of the double-stranded 32P-labeled oligonucleotide (≍35 fmol) and a second incubation at room temperature for 20 min. Where indicated, antiserum to C/EBP-α, -β, or -δ (1 µl of 1:10 dilution; generously provided by Dr. S. McKnight, Tularik, South San Francisco, CA) was incubated with nuclear extract at room temperature for 1 h, and then the procedure was as above. Samples (5 µg of protein in each lane) were loaded directly onto nondenaturing polyacrylamide/bisacrylamide (4% for the 115-bp probe; 8% for the 14-bp probe) prepared in 45 mM Tris, 45 mM boric acid, 0.1 m EDTA (0.5 × TBE). Electrophoresis was performed at room temperature for 1.5–2 h at 200 V. For competition studies, a 100-fold molar excess of one of the above unlabeled probes was employed or unlabeled 18-bp probe for hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-l (32Semenza G. Wang G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 5447-5454Crossref PubMed Scopus (2209) Google Scholar) was used. In the latter case the probe included 5′-GCCCTACGTGCTGTCTCA-3′ (HIF-1–1) and 5′-TGAGA-CAGCCGTAGGGC-3′ (HIF-1–2). Oligonucleotide probes for Spl, used as controls for nonspecific binding, were as described previously (33Anderson M. Freytag S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1991; 11: 1935-1943Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). Exposure of cultured murine, human, or bovine ECs to hypoxia (pO2) ≍12–14 torr) did not alter cell viability as assessed by (i) continued incorporation of [3H]leucine into protein with a reduction of only ≍30% at the longest time points, 24 h of hypoxia; (ii) lack of release of intracellular contents, such as lactate dehydrogenase; (iii) continued exclusion of trypan blue; and (iv) maintenance of cell adherence to the growth substrate. This is consistent with results of previous studies (3Shreeniwas R. Koga S. Karakurum M. Pinsky D. Kaiser E. Brett J. Wolitzky B. Norton C. Plocinski J. Benjamin W. Burns D. Goldstein A. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 2333-2339Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar, 4Koga S. Ogawa S. Kuwabara K. Brett J. Leavy J. Ryan J. Koga Y. Plocinski J. Benjamin W. Burns D. Stern D. J. Invest. 1990; 85: 1090-1098Crossref PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar). Despite maintenance of cellular integrity, this degree of hypoxia has been shown to induce changes in EC expression of genes relevant to vascular homeostasis, such as IL-1 and -8 (3Shreeniwas R. Koga S. Karakurum M. Pinsky D. Kaiser E. Brett J. Wolitzky B. Norton C. Plocinski J. Benjamin W. Burns D. Goldstein A. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 2333-2339Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar, 6Karakurum M. Shreeniwas R. Chen J. Pinsky D. Yan S.-D. Anderson M. Sunouchi K. Major J. Hamilton T. Kuwabara K. Rot A. Nowygord R. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 93: 1564-1570Crossref PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar), leading us to examine changes in IL-6 gene expression as well. Exposure of murine ECs to hypoxia resulted in time-dependent elaboration of IL-6 antigen into culture supernatants compared with normoxic controls (Fig. 1A). IL-6 increased by 2 h of hypoxia, continued to accumulate for up to 5 h, and then appeared to level off. PCR analysis of murine ECs exposed to hypoxia demonstrated induction of IL-6 transcripts by 2 h with sustained expression up to 4 h (Fig. 1BI). The identity of these amplicons was confirmed by Southern blotting with a human IL-6 cDNA (Fig. 1BII). Amplification of β-actin transcripts in the same samples did not show parallel induction of this housekeeping gene under these conditions (Fig. 1BIII). Consistent with these results, human ECs subjected to hypoxia also demonstrated enhanced levels of IL-6 transcripts in a time-dependent manner (Fig. 1CI–II), without change in the level of transcripts for the housekeeping gene control (Fig. 1CIII). That induction of IL-6 transcripts in hypoxia was not limited to ECs was indicated by PCR analysis of hypoxic human vascular smooth muscle cells, which also demonstrated induction of IL-6 transcripts (Fig. 1D). In view of the previous association of hypoxia with increased transcription of certain genes relevant to vascular function, such as endothelin and IL-8 (6Karakurum M. Shreeniwas R. Chen J. Pinsky D. Yan S.-D. Anderson M. Sunouchi K. Major J. Hamilton T. Kuwabara K. Rot A. Nowygord R. Stern D. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 93: 1564-1570Crossref PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar, 35Kourembanas S. Hannan R. Faller D. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 86: 670-674Crossref Scopus (339) Google Scholar), we inquired whether increased levels of IL-6 transcripts could be due to an increased rate of transcription. Nuclear run-on analysis showed an ≍8-fold increase in IL-6 transcription in nuclei harvested from hypoxic ECs, compared with their counterparts in normoxia (Fig. 2A, IL-6), based on densitometry (Fig. 2B). Transcription of β-actin appeared to be unchanged under the same conditions (Fig. 2, β-actin). These data indicate that hypoxia increases transcription of the IL-6 gene compared with the housekeeping gene β-actin and suggest that this contributes, at least in part, to increased levels of mRNA observed in hypoxic cells by PCR (Fig. 1, B and C). To extrapolate these data to the in vivo setting, up-regulation of IL-6 was studied in vivo using

Human placenta thioredoxin reductase (HP-TR) in the presence of NADPH-catalyzed reduction of (15S)-hydroperoxy-(5Z),(8Z),11(Z),13(E)-eicosatetraenoic acid ((15S)-HPETE) into the corresponding alcohol ((15S)-HETE). Incubation of 50 nM HP-TR and 0.5 mM NADPH with 300 μM 15-HPETE for 5 min resulted in formation of 16.5 μM 15-HETE. After 60 min, 74.7 μM 15-HPETE was reduced. The rate of the reduction of 15-HPETE by the HP-TR/NADPH peroxidase system was increased 8-fold by the presence of 2.5 μM selenocystine, a diselenide amino acid. In this case, 15-HPETE was catalytically reduced by the selenol amino acid, selenocysteine, generated from the diselenide by the HP-TR/NADPH system. To a smaller extent, selenodiglutathione or human thioredoxin also potentiated the reduction of 15-HPETE by HP-TR. Hydrogen peroxide and 15-HPETE were reduced at approximately the same rate by HP-TR, thioredoxin, and selenocystine. In contrast, t-butyl hydroperoxide was reduced at a 10-fold lower rate. Our data suggest two novel pathways for the reduction and detoxification of lipid hydroperoxides, hydrogen peroxide, and organic hydroperoxides, i.e. the human thioredoxin reductase-dependent pathway and a coupled reduction in the presence of selenols or selenide resulting from the reduction of selenocystine or selenodiglutathione. Polyunsaturated fatty acids can be oxygenated into hydroperoxides, either non-enzymatically (1Gardner H.W. Free Radical Biol. & Med. 1989; 7: 65-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (586) Google Scholar) or in the presence of specific lipoxygenases (2Yamamoto S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1128: 117-131Crossref PubMed Scopus (569) Google Scholar). Thus, arachidonic acid, an abundant polyunsaturated fatty acid in tissues, can provide (15R,S)-HPETE1 1The abbreviations used are: HPETEhydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acidHETEhydroxyeicosatetraenoic acidTRthioredoxin reductaseTrxthioredoxinHP-TRhuman placenta thioredoxin reductaseCT-TRcalf thymus thioredoxin reductaseHPLChigh performance liquid chromatographyGS-Se-SGselenodiglutathioneGRglutathione reductaseGSH-Pxglutathione peroxidase. and its regioisomers by non-enzymatic oxygenation as well as (15S)-HPETE when exposed to arachidonic acid 15-lipoxygenase (3Ford-Hutchinson A.W. Eicosanoids. 1991; 4: 65-74PubMed Google Scholar). Further conversion of 15-HPETE, enzymatically and non-enzymatically, leads to the formation of epoxy alcohols and trihydroxyeicosatrienoic acids (4Bryant R.W. Bailey J.M. Prog. Lipid Res. 1981; 20: 279-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar), to dioxygenated derivatives such as 5,15-diHPETE, 8,15-diHETE, and 14,15-diHETE (3Ford-Hutchinson A.W. Eicosanoids. 1991; 4: 65-74PubMed Google Scholar) and to lipoxins (5Serhan C.N. Hamberg M. Samuelsson B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1984; 81: 5335-5339Crossref PubMed Scopus (608) Google Scholar). In addition, glutathione peroxidase-catalyzed reduction of 15-HPETE into the corresponding hydroxy acid (15-HETE) is likely to have importance for in vivo detoxification of 15-HPETE and other fatty acid hydroperoxides. hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid thioredoxin reductase thioredoxin human placenta thioredoxin reductase calf thymus thioredoxin reductase high performance liquid chromatography selenodiglutathione glutathione reductase glutathione peroxidase. Thioredoxin (Trx) is a ubiquitous 12-kDa protein with the conserved active-site sequence -Cys-Gly-Pro-Cys- located on a protrusion in its three-dimensional structure (6Holmgren A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1985; 54: 237-271Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Oxidized thioredoxin with an active-site disulfide is reduced by NADPH and thioredoxin reductase (TR), and reduced thioredoxin is a powerful general protein disulfide reductase (6Holmgren A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1985; 54: 237-271Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13963-13966Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Since its original isolation from Escherichia coli as a hydrogen donor for the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase essential for the synthesis of deoxyribonucleotides and DNA (8Thelander L. Reichard P. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1979; 48: 133-158Crossref PubMed Scopus (915) Google Scholar), many new functions have been discovered (6Holmgren A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1985; 54: 237-271Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13963-13966Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, thioredoxin can regulate the activity of enzymes, receptors, or transcription factors via thiol-redox control (7Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13963-13966Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Adult T-cell leukemia-derived factor is a secreted form of human thioredoxin operating as a cytokine (9Yodoi J. Tursz T. Adv. Cancer Res. 1991; 57: 381-411Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). Thioredoxin reductase is a FAD-containing dimeric enzyme that has been purified and characterized from a variety of species (10Williams C.H.J. Müller F. Chemistry and Biochemistry of Flavoenzymes. Vol. 3. CRC Press, Inc., Boca Raton, FL1992: 121-211Google Scholar). Mammalian TR has a broad substrate specificity and reacts not only with its homologous Trx but also with E. coli Trx (11Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1977; 252: 4600-4606Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), 5,5’-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid) (11Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1977; 252: 4600-4606Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), GS-Se-SG (12Björnstedt M. Kumar S. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8030-8034Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), selenite (13Kumar S. Björnstedt M. Holmgren A. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 207: 435-439Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar), vitamin K (14Luthman M. Holmgren A. Biochemistry. 1982; 21: 6628-6633Crossref PubMed Scopus (510) Google Scholar), alloxan (15Holmgren A. Lyckeborg C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1980; 77: 5149-5152Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar), and the active-site selenocysteine residue in glutathione peroxidases (GSH-Px) (16Björnstedt M. Xue J. Huang W.B. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 29382-29384Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Selenium is an essential trace element that is known to have antioxidant properties. The most established mechanism behind the antioxidant function is the formation of selenocysteine from selenide and the incorporation of this amino acid in the active site of glutathione peroxidases (17Böck A. Forchhammer K. Heider J. Leinfelder W. Sawers G. Veprek B. Zinoni F. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 515-520Crossref PubMed Scopus (555) Google Scholar). These enzymes detoxify hydrogen peroxide, lipid hydroperoxides, and organic hydroperoxides (18Flohé L. Dolphin B. Poulson R. Avramovich O. GSH: Chemical, Biochemical and Medical Aspects. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., New York1989: 644-729Google Scholar). Selenite and GS-Se-SG are both efficiently reduced directly by mammalian TR or the complete thioredoxin system (12Björnstedt M. Kumar S. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8030-8034Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Kumar S. Björnstedt M. Holmgren A. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 207: 435-439Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). In these reactions selenide (HSe-) is formed and recycles with oxygen giving rise to a non-stoichiometric large oxidation of NADPH. Recently we showed that thioredoxin reductase with or without reduced thioredoxin is an electron donor to human plasma GSH-Px in the reduction of hydroperoxides (16Björnstedt M. Xue J. Huang W.B. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 29382-29384Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The aim of the present study was to investigate whether thioredoxin reductase and thioredoxin can reduce lipid hydroperoxides and if low molecular weight selenium compounds could act as charge transfer catalysts. This could be an important alternative pathway for the detoxification of hydroperoxides in addition to GSH-Px-mediated reduction. (15S)-HPETE (purity, in excess of 96%) was obtained by incubation of arachidonic acid (Nu-Chek-Prep, Inc., Elysian, MN) with soybean lipoxygenase at 0°C (19Hamberg M. Samuelsson B. J. Biol. Chem. 1967; 242: 5329-5335Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). (15R,S)-HPETE was prepared by autoxidation of arachidonic acid followed by isolation by silicic acid chromatography and straight-phase HPLC (cf. Ref. 20Hamberg M. Lipids. 1989; 24: 249-255Crossref Scopus (24) Google Scholar). (15S)-HETE was prepared in quantitative yield by reduction of (15S)-HPETE with triphenylphosphine in diethyl ether. t-Butyl hydroperoxide and yeast GR were from Sigma. DL-Selenocystine was from Serva. TR from human placenta and calf thymus was purified essentially as described by Luthman and Holmgren (14Luthman M. Holmgren A. Biochemistry. 1982; 21: 6628-6633Crossref PubMed Scopus (510) Google Scholar). Enzyme activities were standardized by using 5,5’-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid) as a substrate (14Luthman M. Holmgren A. Biochemistry. 1982; 21: 6628-6633Crossref PubMed Scopus (510) Google Scholar). E. coli TR was a homogenous preparation as described previously (13Kumar S. Björnstedt M. Holmgren A. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 207: 435-439Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). Recombinant human Trx was prepared as described by Ren et al.(21Ren X. Björnstedt M. Shen B. Ericson M.L. Holmgren A. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9701-9708Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar) and was reduced prior to use with dithiothreitol followed by desalting over a Sephadex G-25 column. GS-Se-SG was prepared as described by Björnstedt et al.(12Björnstedt M. Kumar S. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8030-8034Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The reduction of selenocystine was performed in 50 mM Tris-HCl, 1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5, with 200 μM NADPH. The reduction was followed at 340 nm as oxidation of NADPH using a mM extinction coefficient of 6.2. To both the reference and the sample cuvette was added HP-TR. The reactions were started by addition of selenocystine to the sample cuvette and an equal volume of buffer to the reference cuvette. The final volume was 0.50 ml. The reactions were performed in 50 mM Tris-HCl, 1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5, with 500 μM NADPH. The reduction of hydroperoxides was followed as oxidation of NADPH at 340 nm. To the cuvettes were added HP-TR, Trx, and selenocystine to final concentrations of 50 nM, 2.0 μM, and 2.5 μM, respectively. The reactions were started by addition of peroxide (150 μM) to the sample cuvette and an equal volume of 99.5% ethanol to the reference cuvette. To a reaction mixture composed of 50 mM Tris-HCl, 1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5, and 0.5 mM or 1 mM NADPH was added either TR, TR + Trx, TR + selenocystine, TR + GS-Se-SG, or GR. The reactions were started by addition of (15S)-HPETE to a final concentration of 300 μM. After incubation at room temperature for 15 min (if not otherwise indicated) the reactions were terminated by rapid freezing in dry ice/ethanol. Incubation mixtures of 15-HPETE (0.5 ml) were acidified to pH 4 and rapidly extracted with 7 ml of diethyl ether. The ether phase was washed three times with water and taken to dryness. The residue was analyzed by straight-phase HPLC using a column of Nucleosil 50-5 (250 x 4.6 mm; Macherey-Nagel (Düren, Germany)) and 2-propanol/hexane/acetic acid (1.5:98.5:0.02, v/v/v) at a flow rate of 1.5 ml/min. The absorbance at 235 nm of the effluent was monitored and the digitized signal integrated using a Macintosh SE/30. The retention volumes of (15S)-HETE and (15S)-HPETE were 10.2-10.9 and 12.8-13.5 ml, respectively. (15S)-HPETE (300 μM) incubated with HP-TR or CT-TR and NADPH was reduced to (15S)-HETE (Fig. 1). In order to investigate possible stereospecificity, (15R,S)-HPETE was incubated with CT-TR/NADPH and the 15-HETE produced (32% reduction) as well as the remaining 15-HPETE (68%) were subjected to steric analysis (22Zhang L.-Y. Hamberg M. Chem. Phys. Lipids. 1994; 74: 151-161Crossref Scopus (8) Google Scholar). Both compounds were found to be virtually racemic (ratio of S to R enantiomers, 49.9:50.1 (15-HETE) and 50.8:49.2 (15-HPETE)). Thus there was no discrimination between enantiomers in the CT-TR-promoted reduction of 15-HPETE. The initial part of the reaction was faster using CT-TR compared with HP-TR (Fig. 1). There was an almost linear relation between the concentration of (15S)-HPETE and product formed up to 500 μM concentration of (15S)-HPETE (Fig. 2). Addition of Trx to HP-TR increased the rate of the reduction of (15S)-HPETE by 60% (Fig. 3) indicating that both proteins of the human Trx system can reduce lipid hydroperoxides. In contrast, neither E. coli thioredoxin reductase nor yeast glutathione reductase had any significant peroxidase activity (Fig. 3).Figure 2:Reduction of (15S)-HPETE as a function of substrate concentration. The values are averages of at least two individual experiments.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Addition of HP-TR (50 nM) to selenocystine resulted in a very rapid oxidation of a stoichiometric amount of NADPH consistent with cleavage of each molecule of selenocystine into two molecules of selenocysteine (Fig. 4). Addition of GS-Se-SG or selenite to mammalian TR results in redox cycling with oxygen and a large non-stoichiometric oxidation of NADPH (12Björnstedt M. Kumar S. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8030-8034Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Kumar S. Björnstedt M. Holmgren A. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 207: 435-439Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). In the reaction between TR and selenocystine, especially at high concentrations of selenocystine, the oxidation of NADPH continued after oxidation of a stoichiometric amount (Fig. 4). This is consistent with redox cycling with oxygen. Thus, selenocysteine is autoxidized by oxygen, and the resulting selenocystine is again reduced by TR. The presence of selenocystine (2.5 μM) increased the peroxidase activity of HP-TR 8-fold (Fig. 3). After 15 min of incubation of HP-TR and selenocystine 72.5% of (15S)-HPETE (or 108.8 nmol) was reduced. Similar results were obtained with two other fatty acid hydroperoxides, i.e. the α-linolenic acid-derived (13S)-hydroperoxy-(9Z),(11E),(15Z)-octadecatrienoic acid and (9S)-hydroperoxy-(10E),(12Z),(15Z)-octadecatrienoic acid (data not shown). The presence of Trx only marginally increased the rate of the selenocysteine-coupled reaction (Fig. 3). Even when used in 0.5 μM concentration, selenocystine approximately doubled the rate of the TR/Trx-dependent peroxidase reaction (data not shown). Hydrogen peroxide and (15S)-HPETE were reduced at approximately the same rate by HP-TR, Trx, and selenocystine (Fig. 5). However, the rate of reduction of t-butyl hydroperoxide was slower. Addition of GS-Se-SG (5 μM) to HP-TR increased the rate of the reaction by 60% (Fig. 3). GS-Se-SG will react with TR and form selenide (12Björnstedt M. Kumar S. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8030-8034Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The results show that selenide can act as a charge transfer catalyst between TR and hydroperoxides. As a control, selenocystine (2.5 μM) without TR and NADPH was added to (15S)-HPETE (300 μM). The extent of reduction (0.6%) of the hydroperoxide did not differ from that observed with buffer (Fig. 3). Our results show that lipid hydroperoxides can be reduced by TR. The mechanism of TR-dependent peroxidase activity is likely as shown in Fig. 6A. Trx has previously been shown to slowly reduce hydrogen peroxide and other non-disulfide reagents if coupled with NADPH and thioredoxin reductase (14Luthman M. Holmgren A. Biochemistry. 1982; 21: 6628-6633Crossref PubMed Scopus (510) Google Scholar, 15Holmgren A. Lyckeborg C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1980; 77: 5149-5152Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 23Mitsui A. Hirakawa T. Yodoi J. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1992; 186: 1220-1226Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar, 24Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 9113-9119Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Selenocystine is a diselenide amino acid (25Yasuda K. Watanabe H. Yamazaki S. Toda S. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1980; 96: 243-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 26Tanaka H. Soda K. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 143: 240-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Upon reduction selenocystine is decomposed into two molecules of the selenol amino acid selenocysteine (26Tanaka H. Soda K. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 143: 240-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). This amino acid is an essential component of several proteins including GSH-Px (17Böck A. Forchhammer K. Heider J. Leinfelder W. Sawers G. Veprek B. Zinoni F. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 515-520Crossref PubMed Scopus (555) Google Scholar). In mammalian cells selenocysteine is incorporated in proteins by a selenocysteinyl-tRNAser that recognizes the nonsense codon UGA (27Lee B.J. Worland J.N. Davis J.N. Stadtman T.C. Hatfield D. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 9724-9727Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Free selenocysteine is produced in mammalian tissues by decomposition of selenoproteins and trans-sulfuration of selenomethionine (28Burk R.F. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 2274-2279Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). Selenocysteine is catabolized by selenocysteine β-lyase into L-alanine and selenide (29Esaki N. Nakamura T. Tanaka H. Soda K. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 4386-4391Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, the Knmof this enzyme is high (0.83 mM) (29Esaki N. Nakamura T. Tanaka H. Soda K. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 4386-4391Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), indicating that it is important only at rather high concentrations of selenocysteine. In the present study it was shown that selenocystine was efficiently reduced by TR and NADPH. Experiments with low concentrations of TR indicated that the kinetic parameters for the reaction with selenocystine are similar to that of the natural substrate thioredoxin, i.e. a low Knmand a high turnover number.2 2M. Björnstedt, M. Hamberg, and A. Holmgren, manuscript in preparation. The very fast reduction of selenocystine by TR suggests that selenocystine is kept reduced intracellularly. Rotruck et al.(30Rotruck J.T. Pope A.L. Ganther H.E. Swanson A.B. Hafeman D.G. Hoekstra W.G. Science. 1973; 179: 588-590Crossref PubMed Scopus (6275) Google Scholar) in 1973 reported the presence of selenium as a component of GSH-Px. The field of selenium and antioxidant functions have expanded to include intracellular and extracellular GSH-Px (28Burk R.F. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 2274-2279Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar) as well as synthetic selenium compounds like ebselen (31Maiorino M. Roveri A. Coassin M. Ursini F. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1988; 37: 2267-2271Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). GSH has been considered to be the only electron source for selenium-dependent hydroperoxide reduction, but human plasma contains essentially no free GSH (32Wendel A. Cikryt P. FEBS Lett. 1980; 120: 209-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). Recently we showed that the human Trx system is an efficient electron donor to human plasma GSH-Px (16Björnstedt M. Xue J. Huang W.B. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 29382-29384Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In this reaction TR or TR + Trx regenerates the charge of the active-site selenocysteine, which is oxidized during the peroxidase reaction. To investigate if this selenium-coupled peroxidase activity of TR was dependent on selenium inserted in a protein, i.e. GSH-Px, we added free selenocystine and GS-Se-SG to TR. The selenium-coupled reaction involves regeneration of Cys-Se- from Cys-SeOH (Fig. 6B), in accordance with the regeneration of the active-site charge of GSH-Px (16Björnstedt M. Xue J. Huang W.B. Holmgren A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 29382-29384Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Cys-Se- reduces hydroperoxides to the corresponding alcohol. At high concentrations of selenocystine, reduction of Cys-SeOH by Cys-Se- and formation of Cys-Se-Se-Cys will occur. A possible mechanism for the potentiation of TR-dependent peroxidase activity by GS-Se-SG is the regeneration of HSe- from HSeOH. One explanation for the higher activity of selenocystine compared with selenide is that the nucleophilicity of the selenium atom in selenocysteine should be greater than that of selenium in selenide. Selenocystine was previously reported to have a low GSH-Px activity together with 2 mM GSH and GR (25Yasuda K. Watanabe H. Yamazaki S. Toda S. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1980; 96: 243-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). However, this activity is unlikely to be of physiological significance since the pH optimum for the reaction was 8.0 and the reaction was observed with 10.0 μM selenocystine and the maximum turnover based on the Vmax was only 0.01 x min-1(25Yasuda K. Watanabe H. Yamazaki S. Toda S. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1980; 96: 243-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). In fact sodium selenite was found to be more active than selenocystine. In the present study we found that the turnover of the selenol with hydroperoxide in the reaction catalyzed by TR was 6 x min-1. Unsaturated fatty acid hydroperoxides serve as intermediates in the formation of biologically important compounds such as leukotrienes and lipoxins. In other situations, lipid hydroperoxides can accumulate in tissues and exert harmful effects. Specifically, 15-HPETE, the hydroperoxide used in the present study, can oxidatively modify low density lipoprotein and has been implicated in atherosclerosis (33Ylä-Herttuala S. Rosenfield M.E. Parthasarathy S. Glass C.K. Sigal E. Witztum J.L. Steinberg D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 6959-6963Crossref PubMed Scopus (405) Google Scholar). One pathway for the elimination of lipid hydroperoxides involves reduction in the presence of glutathione peroxidase and glutathione. The present work gives evidence for another mechanism for detoxification of lipid hydroperoxides, i.e. the reduction into alcohols in the presence of thioredoxin reductase and NADPH. This pathway and its high capacity when operating together with catalytic amounts of selenocysteine could serve as an important alternative to glutathione peroxidase.

Dystroglycan is a novel laminin receptor that links the extracellular matrix and sarcolemma in skeletal muscle. The dystroglycan complex containing α- and β-dystroglycan also serves as an agrin receptor in muscle, where it may regulate agrin-induced acetylcholine receptor clustering at the neuromuscular junction. β-Dystroglycan has now been expressed in vitro and shown to directly interact with Grb2, an adapter protein involved in signal transduction and cytoskeletal organization. Protein binding assays with two Grb2 mutants, Grb2/P49L and Grb2/G203R, which correspond to the loss-of-function mutants in the Caenorhabditis elegans sem -5, demonstrated that the dystroglycan-Grb2 association is through β-dystroglycan C-terminal proline-rich domains and Grb2 Src homology 3 domains. Affinity chromatography has also shown endogenous skeletal muscle Grb2 interacts with β-dystroglycan. Immunoprecipitation experiments have demonstrated that Grb2 associates with α/β-dystroglycan in vivo in both skeletal muscle and brain. The specific dystroglycan-Grb2 interaction may play an important role in extracellular matrix-mediated signal transduction and/or cytoskeleton organization in skeletal muscle that may be essential for muscle cell viability. Platelet stimulation by thrombin leads to the activation of phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI 3-K) and to the production of the D3 phosphoinositides, phosphatidylinositol 3,4-bisphosphate (PdtIns-3,4-P2) and 3,4,5-trisphosphate (PdtIns-3,4,5-P3). Because changes in the levels of these phosphoinositides correlate with the kinetics of actin assembly, they have been proposed to mediate actin assembly, causing cell shape changes. Wortmannin and LY294002, two unrelated inhibitors of PI 3-K, were used to investigate the role of PI 3-K in platelet actin assembly and aggregation. Both PI 3-K inhibitors abrogated the production of PdtIns-3,4-P2 and PdtIns-3,4,5-P3 in thrombin receptor-activating peptide (TRAP)-stimulated cells. However, neither wortmannin nor LY294002 altered the kinetics of actin assembly or the exposure of nucleation sites in TRAP-stimulated cells. In contrast, PI 3-K inhibitors showed a specific inhibitory pattern of cell aggregation, characterized by a primary phase of aggregation followed by progressive disaggregation. Flow cytometry analysis with the PAC1 monoclonal antibody or with FITC-labeled fibrinogen indicated that wortmannin inhibited the maintenance of the platelet integrin GPIIb-IIIa in its active state. Wortmannin also inhibited, in a dose-dependent manner, platelet aggregation induced by the binding of the monoclonal antibodies P256 and LIBS-6 to GPIIb-IIIa. LIBS Fab-induced aggregation also led to the production of PdtIns-3,4-P2. Platelet secretion, as evidenced by the release of preloaded 14C-5-hydroxy-tryptamine secretion or P-selectin up-regulation, was not affected by PI 3-K inhibition. These results demonstrate that the generation of D3 phosphoinositides is not required for actin assembly in TRAP-activated platelets. However, PI 3-K stimulation is necessary for prolonged GPIIb-IIIa activation and irreversible platelet aggregation. PI 3-K stimulation downstream of GPIIb-IIIa engagement may provide positive feedback required to sustain active GPIIb-IIIa. Because changes in the levels of these phosphoinositides correlate with the kinetics of actin assembly, they have been proposed to mediate actin assembly, causing cell shape changes. Wortmannin and LY294002, two unrelated inhibitors of PI 3-K, were used to investigate the role of PI 3-K in platelet actin assembly and aggregation. Both PI 3-K inhibitors abrogated the production of PdtIns-3,4-P2 and PdtIns-3,4,5-P3 in thrombin receptor-activating peptide (TRAP)-stimulated cells. However, neither wortmannin nor LY294002 altered the kinetics of actin assembly or the exposure of nucleation sites in TRAP-stimulated cells. In contrast, PI 3-K inhibitors showed a specific inhibitory pattern of cell aggregation, characterized by a primary phase of aggregation followed by progressive disaggregation. Flow cytometry analysis with the PAC1 monoclonal antibody or with FITC-labeled fibrinogen indicated that wortmannin inhibited the maintenance of the platelet integrin GPIIb-IIIa in its active state. Wortmannin also inhibited, in a dose-dependent manner, platelet aggregation induced by the binding of the monoclonal antibodies P256 and LIBS-6 to GPIIb-IIIa. LIBS Fab-induced aggregation also led to the production of PdtIns-3,4-P2. The functional responses of platelets to agonist-induced activation are well characterized and include actin assembly, which results in platelet shape changes, secretion of granular contents, and platelet aggregation. The signal transduction mechanisms regulating platelet secretion and aggregation are well characterized (1Siess W. Physiol. Rev. 1989; 69: 58-179Crossref PubMed Scopus (793) Google Scholar). The mechanisms controlling actin assembly in cells and the role of polyphosphoinositides are less clear. The removal from actin filament ends of capping proteins such as gelsolin and adseverin, referred to as uncapping, is thought to represent a critical step in initiating actin assembly (2Stossel T.P. Science. 1993; 260: 1086-1094Crossref PubMed Scopus (905) Google Scholar). Based on in vitro evidence showing that phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate (PdtIns-4-P) 1The abbreviations used are: PdtIns-4-P, phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate; PdtIns-4,5-P2, phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphophate; PI 3-K, phosphoinositide 3-kinase; PdtIns-3-P, phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate; PdtIns-3,4-P2, phosphatidylinositol 3,4-bisphophate; PdtIns-3,4,5-P3, phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate; TRAP, thrombin receptor-activating peptide; FITC, fluorescein isothiocyanate; GP, glycoprotein; BSA, bovine serum albumin; F-actin, filamentous actin; GTPγS, guanosine 5′-3-O-(thio)trisphosphate; LIBS, ligand-induced binding site; HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography; Pipes, 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid; fMLP, N-formylmethionylleucyl-phenylalanine; TRAF, thrombin receptor activating factor. and phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PdtIns-4,5-P2) inhibit the interaction of capping proteins with actin filaments, D4 phosphoinositides have been proposed to regulate filament end uncapping (reviewed in Ref. 3Janmey P.A. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1994; 56: 169-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar). However, in vivo bulk levels of PdtIns-4,5-P2 drop initially after activation (4Bengtsson T. Rundquist I. Stendahl O. Wymann M. Andersson T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17385-17389Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5Agranoff B. Murthy P. Seguin E. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 2076-2078Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 6Billah M. Lapetina E. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 12705-12708Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7Traynor-Kaplan A. Harris A. Thompson B. Taylor P. Sklar L. Nature. 1988; 334: 353-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar) and do not increase temporally with actin assembly in several cell types (4Bengtsson T. Rundquist I. Stendahl O. Wymann M. Andersson T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17385-17389Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Eberle M. Traynor-Kaplan A. Sklar L. Norgauer J. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 16725-16728Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Dadabay C.Y. Patton E. Cooper J. Pike L. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 112: 1151-1156Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). In contrast, the correlation of the time course of actin assembly with the production of phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate (PdtIns-3,4,5-P3), which is produced in response to phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI 3-K) activation in fMLP-treated neutrophils, has led to the conclusion that it is the D3 phosphoinositides that participate in filament uncapping, although they have not been available in suitable form for testing in vitro (7Traynor-Kaplan A. Harris A. Thompson B. Taylor P. Sklar L. Nature. 1988; 334: 353-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar, 8Eberle M. Traynor-Kaplan A. Sklar L. Norgauer J. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 16725-16728Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Experimentally, PI 3-K inhibition has had contradictory results on cytoskeletal reorganization. On the one hand, membrane ruffling in fibroblasts in response to platelet-derived growth factor, insulin-like growth factor, and insulin, which presumably requires actin assembly, is prevented after PI 3-K inactivation (10Kotani K. Yonezawa K. Hara K. Ueda H. Kitamura Y. Sakaue H. Ando A. Chavanieu A. Calas B. Grigorescu F. Nishiyama M. Waterfield M. Kasuga M. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 2313-2321Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 11Wennström S. Siegbahn A. Yokote K. Arvidsson A. Heldin C. Mori S. Claesson-Welch L. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 651-660PubMed Google Scholar, 12Wymann M. Arcaro A. Biochem. J. 1994; 298: 517-520Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). On the other hand, in fMLP-stimulated neutrophils, inhibition of PI 3-K by wortmannin fails to prevent actin assembly, although it does modify assembly such that temporal oscillations in the amounts of F-actin become readily observable (13Arcaro A. Wymann M. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 297-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (1055) Google Scholar). PI 3-K phosphorylates the D-3 position of the inositol ring of phosphatidylinositol, PdtIns-4-P, and PdtIns-4,5-P2, producing phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate (PdtIns-3-P), phosphatidylinositol 3,4-bisphosphate (PdtIns-3,4-P2), and PdtIns-3,4,5-P3, respectively (14Auger K.R. Serunian L. Soltoff S. Libby P. Cantley L. Cell. 1989; 57: 167-175Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (684) Google Scholar). Two distinct forms of PI 3-K have been described: (i) a heterodimer consisting of an 85-kDa regulatory subunit and a 110-kDa catalytic subunit (15Carpenter C.L. Duckworth B. Auger K. Cohen B. Schaffhausen B. Cantley L. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 19704-19711Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), which is activated by receptors with intrinsic or associated tyrosine kinase activity (16Cantley L.C. Auger K. Carpenter C. Duckworth B. Graziani A. Kappeler R. Soltoff S. Cell. 1991; 64: 281-302Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2187) Google Scholar), and (ii) a βγ-sensitive form, found in cells of myeloid lineage, which is thought to be activated in platelets and in neutrophils, respectively, by thrombin and by formyl peptides via heterotrimeric G-protein pathways (17Stephens L. Smrcka A. Cooke F. Jackson T. Sternweis P. Hawkins P. Cell. 1994; 77: 83-89Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar, 18Thomason P.A. James S. Casey P. Downes C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 16525-16528Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The two PI 3-Ks appear to be immunologically distinct, although the βγ-sensitive form has not yet been characterized at the molecular level (17Stephens L. Smrcka A. Cooke F. Jackson T. Sternweis P. Hawkins P. Cell. 1994; 77: 83-89Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar). Although PdtIns-3-P, PdtIns-3,4-P2 and PdtIns-3,4,5-P3 are thought to act as secondary messengers, since they are produced by PI 3-K activation and are not substrates for phospholipases, their molecular targets have not yet been defined. In vitro evidence suggests that nonconventional protein kinase C isoforms may be regulated by PdtIns-3,4-P2 and PdtIns-3,4,5-P3, but this mechanism has yet to be confirmed by in vivo studies (19Nakanishi H. Brewer K. Exton J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 13-16Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Toker A. Meyer M. Reddy K. Falck J. Aneja R. Aneja S. Parra A. Burns D. Balias L. Cantley L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 32358-32367Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thrombin activation of human platelets leads to PI 3-K activation, as assessed by the production of PdtIns-3,4-P2 and PdtIns-3,4,5-P3 (21Sultan C. Breton M. Mauco G. Grondin P. Plantavid M. Chap H. Biochem. J. 1990; 269: 831-834Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 22Kucera G.L. Rittenhouse S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 5345-5348Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Nolan R.D. Lapetina E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 2441-2445Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The most abundant product is PdtIns-3,4-P2, which peaks 3–4 min following thrombin stimulation (21Sultan C. Breton M. Mauco G. Grondin P. Plantavid M. Chap H. Biochem. J. 1990; 269: 831-834Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 22Kucera G.L. Rittenhouse S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 5345-5348Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Nolan R.D. Lapetina E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 2441-2445Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Kucera et al. (22Kucera G.L. Rittenhouse S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 5345-5348Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) also detected a small peak of PdtIns-3,4,5-P3, which reached a maximum 30 s following activation. Both the βγ-sensitive isoform and the conventional form of PI 3-K have been detected in human platelets (18Thomason P.A. James S. Casey P. Downes C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 16525-16528Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Zhang J. Fry M. Waterfield M. Jaken S. Liao L. Fox J. Rittenhouse S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4686-4692Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The regulation of PI 3-K activity in response to thrombin stimulation is complex. PI 3-K activation in response to thrombin is dependent on a heterotrimeric G-protein (18Thomason P.A. James S. Casey P. Downes C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 16525-16528Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22Kucera G.L. Rittenhouse S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 5345-5348Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). An additional requirement for PI 3-K activation is the small G-protein Rho, which is required for PI 3-K activation in the presence of GTPγS (25Zhang J. King W. Dillon S. Hall A. Feig L. Rittenhouse S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 22251-22254Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Finally, PI 3-K activation is increased by protein kinase C stimulation (26King W.G. Kucera G. Sorisky A. Zhang J. Rittenhouse S. Biochem. J. 1991; 278: 475-480Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar) and by GPIIb-IIIa engagement, since RGDS, which prevents aggregation, prevented thrombin-induced production of PdtIns-3,4-P2 by 60–70% (27Sorisky A. King W. Rittenhouse S. Biochem. J. 1992; 286: 581-584Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 28Sultan C. Plantavid M. Bachelot C. Grondin P. Breton M. Mauco G. Levy-Toledano S. Caen J. Chap H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 23554-23557Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A functional role for PI 3-K during platelet activation has not been demonstrated yet. The fungal metabolite, wortmannin, inhibits PI 3-K in the nanomolar range in various cell types (13Arcaro A. Wymann M. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 297-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (1055) Google Scholar, 17Stephens L. Smrcka A. Cooke F. Jackson T. Sternweis P. Hawkins P. Cell. 1994; 77: 83-89Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar, 18Thomason P.A. James S. Casey P. Downes C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 16525-16528Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29Kimura K. Hattori S. Kabuyama Y. Shizawa Y. Takayanagi J. Nakamura S. Toki S. Matsuda Y. Onedera K. Fukui Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 18961-18967Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 30Okada T. Sakuma L. Fukui Y. Hazeki O. Ui M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3563-3567Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 31Yano H. Nakanishi S. Kimura K. Hanai N. Saitoh Y. Fukui Y. Nonomura Y. Mutsuda Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25846-25856Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 32Yatomi Y. Hazeki O. Kume S. Ui M. Biochem. J. 1992; 285: 745-751Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar), presumably by binding to the 110-kDa catalytic chain (13Arcaro A. Wymann M. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 297-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (1055) Google Scholar, 30Okada T. Sakuma L. Fukui Y. Hazeki O. Ui M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3563-3567Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 31Yano H. Nakanishi S. Kimura K. Hanai N. Saitoh Y. Fukui Y. Nonomura Y. Mutsuda Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25846-25856Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). More recently, an unrelated synthetic compound, LY294002, has also been shown to inhibit selectively PI 3-K in vitro and in human neutrophils (33Vlahos C.J. Matter W. Hui K. Brown R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5241-5248Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We have taken advantage of these compounds to study the effect of PI 3-K inhibition on actin assembly and other cellular responses in thrombin receptor-activating peptide (TRAP)-stimulated platelets. In this report, we present data demonstrating that PI 3-K is not required for the initiation of actin assembly in human platelets but is necessary for the sustained exposure of GPIIb-IIIa and for irreversible platelet aggregation. Reagents—Human thrombin, prostaglandin El, wortmannin, bovine serum albumin (BSA), fibrinogen, phallacidin, and miscellaneous chemical reagents were purchased from Sigma; thrombin receptor-activating peptide, either the 14-residue (TRAP) or the 6-residue (TRAF) forms, from Bachem, King of Prussia, PA; AC1.2, an anti-P-selectin (CD62) mouse monoclonal antibody, and RUU-PL7F12, an anti-GPIIIa (CD61) mouse monoclonal antibody, from Becton Dickinson Immunocytometry Systems, San Jose, CA; fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) -labeled F(ab′)2 fragments of goat anti-mouse IgG from Tago Immunologicals, BioSource International, Camarillo, CA; 32P-orthophosphoric acid and l4C-5-hydroxytryptamine from DuPont NEN. LY294002 has been synthesized as described previously (33Vlahos C.J. Matter W. Hui K. Brown R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5241-5248Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). PAC1, a monoclonal mouse IgM directed against the active form of GPIIb-IIIa (34Shattil S.J. Hoxie J. Brass M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 11107-11114Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), was obtained from Dr. Sanford Shattil (Pennsylvania University Medical School, Philadelphia, PA). FITC-fibrinogen was a generous gift of Dr. Pascal Goldschmidt-Clermont (Division of Cardiology, Department of Medicine, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD). Ligand-induced binding site (LIBS) antibody was generously provided by Dr. Mark H. Ginsberg (Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA). Isolation and Activation of Platelets—Human platelets were purified as described previously (35Hartwig J.H. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 118: 1421-1442Crossref PubMed Scopus (334) Google Scholar), with a few modifications. Briefly, human blood was drawn from volunteers who had not ingested aspirin for at least 10 days into 0.1 volume of Aster-Jandl anticoagulant and centrifuged at 200 × g for 15 min. Platelet-rich plasma, to which 1 µm prostaglandin E1 was added, was gel-filtered over a Sepharose 2B column (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) preequilibrated with platelet buffer (10 mm Hepes, 145 mm sodium chloride, 5 mm KCl, 2 mm magnesium chloride, 0.5 mm NaH2PO4, 10 mm glucose, 0.3% BSA, pH 7.4) at 37 °C. Gel-purified platelets were rested for 60 min at 37 °C before use. The platelet concentration determined on a Coulter counter (Coulter Corp., Hialeah, FL) was typically 2.5–3.0 × 108/ml. TRAP was used to activate directly the thrombin receptor (36Vu T.-K.H. Hung D. Wheaton V. Coughlin S. Cell. 1991; 64: 1057-1068Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2680) Google Scholar). Both the 14-residue peptide (TRAP) and the 6-residue peptide (TRAF) (37Vouret-Craviari V. Obberghren-Schilling E.V. Rasmussen U. Pavirani A. Lecocq J. Pouysségur J. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1992; 3: 95-102Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 38Vassallo R.R. Kieber-Emmons T. Cichowski K. Brass L. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 6081-6085Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) gave similar results (data not shown). Resting cells were also exposed to antibodies that activate the GPIIb-IIIa receptor. In these experiments, platelets were treated with 4 µm LIBS-6 Fab or 8 µg/ml P256 F(ab′)2 for 5 min prior to the addition of 500 µg/ml fibrinogen (39Frelinger III, A.L. Du X. Plow E. Ginsberg M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 17106-17111Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Unless otherwise indicated, platelets were activated by the addition of 25 µm TRAP after preincubation for 1 min with 500 µg/ml fibrinogen. In experiments involving labeling with 32P-orthophoshoric acid, platelets were first purified from plasma by two centrifugations at 800 × g for 10 min at 37 °C in the presence of 1 µm prostaglandin El; 32P-Labeled platelets were separated from unbound 32P by gel filtration over a Sepharose 2B column. A few experiments utilized platelets prepared over a metrizamide gradient, as described previously (40Bachelot C. Cano E. Grelac F. Saleun S. Druker B. Levy-Toledano S. Fischer S. Rendu F. Biochem. J. 1991; 284: 923-928Crossref Scopus (67) Google Scholar) and gave similar results (data not shown). Wortmannin and LY294002 were preincubated with platelets at 37 °C for 15 and 10 min, respectively, before the exposure of cells to TRAP or TRAF. Wortmannin and LY294002 were added to platelets from 10 mm and 5 mm stock solutions, respectively, in dimethyl sulfoxide (ME2SO). The final concentration of ME2SO did not exceed 0.1%. Phospholipid Labeling and Extraction—Platelets isolated by centrifugation (109/ml) were incubated for 1 h at 37 °C with 2 mCi/ml of 32P-orthophosphoric acid. Unbound 32P was separated from platelets by gel filtration over a Sepharose 2B column in the presence of 1 µm prostaglandin El. After activation under aggregating conditions, lipids were analyzed as described in Auger et al. (14Auger K.R. Serunian L. Soltoff S. Libby P. Cantley L. Cell. 1989; 57: 167-175Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (684) Google Scholar). In experiments studying TRAP-activated platelets, lipids were extracted after exposure to TRAP for 4 min. Phospholipids produced after exposure to LIBS-6 Fab for increasing lengths of time in the presence of fibrinogen were also analyzed. To analyze phospholipids, 1 ml of purified platelets were extracted in 3.75 ml of chloroform/methanol/concentrated HC1 (20v/40v/1v). To this extract 20 µg of crude brain phosphoinositides was added as a carrier. This mixture was vortexed vigorously, and 1.25 ml of chloroform was added to separate the phases. This solution was vortexed again and spun briefly to separate the phases. The lower chloroform phase was removed to a new tube and washed once with 2 ml of methanol, 1 m HC1 (1:1) and once with 2 ml of methanol, 0.1 m EDTA (1:1). The chloroform phase was then removed to a 15-ml glass scintillation vial and dried in preparation for deacylation and SAX HPLC analysis as described elsewhere. Lipids were quantitated using a Radiomatic A500 on-line radioactivity counter (Packard). Platelet Aggregation Studies—Gel-filtered platelets (3 × 108/ml) were preincubated with or without the indicated amounts of wortmannin or LY294002. They were added to an aggregation cuvette, and the reaction was started by the addition of 25 µm TRAP and 500 µg/ml fibrinogen under constant stirring conditions. The reaction was recorded on a Chrono-Log aggregometer (Chrono-Log Corp., Havertown, PA) for at least 5 min. Aggregation induced by GPIIb-IIIa antibodies was initiated after preincubating the cells with the antibody for 5 min and then adding 500 µg/ml of fibrinogen in the presence or absence of 100 nm wortmannin or 30 µm RGDS peptide. Flow Cytometry Studies—Different protocols were used depending on the particular primary antibody or ligand analyzed. To detect total GPIIb-IIIa and P-selectin using the mouse monoclonal antibodies AC1.2 or RUU-PL 7F12, respectively, platelets were first fixed after activation by adding an equal volume of 4% paraformaldehyde in platelet buffer and washed twice by centrifugation for 5 min at 3000 × g. Washed platelets (2 × 107/100 µl) were incubated for 1 h at room temperature with either AC1.2 or RUU-PL 7F12 at saturating conditions in Hepes buffer (5 nm Hepes, 140 nm NaCl, pH 7.4) containing 0.3% BSA. To remove unbound primary antibody, platelets were washed twice and were incubated for 45 min at room temperature with FITC-labeled F(ab′)2 fragments of goat anti-mouse IgG at dilutions recommended by the manufacturer. To detect the activated form of GPIIb-IIIa, platelets were labeled with FITC-PAC1 using a modification of the technique described by Golden et al. (41Golden A. Brugge J. Shattil S. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 111: 3117-3127Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar). Briefly, 2 × 106 platelets were mixed in 50 µl with 20 µg/ml of FITC-labeled PAC1 prior to activation with TRAP. Fifteen minutes after activation, the platelets were fixed by adding an equal volume of 4% paraformaldehyde. The platelets were washed once and resuspended in Hepes buffer. GPIIb-IIIa exposure was also measured using the binding of FITC-fibrinogen, using a modification of the technique of Faraday et al. (42Faraday N. Goldschmidt-Clermont P. Dise K. Bray P. J. Lab. Clin. Med. 1994; 123: 728-740PubMed Google Scholar). FITC-fibrinogen (100 µg/ml) was added to 200 µl of gel-filtered platelets (2 × 107/ml) prior to activation with TRAP. Platelets were fixed 15 min after stimulation with 2% paraformaldehyde. Fixed FITC-labeled platelets were read in a Becton Dickinson FACScan (Becton Dickinson Immunocytometry Systems, San Jose, CA). The samples were gated for platelets, and aggregates were excluded based on forward and side scatter profiles. 10,000 events were recorded, and the results were analyzed using Lysis II software. Platelet Actin Assembly—The ability of platelet lysates to stimulate pyrene actin polymerization in vitro was determined as described previously (35Hartwig J.H. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 118: 1421-1442Crossref PubMed Scopus (334) Google Scholar). Platelets activated with 10 µm TRAP in the presence or absence of wortmannin or LY294002 were permeabilized with 1/10 volume of PHEM buffer (60 mM Pipes, 25 mM Hepes, 10 mM EGTA, and 2 mM MgCl2) containing 0.1 µm phallacidin and protease inhibitors. Detergent lysates were assayed for actin assembly by addition of pyrene-labeled rabbit skeletal muscle actin using a Perkin-Elmer spectrophotometer with an excitation wavelength of 366 nm and an emission wavelength of 386 nm. The rate of actin assembly and the number of barbed end equivalent nucleation sites were determined as described (35Hartwig J.H. J.
