It as been affinity-purified from a Escherichia coli protein-soluble fraction using the pAb421 monoclonal antibody as described in Ref. 23Hupp T.R. Meek D.W. Midgley C.A. Lane D.P. Cell. 1992; 71: 875-886Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (866) Google Scholar. Recombinant c-Jun (24Abate C. Luk D. Curran T. Cell Growth & Differ. 1990; 1: 455-462PubMed Google Scholar) was purified from E. coli as follows. 400 ml of mid-exponential phase bacteria were induced for 3 h in the presence of 1 mM isopropyl-1-thio-β-D-galactopyranoside, centrifuged down, resuspended in 3 ml of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8, 1 mM EDTA, 100 mM NaCl, 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.3 mg/ml lysozyme and let on ice for 20 min. 4 mg of nadeoxycholate and 200 units of Benzon nuclease (Merck) were added, and the mixture was incubated for 30 min at 37 °C. Inclusion bodies, which contain the bulk of c-Jun, were pelleted (7,000 × g for 15 min), resuspended in 10 ml of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8, 10 mM EDTA, 100 mM NaCl, 0.5% Triton X-100, 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and washed under agitation for 5 min at room temperature. The washing procedure was repeated twice, and the pellet was dissolved in 3 ml of denaturing buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8,100 mM NaCl, 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 8 M urea) for 1 h at 37 °C. The solution was centrifuged for 1 h at 15,000 × g at room temperature, and the supernatant was either frozen or used for further processing. c-Jun, which represent more than 95% of proteins of inclusion body proteins as determined by electrophoretic analysis, was purified to homogeneity by electrophoresis through SDS-containing 12% Polyacrylamide gels using the Prep Cell apparatus from Bio-Rad. The renaturation protocol described is an adaptation of that of Chang et al. (25Chang L.M. Plevani P. Bollum F.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 5700-5706Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and proved reproducible. Electrophoresis-purified c-Jun, in a volume of approximately 50 ml of 150 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.6, 0.1% SDS was concentrated to 1–2 ml using Macrosep filters (Filtron) at room temperature. The solution was then filtered through a 0.2-μm Minisart filter (Sartorius) and dialyzed for 16 h against 50 ml of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7, 50 mM DTT, 2 mM EDTA, 7 M guanidimum chloride in order to quantitatively precipitate c-Jun. Progressive redissolution was obtained through 5 cycles of 2-h dialysis against 100 ml of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7, 100 mM NaCl, 2 mM DTT, 2 mM EDTA, 0.1% Nonidet P-40 at 20–25 °C. The solution was adjusted to 50% glycerol, and c-Jun was kept frozen at –20 °C at a concentration of 0.5 mg/ml until use. 125I iodination of ubiquitin was performed using the chloramin T method exactly as described in Hershko et al. (19Hershko A. Heller H. Elias S. Ciechanover A. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 8206-8214Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Ubiquitinylation reactions were incubated for 30 min at 37 °C in a volume of 50 μl in the presence of 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 2 mM ATP, 5 mM MgCl2, 10 mM phosphocreatine (Sigma), 1 mg/ml creatine kinase (Sigma), 2 mM DTT, 5 μg of 12BI-labeled ubiquitin, and 2 mg/ml protein extract. Samples were electrophoresed through a 15% Polyacrylamide gel and then autoradiographed. Degradation experiments were performed at 37 “C in a volume of 100 μl in the presence of 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 350 ng of recombinant rat c-Jun (or other proteins), and usually 40 μg of proteins from the different extracts (similar results were obtained with 10-fold less proteins). When needed, ATP and MgCl2 (5 mM each), ubiquitin (500 μg/ml), and the calpastatin peptide (160 ng/ml) were added. Aliquot fractions were sampled at various time points and immediately boiled for 10 min in Laemmli sample buffer. Proteins were fractionated through 15% Polyacrylamide gels and electrotransferred onto nitrocellulose. Immunodetection was carried out as described above. The multiubiquitinylation of proteins involves multiple steps (18Ciechanover A. Cell. 1994; 79: 13-21Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1602) Google Scholar, 26Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 761-807Crossref PubMed Scopus (1210) Google Scholar, 27Jentsch S. Annu. Rev. Genet. 1992; 26: 179-206Crossref PubMed Scopus (450) Google Scholar). Free ubiquitin is first bound by an ubiquitin-activating enzyme, El. E2 ubiquitin-carrier proteins then catalyze the transfer of activated ubiquitin from E1 to protein substrates eventually bound to specific E3 ubiquitin-protein ligases. To determine whether ubiquitinylation is necessary for the rapid breakdown of c-Jun, ubiquitinylation competent and incompetent rat liver-derived cell-free degradation assays were developed. Preparation of protein extracts was carried out as follows. In a first step, a protein fraction was purified by anion-exchange chromatography (F2) from a crude rat liver cytosolic extract according to Hershko et al. (19Hershko A. Heller H. Elias S. Ciechanover A. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 8206-8214Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Here, two points are worth being emphasized. First, ATP was depleted from the cytosolic extract to allow deconjugation of ubiquitin, which, in its free form, is quantitatively eliminated during the chromatography step. Second, F2 still contains El, as well as most, but not all, of E2s and E3s together with major soluble proteolytic enzymes. To ensure the total absence of ubiquitinylation in further degradation assays, either of two additional treatments were applied separately to F2. In one case, residual ubiquitin, if any, was eliminated using an antibody-specific for both free and conjugated ubiquitin (F2ΔUb extract). In the other case, the ubiquitinylation pathway was inactivated by E1 immunodepletion (F2ΔE1 extract). Western blotting analysis (Fig. 1A) shows that free ubiquitin and intermediate molecular weight ubiquitin-protein conjugates were quantitatively eliminated from F2 and F2ΔUb. However, high molecular weight bands due to the detection system used (Fig. IB) are found in all types of extracts and may mask residual ubiquitin-protein conjugates in F2 and F2ΔUb extracts. The possibility of ubiquitin recycling during the time course of degradation experiments was, however, ruled out since, on one hand, incubation of F2 extracts for 2 h under degradation experiment conditions (see below) did not lead to any detectable modification in the pattern of bands and, on the other hand, in a comparable experiment carried out in the presence of anti-ubiquitin antibodies, we detected no release of free ubiquitin as assessed by Western blotting (not shown). F2ΔB1 extract does not allow ubiquitinylation, either, as tested by lack of conjugation of exogenous 12SI-labeled ubiquitin to proteins of the extract in contrast to both F2 and F2 processed with a preimmune serum (F2ΔPreI), which by the same test are shown to be competent for ubiquitinylation (Fig. 1C). For degradation experiments, E. coli-produced rat c-Jun (24Abate C. Luk D. Curran T. Cell Growth & Differ. 1990; 1: 455-462PubMed Google Scholar), E. eoK-produced human wild-type p53 (23Hupp T.R. Meek D.W. Midgley C.A. Lane D.P. Cell. 1992; 71: 875-886Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (866) Google Scholar), and rabbit immunoglobulins were added in parallel experiments to the different extracts in the presence, or in the absence, of ATP, and aliquot fractions of the reaction mix were sampled at different time points for immunoelectroblotting analysis. Importantly, appropriate folding of c-Jun was controlled both by testing its ability to homodimerize and to bind specifically to AP-1 DNA motifs and to stimulate transcription in an in vitro assay and by analysis of calpain-generated cleavage products since this protease revealed a good topological probe due to both its specificity for tertiary structural determinants and its limited action on c-Jun (not shown) (13Hirai S.-L. Kawasaki H. Yaniv M. Susuki K FEBS Lett. 1991; 287: 57-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar, 14Watt F. Molloy P.L. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 5092-5100Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 15Carillo S. Pariat M. Steff A.-M. Roux P. Etienne-Julan M. Lorca T. Piechaczyk M. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 1679-1689PubMed Google Scholar). c-Jun turned out to be degraded at a similar rate in all extracts in an ATP-dependent manner (Fig. ID). On the contrary, immunoglobulins (Fig. IF) and p53 (Fig. IE) remained unaffected, in keeping with the observations that antibodies are very stable when expressed intracellularly, and, although p53 is very unstable and degraded through the ubiquitin pathway, the E2 enzyme specific for ubiquitinylation of p53 is absent from F2 (28Ciechanover A. Shkedy D. Oren M. Bercovich B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 9582-9589Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Interestingly, the addition of high amounts of exogenous ubiquitin to F2 did not accelerate c-Jun decay (Fig. ID). Moreover, calpains, which, as mentioned previously, are capable of cleaving c-Jun (13Hirai S.-L. Kawasaki H. Yaniv M. Susuki K FEBS Lett. 1991; 287: 57-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar, 14Watt F. Molloy P.L. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 5092-5100Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 15Carillo S. Pariat M. Steff A.-M. Roux P. Etienne-Julan M. Lorca T. Piechaczyk M. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 1679-1689PubMed Google Scholar), did not interfere in degradation experiments since a highly specific inhibitor peptide (29Maki M. Bagci H. Hamaguchi K. Ueda M. Murachi T. Hatanaka M. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 254: 18866-18869Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar) derived from calpastatin, which is the physiological inhibitor of calpains, does not stabilize c-Jun. Thus, selective degradation of c-Jun in F2 rat liver extracts is neither dependent on ubiquitinylation nor stimulated by the presence of ubiquitin. The 26 S proteinase complex(es) (26 S proteasome(s)) is the major soluble neutral proteolytic activity in the cell. Its proteolytic core, the 20 S proteasome, is perhaps never found free in cells and, in contrast to the 26 S particle, neither requires ATP for proteolysis nor usually degrades large proteins (16Rivett J.A. Biochem. J. 1993; 291: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (383) Google Scholar, 17Peters J.-M. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 377-382Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (300) Google Scholar, 18Ciechanover A. Cell. 1994; 79: 13-21Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1602) Google Scholar). To determine whether the proteasome is responsible for the ATP-dependent degradation of c-Jun in rat liver extracts, F2 was proteasome-immunodepleted (F2Δprot) using an anti-proteasome antiserum already shown efficient for such a purpose (30Murakami Y. Matsufuji S. Kameji T. Hayashi S.-L. Tamura K. Tanaka K. Ichihara A. Nature. 1992; 360: 597-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (669) Google Scholar). Depletion was controlled as follows: (i) proteasome proteolytic activity was shown to be reduced >200-fold using the Suc-Leu-Leu-Val-Tyr-NH-7-amido-4-methylcoumarin peptide substrate, which is reported to be a good substrate for the proteasome (31Tanaka K. Yoshimura T. Kumatori A. Ichihara A. Ikai A. Nishigai M. Kameyama K. Takagi T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 16209-16217Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and (ii) removal of two peptide components of the proteasome was assayed using two specific monoclonal antibodies (Fig. 2A). The latter are the cross-species reactive anti-duck p27K (IB5) antibody and anti-duck p31K (AA4 antibody) (32Grossi-de-Sa M.F. Sa C.M.D. Harper F. Coux O. Akhayat O. Florentin Y. Paul J.K. Scherrer K. J. Cell Sci. 1988; 89: 151-165Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). c-Jun was no longer degraded in F2Δprot as compared with F2 and F2ΔpreI (Fig. 2S). Definitely establishing that c-Jun is a target for the proteasome, complementation of F2Δprot with purified rat liver 26 S proteasome (see below) restores quantitative degradation of c-Jun (Fig. 2B). To determine whether c-Jun is a target for the 20 S and/or the 26 S proteasome and whether a putative co-factor, present in F2, is necessary for c-Jun proteolysis, degradation experiments were conducted with comparable amounts of 20 and 26 S proteasome instead of F2 extracts. Peptide compositions of purified rat liver particles were similar to those published by others (30Murakami Y. Matsufuji S. Kameji T. Hayashi S.-L. Tamura K. Tanaka K. Ichihara A. Nature. 1992; 360: 597-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (669) Google Scholar, 33Ugai S.-L. Tamura T. Tanahashi N. Takai S. Komi N. Chung C.H. Tanaka K. Ishihara A. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1993; 113: 754-768Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar) (Fig. 3A). Under the conditions tested (50–500 ng/ml of purified particles; for experimental conditions, see legend to Fig. 3 and “Materials and Methods”), c-Jun was not degraded by the 20 S proteasome, whereas it was degraded by the 26 S proteasome, but only in the presence of ATP. As a support to the selectivity of the process, p53 and immunoglobulins revealed a resistance to both types of particles, even in the presence of ATP (Pig. 3, B and C). Importantly, (i) addition of calpastatin did not stabilize c-Jun, ruling out contamination by calpain (not shown), (ii) about 10% of c-Jun is consistently degraded without any addition of exogenous ATP, perhaps on account of 0.02 mu ATP present in the reaction mixture (since the 26 S proteasome is stored in the presence of 2 rasi ATP), (iii) c-Jun is susceptible to higher concentrations (above 5 μg/ml) of 20 S proteasome in an ATP-independent but selective manner since p53 and immunoglobulins remained insensitive under the same conditions (not shown), and (iv) c-Jun degradation is still selective and ATP-dependent at a higher concentration of 26 S proteasome (5 µg/ml of purified 26 S proteasome; not shown). The ubiquitin-proteasome proteolytic pathway is thought to account for the degradation of the bulk of short-lived and abnormal cellular proteins (18Ciechanover A. Cell. 1994; 79: 13-21Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1602) Google Scholar, 26Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 761-807Crossref PubMed Scopus (1210) Google Scholar, 27Jentsch S. Annu. Rev. Genet. 1992; 26: 179-206Crossref PubMed Scopus (450) Google Scholar). It has also been implied in antigen processing for subsequent presentation of antigenic peptides by major histocompatibility complex class I molecules (34Michalek M.T. Grant E.P. Gramm C. Goldberg A.L. Rock K.L. Nature. 1993; 363: 552-554Crossref PubMed Scopus (285) Google Scholar, 35Rock K.L. Gramm C. Rothstein L. Clark K. Stein R. Dick L. Hwang D. Goldberg A.L. Cell. 1994; 78: 761-771Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2206) Google Scholar) and protein processing as in the case of the pl05 NFKB1 precursor protein (36Palombella V.J. Rando O.J. Goldberg A.L. Maniatis T. Cell. 1994; 78: 773-785Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1922) Google Scholar). On the other hand, Rock et al. (35Rock K.L. Gramm C. Rothstein L. Clark K. Stein R. Dick L. Hwang D. Goldberg A.L. Cell. 1994; 78: 761-771Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2206) Google Scholar) have shown that the proteasome is involved in the degradation of the bulk of long lived intracellular proteins, whereas Gropper et al. (37Gropper R. Brandt R. Elias S. Bearer C.F. Mayer A. Schwartz A.L. Ciechanover A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 3602-3610Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have reported that inhibition of the £1 ubiquitin-activating enzyme does not affect their breakdown. This suggests that degradation of this class of proteins is likely proteasome-dependent but ubiquitin-independent. Finally, little information is available on the involvement of both the proteasome and of the ubiquitin pathway in the degradation of specific cellular proteins (16Rivett J.A. Biochem. J. 1993; 291: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (383) Google Scholar, 17Peters J.-M. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 377-382Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (300) Google Scholar, 18Ciechanover A. Cell. 1994; 79: 13-21Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1602) Google Scholar). We report here that c-Jun protein can be degraded in a selective and ATP-dependent manner involving the proteasome in rat liver extracts since immunoglobulins and p53 protein (along with bovine serum albumin; data not shown) are not degraded under the same experimental conditions. Thus, this adds one example to the very few characterized cellular substrates of the proteasome. Moreover, we also show that tagging by ubiquitin is not an absolute requirement for recognition and degradation of c-Jun by the 26 S proteasome. Ornithine decarboxylase, which is one of the most rapidly turned over proteins, is the only other example of such a situation. Using the reticulocyte lysate as a cell-free degradation assay, Bercovitch et al. (38Bercovich Z. Rosenberg-Hasson Y. Ciechanover A. Kahana C. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15949-15952Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have shown that ornithine decarboxylase breakdown is ATP-dependent but ubiquitin-independent. More recently, using both different cell extracts and purified proteasome, Murakami et al. (30Murakami Y. Matsufuji S. Kameji T. Hayashi S.-L. Tamura K. Tanaka K. Ichihara A. Nature. 1992; 360: 597-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (669) Google Scholar) have identified the 26 S proteasome as the protease responsible for ornithine decarboxylase degradation. It is worth emphasizing that if breakdown of ornithine decarboxylase does not require tagging by ubiquiting, triggering of proteolysis is dependent upon association of ornithine decarboxylase with a specific peptide co-factor, called antizyme. At variance, with ornithine decarboxylase, no specific co-factor is needed for degradation of c-Jun by purified 26 S proteasome. To our knowledge, c-Jun is thus the first demonstration that a cellular protein can bear intrinsic signal(s) for selective recognition and quantitative ATP-dependent degradation by the 26 S proteasome. This, of course, does not exclude that some co-factors may be involved in the regulation of c-Jun breakdown in vivo. c-Jun appears unique with regard to protein catabolism since several proteolytic systems have been proposed to operate on it. First, as mentioned in the introduction, in vitro and in vivo lines of evidence suggest that c-Jun degradation can be initiated in the cytoplasm by calpains (13Hirai S.-L. Kawasaki H. Yaniv M. Susuki K FEBS Lett. 1991; 287: 57-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar, 14Watt F. Molloy P.L. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 5092-5100Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 15Carillo S. Pariat M. Steff A.-M. Roux P. Etienne-Julan M. Lorca T. Piechaczyk M. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 1679-1689PubMed Google Scholar). However, since cleavage of c-Jun by calpains is limited, it is likely that other proteolytic activities are involved in the completion of degradation. Preliminary experiments by our group point to the involvement of the proteasome. Second, Trier et al. (12Treier M. Staszewski L.M. Bohmann D. Cell. 1994; 78: 787-798Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (847) Google Scholar) have recently shown that (i) a small fraction of c-Jun is ubiquitinylated in vivo, (ii) a 27-amino acid domain (δ domain), located in the N-terminal part of c-Jun and which is deleted from the stabilized v-JmrASV17 protein, is determining for the conjugation of ubiquitin at multiple sites on the protein, and (iii) the capability to be ubiquitinylated correlates with rapid turnover since v-JunASV77 is not, or little, ubiquitinylated. However, the formal demonstration that degradation of c-Jun is actually triggered by conjugation of ubiquitin has not been brought, and the involvement of the proteasome has not been investigated. It cannot thus be ruled out that the δ domain is instrumental for rapid degradation of c-Jun through another mechanism. Third, we report here that c-Jun can be degraded by the 26 S proteasome in the absence of ubiquitinylation, at least in vitro. An important question to solve is obviously to determine whether ubiquitin-dependent and ubiquitin-independent pathways actually act in vivo for c-Jun breakdown and whether they act synergistically or independently under different physiological conditions or in different cell types. To our knowledge, the possibility that an unstable protein can be degraded according to different pathways has not yet been reported. It is, however, worth noting that the situation has already been described at the RNA level since two destabilizers of the c-fos mRNA have been shown to exert their effects under different cell culture conditions (39Shyu A.B. Greenberg M.E. Belasco J.G. Genes & Dev. 1989; 3: 60-72Crossref PubMed Scopus (452) Google Scholar). Addressing the issue of the possible differential contributions of the different proteolytic machineries involved in c-Jun degradation in vivo will, however, be difficult. As a matter fact, little is known about the activation of calpains in vivo (40Croall D.E. De Martino G.N. Physiol. Rev. 1991; 71: 813-847Crossref PubMed Scopus (782) Google Scholar), on one hand, and the 26 S proteasome might have variable subunit structures according to its cellular origin and, perhaps, intracellular localization on the other hand. One can thus speculate that certain isoenzymes degrade c-Jun in an ubiquitin-dependent manner, whereas others act independently of ubiquitinylation. Purification and characterization of the different 26 S proteasomes will thus be necessary for solving this point. We thank Dr. K. Tanaka and K. Scherrer for the kind gift of anti-whole proteasome and monoclonal anti-prosome subunit antibodies, respectively. We also thank Dr. L. Debüssche for the kind gift of recombinant p53 and Drs. I. Robbins and U. Hibner for careful reading of the manuscript.

In voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels, the β subunit interacts with the α1 subunit via a cytoplasmic site. A biochemical assay has been developed to quantitatively describe the interaction between both subunits. In vitro synthesized 35S-labeled β subunits specifically bind to a glutathione S -transferase (GST) fusion protein containing the α1a interaction domain (AIDA, located between the amino-acids 383 and 400 of the cytoplasmic loop between the hydrophobic domains I and II). Kinetic analysis demonstrates that the association of 35S-labeled β1b subunit to the AIDA GST fusion protein occurs with a fast rate constant at 4°C. The binding is almost irreversible as demonstrated by the absence of dissociation observed after an 8-h incubation with an 18-amino acid synthetic AIDA peptide. The α1-β binding site does not seem to be a target for cytoplasmic regulation. The interaction is mostly unaffected by changes in ionic strength, pH, and Ca2+ concentration or by protein kinase C phosphorylation. The specificity of subunit interaction in voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels was also followed by saturation analyses. The data obtained show that the AIDA GST fusion protein binds to a single site on the β1b with an apparent Kdof 5 nM. The affinities of AIDA GST fusion protein for various β subunits was measured and demonstrate that β subunits associate with different affinities to each α1 interaction domain. The rank order of AIDA affinity for each β subunit is as follows: β> > β> > β1b»β3. The binding of the β subunit to α1 subunit can be inhibited in vitro by the AIDA synthetic peptide with an apparent Kiof 285 nM. This interaction can also be prevented in heterologous Ca2+ channels by the injection of the AIDA GST fusion protein into Xenopus oocytes. Our results demonstrate that the site of interaction between AID and β subunit is responsible for anchoring the β subunit to the α1 subunit and thus allowing the β subunit to modify Ca2+ channel activity. Limited proteolysis was used to study the domain structure and to produce a large N-terminal fragment of human apolipoprotein AI (apoAI). Digestion of reconstituted high density lipoprotein (rHDL) prepared with apoAI and dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine or palmitoyloleoyl phosphatidylcholine by chymotrypsin, trypsin, elastase, and subtilisin generated a major fragment of 22 kDa. Under milder conditions proteolysis of lipid-free apoAI produced a fragment of similar size. The fragments shared the same N terminus as intact apoAI, and the chymotryptic fragment had a molecular weight of 22,384 as determined by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry. Thus the fragment consists of the N-terminal 192 amino acid residues of apoAI, and the region around Tyr192 seems to be especially accessible to proteases.In aqueous solution the fragment, apoAI-(1–192), had an α-helix content similar to that of apoAI (~52%) but existed only as monomers and dimers. ApoAI-(1-192) lysed dimyristoyl phosphatidylcholine liposomes slowly compared with apoAI but did form rHDL complexes with palmitoyloleoyl phosphatidylcholine or dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine when prepared by the sodium cholate dialysis method. ApoAI-(l-192) rHDL exhibited sizes and size distributions distinct from apoAI rHDL but displayed similar stability against denaturation. The isolated apoAI-(l-192) rHDLs retained a high ability to activate lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase, comparable with the most effective apoAI rHDL. The results suggest that the C-terminal domain of apoAI is crucial for self-association and initial lipid binding but is not involved in specific lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase activation. Limited proteolysis has proven to be a powerful tool in elucidating the domain structure and the structure-function relationships of many proteins (17Creighton T.E. Proteins: Structures and Molecular Principles. Freeman Publications, San Francisco1983: 316-317Google Scholar), including apolipoprotein E (18Wetterau J.R. Aggerbeck L.P. Rall Jr., S.C. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6240-6248Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Wilson C. Wardell M.R. Weisgraber K.H. Mahley R.W. Agard D.A. Science. 1991; 252: 1817-1822Crossref PubMed Scopus (601) Google Scholar). The earliest studies on the digestion of HDL with proteases provided limited information about the structure of apoAI in HDL (20Camejo G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1969; 175: 290-300Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar, 21Shore V.G. Sae A. S-W. Shore B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1978; 529: 319-330Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar, 22Byrne R.E. Scanu A.M. Biochemistry. 1983; 22: 2894-2903Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar, 23Swaney J.B. J. Lipid Res. 1983; 24: 245-252Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), in part because of the heterogeneity of native HDL. More recently, limited proteolysis was used to study the structure of apoAI in rHDL as well as in native HDL (16Dalton M.B. Swaney J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19274-19283Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Lins L. Piron S. Conrath K. Vanloo B. Brasseur R. Rosseneu M. Baert J. Ruysschaert J.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1151: 137-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). While Lins et al. (24Lins L. Piron S. Conrath K. Vanloo B. Brasseur R. Rosseneu M. Baert J. Ruysschaert J.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1151: 137-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar) reported that the N-terminal region of apoAI in lipid complexes is susceptible to proteolysis, Dalton and Swaney (16Dalton M.B. Swaney J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19274-19283Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) indicated that the N-terminal region is resistant to proteolytic digestion and that there exists a susceptible site in the central region. Therefore, the location of the most susceptible site(s) to proteolysis remains controversial. In addition, results on the limited proteolysis of lipid-free apoAI have not been reported. Here we report our studies of the limited proteolysis of apoAI in well characterized rHDL and in aqueous solution. We also describe some of the interesting properties of an N-terminal chymotryptic fragment, apoAI-(1–192). Human apoAI, low density lipoprotein (LDL), and LCAT were prepared by the routine methods used in our laboratory (9Jonas A. Kézdy K.E. Wald J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 4818-4824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 10Wald J.H. Krul E.S. Jonas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20037-20043Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) from blood plasma purchased from the Champaign County Blood Bank Regional Health Resource Center. The purity of the apoAI and LCAT preparations (>95%) was confirmed by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and silver or Coomassie Blue staining, using the Pharmacia Phast System. The L-α-dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC), L-α-palmitoyloleoyl PC (POPC), L-α-dimyristoyl PC (DMPC), sodium cholate, crystalline cholesterol, tosylphenylalanyl chloromethyl ketone (TPCK)-treated bovine pancreatic trypsin (Type XIII), l-chloro-3-tosylamido-7-amino-2-heptanone (TLCK)-treated bovine pancreatic α-chymotrypsin (Type VII), insoluble bovine pancreatic α-chymotrypsin attached to carboxylmethyl cellulose (CMC-chymotrypsin), subtilisin Carlsberg, and phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride were purchased from Sigma. Porcine pancreatic elastase was obtained from Boehringer Mannheim. Radiolabeled [4-14C]cholesterol was purchased from DuPont NEN. Ultrapure guanidine hydrochloride (GdnHCl) was purchased from ICN Biomedicals Inc. Bis(sulfosuccinimidyl)suberate (BS3) was obtained from Pierce. Polyvinylidene difluoride membranes (0.2 μm) were from Bio-Rad Laboratories. Preparation of rHDL—The rHDL complexes were prepared by the original sodium cholate dialysis method (9Jonas A. Kézdy K.E. Wald J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 4818-4824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 10Wald J.H. Krul E.S. Jonas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20037-20043Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 25Matz C.E. Jonas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 4535-4540Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 26Jonas A. Methods Enzymol. 1986; 128: 553-582Crossref PubMed Scopus (296) Google Scholar) with only minor modifications. Briefly, the DPPC rHDL was prepared from a molar ratio of 100:1:100 DPPC:apoAI:sodium cholate. After removal of sodium cholate by extensive dialysis against 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm NaN3, and 0.01% EDTA (Tris-salt buffer), the complex was incubated at 50 °C for 24 h to enhance the homogeneity of rHDL particles. The POPC rHDL was prepared from a molar ratio of 80:4:1:80 POPC:cholesterol:apoAI:sodium cholate (9Jonas A. Kézdy K.E. Wald J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 4818-4824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). After removal of sodium cholate, the rHDL complex was incubated with LDL (rHDL to LDL protein, 1:1 (w/w)) at 37 °C for 18 h. LDL was removed by ultracentrifugal flotation, and homogeneous 78- and 108-Å POPC rHDL particles were isolated by gel filtration chromatography on a Superose 6 column (60 × 1.8 cm) using the Pharmacia FPLC System. Similarly POPC rHDL particles were prepared with the main chymotryptic fragment of apoAI (residues 1–192) (see below) instead of the intact apoAI, using a molar ratio of 80:4:1:160 POPC:cholesterol:fragment:sodium cholate. The particles were isolated by gel filtration as described above but without incubation with LDL. The size and purity of rHDL particles were determined by nondenaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (GGE) on 8–25% gradient gels using the Pharmacia Phast System. After Coomassie Blue staining and appropriate destaining, the gels were scanned with a Pharmacia UltroScan XL laser densitometer. The size of rHDL particles was then determined by their mobility as compared with that of protein standards of known Stokes radii, which were supplied by Pharmacia. Limited Proteolysis of ApoAI and rHDL—ApoAI or rHDL was diluted with the Tris-salt buffer to get a final concentration of 1 mg/ml apoAI. The proteases were added and mixed well to start the digestion at 25 °C in a shaking water bath. Preliminary experiments were performed to determine optimal digestion time and appropriate enzyme:substrate ratios. For time course experiments, the following enzyme:substrate ratios (w/w) were used to digest rHDL and apoAI, respectively: TLCK-chymotrypsin, 1:100 and 1:200; TPCK-trypsin, 1:200 and 1:500; elastase, 1:100 and 1:200; and subtilisin, 1:2000 and 1:5000. At various time intervals, aliquots were removed, SDS was added to obtain a final concentration of 4%, and samples were boiled for 2 min to terminate the reaction. The digestion products were stored at –20 °C until analyzed by electrophoresis. A pure chymotryptic fragment of apoAI was prepared by the digestion of apoAI using insoluble CMC-chymotrypsin (490 units/g). After being appropriately washed in the Tris-salt buffer, the CMC-chymotrypsin suspension was mixed with apoAI (10 mg of CMC-chymotrypsin/mg of apoAI) and reacted on a tilted rotator at room temperature for 2 h. CMC-chymotrypsin was then removed by centrifugation, and phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride was added (0.2 M, final concentration) to the supernatant to inactivate any residual chymotrypsin. Finally solid GdnHCl was added to attain a final concentration of 3 M, and the digestion products were transferred to dialysis tubing with a molecular weight cut-off of 12,000–14,000 and dialyzed exhaustively against 3 M GdnHCl and the Tris-salt buffer in sequence in order to remove small peptides. Analysis of Proteolytic Products—The digestion products were analyzed by SDS-PAGE using a discontinuous Tris-Tricine system (27Schagger H. von Jagow G. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 166: 368-379Crossref PubMed Scopus (10503) Google Scholar). A 16.5% T, 3% C resolving gel and a 4% T, 3% C stacking gel were used. After electrophoresis, the peptide bands in the gels were either visualized with Coomassie Blue or electrophoretically transferred to membranes. The membranes were then stained, and the bands of interest were excised and subjected to automated Edman degradation analysis (Genetic Engineering Facility, University of Illinois Biotechnology Center). At least five reaction cycles were performed. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry using a VG Quattro instrument was employed to determine the molecular weight of the main chymotryptic fragment of apoAI (Mass Spectrometry Laboratory, University of Illinois School of Chemical Sciences). The samples were dialyzed exhaustively against 5% HOAc before mass spectrometry analysis. Chemical Composition and Cross-linking—Protein concentration, phospholipid content, and cholesterol content in rHDL were measured as described previously (9Jonas A. Kézdy K.E. Wald J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 4818-4824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The extent of apoAI or fragment self-association and the number of apoAI or fragment molecules per rHDL particle were determined by cross-linking the proteins with BS3 (9Jonas A. Kézdy K.E. Wald J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 4818-4824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). DMPC Binding Studies—The binding of apoAI and the chymotryptic fragment to DMPC multilamellar liposomes were studied by kinetic turbidimetric methods as described by Pownall et al. (28Pownall H.J. Massey J.B. Kusserow S.K. Gotto Jr., A.M. Biochemistry. 1978; 17: 1183-1188Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar). ApoAI or the fragment was added to a DMPC suspension in the Tris-salt buffer (adjusted to d = 1.062 g/ml with NaCl to prevent settling of the liposomes) at a DMPC:protein ratio of 2.5:1 (w/w) (0.2 mg/ml of protein). The experiments were performed at 24 °C, and the absorbance at 325 nm was monitored at 5-min intervals with a Kinetics Soft-Pac™ module on a Beckman DU60 spectrophotometer. After incubation for 8 h, the density of the reaction mixture was adjusted with NaBr to 1.22 g/ml, and the mixture was fractionated by ultracentrifugation at 50,000 rpm and 24 °C for 24 h. After removal of excess salt by dialysis the protein content in the top and bottom portions was determined by the method of Lowry et al. (29Lowry O.H. Rosebrough N.J. Farr A.L. Randall R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Fluorescence Experiments—Uncorrected tryptophan fluorescence spectra were measured with a Perkin-Elmer MPF-66 fluorescence spectrophotometer using a 280-nm excitation wavelength and 4-nm excitation and emission slit widths at room temperature. All samples were adjusted to an A280 of 0.100. For the GdnHCl denaturation experiments, solid GdnHCl was added to 0.7 ml of sample in a sequential manner to give a range of GdnHCl concentrations from 0.72 to 6.37 M. Circular Dichroism Measurements—CD spectra were recorded with a Jasco J720 spectropolarimeter at room temperature at the Laboratory for Fluorescence Dynamics, University of Illinois. Prior to the measurements all samples were adjusted to an A280 of 0.100, and CD spectra were measured in a 0.1-cm path length quartz cuvette. Ten scans from 250 to 200 nm were collected and averaged. The mean residue ellipticity at 222 nm was calculated from the following relationship: [θ]222 = MRW·θ222/10·l·c, where θ222 is the observed ellipticity at 222 nm in degrees, l is the cuvette path length in cm, and c is the protein concentration in g/ml. A mean residue weight (MRW) of 115.4 and 116.4 was used for apoAI and the chymotryptic fragment, apoAI-(1–192), respectively. The percentage of α-helicity was estimated from the empirical expression of Chen et al. (30Chen Y-H. Yang J.T. Martinez H.M. Biochemistry. 1972; 11: 4120-4131Crossref PubMed Scopus (1912) Google Scholar): [θ]222 = –30,300fH – 2,340. LCAT Reaction Kinetics—The rHDL complexes containing apoAI or the chymotryptic fragment were incubated with aliquots of [14C]cholesterol (~4 × 104 cpm) dispersed in 4% defatted bovine serum albumin at 4 °C overnight and then at 37 °C for 2 h to label the substrate particles (9Jonas A. Kézdy K.E. Wald J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 4818-4824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 31Stokke K.T. Norum K.R. Scand. J. Clin. Lab. Invest. 1971; 27: 21-27Crossref PubMed Scopus (464) Google Scholar). Each reaction mixture contained 4% defatted bovine serum albumin, 4 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 20 ng of pure LCAT, and various concentrations of rHDL particles containing from 10−7 to 10−6 M apoAI or fragment in 0.5 ml of the Tris-salt buffer. The reaction was carried out for 20–30 min, and the conversion of [14C]cholesterol to cholesterol ester was less than 10%, ensuring that the initial velocity was being measured (32Matz C.E. Jonas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 4541-4546Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The apparent kinetic constants were determined by nonlinear least squares fit of the data to the expected hyperbola using the KaleidaGraph program (33Cleland W.W. Methods Enzymol. 1979; 63: 103-138Crossref PubMed Scopus (1929) Google Scholar). The size and homogeneity of the apoAI rHDL particles to be subjected to limited proteolysis were examined by nondenaturing GGE. The reaction of apoAI with DPPC originally gave a closely spaced doublet (96 and 94 Å in diameter) (10Wald J.H. Krul E.S. Jonas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20037-20043Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), but after incubation at 50 °C for 12 h, a single band corresponding to 94 Å was obtained (data not shown). POPC-apoAI rHDL particles with diameters of 78 and 96 Å were also isolated and characterized as previously reported (9Jonas A. Kézdy K.E. Wald J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 4818-4824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 34Jonas A. Wald J.H. Toohill K.L.H. Krul E.S. Kézdy K.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 22123-22129Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Limited Proteolysis of apoAI and Its rHDL—Limited proteolysis was employed to study the structure of apoAI molecules in rHDL complexes as well as in lipid-free form. Four proteolytic enzymes with different specificities were chosen for the study: chymotrypsin, trypsin, elastase, and subtilisin. It had been previously observed that free apoAI was much more susceptible to proteolysis than apoAI in rHDL (16Dalton M.B. Swaney J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19274-19283Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Lins L. Piron S. Conrath K. Vanloo B. Brasseur R. Rosseneu M. Baert J. Ruysschaert J.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1151: 137-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar); thus in order to attain a similar extent of hydrolysis the digestion time and enzyme:substrate ratios were decreased for lipid-free apoAI relative to rHDL. The digestion products were separated by SDS-PAGE. In Fig. 1, A-D, we show the time course of proteolysis of the 94-Å DPPC rHDL (left of the standard (Std.) lane) and lipid-free apoAI (right of the standard lane). All four digestions produced a relatively stable intermediate of approximately 22 kDa. This fragment appeared immediately after the digestion started and accumulated to a significant amount during the course of hydrolysis. Lipid-free apoAI was more susceptible to proteolytic digestion than its lipid-bound forms as indicated by its extensive degradation at shorter times and lower enzyme: apoAI ratios. In contrast, apoAI in rHDL was much more resistant to proteolysis, and there was intact apoAI left after prolonged digestion. While the 22-kDa fragment was the major intermediate in rHDL digestion, some smaller fragments of about 12, 10, and 3 kDa were also observed during the degradation of lipid-free apoAI (Fig. 1, A–C). Similar results were obtained from the digestion of 78-Å and 96-Å POPC-apoAI rHDL. However, while apoAI in 78-Å rHDL was more susceptible to proteolysis, apoAI in 96-Å rHDL exhibited similar susceptibility to digestion as the 94-Å DPPC rHDL. This result agrees with our previous observations that apoAI in the 78-Å rHDL denatures more readily than either the 96-Å POPC (34Jonas A. Wald J.H. Toohill K.L.H. Krul E.S. Kézdy K.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 22123-22129Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) or the 94-Å DPPC rHDL (10Wald J.H. Krul E.S. Jonas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20037-20043Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Nevertheless, all digestion reactions produced a relatively stable 22-kDa fragment (data not shown). Of particular interest is the limited digestion of lipid-free apoAI by chymotrypsin (Fig. 1A). When treated with chymotrypsin at a 1:200 (w/w) enzyme:substrate ratio for 1 h, all intact apoAI was transformed into a 22.4-kDa fragment along with a 3-kDa product. After mixing with GdnHCl and dialysis in a tubing with molecular weight cut-off of 12,000–14,000 against 3 m GdnHCl, the 3-kDa fragment was removed, and the 22.4-kDa fragment was recovered pure (>95%) for further characterization. Identification of Cleavage Sites—The N-terminal sequencing results of tryptic and chymotryptic fragments from free apoAI and rHDL are summarized in Table I. The results indicate that all large fragments contain the N terminus of apoAI. Thus proteolytic cleavage must have occurred in the C-terminal region. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometric analysis of the large chymotryptic fragment gave an apparent molecular weight of 22,384 and confirmed its purity. From the known amino acid sequence of apoAI (1Mahley R.W. Innerarity T.L. Rall Jr., S.C. Weisgraber K.H. J. Lipid Res. 1984; 25: 1277-1294Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), a fragment encompassing Asp1–Tyr192 would have a molecular weight of 22,385, which is very close to the experimental result. Open table in a new tab Self-association and Lipid Binding Properties of ApoAI-(1–192)—The 22.4-kDa N-terminal fragment, apoAI-(1–192), was used in the following experiments for structural and functional studies. Cross-linking experiments were conducted to study the self-association of apoAI-(1–192) in aqueous solution in comparison with apoAI. As shown in Fig. 2, apoAI formed several oligomers, including dimers, trimers, tetramers, pentamers, etc. in addition to monomers (lane 1). In contrast, apoAI-(1–192) gave almost exclusively monomers and dimers (lane 4). The dimer formation appeared to be concentration-dependent in the range of 0.5–2.5 mg/ml; however, even at 2.5 mg/ml, no higher oligomers were seen on the SDS gel. The ratio of dimer to monomer for apoAI-(1–192) was estimated to be 1:2 at 2.5 mg/ml (Fig. 2, lane 4) when the gel was scanned and the area under each peak was measured. Evidently the C-terminal region of apoAI plays a critical role in the oligomerization of the protein in aqueous solution. DMPC binding experiments were performed to study the effect of the loss of the C-terminal region on the initial interaction of apoAI with phospholipid bilayers. As illustrated in Fig. 3, intact apoAI bound and solubilized DMPC rapidly as indicated by the dramatic decrease in the turbidity of DMPC dispersions. In contrast, apoAI-(1–192) at the same concentration as apoAI interacted very slowly with DMPC. When the reaction mixtures were fractionated by ultracentrifugation at 1.22 g/ml after incubation at 24 °C for 8 h, ~80% of apoAI was recovered from the top fraction in DMPC-bound form, while for apoAI-(1–192) only ~35% of the protein was recovered in the top fraction. Apparently the loss of the C-terminal region diminishes the ability of the apolipoprotein to bind to lipid and to spontaneously form rHDL. Preparation and Chemical Composition of ApoAI-(1–192) rHDL—Fig. 4A shows a representative preparation of POPC-apoAI-(1–192) rHDL. At a POPC:cholesterol:protein molar ratio of 80:4:1, the major rHDL species were 77, 100, and 115 Å in diameter with some minor species about 120 A and larger. When apoAI-(1–192) rHDLs were compared with apoAI rHD

We previously purified a protein factor, named REKS (Ras-dependent Extracellular Signal-regulated Kinase (ERK)/mitogen-activated protein kinase Kinase (MEK) Stimulator), from Xenopus eggs by use of a cell-free assay system in which recombinant GTPγS (guanosine 5’-(3-O-thio)triphosphate)-Ki-Ras activates recombinant MEK. By use of this assay system, we purified here bovine REKS to near homogeneity from the cytosol fraction of bovine brain by successive chromatographies of Mono S, Mono Q, GTPγS-glutathione S-transferase-Ha-Ras-coupled glutathione-agarose, and Mono Q columns. It was composed of three proteins with masses of about 95, 32, and 30 kDa as estimated by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The 95-, 32-, and 30-kDa proteins were identified by immunoblot analysis to be B-Raf protein kinase, 14-3-3 protein, and 14-3-3 protein, respectively. Moreover, the REKS activity was specifically immunoprecipitated by an anti-B-Raf antibody. Bovine REKS was activated by lipid-modified GTPγS-Ki-Ras far more effectively than by a lipid-unmodified one. Lipid-modified GDP-Ki-Ras was inactive. Exogenous addition of 14-3-3 proteins stimulated further the REKS activity both in the presence and absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. These results indicate that at least one of the direct targets of Ras is B-Raf complexed with 14-3-3 proteins in bovine brain. Science. 1994; 266: 56-57Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar).In the present study, we have attempted to purify REKS from bovine brain cytosol and to identify it. We have found that bovine brain REKS is composed of B-Raf complexed with 14-3-3 proteins.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESPurification of REKSBovine brains were obtained from the heads of freshly slaughtered cattle. All the purification procedures were performed at 0-4°C. Gray matter of cerebra (about 1.6 kg, wet weight) were homogenized in a Waring blender with 1.7 volumes of Homogenizing Buffer (20 mM Tris/HCl at pH 7.9, 2 mM EDTA, 5 μM APMSF, 1 mg/l leupeptin, and 1 mg/l pepstatin A). The homogenate was centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 1 h. After one-ninth volume of Buffer A (200 mM Tris/HCl at pH 8.0, 10 mM DTT, 100 mM EGTA, and 50 mM MgCl2) was added to the supernatant, one-ninth volume of ethylene glycol was added to give the final concentration of 10%. The supernatant was then immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C until use.Bovine brain cytosol (200 ml, 1.4 g of protein) was thawed on ice, and the supernatant was obtained by centrifugation at 100,000 × g for 1 h. The supernatant was sequentially filtrated through 2.0-, 0.8-, 0.45-, and 0.2-μm filters. The filtrated supernatant (160 ml, 1.1 g of protein) was then applied to a Mono S column (1.0 × 10 cm) equilibrated with 80 ml of Buffer B (20 mM HEPES/NaOH at pH 7.0, 1 mM DTT, 10 mM EGTA, 5 mM MgCl2, and 10 μM APMSF). After the column was washed with 80 ml of Buffer B, elution was performed with a 240-ml linear gradient of NaCl (0-1.0 M) in Buffer B and fractions of 4 ml each were collected. REKS appeared in fractions 80-90 (Fig. 1A). After 1.5 M Tris was added to 160 ml of the active fractions of Fig. 1A to adjust pH to 7.5, the active fractions were diluted with an equal volume of Buffer C (20 mM Tris/HCl at pH 7.5, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM EGTA, 5 mM MgCl2, and 10 μM APMSF) and applied to a Mono Q column (1.0 × 10 cm) equilibrated with 80 ml of Buffer C. After the column was washed with 80 ml of Buffer C, elution was performed with a 240-ml linear gradient of NaCl (0.125-0.5 M) in Buffer C and fractions of 4 ml each were collected. REKS appeared in fractions 118-122 (Fig. 1B). GTPγS- or GDP-GST-Ha-Ras (15 nmol each) was separately applied to a glutathione-agarose column (0.6 ml) pre-equilibrated with 9 ml of Buffer D (20 mM Tris/HCl at pH 7.5, 1 mM DTT, 5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM EGTA), and the column was washed with 15 ml of Buffer D. Forty ml of the active fractions of Fig. 1B was applied to this column and washed sequentially with 6 ml of Buffer D, 6 ml of Buffer D containing 0.25 M NaCl, and 6 ml of Buffer D. Elution was performed with 1.8 ml of Buffer D containing 20 mM reduced glutathione (Fig. 1C). The active eluate fractions of Fig. 1C were applied to a Mono Q column (0.16 × 5 cm) equilibrated with 1 ml of Buffer D. After the column was washed with 2 ml of Buffer D, elution was performed with a linear gradient of NaCl (0-0.5 M) in Buffer D. At 190 mM NaCl, however, the gradient was placed on hold for 4 ml to remove REKS-unbound GST-Ha-Ras and then continued. Fractions of 100 μl each were collected (Fig. 2A). REKS appeared in fractions 93-100.Figure 2:Second Mono Q column chromatography of the affinity-purified REKS. Each fraction (1 μl) was assayed for the REKS activity. Another aliquot (60 μl) of each fraction was subjected to SDS-PAGE followed by silver staining and immunoblot analysis. A, REKS activity. B, silver staining. C, immunoblot analysis with anti-B-Raf and anti-14-3-3 protein antibodies. Lanes 1 and 3, bovine brain cytosol (100 μg of protein); lanes 2 and 4, 60 μl of fraction 94. An arrowhead and arrows indicate the positions of the 95-kDa protein, and both the 32- and 30-kDa proteins, respectively. The protein markers used were myosin (Mr = 200,000), β-galactosidase (Mr = 116,000), bovine serum albumin (Mr = 66,000), ovalbumin (Mr = 45,000), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (Mr = 36,000), carbonic anhydrase (Mr = 29,000), and trypsin inhibitor (Mr = 20,100). The results shown are representative of three independent experiments.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Materials and Other ProceduresPost-translationally lipid-modified and -unmodified Ki-Ras, GST-MEK, GST-ERK2, and GST-Ha-Ras were prepared as described (35Shimizu K. The same sample of an anti-14-3-3 protein polyclonal antibody as used previously (35Shimizu K. Kuroda S. Yamamori B. Matsuda S. Kaibuchi K. Yamauchi T. Isobe T. Irie K. Matsumoto K. Takai Y. J. Biol. Anti-c-Raf-1, anti-A-Raf, and anti-B-Raf polyclonal antibodies were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology (Santa Cruz, CA). The same sample of rat brain 14-3-3 proteins as used previously (35Shimizu K. Kuroda S. Yamamori B. Matsuda S. Kaibuchi K. Yamauchi T. Isobe T. Irie K. Matsumoto K. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22917-22920Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) was kindly provided from T. Yamauchi (Tokushima University, Tokushima, Japan). REKS activity was assayed by measuring the phosphorylation of myelin basic protein by recombinant GST-ERK2 in the presence of recombinant GST-MEK as described (35Shimizu K. Kuroda S. Yamamori B. SDS-PAGE was performed by the method of Laemmli (40Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (206016) Google Scholar). Protein concentrations were determined with bovine serum albumin as a standard protein by the method of Bradford (41Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (213347) Google Scholar). Immunoblot was carried out as described (35Shimizu K. Kuroda S. Yamamori B. Matsuda S. Kaibuchi K. Yamauchi T. Isobe T. Irie K. Matsumoto K. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22917-22920Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).RESULTSWhen filtrated bovine brain cytosol was subjected to a Mono S column chromatography and each fraction was assayed for the REKS activity, two peaks appeared (Fig. 1A). The second peak was enhanced by GTPγS-Ki-Ras, but not by GDP-Ki-Ras, whereas the first peak was not affected by GTPγS-Ki-Ras. Moreover, the second peak was dependent on MEK, whereas the first peak was not (data not shown). Therefore, the second peak was a bovine counterpart of Xenopus REKS. When the active fractions of Fig. 1A were subjected to a Mono Q column chromatography and each fraction was assayed for the REKS activity, three peaks appeared (Fig. 1B). The first peak was enhanced by GTPγS-Ki-Ras, whereas the second and third peaks were not. All peaks were dependent on recombinant MEK (data not shown). Therefore, the first peak was REKS and the other peaks were unknown MEK kinases. The active fractions of Fig. 1B were applied to a GTPγS-GST-Ha-Ras-coupled glutathione-agarose column chromatography. About 45% of the total REKS activity was adsorbed to the column and was eluted by reduced glutathione (Fig. 1C). About 70% of GTPγS-GST-Ha-Ras was also eluted by reduced glutathione (data not shown). Any REKS activity was not adsorbed to the GDP-GST-Ha-Ras-coupled glutathione-agarose column. When the active eluate fractions of Fig. 1C were subjected to a Mono Q column chromatography, the REKS activity was detected as a single peak (Fig. 2A). When each fraction was subjected to SDS-PAGE followed by protein staining, the peak of REKS was accompanied with four proteins and most GST-Ha-Ras was recovered in other fractions (Fig. 2B). The masses of these proteins were about 95, 49, 32, and 30 kDa. The protein with a mass of 49 kDa was GST-Ha-Ras itself. The proteins with masses of 95, 32, and 30 kDa were identified by immunoblot analysis to be B-Raf, 14-3-3 protein, and 14-3-3 protein, respectively (Fig. 2C).To further confirm that REKS includes B-Raf, we examined the immunoprecipitation of REKS with an anti-B-Raf antibody. After the REKS sample of Fig. 1B was incubated with or without an anti-B-Raf antibody, its activity was measured in the supernatant and precipitate (Fig. 3A). In the presence of the antibody, the REKS activity was recovered in the precipitate, whereas, in the absence of the antibody, the REKS activity was recovered in the supernatant. Moreover, the REKS activity was not immunoprecipitated by any of the antibodies against A-Raf and c-Raf-1 and no immunoreactivities against A-Raf and c-Raf-1 were detected in the REKS sample of Fig. 1B (data not shown). It may be noted that the recovery of the REKS activity in the precipitate was about 500% (Fig. 3A). To clarify the reason for this increase in the recovery, the REKS activity was measured in the presence or absence of the anti-B-Raf antibody. The REKS activity increased about 5-fold in the presence of the antibody compared to that in the absence of the antibody (Fig. 3B).Figure 3:Immunoprecipitation of REKS by an anti-B-Raf antibody and effect of an anti-B-Raf antibody on the REKS activity. A, immunoprecipitation of REKS by an anti-B-Raf antibody. The first peak of Fig. 1 B (100 μl) was incubated with or without an anti-B-Raf antibody (40 μl) for 1.5 h at 4°C. After Protein A-Sepharose beads (20 μl) were added, the immunocomplex was precipitated and washed sequentially with Buffer C containing 0.5% Nonidet P-40 and with Buffer C. The precipitate (1 μl) or supernatant (1 μl) was assayed for the REKS activity in the presence or absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. Open bar, in the absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. Closed bar, in the presence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. Lanes 1, 2, 5, and 6, without an anti-B-Raf antibody; lanes 3, 4, 7, and 8, with an anti-B-Raf antibody. Lanes 1-4, supernatant; lanes 5-8, precipitate. B, effect of an anti-B-Raf antibody on the REKS activity. After the REKS sample of Fig. 1 B (100 μl) was incubated with or without an anti-B-Raf antibody (5 μl) for 1.5 h at 4°C, the mixture (1 μl) was assayed for the REKS activity in the presence or absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. Open bar, without GTPγS-Ki-Ras. Closed bar, with GTPγS-Ki-Ras. Lanes 1 and 2, without an anti-B-Raf antibody; lanes 3 and 4, with an anti-B-Raf antibody. The results shown are representative of three independent experiments.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)We have shown previously that lipid-modified Ras is far more effective than lipid-unmodified Ras on the activation of Xenopus REKS (28Itoh T. Kaibuchi K. Masuda T. Yamamoto T. Matsuura Y. Maeda A. Shimizu K. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 3025-3028Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Similarly, lipid-modified GTPγS-Ki-Ras activated bovine REKS, whereas lipid-unmodified GTPγS-Ki-Ras was nearly inactive (data not shown). The Kavalue for lipid-modified GTPγS-Ki-Ras, giving a half-maximum activation, was about 20 nM. We have reported previously that 14-3-3 proteins and GTPγS-Ki-Ras synergistically stimulate Xenopus REKS (35Shimizu K. Kuroda S. Yamamori B. Matsuda S. Kaibuchi K. Yamauchi T. Isobe T. Irie K. Matsumoto K. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22917-22920Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). 14-3-3 proteins purified from rat brain markedly stimulated the REKS activity in the absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras, whereas 14-3-3 proteins slightly stimulated it in the presence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras (data not shown). However, the maximal levels activated by the addition of 14-3-3 proteins were almost the same in the presence and absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. The Kavalues for 14-3-3 proteins were also the same in the presence and absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras and were about 100 nM.DISCUSSIONWe have purified here REKS from bovine brain cytosol and shown that bovine brain REKS is composed of at least three proteins with masses of about 95, 32, and 30 kDa. The 95-, 32-, and 30-kDa proteins have been identified to be B-Raf, 14-3-3 protein, and 14-3-3 protein, respectively. These results are consistent with the earlier observations that MAP kinase is activated by B-Raf in response to nerve growth factor in PC12 cells (13Jaiswal R.K. Moodie S.A. Wolfman A. Landreth G.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 6944-6953Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), that association of MEK with immobilized Ras is dependent on B-Raf in rat brain (14Moodie S.A. Paris M.J. Kolch W. Wolfman A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 7153-7162Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar), and that MEK activating activity is accompanied with B-Raf in bovine brain or chromaffin cells (15Catling A.D. Reuter C.W.M. Cox M.E. Parsons S.J. Weber M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30014-30021Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because we have purified here REKS by the GTPγS-GST-Ha-Ras-coupled glutathione-agarose column chromatography, the purified REKS is likely to be complexed with GTPγS-GST-Ha-Ras and to be converted to an active form. Therefore, the possibility cannot be excluded that an inactive form of REKS contains a component other than B-Raf and 14-3-3 proteins.14-3-3 proteins interact directly with c-Raf-1 in in vivo and in vitro systems and enhance its activity (31Freed E. Science. 1994; 265: 1716-1719Crossref PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar, 33Fu H. Xia K. Pallas D.C. Cui C. Conroy K. Narsimhan R.P. Mamon H. Collier R.J. Roberts T.M. Science. 1994; 266: 126-129Crossref PubMed Scopus (242) Google Scholar, 34Fantl W.J. Muslin A.J. Kikuchi A. Martin J.A. MacNicol A.M. Gross R.W. Williams L.T. Nature. 1994; 371: 612-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar). We have described previously that 14-3-3 proteins slightly activate Xenopus REKS in the absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras, whereas they synergistically activate it in the presence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras (35Shimizu K. Kuroda S. Yamamori B. Matsuda S. Kaibuchi K. Yamauchi T. Isobe T. Irie K. Matsumoto K. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22917-22920Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, 14-3-3 proteins markedly stimulated bovine REKS in the absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras and slightly stimulated it in the presence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras, although the maximal levels activated by the addition of 14-3-3 proteins were almost the same in the presence and absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. This present result is not consistent with our earlier observation for Xenopus REKS, but this discrepancy may be due to the difference of the properties between Xenopus REKS and bovine REKS. Furthermore, to examine whether 14-3-3 proteins are essential for the Ras-dependent activation of bovine REKS, we have attempted to separate 14-3-3 proteins from B-Raf but have not yet succeeded. It remains to be clarified whether 14-3-3 proteins are essential for the Ras-dependent activation of B-Raf.We have found here that the REKS activity immunoprecipitated by the anti-B-Raf antibody is enhanced by the antibody irrespective of the presence or absence of GTPγS-Ki-Ras. The N-terminal domain of c-Raf-1 inhibits its kinase activity presumably by masking its kinase domain (42Stanton Jr., V.P. Nichols D.W. Laudano A.P. Cooper G.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 639-647Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar, 43Heidecker G. Huleihel M. Cleveland J.L. Kolch W. Beck T.W. Lloyd P. Pawson T. Rapp U.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 2503-2512Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar, 44Bruder J.T. Heidecker G. Rapp U.R. Genes & Dev. 1992; 6: 545-556Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar). It is possible that the association of an anti-B-Raf antibody with B-Raf relieves it from the inhibitory action of the N-terminal domain, resulting in the activation of REKS. This result has raised a possibility that there may be another factor that mimics the action of the antibody.We have previously identified a possible protein of Xenopus REKS with a mass of 98 kDa, immunologically distinct from B-Raf (30Kuroda S. Shimizu K. Yamamori B. Matsuda S. Imazumi K. Kaibuchi K. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 2460-2465Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). However, Xenopus REKS and bovine REKS share the similar properties. They are adsorbed to the GTPγS-GST-Ha-Ras-coupled glutathione-agarose column. They have similar minimum molecular sizes on SDS-PAGE. Lipid modifications of Ras are critical for their activation. These observations suggest that the 98-kDa protein of Xenopus REKS is the counterpart of the 95-kDa protein of bovine REKS. The reason why the 98-kDa protein of Xenopus REKS was not recognized by an anti-B-Raf antibody is not known, but it is possible that the amino acids of the C terminus of the Xenopus 98-kDa protein are different from those of the bovine 95-kDa protein, namely B-Raf, against which the anti-B-Raf antibody was generated.A-Raf, B-Raf, and c-Raf-1 are expressed in brain (45Storm S.M. Cleveland J.L. Rapp U.R. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 345-351PubMed Google Scholar). We have identified here REKS as B-Raf, but not A-Raf or c-Raf-1, in brain. On the other hand, c-Raf-1 directly interacts with GTP-Ras in cell-free assay systems (19Moodie S.A. Willumsen B.M. Weber M.J. Wolfman A. Vincent L.A. Roberts T.M. Sturgill T.W. Science. 1992; 257: 1404-1407Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar, 9Howe L.R. Leevers S.J. Gómez N. Nakielny S. Cohen P. Marshall C.J. Nature. 1992; 358: 417-421Crossref PubMed Scopus (966) Google Scholar). Although these earlier observations suggest that c-Raf-1 activated by GTP-Ras activates MEK, no direct evidence has thus far been obtained that GTP-Ras activates c-Raf-1 or A-Raf in cell-free assay systems. The failure that bovine brain A-Raf or c-Raf-1 is not activated by GTPγS-Ki-Ras in our system may be due to the contamination of some interfering materials in the A-Raf or c-Raf-1 fractions, or to the absence of a certain factor necessary for the Ras-dependent MEK activation. B-Raf is expressed only in cerebrum, spinal cord, and testis (45Storm S.M. Cleveland J.L. Rapp U.R. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 345-351PubMed Google Scholar). If A-Raf or c-Raf-1 is not responsible for the Ras-dependent MEK activation, another B-Raf isoform or another MEK kinase may be present and responsible for the Ras-dependent MEK activation in other tissues. The 14-3-3 protein family, consisting of at least seven members, is known to be an activator protein of tyrosine and tryptophan hydroxylases, to modulate the protein kinase C activity, to stimulate secretion, to be a phospholipase A2per se, to stimulate mitochondrial import of protein, to interact with c-Bcr and Bcr-Abl, and to interact with middle tumor antigen of polyomavirus (36Hachiya N. Science. 1994; 266: 56-57Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar).In the present study, we have attempted to purify REKS from bovine brain cytosol and to identify it. We have found that bovine brain REKS is composed of B-Raf complexed with 14-3-3 proteins.

The N-end rule relates the in vivo half-life of a protein to the identity of its N-terminal residue. Tertiary destabilizing N-terminal residues asparagine and glutamine function through their conversion, by enzymatic deamidation, into the secondary destabilizing residues aspartate and glutamate, whose activity requires their enzymatic conjugation to arginine, one of the primary destabilizing residues. We isolated a Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene, termed NTA1, that encodes an amidase (Nt-amidase) specific for N-terminal asparagine and glutamine. Alterations at the putative active-site cysteine of the 52-kDa Nt-amidase inactivate the enzyme. Null nta1 mutants are viable but unable to degrade N-end rule substrates that bear N-terminal asparagine or glutamine. The effects of overexpressing Nt-amidase and other components of the N-end rule pathway suggest interactions between these components and the existence of a multienzyme targeting complex. We isolated a Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene, termed NTA1, that encodes an amidase (Nt-amidase) specific for N-terminal asparagine and glutamine. Alterations at the putative active-site cysteine of the 52-kDa Nt-amidase inactivate the enzyme. Null nta1 mutants are viable but unable to degrade N-end rule substrates that bear N-terminal asparagine or glutamine. The effects of overexpressing Nt-amidase and other components of the N-end rule pathway suggest interactions between these components and the existence of a multienzyme targeting complex.

A colony-stimulating factor 1-dependent cell line was used to determine the relationship between the inhibition of phospholipid synthesis and the cytotoxic activity of the antineoplastic ether lipid, 1-O-octadecyl-2-O-methyl-rae-glycero-3-phosphocholine (ET-18-OCH3). ET-18-OCH3 inhibited choline incorporation into phosphatidylcholine as well as total phospholipid synthesis. Exposure to ET-18-OCH3 at the G1/S boundary led to the accumulation of cells in G2, whereas the addition of ET-18-OCH3 in the G1 phase of the cell cycle prevented entry into the S phase. In both cases, ET-18-OCH3 treatment triggered DNA fragmentation and morphological changes associated with apoptosis within 10 h. The addition of lysophosphatidylcholine provided an exogenous source of cellular phospholipid and prevented ET-18-OCH3-dependent accumulation of cells in G2 and apoptosis. However, lysophosphatidylcholine did not overcome the ET-18-OCH3-dependent Gx block, although the growth-arrested cells remained viable. These data indicate that restoring phosphatidylcholine synthesis by supplementation with lysophosphatidylcholine overrides the cytotoxic but not the cytostatic activity of ET-18-OCH3. A colony-stimulating factor 1-dependent cell line was used to determine the relationship between the inhibition of phospholipid synthesis and the cytotoxic activity of the antineoplastic ether lipid, 1-O-octadecyl-2-O-methyl-rae-glycero-3-phosphocholine (ET-18-OCH3). ET-18-OCH3 inhibited choline incorporation into phosphatidylcholine as well as total phospholipid synthesis. Exposure to ET-18-OCH3 at the G1/S boundary led to the accumulation of cells in G2, whereas the addition of ET-18-OCH3 in the G1 phase of the cell cycle prevented entry into the S phase. In both cases, ET-18-OCH3 treatment triggered DNA fragmentation and morphological changes associated with apoptosis within 10 h. The addition of lysophosphatidylcholine provided an exogenous source of cellular phospholipid and prevented ET-18-OCH3-dependent accumulation of cells in G2 and apoptosis. However, lysophosphatidylcholine did not overcome the ET-18-OCH3-dependent Gx block, although the growth-arrested cells remained viable. These data indicate that restoring phosphatidylcholine synthesis by supplementation with lysophosphatidylcholine overrides the cytotoxic but not the cytostatic activity of ET-18-OCH3. There is a growing interest in antineoplastic ether-linked phospholipid analogs because they do not directly target DNA and could potentially complement existing DNA-directed anticancer treatment regimens.
