ET-18-OCH3 inhibition of PtdCho synthesis arises from the inhibition of CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase activity where ET-18-OCH3 is thought to act as a LPC analog (38Boggs K.P. Rock C.O. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7757-7764Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar). CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase catalyzes the formation of CDP-choline and is the rate-controlling step in de novo PtdCho synthesis (39Kent C. Prog. Lipid Res. 1990; 29: 87-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar, 40Vance D.E. Vance D.E. Phosphatidylcholine Metabolism. CRC Press, Inc., Boca Raton, FL1989: 225-239Google Scholar). CTP: phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase activity is necessary for cell survival (41Esko J.D. Wermuth M.M. Raetz C.R.H. J. Biol Chem. 1981; 256: 7388-7393Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), not only because PtdCho is the major membrane constituent but also because PtdCho is a precursor to the two other most abundant membrane phospholipids, sphingomyelin (42Voelker D.R. Kennedy E.P. Biochemistry. 1982; 21: 2753-2759Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar) and phosphatidylethanolamine (43Voelker D.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1984; 81: 2669-2673Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Although it is clear that the CDP-choline pathway for PtdCho biosynthesis is blocked in vivo by LPC and its analogs (38Boggs K.P. Rock C.O. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7757-7764Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar), whether the inhibition of PtdCho synthesis plays a determinant role in the cytotoxic action of ET-18-OCH3 or whether it is an unrelated metabolic effect that does not contribute to ET-18-OCH3 action remains an open question. LPC can circumvent the requirement for CDP-choline production by its uptake and acylation to PtdCho (44Jamil H. Yao Z. Vance D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 4332-4339Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 45Jamil H. Hatch G.M. Vance D.E. Biochem. J. 1993; 291: 419-427Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). The addition of LPC to the culture medium restores the proliferative capacity of a CHO cell line with a conditional defect in CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase activity (46Esko J.D. Nishijima M. Raetz C.R.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1982; 79: 1698-1702Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). We have examined the effects of LPC on ET-18-OCH3 toxicity to elucidate the role of inhibiting membrane phospholipid synthesis in the action of this antineoplastic agent. Sources of supplies were: DuPont NEN, [32P]orthophosphate (carrier free), phospho[14C]choline (specific, activity 50 mCi/mmol), [3H]choline (specific activity, 86.6 Ci/mmol); CDP-[14C]choline (specific activity, 58 mCi/mmol), [3H]thymidine (specific activity, 87.7 Ci/mmol), and 125I-protein A (specific activity, 30 mCi/mg); Analtech, Silica Gel G thin-layer plates; Hyclone Inc., fetal calf serum; Life Technologies, Inc., Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, choline-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, and other tissue culture supplies; and Sigma, phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, CDP-choline, lactate dehydrogenase assay kit, leupeptin, CTP, and aprotinin. Polyclonal rabbit antibodies against purified rat CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase were the same as described by Jackowski (47Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3858-3867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Recombinant CSF-1 was kindly provided by the Genetics Institute. All other materials were reagent grade or better. The cell line used in this work was BAC1.2F5, a macrophage-like, CSF-l-dependent clone derived from the BACI line (48Morgan C. Pollard J.W. Stanley E.R. J. Cell. Physiol. 1987; 130: 420-427Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar) that originated from transfection of splenic adherent cells from a (BALB/c × A.CA)F, mouse with simian virus 40 origin-defective DNA (49Schwarzbaum S. Halpern R. Diamond B. J. Immunol. 1984; 132: 1158-1162PubMed Google Scholar). The BAC1.2F5 line exhibits many properties of macrophages, including production of lysozyme, collagenase, and esterase. BAC1.2F5 cells have an absolute requirement for CSF-1 for both proliferation and survival (50Tushinski R.J. Stanley E.R. J. Cell. Physiol. 1985; 122: 221-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar). BAC1.2F5 cells were routinely grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 15% fetal calf serum, 25% LCM, 1% glutamine, and 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.3. Human recombinant CSF-1 was added at a concentration of 200 units/ml (90 ng/ml). The human growth factor was as effective as murine CSF-1, and stimulation of the cells with 25% LCM was equivalent to the addition of 300 ng/ml CSF-1. BAC1.2F5 cells were arrested in G1 by the removal of CSF-1 for 18 h and stimulated to traverse the cell cycle by the readdition of either recombinant CSF-1 or LCM. The timing of the BAC1.2F5 cell cycle under these conditions has been determined (51Rock C.O. Cleveland J.L. Jackowski S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 2351-2358Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). BAC1.2F5 cells were seeded into 12-well cluster dishes at 6 × 104/well in 2.5 ml of complete medium on day 1. On day 2, the medium was replaced with fresh growth medium. On day 3, the medium was replaced with medium without CSF-1 to synchronize the cells in Gx. On day 4, the starvation medium was replaced and conditions were as described in the figure legends with the addition of [3H]thymidine (15 μCi/ml). 24 h later, the medium was removed, and the cells in the medium were recovered by centrifugation and washed twice with PBS. The adherent cells were washed twice with PBS and released from the dish by a short (∼1 min) treatment with trypsin-EDTA (0.05% trypsin, 0.53 mM EDTA in Hanks’ balanced salt solution, Life Technologies, Inc.). [3H]Thymidine incorporation was determined in duplicate aliquote from each sample by liquid scintillation counting. BAC1.2F5 cells were seeded at 0.5 × 106/dish in 100-mm dishes in complete LCM on day 1. On days 2–4, conditions were as described in the figure legends. The number of viable cells was determined on days 2–5 by trypan blue exclusion. The data are expressed as the mean number of viable cells/dish ± S.E. BAC1.2F5 cells were incubated in complete LCM for 48 h. The medium was replaced with choline-depleted complete LCM, and, 24 h later, fresh choline-depleted medium was added. Conditions were as described in the figure legends with the addition of [3H]choline (final concentrations, 2 μΜ and 1.5 μCi/ml). After the intervals indicated, the adherent cells were washed with ice-cold PBS and harvested by scraping into 1 ml of PBS. The cells were pelleted by centrifugation. The incorporation of label into the aqueous and organic soluble phases was determined after lipid extraction (52Bligh E.G. Dyer W.J. Can. J. Biochem. Physiol. 1959; 37: 911-917Crossref PubMed Scopus (43126) Google Scholar). Total phospholipid accumulation was quantitated by equilibrium labeling with [32P]orthophosphate (47Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3858-3867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). BAC1.2F5 cells were incubated in phosphate-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium plus 25% LCM for 2 days, starved for CSF-1 for 18 h, and restimulated with LCM as the source of CSF-1. Thus, the phosphate-deficient medium contained 25% of the total inorganic phosphate found in normal growth medium. All media contained 3 μCi/ml. [32P]orthophosphate. 24 h after the readdition of growth factor, cells were washed twice with ice-cold PBS and scraped into 1 ml of cold methanol. The lipids were extracted (52Bligh E.G. Dyer W.J. Can. J. Biochem. Physiol. 1959; 37: 911-917Crossref PubMed Scopus (43126) Google Scholar), and the incorporation of label into phospholipids was quantitated by scintillation counting. We confirmed that ET-18-OCH3 inhibited PtdCho synthesis in the BAC1.2F5 cell system. Cells were labeled with [3H]choline, and the effect of 12 μΜ ET-18-OCH3 on the incorporation of label into phospholipid over a 6-h time course was determined (Fig. LA). A concentration of 12 μΜ ET-18-OCH3 maximally inhibited [3H]choline incorporation into phospholipid (38Boggs K.P. Rock C.O. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7757-7764Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar). ET-18-OCH3 reduced PtdCho synthesis as early as 1 h in BAC1.2F5 cells (Fig. 1A). This inhibition was not due to the inability of the cells to take up choline, because the accumulation of label in the soluble pool was the same in treated and untreated cells at 2 h. Also, thin-layer chromatography of the soluble pool at 2 h showed that the principal component was phosphocholine, which was present in equal amounts in both treated and untreated cells (data not shown). Furthermore, the exposure of BAC1.2F5 cells to LPC did not reverse the inhibition of PtdCho synthesis by ET-18-OCH3 (Fig. LA), because LPC itself inhibits PtdCho synthesis at the CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase step (38Boggs K.P. Rock C.O. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7757-7764Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar). Because PtdCho is a precursor to the other two major membrane phospholipids in BAC1.2F5 cells, sphingomyelin and phosphatidylethanolamine, the inhibition of PtdCho synthesis should block total membrane phospholipid accumulation. To verify this point, we labeled BAC1.2F5 cells to equilibrium with a constant amount of [32P]orthophosphate for 2 days prior to the experiment, during CSF-1 starvation, and throughout the cell cycle following CSF-1 stimulation. The indicated cultures received ET-18-OCH3 at the time of CSF-1 readdition, and the total [32P]phospholipid accumulation over a 24-h period (one cell cycle) was measured (Fig. 1B). In the absence of the drug, the phospholipid content increased within 24 h as reported previously (47Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3858-3867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, treatment with ET-18-OCH3 blocked the increase in cellular phospholipid content, and the amount of total phospholipid remaining at 24 h was actually less than the amount present at the start of Gx. Both PtdCho synthesis and degradation are operative during the G1 phase, resulting in rapid turnover of the PtdCho pool (47Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3858-3867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The lower phospholipid content in the presence of ET-18-OCH3 is consistent with continued PtdCho degradation in the absence of new synthesis, resulting in a smaller pool of phospholipid. Addition of ET-18-OCH3 at the G1/S Boundary Inhibits Completion of the Cell Cycle—BAC1.2F5 cells increase their phospholipid mass during the S phase (47Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3858-3867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), so we first determined the effect of ET-18-OCH3 inhibition of phospholipid synthesis on progression through the S and G2/M phases by adding the drug at the G1/S boundary (10 h). As expected, untreated control cells traversed the cell cycle and returned to G1 phase 24 h after the readdition of CSF-1 (Fig. 2A, panel I). As another control, cells were treated with nocodazole, a cell cycle blocker known to arrest cells in the M phase, which led to the accumulation of cells containing 4 n DNA (Fig. 2A, panel II). CSF-1 starvation is an excellent cell synchronization technique, but growth factor deprivation results in a loss of cell viability between 15 and 25% (51Rock C.O. Cleveland J.L. Jackowski S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 2351-2358Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). The cells remaining in G1 in nocodazole-treated cells represent the population of nonviable cells (in this case 15% of the total) that did not recover from CSF-1 starvation and lost the capacity to traverse the cell cycle. The addition of ET-18-OCH3 at 10 h resulted in the accumulation of the cells in the G2/M phase (Fig. 2A, panel III). An additional feature of the flow cytofluorometry profile of ET-18-OCH3-treated cells was the appearance of cells with DNA contents less than 2 n (Fig. 2A, panel III) showing that ET-18-OCH3 treatment led to DNA fragmentation. DNA degradation likely occurred in 4 n as well as 2 n cells, obscuring a clear view of the number of cells in the S phase, but the lack of a significant accumulation of S phase cells indicated that DNA replication was largely completed, whereas phospholipid synthesis was inhibited by ET-18-OCH3. This observation is in agreement with earlier results that demonstrated the independence of the two processes (47Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3858-3867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Microscopic examination of Giemsa-stained cytospins revealed that the ET-18-OCH3-treated cells either had apoptotic morphology or maintained intact nuclear membranes (data not shown). The absence of mitotic figures suggested that the cells were primarily accumulating in G2. Maximum accumulation in the G2/M phase occurred at 12 μΜ ET-18-OCH3 (Fig. 2B), the same concentration required to maximally inhibit PtdCho synthesis (38Boggs K.P. Rock C.O. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7757-7764Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1A). Thus, ET-18-OCH3 addition at the G1/S boundary inhibited progression beyond the G2 phase, whereas S phase progression was relatively unaffected. Addition of ET-18-OCH3 in G1 Prevents Progression to S Phase—A more comprehensive set of experiments was performed to determine the effect of ET-18-OCH3 on cell cycle progression. BAC1.2F5 cells were synchronized in G1; and the growth factor was added back to initiate the cycle. The drug was added at different times during the Gx or S phase, and the effect of ET-18-OCH3 on the cell cycle parameters at 24 h was determined (Fig. 3). First, the addition of ET-18-OCH3 at the same time as CSF-1 resulted in a Gx profile and the appearance of a large fragmented DNA signal (Fig. 3G). Fragmented DNA was detected as less than 2 N DNA content in the histograms. These data are consistent with ET-18-OCH3 preventing the cells from exiting the G1 phase. Although the flow cytofluorometry profile could be interpreted to mean that ET-18-OCH3-treated cells traversed the entire cell cycle and returned to the G1 phase as was the case with untreated control cells (Fig. 3K), further experiments showed that the addition of ET-18-OCH3 at the same time as CSF-1 blocked [3H]thymidine incorporation, demonstrating that ET-18-OCH3-treated cells did not enter the S phase (see below). After the addition of ET-18-OCH3 at 6 h, the majority of the cells remained in the G1 phase, although a population of cells were blocked in the G2/M phase, and fragmented DNA was evident (Fig. 3if). The addition of ET-18-OCH3 at 10 h gave the highest percentage of cells in the G2/M phase and lower levels of fragmented DNA (Fig. 3I). The addition of ET-18-OCH3 at 18 h (late S phase) (Fig. 3D) did not arrest the cells in the G2/M phase as indicated by the approximate doubling of viable cell counts. Fragmented DNA was not detected 6 h later when the cells were harvested (Fig. 3J). Again, the population of cells in G1 in Fig. 3D represents those cells that did not recover from CSF-1 starvation and were not able to enter the cell cycle. Finally, the addition of ET-18-OCH3 to an asynchronous population of cells for 24 h showed the accumulation of fragmented DNA and cells arrested in both Gt and G2/M phases (Fig. 3L). These data suggest the working hypothesis that ET-18-OCH3 inhibits cell cycle progression in the gap phases. Furthermore, the longer the exposure to ET-18-OCH3 the greater the accumulation of fragmented DNA, regardless of whether the cells accumulated in the Gx or G2 phase. These data also indicated that the cytotoxic action of ET-18-OCH3 was associated with apoptosis. The acylation of LPC to form PtdCho is a mechanism for the synthesis of PtdCho that circumvents a requirement for the CDP-choline pathway. We reasoned that if a block in PtdCho synthesis was responsible for the cytotoxic effects of ET-18-OCH3, then the addition of LPC might enable the cells to overcome ET-18-OCH3 inhibition of membrane synthesis during the cell cycle and perhaps the associated DNA fragmentation and cell death. We first determined whether LPC addition affected the accumulation of cells in the G2 phase when ET-18-OCH3 was added at 10 h at the Gt/S boundary (Fig. 4). These data clearly demonstrate that the presence of LPC allowed the cells to overcome the ET-18-OCH3-dependent accumulation of 4 N cells and prevented the accumulation of fragmented DNA (less than 2 N DNA content) (Fig. 4). LPC did not relieve the ET-18-OCH3 inhibition of the CDP-choline pathway for membrane PtdCho synthesis (Fig. 1A) but rather was incorporated into the membrane phospholipid fraction and rapidly acylated to yield PtdCho (38Boggs K.P. Rock C.O. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7757-7764Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar), thus providing an alternate route for PtdCho production and maintenance of membrane mass. These experiments suggested that inhibition of membrane PtdCho synthesis contributed to the inhibition of cell growth and the induction of apoptosis. We next tested whether the addition of LPC could overcome the ET-18-OCH3 block in the G1 phase. Cells were synchronized, CSF-1 with or without LPC was added along with the indicated concentration of ET-18-OCH3, and the ability of the cells to incorporate [3H]thymidine was measured (Fig. 5). LPC did not alter the pattern of ET-18-OCH3 inhibition of [3H]thymidine incorporation, demonstrating that LPC did not allow the cells to overcome the block in the G± phase. However, flow cytofluorometry of cells treated for 24 h in the presence of ET-18-OCH3 plus LPC revealed that LPC prevented ET-18-OCH3-dependent DNA fragmentation (data not shown and Fig. 4). These data suggested that, although BAC1.2F5 cells would not divide and proliferate in the presence of ET-18-OCH3, the addition of LPC would protect the cells from the cytotoxic effects of the drug, and they would remain viable. To test this idea, we performed a series of long term growth experiments to provide additional information on how LPC modulates the effects of ET-18-OCH3. Exponentially growing cells were treated on day 2 with 4 μΜ ET-18-OCH3 either in the presence or absence of 50 μΜ LPC, and the viable cell number was measured over the next 3 days (Fig. 6). Cells treated with ET-18-OCH3 alone quickly lost viability. LPC had little effect on the growth of control cells but prevented the ET-18-OCH3-treated cells from dying. These data are consistent with the previous experiments where LPC was shown to override G2/M inhibition and prevent the accumulation of fragmented DNA (Fig. 4); but the LPC was unable to overcome the G1 block (Fig. 5), and the cells remained in growth stasis. The exposure of BAC1.2F5 cells to ET-18-OCH3 resulted in progressive morphological changes characteristic of apoptosis (Fig. 7, B and C). The first noticeable change in the cell population was the appearance of cells with condensed and fragmented nuclei (Fig. IB). This was followed by the accumulation of enucleated “ghosts,” which contained only scattered remnants of condensed nuclei (Fig. 7C). These morphological changes were consistent with ET-18-OCH, triggering apoptosis in BAC1.2F5 cells and were consistent with the findings made in other cell lines (27Downing J.R. Margolis B.L. Zilberstein A. Ashmun R.A. Ullrich A. Sherr C.J. Schlessinger J. EMBO J. 1989; 8: 3345-3350Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 28Whetton A.D. Monk P.N. Consalvey S.D. Downes C.P. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 3281-3286Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Another important result from microscopic examination of ET-18-OCH3-treated cells inhibited in progression through the G2/M phase (Fig. 7B) was the presence of an intact nuclear membrane and the absence of mitotic figures in those cells that did not yet show evidence of apoptosis, consistent with accumulation in the G2 rather than the M phase. BAC1.2F5 cells treated with ET-18-OCH3 plus LPC were not morphologically distinguishable from control cells (Fig. 7, compare A and D) indicating that LPC abrogated the cytotoxicity of ET-18-OCH3 (Fig. 6) by preventing programmed cell death. Our data are consistent with the inhibition of membrane PtdCho synthesis, accounting for the cytotoxic but not the cytostatic activity of ET-18-OCH3. Earlier research established that ET-18-OCH., blocks PtdCho synthesis (29Hamilton J.A. Veis N. Bordun A.M. Vairo G. Gonda T.J. Phillips W.A. J. Cell. Physiol. 1989; 141: 618-626Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 30Imamura K. Dianoux A. Nakamura T. Kufe D. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 2423-2429Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 31Mollinedo F. Martinez-Dalmau R. Modolell M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1993; 192: 603-609Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar, 32Diomede L. Colotta F. Piovani B. Re F. Modest E.J. Samona M. Int. J. Cancer. 1993; 53: 124-130Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 33Modolell M. Andreesen R. Pahlke W. Brugger U. Munder P.G. Cancer Res. 1979; 39: 4681-4686PubMed Google Scholar) and ET-18-OCH3 also halts PtdCho and total phospholipid synthesis in the BAC1.2F5 cell line (Fig. 1). The significance of these observations of the action of the drug was not clear previously, because ET-18-OCH3 also inhibits other key enzymes, such as protein kinase C and phospholipase C (13Daniel L.W. Hickman J.A. Tritton T.R. Cancer Chemotherapy. Blackwell Scientific Publications Ltd, Oxford1993: 146-178Google Scholar, 19Parker J. Daniel L.W. Waite M. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 5385-5393Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Salari H. Dryden P. Davenport R. Howard S. Kones K. Bittman R. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1134: 81-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 21Heesbeen E.C. Verdonck L.F. Haagmans M. van Heugten H.G. Staal G.E.J. Ruksen G. Leuk. Res. 1993; 17: 143-148Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar, 22Daniel L.W. Etkin L.A. Morrison B.T. Parker J. Morris-Natschke S. Surles J.R. Piantadosi C. Lipids. 1987; 22: 851-855Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). However, providing an exogenous source of PtdCho by adding LPC to the medium prevents ET-18-OCH3-dependent accumulation of cells in the G2 phase as well as the onset of apoptosis (FIG. 4, FIG. 6), thereby supporting the conclusion that the inhibition of de novo PtdCho synthesis is a determining factor in the cytotoxic action of ET-18-OCH3. However, the biochemical target for ET-18-OCH3 inhibition of cell growth in G1 remains to be resolved. The presence of LPC does not shift the dose-response curve for ET-18-OCH3 (Fig. 5), indicating that LPC does not act by preventing the accumulation of ET-18-OCH3 by the cells. CSF-1 triggers rapid and sustained degradation of PtdCho throughout the G1 phase (46Esko J.D. Nishijima M. Raetz C.R.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1982; 79: 1698-1702Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). PtdCho degradation is implicated as an important component of the signal transduction pathway based on the finding that degradation of PtdCho by exogenous PtdCho-specific phospholipase C mimics the mitogenic action of CSF-1 (23Xu X.X. Tessner T.G. Rock C.O. Jackowski S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1522-1533Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase may also be an ET-18-OCH3 target in the G1 phase if the inhibition of PtdCho resynthesis interrupts the PtdCho turnover cycle and prevents signal transduction through PtdCho-specific phospholipase C. Other enzymes that interact with lysophospholipid substrates, like the 85-kDa phospholipase A2 (for review see Ref. 54Leslie C.C. Adi;. Mol. Cell Biol. 1995; (in press)Google Scholar), should also be considered as potential ET-18-OCH3 targets. Our results suggest that other members of the cytotoxic ether-linked phospholipid family also inhibit PtdCho synthesis and function by inhibiting the progression of cells through the gap phases and triggering apoptosis. Other biologically active ether lipids such as BM41.440 and hexadecylphosphocholine have a high degree of structural similarity to ET-18-OCH3 (for review see Ref. 13Daniel L.W. Hickman J.A. Tritton T.R. Cancer Chemotherapy. Blackwell Scientific Publications Ltd, Oxford1993: 146-178Google Scholar). Hexadecylphosphocholine blocks choline incorporation into PtdCho (55Geilen C.C. Wieder T. Reutter W. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 267: 6719-6724Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar, 56Geilen C.C. Wieder T. Haase A. Reutter W. Morré D.M. Morré D.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1211: 14-22Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar, 57Wieder T. Geilen C.C. Reutter W. Biochem. J. 1993; 291: 561-567Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar), and CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase is implicated as the target based on the partial inhibition of CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase activity in crude cell extracts (58Haase R. Wieder T. Geilen C.C. Reutter W. FEBS Lett. 1991; 288: 129-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). BM41.440 arrests CA46 cells in the G2 phase of the cell cycle (59Hofmann J. O'Connor P.M. Jackman J. Schubert C. Ueberall F. Kohn K.W. Grunicke H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 199: 937-943Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), thus mimicking our findings with ET-18-OCH3 (Fig. 2). It will be important to determine whether LPC also overrides the cytotoxic effects of these drugs. Our results also suggest that membrane phospholipid content may be monitored by the mammalian cell cycle apparatus. The arrest of BAC1.2F5 cells in the G2 phase when phospholipid accumulation is blocked during the S phase is reminiscent of the response of cells to S phase DNA damage. Cells irradiated in the S phase delay in G2 to allow DNA repair before the cells commit to mitosis (60O'Conner P.M. Kohn K.W. Semin. Cancer Biol. 1992; 3: 409-416PubMed Google Scholar). By analogy, the G2 arrest of cells with insufficient phospholipid would provide a mechanism to ensure complete membrane formation prior to cell division. Hartwell and Weinert (61Hartwell L.H. Weinert T.A. Science. 1989; 246: 629-634Crossref PubMed Scopus (2431) Google Scholar) coined the term “checkpoint” to define the process in G2 that monitors completion of DNA replication and DNA damage before allowing progression into the M phase. Research on the biochemical mechanism for G2 arrest in response to DNA damage has focused on the regulation of the cyclin B/cdc2 kinase complex, because the formation and activation of this complex are necessary for entry into the M phase (61Hartwell L.H. Weinert T.A. Science. 1989; 246: 629-634Crossref PubMed Scopus (2431) Google Scholar, 62Lock R.B. Ross W.E. Cancer Res. 1990; 50: 3761-3766PubMed Google Scholar, 63Lock R.B. Ross W.E. Cancer Res. 1990; 50: 3767-3771PubMed Google Scholar, 64Muschel R.J. Zhang H.B. Iliakis G. McKenna W.G. Cancer Res. 1991; 51: 5113-5117PubMed Google Scholar, 65Lock R.B. Cancer Res. 1992; 52: 1817-1822PubMed Google Scholar, 66Tsao Y.-P. D'Arpa P. Liu L.F. Cancer Res. 1992; 52: 1823-1829PubMed Google Scholar, 67O'Conner P.M. Ferris D.K. White G.A. Pines J. Hunter T. Longo D.L. Kohn K.W. Cell Growth & Differ. 1993; 3: 43-52Google Scholar, 68O'Conner P.M. Ferris D.K. Pagano M. Draetta G. Pines J. Hunter T. Longo D.L. Kohn K.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8298-8308Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Cells delayed in G2 accumulate the hyper-phosphorylated, inactive form of the cdc2 kinase subunit. ET-18-OCH3 and other cytotoxic ether lipids may not arrest cells by exactly the same mechanism, because they do not directly damage DNA (11Berdel W.E. Br. J. Cancer. 1991; 64: 208-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 13Daniel L.W. Hickman J.A. Tritton T.R. Cancer Chemotherapy. Blackwell Scientific Publications Ltd, Oxford1993: 146-178Google Scholar). A unique biochemical mechanism for G2 arrest by antineoplastic lipids is suggested by the finding that, in cells arrested in the G2 phase with BM41.440, the cdc2 kinase is dephosphorylated; however, cyclin B protein levels are significantly reduced (59Hofmann J. O'Connor P.M. Jackman J. Schubert C. Ueberall F. Kohn K.W. Grunicke H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 199: 937-943Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Additional experiments are needed to determine if the regulation of cyclin B levels is a direct or indirect consequence of the inhibition of PtdCho synthesis. We thank Robyn Roberts, Huong Nguyen, and Margarita Pecha for expert technical assistance. We also thank Richard Ashmun for the flow cytofluorometry analysis.

The rate of RNA elongation by RNA polymerase II (pol II) is affected by DNA sequences called intrinsic arrest sites. Efficient transcription through these sites requires elongation factor SIL In addition to the sequence-specific features of the DNA, we show that the acquisition of SII-dependence is a function of its “dwell-time” at an arrest site. This temperature-dependent decay in elongation potential appears irreversible, implying that factor-dependent and factor-independent elongation complexes are not mutually interconvertible at this position. TFIIF and NH4C1 are known to increase the elongation rate of pol II. Both agents preempt arrest, consistent with the idea that elongation dwell time influences the process. TFIIF and SII act upon different steps in a complementary way to prevent or resolve arrest, respectively. They are probably instrumental in facilitating the efficient transcription of large eukaryotic genes in vivo. The rate of RNA elongation by RNA polymerase II (pol II) is affected by DNA sequences called intrinsic arrest sites. Efficient transcription through these sites requires elongation factor SIL In addition to the sequence-specific features of the DNA, we show that the acquisition of SII-dependence is a function of its “dwell-time” at an arrest site. This temperature-dependent decay in elongation potential appears irreversible, implying that factor-dependent and factor-independent elongation complexes are not mutually interconvertible at this position. TFIIF and NH4C1 are known to increase the elongation rate of pol II. Both agents preempt arrest, consistent with the idea that elongation dwell time influences the process. TFIIF and SII act upon different steps in a complementary way to prevent or resolve arrest, respectively. They are probably instrumental in facilitating the efficient transcription of large eukaryotic genes in vivo. RNA polymerases are processive enzymes. In general, they cannot extend pre-existing RNA chains, hence RNA release from the template is a terminal event in RNA synthesis (reviewed in Kane, 1994Kane C.M. Conaway R.C. Conaway J.W. Transcription Mechanisms and Regulation. Raven Press, New York1994: 279-296Google Scholar). It is especially detrimental for RNA polymerase II (pol II) 1The abbreviation used is: pol IIRNA polymerase II to terminate prematurely since it transcribes the longest nuclear transcription units, some of which can exceed millions of base pairs. Furthermore, chain elongation is a regulated process that controls gene expression (Kane, 1994Kane C.M. Conaway R.C. Conaway J.W. Transcription Mechanisms and Regulation. Raven Press, New York1994: 279-296Google Scholar) and embryonic development (Thummel, 1992Thummel C.S. Science. 1992; 255: 39-40Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). In vivo, processing of the primary transcript for polyadenylation is coupled to termination by pol II (Logan et al., 1987Logan J. Falck-Pederson E. Darnell J.E. Shenk T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8306-8310Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar; Connelly and Manley, 1988Connelly S. Manley J.L. Genes & Dev. 1988; 2: 440-452Crossref PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar). Thus, pol II has evolved to be extremely processive once it becomes template engaged, and a specialized release signal is required for termination. RNA polymerase II At specific sites within genes, pol II becomes unable to continue chain elongation but does not release its nascent RNA. This loss of elongation competence is referred to as arrest, the molecular mechanism of which is poorly understood. Some arrest sequences are coincident with a bend in the DNA (Kerppola and Kane, 1990Kerppola T.K. Kane C.M. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 269-278Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Template sequence and structure is an important component of the arrest signal since randomly halting transcription by nucleotide starvation does not typically result in arrest. Arrested complexes are not inactive; they resume transcription through the action of elongation factor SII (also known as TFIIS). SII, a pol II-binding protein, associates with the elongation complex and activates nascent RNA cleavage (Reines, 1992Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3795-3800Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Izban and Luse, 1992bIzban M.G. Luse D.S. Genes & Dev. 1992; 6: 1342-1356Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar; Wang and Hawley, 1993Wang D. Hawley D.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 843-847Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar; reviewed in Reines, 1994Reines D. Conaway R. Conaway J. Transcription. Raven Press, New York1994: 263-278Google Scholar). Transcript shortening precedes, and appears required for, SII-mediated readthrough (Reines et al., 1992Reines D. Ghanouni P. Li Q-q. Mote J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 15516-15522Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Izban and Luse, 1992bIzban M.G. Luse D.S. Genes & Dev. 1992; 6: 1342-1356Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). Multiple rounds of nascent RNA cleavage and re-extension are required to achieve full readthrough (Gu et al., 1993Gu W. Powell W. Mote Jr., J. Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25604-25616Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Guo and Price, 1993Guo H. Price D.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 18762-18770Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Although the exact means by which arrested complexes are reactivated are not understood, recent models postulate that cleavage restores the proximity of the enzyme’s catalytic site to the 3′-end of the nascent RNA, the topology of which is altered during arrest (Chamberlin, 1994Chamberlin M.J. The acquisition of factor dependence is a first-order decay of the elongation potential of pol II that is temperature dependent and irreversible in the absence of RNA cleavage. We have analyzed the effect of NH4Cl and elongation factor TFIIF, which are known to reduce the average time pol II spends between nucleotide incorporation events, on the arrest process. Although mechanistically distinct, SII and TFIIF probably cooperate in enabling pol II to transcribe lengthy eukaryotic genes. For 3′-end labeling of the RNA and walking experiments complexes were washed three times by microcentrifugation and resuspension in reaction buffer (60 mm KCl, 20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.9, 2 mm dithiothreitol, 3mm HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.9, 0.5 mm EDTA, 0.2 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, 2.2% (w/v) polyvinyl alcohol, 3% (v/v) glycerol). Rat liver SII (phosphocellulose) was added, and the reaction was incubated at 28 °C for 1.5 min in the presence of 7 mM MgCl2 for nascent RNA cleavage. After two washings, RNA was labeled with 20 μCi of [α-32P]CTP (3000 Ci/mmol), 400 μΜ GTP (unless otherwise indicated) and 7 mm MgCl2 at 28 °C for 10 min. These complexes were washed again and manipulated as described in the text. RNA was prepared for electrophoresis and separated on 5% Polyacrylamide gels as described (Reines, 1992Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3795-3800Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). For quantitation, gels were analyzed using a Molecular Dynamics PhosphorImager. To examine the arrest process under conditions that allow us to control elongation, we employed RNA polymerase “walking” experiments. Elongation is restricted by providing a limited subset of the four nucleoside triphosphates (NTPs), removing them, and repeating the process with the next appropriate NTP(s) to assemble elongation complexes bearing sequentially larger RNA chains. Similar approaches have been exploited effectively in the study of bacterial and viral RNA polymerase elongation and termination (Carpousis and Gralla, 1985Carpousis A.J. Gralla J.D. J. Mol. Upon encounter with a well-characterized site called Ia, pol II becomes arrested with ≍50% efficiency at positions +205, 206, and 207 relative to the transcription start site (+1) (Gu et al., 1993Gu W. Powell W. Mote Jr., J. Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25604-25616Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. In the presence of SII, pol II quantitatively resumes elongation from this site after the arrested RNA is shortened at its 3′-end and re-extended (Reines et al., 1989Reines D. Chamberlin M.J. Kane C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 10799-10809Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Arrested complexes were precipitated with a monoclonal antibody against RNA and washed free of NTPs (Reines, 1992Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3795-3800Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). After the addition of MgCl2 and SII, the nascent transcripts (205–207 nt) were cleaved to a specific 198-nucleotide transcript terminating in an A residue (Fig. 1, lane 2 versus lane 3; Gu et al., 1993Gu W. Powell W. Mote Jr., J. Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25604-25616Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. We refer to this as an A198 complex using the conventional notation citing the identity of the last base and its position in the RNA chain. Unlabeled A198-RNA was extended and uniquely labeled at position 199 with [α-32P]CTP (C199; Fig. 1, lane 4). This RNA could be extended by a single base when GTP was added (G200; lane 5). Addition of varying concentrations of UTP to G200 complexes after removal of CTP and GTP by another round of washing resulted in extension of the chain by an additional 1–7 bases through a tract of seven template A residues (U201-U207 lanes 6–11). Complexes A198 through U204 were stable and each remained elongation competent, i.e. they did not require SII for the resumption of elongation when UTP was restored (Fig. 2, lane 1 versus lane 8, lane 2 versus lane 3, lane 4 versus lane 5, and lane 6 versus lane 7). Since CTP (required at position 208) was not added during this chase period, RNAs were extended no further than position 207 (Ia; Fig. 2, lanes 3, 5, 7, and 8). If CTP was supplied at the same time as UTP, half of these complexes readthrough site Ia in a factor-independent manner and stop at position 216 due to the lack of GTP (Fig. 3A, lane 6). This confirmed prior work demonstrating that the readthrough efficiency in the absence of SII is ≍50% for both the first and second encounter of pol II with site Ia (Fig. LA, lane 1 and Fig. 3B, lane 1; Gu et al., 1993Gu W. Powell W. Mote Jr., J. Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25604-25616Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. The complexes arrested at site Ia can be quantitatively chased to runoff length by the addition of SII (Gu et al., 1993Gu W. Powell W. Mote Jr., J. Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25604-25616Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Hence, two types of complexes bearing a 207-base transcript can be identified after transcript cleavage and walk-back; one group that can extend the 207-base RNA when CTP is present (U216; Fig. 3A, lane 6), and another that requires CTP and the assistance of SII (Ia; Fig. 3A, lane 6). We will show below that this former class can be converted rapidly into the latter class. If G200 complexes were incubated with UTP but not CTP, all RNA chains could be extended back to the arrest site (Fig. 3A, lane 4) but none could respond to CTP added at a later time (Fig. 3A, lane 5), i.e. they had all become arrested. This suggested that poor availability of the next nucleotide could convert complexes that were elongation competent into an SII-dependent form as reported for a viral arrest site (Wiest and Hawley, 1990Wiest D.K. Hawley D.K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 5782-5792Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar; Wiest et al., 1992Wiest D.K. Wang D. Hawley D.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 7733-7744Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. This was only the case for complexes walked downstream to the arrest site since upstream complexes (A198 to U204) did not display the arrest phenotype when their next nucleotide was absent (Fig. 2, Fig. 3). These results indicated that we were observing pol II molecules in the process of becoming arrested and that we should be able to track the time course of this event. A simple way to alter the complex’s dwell time at the arrest site was to limit the concentration of the next nucleotide. Indeed, there was a clear relationship between the CTP concentration and transcription through site Ia (Fig. 3B, lanes 3–7). Readthrough was half-maximal at ≍160 μΜ CTP and reached a plateau at 800 μΜ CTP (lower curve, Fig. 4). Complexes that were unable to pass site Ia at low CTP (Fig. 3B, lane 4) were refractory to a high CTP chase (Fig. 3B, lane 8) showing that they had become arrested. This suggested that the length of time pol II spent between incorporation events or its “dwell” time (von Hippel and Yager, 1991von Hippel P.H. Yager T.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 2307-2311Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar) was a critical factor in attaining the arrested phenotype. The time course of acquisition of the arrested phenotype was measured by providing UTP to the G200 complex for varying lengths of time and testing for elongation competence with a challenge of 800 μΜ CTP. Pol II progressively lost its ability to escape from site Ia as the time interval between UTP addition and CTP addition increased (Fig. 5A, diamond symbols). This decay was rapid and essentially complete by 5 s at 28 °C. We repeated this experiment at 15 °C to facilitate a more accurate measurement of the decay and to assess its temperature dependence. A similar profile was observed showing a longer half-life (120 s; Fig. 5, A and B) at 15 °C. The data can be plotted as a first-order process with an apparent rate constant of 0.008 s−1 (Fig. 5A, inset). This measurement includes the time pol II takes to reach Ia from G200 as well as that required to assume the arrested phenotype or achieve readthrough to position 216. An independent measurement revealed that half of the G200 complexes extended their chains to position 207 in 75 s.2 Hence, the decay in elongation potential displayed a half-life of approximately 50 s at 15 °C which was at least 10-fold slower than that observed at 28 °C. Note that maximal readthrough efficiency varied as a function of temperature (Fig. 5A, t = 0: 44% at 15 °C versus 57% at 28 °C). This demonstrated that the relative partitioning of Ia complexes between the alternatives of chain extension and arrest was temperature-dependent. To strengthen the argument that dwell time at site Ia is a determinant of arrest, we measured the effect of TFIIF and NH4C1 on readthrough at different CTP concentrations. Consistent with this idea, both agents increased the efficiency of readthrough at low CTP levels in the absence of added SII (Fig. 4, upper versus lower curve and Fig. 6, lane 5 versus 6). The maximal extent of readthrough at saturating CTP (800 μΜ) was also higher in the presence of either NH4C1 (Fig. 4, upper versus lower curves) or TFIIF (Fig. 6, lane 3 versus lane 4). Neither NH4Cl2 nor TFIIF (Fig. 6, lane 1 versus lane 2) rescued pol II after it had become arrested, in accordance with the work of others (Bengal et al., 1991Bengal E. Flores O. Krauskopf A. We take this as additional evidence that the longer pol II dwells at an arrest site the more likely it is to assume the arrested configuration. RNA polymerases located at a single template position can assume more than one state due to the partitioning of complexes between different functional pathways (Yager and von Hippel, 1991Yager T.D. von Hippel P.H. The pathway choice can be influenced by transcription elongation or termination factors and is an important point of regulatory control in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes (Roberts, 1992Roberts J. McKnight S.L. Yamamoto K.R. Transcriptional Regulation. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1992: 389-406Google Scholar; Kane, 1994Kane C.M. Conaway R.C. Conaway J.W. Transcription Mechanisms and Regulation. Raven Press, New York1994: 297-321Google Scholar; Chamberlin, 1994Chamberlin M.J. Harvey Lect. 1994; 88: 1-21Google Scholar). The options for an elongation complex include: 1) insert the next nucleotide, 2) terminate transcription via RNA release, or 3) cease elongation without RNA release. The length of time at which RNA polymerases dwell at a specific template position contributes to the efficiency of termination by E. coli RNA polymerase (reviewed in von Hippel and Yager, 1991von Hippel P.H. Yager T.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 2307-2311Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar; Roberts, 1992Roberts J. McKnight S.L. Yamamoto K.R. Transcriptional Regulation. Raven Press, New York1994: 297-321Google Scholar; Chamberlin, 1994Chamberlin M.J. Harvey Lect. 1994; 88: 1-21Google Scholar) and arrest by pol II (Wiest and Hawley, 1990Wiest D.K. Hawley D.K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 5782-5792Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar; Wiest et al., 1992Wiest D.K. Wang D. Hawley D.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 7733-7744Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Dwell time can be modulated by template sequence, auxiliary transcription factors, availability of nucleotide substrates, the structure of nascent RNA, translation (in prokaryotes), and perhaps co-transcriptional processing of the primary transcript in eukaryotes. The influence of substrate availability on elongation by pol II was elucidated by experiments where the dependence of arrest was altered from GTP to CTP or UTP when the template base downstream from an arrest site was mutated from C to G or A, respectively (Wiest et al., 1992Wiest D.K. Wang D. Hawley D.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 7733-7744Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Here, we have observed and measured the rate at which RNA polymerase II assumes the arrested conformation. Arrest efficiency is determined in part by a kinetic competition between the rate at which pol II incorporates the next nucleotide and the rate at which its elongation potential decays. Partitioning is temperature dependent with more arrest at lower temperature. This is congruent with observations that the extent of DNA bending is accentuated at lower temperature (Marini et al., 1984Marini J. Effron P. Goodman T. Singleton C. Wells R. Wartell R. Englund P. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 8974-8979Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Griffith et al., 1986Griffith J. Bleyman M. Rauch C. Kitchin P. Englund P. Cell. 1986; 46: 717-724Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar and supports the idea that a bend in this template is causally involved in arrest (Kerppola and Kane, 1990Kerppola T.K. Kane C.M. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 269-278Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar; Reines, 1992Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3795-3800Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Elongation complexes at most template positions cannot be forced into an SII-dependent form since pol II held at a variety of template positions by nucleotide starvation or lac repressor remains elongation competent even after dwell times of >1 h (Reines and Mote, 1993Reines D. Mote Jr., J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 1917-1921Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). The arrest pathway is apparently a site-specific option for pol II, i.e. there is a thermodynamic “well” found at intrinsic arrest sites. If so, the absence of arrest at most template locations is not necessarily due to kinetic escape via rapid insertion of the next base which outcompetes a pathway to arrest. Instead, there may not be an accessible arrest conformation for pol II under these conditions. Similar conclusions have been drawn for termination by E. coli RNA polymerase (von Hippel and Yager, 1992von Hippel P.H. Yager T.D. Science. 1992; 255: 809-812Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Termination by E. coli RNA polymerase and RNA polymerase I has been described as a two-step process, a slowed rate of next-nucleotide insertion and a template location where elongation capacity can be lost (Yager and von Hippel, 1987Yager T.D. von Hippel P.H. Neidhart F. Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium: Cellular and Molecular Biology. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1987: 1241-1270Google Scholar; McDowell et al., 1994McDowell J.C. Roberts J.W. Jin D.J. Gross C. Science. 1994; 266: 822-825Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar; Lang et al., 1994Lang W.H. Morrow B.E. Ju Q. Warner J.R. Reeder R.H. Cell. 1994; 79: 527-534Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar. The efficiency of pol II arrest seems to involve similar steps. The features that determine these requirements are not known but may be related to the number of template A residues that encode the U-rich 3′ termini characteristic of many arrested RNAs (Izban and Luse, 1993bIzban M.G. Luse D.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12874-12885Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and a bend in or near the arrest site (Kerppola and Kane, 1990Kerppola T.K. Kane C.M. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 269-278Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). A U-rich RNA terminus and/or the unusual structure of the DNA helix at this site or in the transcription bubble could serve to both reduce polymerization step time and potentiate the rapid decay in elongation potential identified here. Additional signals or factors may be needed for pol II to terminate transcription perhaps in conjunction with processing events such as polyadenylation (Logan et al., 1987Logan J. Falck-Pederson E. Darnell J.E. Shenk T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8306-8310Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar; Connelly and Manley, 1988Connelly S. Manley J.L. Genes & Dev. 1988; 2: 440-452Crossref PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar). In the absence of NTPs, factor-dependent and factor-independent complexes carry out SII-activated nascent RNA cleavage. Dinucleotides or 7–14 base oligonucleotides are liberated from SII-independent and SII-dependent complexes, respectively (Izban and Luse, 1993aIzban M.G. Luse D.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12864-12873Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, Izban and Luse, 1993bIzban M.G. Luse D.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12874-12885Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Luse and co-workers have suggested that this difference in cleavage increment is indicative of a structural distinction between the two states. The difference between SII-dependent and independent elongation complexes may be the loss of proximity of the polymerization catalytic site relative to the 3′-end of the RNA (Izban and Luse, 1993bIzban M.G. Luse D.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12874-12885Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Borukhov et al., 1993Borukhov S. Sagitov V. Goldfarb A. Cell. 1993; 72: 459-466Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar; Chamberlin, 1994Chamberlin M.J. Harvey Lect. 1994; 88: 1-21Google Scholar). The decay of elongation competence measured here may reflect in part the rate of this presumptive conformational change. A covalent modification of one or more components of the elongation complex cannot be ruled out, although any such modification is not expected to involve the carboxyl-terminal domain of pol II which does not affect arrest or SII-activated readthrough in vitro (Christie et al., 1994Christie K.R. Awrey D.E. Edwards A.M. Kane C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 936-943Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Exonuclease III footprinting reveals a subtle, 1 base pair downstream movement of the arrested complex after nascent RNA cleavage (Gu et al., 1993Gu W. Powell W. Mote Jr., J. Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25604-25616Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. There is a large difference between SII-dependent and independent complexes with respect to the position of the RNA 3′-end relative to the downstream boundary (Gu et al., 1993Gu W. Powell W. Mote Jr., J. Reines D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25604-25616Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Arrested complexes have 3′-ends which lie closer to the leading edge than do factor-independent complexes. Similar structural differences have been observed between elongation-competent and arrested E. coli RNA polymerases (Krummel and Chamberlin, 1992bKrummel B. Chamberlin M.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 225: 239-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar; Borukhov et al., 1993Borukhov S. Sagitov V. Goldfarb A. Cell. 1993; 72: 459-466Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar; Nudler et al., 1994Nudler E. Goldfarb A. Kashlev M. Science. 1994; 265: 793-796Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar. The defining features of arrest sites in general have not been thoroughly elucidated. The locations and frequencies of occurrence of such sites in bacterial or eukaryotic genomes are not known. It has been suggested that SII and TFIIF act by different means to influence elongation by pol II. TFIIF only affects readthrough if present before RNA polymerase encounters an arrest site, whereas SII is effective even after the encounter (Bengal et al., 1991Bengal E. Flores O. Krauskopf A. Reinberg D. Aloni Y. Mol. Cell Biol. 1991; 11: 1195-1206Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar; Izban and Luse, 1992aIzban M.G. Luse D.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 13647-13655Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). SII works via arrested RNA cleavage which resolves the fate of those enzymes that do succumb to arrest and can only take place after arrest (Reines, 1994Reines D. Conaway R. Conaway J. Transcription. Raven Press, New York1994: 263-278Google Scholar). Both TFIIF and NH4C1 enhance the ability of pol II to use a limiting level of NTPs (Fig. 4, Fig. 6) as has recently been described for a new elongation factor, SIII (Bradsher et al., 1993bBradsher J.N. Tan S. McLaury H.-J. Conaway J.W. Conaway R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25594-25603Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. The kinetic step accelerated by these agents is unknown. The ability of TFIIF (and NH4+ ions) to support high elongation rates and to reduce dwell time, is a possible explanation for how it reduces the probability that pol II will acquire factor dependence at an arrest site and why it is required before pol II arrives at an arrest site. We cannot exclude the possibility that these agents alter the configuration of the elongation complex such that it is less prone to arrest in a manner that is independent of dwell time. Two RNA polymerase-binding proteins, greA and greB, have been described that enable E. coli RNA polymerase to readthrough arrest sites (Borukhov et al., 1993Borukhov S. Sagitov V. Goldfarb A. Cell. 1993; 72: 459-466Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar; Nudler et al., 1994Nudler E. Goldfarb A. Kashlev M. Science. 1994; 265: 793-796Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar; Chamberlin, 1994Chamberlin M.J. Harvey Lect. 1994; 88: 1-21Google Scholar). Like TFIIF, greA must be present prior to arrest to enable readthrough while greB, like SII, can reactivate arrested complexes via RNA cleavage (Borukhov et al., 1993Borukhov S. Sagitov V. Goldfarb A. Cell. 1993; 72: 459-466Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar. Unlike greA, however, TFIIF has not yet been reported to activate nascent RNA cleavage. These and perhaps other factors (Bengal et al., 1991Bengal E. Flores O. Krauskopf A. Reinberg D. Aloni Y. Mol. Cell Biol. 1991; 11: 1195-1206Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar; Bradsher et al., 1993aBradsher J.N. Jackson K.W. Conaway R.C. Conaway J.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25587-25593Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, Bradsher et al., 1993bBradsher J.N. Tan S. McLaury H.-J. Conaway J.W. Conaway R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25594-25603Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar likely collaborate to minimize the possibility that RNA polymerases will become trapped on transcription units in the absence of physiological transcript release signals. PTP2C, an SH2 domain-containing protein-tyrosine phosphatase, is recruited to the growth factor receptors upon stimulation of cells. To investigate its role in growth factor signaling, we have overexpressed by approximately 6-fold the native PTP2C and a catalytically inactive mutant of the enzyme in 293 human embryonic kidney cells. The native PTP2C was located entirely in the cytosol, while the inactive mutant was nearly equally distributed in cytosolic and membrane fractions. Expression of the latter caused hyperphosphorylation on tyrosine of a 43-kDa protein, which was co-immunoprecipitated and co-partitioned in the plasma membrane fraction with the inactive PTP2C mutant. This protein may represent a physiological substrate of PTP2C. Overexpression of the native PTP2C enhanced epidermal growth factor (EGF)-stimulated mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase kinase activity by 30%, whereas expression of the inactive mutant reduced the stimulated activity by 50%. Similar effects were observed for the activation of MAP kinase as determined by activity assay, gel mobility shift, and tyrosine phosphorylation. The data suggest that the phosphatase activity of PTP2C is partly required for MAP kinase activation by EGF and that PTP2C may function by dephosphorylating the 43-kDa membrane protein. PTP2C, an SH2 domain-containing protein-tyrosine phosphatase, is recruited to the growth factor receptors upon stimulation of cells. To investigate its role in growth factor signaling, we have overexpressed by approximately 6-fold the native PTP2C and a catalytically inactive mutant of the enzyme in 293 human embryonic kidney cells. The native PTP2C was located entirely in the cytosol, while the inactive mutant was nearly equally distributed in cytosolic and membrane fractions. Expression of the latter caused hyperphosphorylation on tyrosine of a 43-kDa protein, which was co-immunoprecipitated and co-partitioned in the plasma membrane fraction with the inactive PTP2C mutant. This protein may represent a physiological substrate of PTP2C. Overexpression of the native PTP2C enhanced epidermal growth factor (EGF)-stimulated mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase kinase activity by 30%, whereas expression of the inactive mutant reduced the stimulated activity by 50%. Similar effects were observed for the activation of MAP kinase as determined by activity assay, gel mobility shift, and tyrosine phosphorylation. The data suggest that the phosphatase activity of PTP2C is partly required for MAP kinase activation by EGF and that PTP2C may function by dephosphorylating the 43-kDa membrane protein. INTRODUCTIONExternal signals, such as growth factors, initiate their signals by binding to ligand-specific growth factor receptors on the cellular membrane (1Ullrich A. Schlessinger J. Cell. 1990; 61: 203-212Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4581) Google Scholar). Receptor autophosphorylation on multiple tyrosyl residues, as a result of ligand binding, provides high-affinity binding sites for specific cellular proteins containing SH21 1The abbreviations used are: SH2src homology 2PTPprotein- tyrosine phosphataseMAP kinasemitogen-activated protein kinaseEGFepidermal growth factorPDGFplatelet-derived growth factorMBPmyelin basic proteinPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. domains. These SH2 domain-phosphopeptide interactions recruit other signaling molecules to the receptors where they can be phosphorylated by the receptors and/or recruit still other proteins (2Koch C.A. Anderson D. Moran M.F. Ellis C. Pawson T. Science. 1991; 252: 668-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (1429) Google Scholar). Among the SH2 domain-containing proteins recruited to the growth factor receptors is a protein-tyrosine phosphatase (PTP) designated as PTP2C (also termed as SH-PTP2, SH-PTP3, PTP1D, and Syp) (3Ahmad S. Banville D. Zhao Z. Fischer E.H. Shen S.-H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 2197-2201Crossref PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar, 4Freeman R.M. Plutzky J. Neel B.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 11239-11244Crossref PubMed Scopus (326) Google Scholar, 5Adachi M. Sekiya M. Miyachi T. Matsuno K. Hinoda Y. Imai K. Yachi A. FEBS Lett. 1992; 314: 335-339Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar, 6Vogel W. Lammers R. Huang J. Ullrich A. Science. 1993; 259: 1611-1614Crossref PubMed Scopus (490) Google Scholar, 7Feng G.-S. Hui C.-C. Pawson T. Science. 1993; 259: 1607-1611Crossref PubMed Scopus (583) Google Scholar). PTP2C is a widely expressed enzyme. It shares high homology with corkscrew, which is required for normal development of Drosophila by playing a positive role in the transduction of the torso signal acting in concert with D-Raf (8Perkins L.A. Larsen I. Perrimon N. Cell. 1992; 70: 225-236Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (329) Google Scholar). The parallel nature of the torso signal transduction pathway to MAP kinase activation in mammalian cells suggests that PTP2C may play a similar role in mammalian systems. Recent studies indeed suggest that PTP2C is involved in growth factor signaling and in MAP kinase activation. First, PTP2C binds to EGF and PDGF receptors (6Vogel W. Lammers R. Huang J. Ullrich A. Science. 1993; 259: 1611-1614Crossref PubMed Scopus (490) Google Scholar, 9Case R.D. Piccione E. Wolf G. Benett A.M. Lechleider R.J. Neel B.G. Shoelson S.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 11479-11481Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 279-283Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (540) Google Scholar, 19Marshall C.J. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1994; 4: 82-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (897) Google Scholar). GRB2, an SH2 and SH3 domain-containing protein, works as an adaptor by binding directly or indirectly via another protein such as SHC to upstream autophosphorylated growth factor receptors or their substrates and to downstream nucleotide exchange factor mSOS, thus activating Ras. GTP-bound Ras facilitates the recruitment of Raf-1 to the plasma membrane, resulting in its activation followed by activation of MAP kinase kinase. MAP kinase kinase, in turn, activates MAP kinase which requires phosphorylation on both tyrosine and threonine residues.To investigate the role of PTP2C in growth factor signaling, we have expressed the native PTP2C and a catalytic inactive form of the enzyme in 293 human embryonic kidney cells. Our study demonstrated that expression of the mutant of PTP2C had a profound impact on protein tyrosine phosphorylation in the cells. Furthermore, while overexpression of the native enzyme increased EGF-stimulated MAP kinase activation, expression of the catalytically inactive mutant decreased such activation.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESMaterialsHuman 293 cells were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection. Polyclonal anti-PTP2C (serum 1263) and anti-MAP kinase (serum 7884) were raised in rabbits against an SH2 domain-truncated form of PTP2C expressed in Escherichia coli (20Zhao Z. Larocque R. Ho W.T. Fischer E.H. Shen S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8780-8785Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and against a 22-amino acid peptide derived from the subdomain XI of MAP kinase (21Seger R. Seger D. Reszka A.A. Munar E.S. Eldar-Finkelman H. Dobrowolska G. Jensen A.M. Campbell J.S. Fischer E.H. Krebs E.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 25699-25709Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), respectively. Monoclonal ribophorin II antibody S.D.1 was kindly provided by Dr. David Meyer (UCLA). Epidermal growth factor (EGF) and monoclonal anti-phosphotyrosine and polyclonal sheep-anti-EGF receptor antibodies were purchased from Upstate Biotechnology Inc. Myelin basic protein (MBP) and [γ-32P]ATP were purchased from Sigma and Amersham, respectively.Buffer A: 50 mMβ-glycerophosphate (pH 7.3) and 2 mM EDTA. Buffer B: 25 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 100 mM NaCl, 50 mM KCl, and 1.5 mM MgCl2. Both buffers were also supplemented with 5 mMβ-mercaptoethanol, 1 mM EGTA, 0.2 mM Na3VO4, 0.1 μM microcystin, 1.0 mM benzamidine, 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 20 μg/ml leupeptin, 1 μM pepstatin A, and 1 μg/ml aprotinin.Construction and Expression of PTP2C in 293 CellsA catalytically inactive form of PTP2C, designated as PTP2C(C-S), was generated by substituting the highly conserved cysteine 459 with a serine in a polymerase chain reaction. The site of mutation was confirmed by DNA sequencing. The cDNA inserts corresponding to the native and the Cys-to-Ser mutant were constructed into the pRC/CMV vector (Invitrogen). Transfection was carried out according to the standard calcium phosphate co-precipitation technique. To obtain stable cell lines, cells were selected in medium containing 0.5 mg/ml geniticin (G418 sulfate, Life Technologies, Inc.), and single colonies expressing high level PTP2C or PTP2C(C-S) were obtained after 2-3 weeks. Wild type 293 cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, 50 μg/ml streptomycin, and 50 units/ml penicillin. The transfected cells were grown in the same medium supplemented with 0.5 mg/ml G418.Immunoprecipitation, Western Blotting, and PTP AssayConfluent 293 cells were lysed in Buffer A supplemented with 1% Triton X-100 and 0.1 M NaCl. The extract was cleared by centrifugation at full speed in a microcentrifuge. For immunoprecipitation with anti-PTP2C antibody, the extracts were preincubated with 50 μl of a 50% slurry of protein A-Sepharose (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) for 2 h at 4°C. After a brief centrifugation, the supernatant was incubated with antibody prebound to protein A-Sepharose overnight. The beads were washed three times with the cold lysis buffer. For Western blot analyses, samples were separated by 10% SDS-PAGE and transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Millipore). The membranes were probed with various primary antibodies and detected using the ECL system with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies (Amersham) according to the manufacturer's protocol.For PTP activity assay, sodium vanadate was omitted from all the buffers used. Assays were performed with anti-PTP2C immunoprecipitates using 1 μM32P-labeled ENDpYINASL peptide (800 cpm/pmol) as the substrate at pH 5.0 as described (20Zhao Z. Larocque R. Ho W.T. Fischer E.H. Shen S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8780-8785Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22Daum G. Solca F. Diltz C.D. Zhao Z. Cool D.E. Fischer E.H. Anal. Biochem. 1993; 211: 50-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar).Fractionation of Cell ExtractsCells were collected, washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline, and suspended in Buffer B. Lysis was performed by nitrogen cavitation for 20 min at 350 p.s.i. Nuclear pellets were removed by centrifugation at 800 × g for 20 min. The postnuclear extract was further centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 45 min to give a clear cytosolic supernatant and a pelleted membrane fraction. The latter pellet, washed once with Buffer B and then dissolved in Buffer B supplemented with 1% Triton X-100, was referred to as the membrane extract. Further fractionation of the membrane fraction was performed by employing a 17.5% Percoll density gradient. The postnuclear extract (1 ml) was loaded on the top of a 9-ml Percoll suspension made in buffer B. Sedimentation was performed for 1 h at 18,000 rpm with a Beckman 50 Ti rotor. A total of 20 fractions were collected from bottom to top.Stimulation of Cells and Assays for MAP Kinase and MAP Kinase KinaseCells (80-90% confluency) were starved at 0% serum for 24 h and then stimulated with EGF for various periods of time. The reactions were stopped by washing with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline. Cells were then collected and lysed in Buffer A by brief sonication. The extracts were cleared by centrifugation at 100,000 × g for 25 min. For protein kinase activity assay, samples were passed through a DEAE 52 minicolumn equilibrated with Buffer A. The column was washed with the same buffer and eluted with 0.3 M NaCl. The flow-through was collected for MAP kinase kinase assay and the elute for MAP kinase assay. The activity of MAP kinase kinase was determined by the ability of the enzyme to stimulate the MBP kinase activity of recombinant ERK2 in a coupled assay system as described (21Seger R. Seger D. Reszka A.A. Munar E.S. Eldar-Finkelman H. Dobrowolska G. Jensen A.M. Campbell J.S. Fischer E.H. Krebs E.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 25699-25709Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). MAP kinase was assayed with MBP as substrate in the presence of PKI peptide and calmidizolium (21Seger R. Seger D. Reszka A.A. Munar E.S. Eldar-Finkelman H. Dobrowolska G. Jensen A.M. Campbell J.S. Fischer E.H. Krebs E.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 25699-25709Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Blanks were run without ERK2 and MBP for MAP kinase and the kinase kinase assays, respectively.To immunoprecipitate ERK1 and ERK2 with anti-MAP kinase antibody, cell extracts were brought to 0.5% SDS and then boiled for 10 min. After cooling down, samples were diluted 5-fold with the extraction buffer and incubated with anti-MAP kinase serum 7884 overnight. The cell extracts and immunoprecipitates were separated on 10% SDS gel. Western blotting was carried out as described above.RESULTSOverexpression of PTP2C and PTP2C(C-S) in 293 CellsConstructs containing PTP2C or the mutant PTP2C(C-S) and the pRC/CMV vector alone were used to transfect 293 cells. Clonal cell lines were isolated by G418 selection. Most of the clones selected an overexpressed substantial level of exogenous PTP2C or PTP2C(C-S) as compared with the vector control and the parental cells. Typically, about 6-8-fold overexpression was obtained as determined by Western blot with anti-PTP2C serum (Fig. 1) followed by densitometric analyses. The activity of PTP2C in the transfected cells was measured following immunoprecipitation of the cell extract with anti-PTP2C serum. To precipitate approximately equal portions of enzyme, extracts from cells overexpressing PTP2C or PTP2C(C-S) were diluted 6-fold with the extraction buffer while that from the vector control cells was undiluted. Upon incubation of an equal volume of cell extracts with anti-PTP2C serum and protein A-Sepharose, each immunoprecipitate gave about an equal amount of anti-PTP2C cross-reactivity in Western blotting analyses (data not shown). PTP activity in the immunoprecipitates was then assayed by employing the 32P-labeled peptide substrate ENDpYINASL in a liquid-solid phase reaction mixture (Table I). As expected, nearly equal amounts of activity were detected in the immunoprecipitates from the control cells and cells over-expressing PTP2C, corresponding to an approximately 6.5-fold total increase of PTP2C activity in the transfected cells. This suggests that the exogenously expressed PTP2C possessed the same activity as the endogenous enzyme. In contrast, the activity per mg of cell extract from the cells overexpressing PTP2C(C-S) was similar to that obtained from the control cells, indicating that the Cys-to-Ser mutant of PTP2C is totally inactive. Control experiments with preimmune serum showed essentially no PTP activity (data not shown).Table IActivity of PTP2C in 293 cell extracts Open table in a new tab Effects of the Altered PTP2C Expression on the Tyrosine Phosphorylation of Proteins in 293 CellsProtein tyrosine phosphorylation was detected by Western blotting analyses employing anti-phosphotyrosine antibody as shown in Fig. 1. Overexpression of the native PTP2C showed essentially no effect on protein tyrosine phosphorylation at the basal level. No significant effect was observed in serum-stimulated cells either (data not shown). However, overexpression of PTP2C(C-S) resulted in changes of tyrosine phosphorylation of proteins in the cells. In particular, a protein of approximately 43 kDa (designated as p43) was hyperphosphorylated on tyrosine. This protein ran as a rather broad band on SDS gel, probably due to differing degrees of phosphorylation on multiple sites. Note that tyrosine phosphorylation of another protein of approximately 100 kDa slightly increased also. Stimulation of the cells with serum did not cause significant change in the tyrosine phosphorylation of these proteins (data not shown).Increased tyrosine phosphorylation of proteins caused by expression of the catalytically inactive mutant of PTP2C has also been observed by others. In one study, hyperphosphorylation of a 120-kDa protein which associated with PTP2C was observed in insulin-stimulated NIH 3T3 cells (14Milarski K.L. Saltiel A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 21239-21243Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In another study, increased tyrosine phosphorylation of the 125-kDa focal adhesion kinase was demonstrated in CHO cells, but the phosphorylation of this protein decreased upon insulin treatment of the cells (16Yamauchi K. Milarski K.L. Saltiel A.R. Pessin J.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 664-668Crossref PubMed Scopus (268) Google Scholar). It is not known whether the 43-kDa and 100-kDa proteins we observed are related to the 120-kDa protein and focal adhesion kinase.Co-fractionation and Co-immunoprecipitation of PTP2C(C-S) with p43Cytosolic and membrane fractions of postnuclear extracts were separated by high speed centrifugation. While almost all the PTP2C in the control cells and cells overexpressing the native PTP2C distributed in the cytosolic fraction, nearly 50% of the enzyme was associated with the membrane fraction in cells expressing PTP2C(C-S) (Fig. 2). PTP assays following immunoprecipitation of the membrane fraction with anti-PTP2C serum yielded essentially no activity, indicating that the anti-PTP2C cross-reactivity detected in the membrane fraction represents the mutant enzyme only. For all cases, almost no PTP2C was found in the nuclear fraction (data not shown). The hyperphosphorylated p43 was also found in the membrane fraction (Fig. 2). In addition, it was co-immunoprecipitated with PTP2C(C-S), which might indicate a direct association of these two proteins. Separation of the postnuclear extract from cells overexpressing PTP2C(C-S) on a Percoll density gradient was shown in Fig. 3. Nearly half of the anti-PTP2C cross-reactivity was detected on the top of the gradient (fractions 16-20), which presumably represent the cytosolic fraction. Most of the rest was found in the middle of the gradient (fractions 6-12) where p43 was also detected. The distribution pattern of p43 and associated PTP2C(C-S) followed that of the EGF receptor, a plasma membrane marker, but differed from that exhibited by the endoplasmic reticulum maker ribophorin II (23Crimaudo C.M. Hortsch H. Gausepohl H. Meyer D.I. EMBO J. 1987; 6: 75-82Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). The data indicate that PTP2C(C-S) and the hyperphosphorylated p43 were partitioned in the plasma membrane fraction. Based on the results, one can postulate that PTP2C(C-S) caused the hyperphosphorylation of p43 by preventing its dephosphorylation by the endogenous native enzyme and that tyrosine-phosphorylated p43, in turn, serves as an anchor for PTP2C(C-S) on the plasma membrane.Figure 2:Distribution of PTP2C, PTP2C(C-S), and the hyperphosphorylated p43 in cell fractions. The number for each fraction is indicated.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Effects of the Altered PTP2C Expression on MAP Kinase ActivationTo examine the role of PTP2C in the MAP kinase activation pathway, 293 cells with altered PTP2C expression were stimulated with EGF. Fig. 4 illustrates the time courses of MAP kinase and MAP kinase kinase activation. The activity profile of both kinases followed a typical biphasic pattern with peak activity occurring at 5 min. Altered PTP2C expression did not affect the time course of activation significantly. However, there was a small but significant impact on its magnitude. Overexpression of the native PTP2C increased the peak of EGF-stimulated MAP kinase kinase activity by about 30% while the expression of the catalytically inactive mutant decreased it by approximately 50% (Fig. 4A). Similar effects were observed for the activity of MAP kinase (Fig. 4B). These results were reproduced in other clonal cell lines selected.Figure 4:Activation of MAP kinase kinase (A) and MAP kinase (B) in 293 cells transfected with vector alone (■–■), PTP2C (▲- - -▲), and PTP2C(C-S) (●- - -●). Serum-starved cells were stimulated with 20 ng/ml EGF for the indicated time. MAP kinase activity was determined by incubating 5-μg samples with MBP and [γ-32P]ATP (1000 cpm/pmol) for 10 min. MAP kinase kinase was analyzed by incubating 2-μg samples with ERK2 and cold ATP for 10 min followed by the addition of MBP and 32P-labeled ATP and further incubating for 10 min. See “Experimental Procedures” for details.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)The effects of the altered PTP2C expression were also apparent in MAP kinase gel shift assays and Western blot analyzed with anti-phosphotyrosine (Fig. 5). Mobility shifts of MAP kinase (ERK1 and ERK2) on SDS-gel reflect the phosphorylations on the enzyme, which are required for its activation. As shown in Fig. 5A, 5- and 10-min stimulation of cells with EGF resulted in a significant portion of both ERK1 and ERK2 shifted in cells with the vector control and the native PTP2C, while much less was observed in the cells expressing the mutant PTP2C. Although the gel shifts were not perfectly correlated with the activity as has been reported (21Seger R. Seger D. Reszka A.A. Munar E.S. Eldar-Finkelman H. Dobrowolska G. Jensen A.M. Campbell J.S. Fischer E.H. Krebs E.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 25699-25709Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the data indicate that the decreased MAP kinase activity in cells with PTP2C(C-S) was due to reduced phosphorylation. Further supporting this were the results from Western blot analyses of the immunoprecipitated MAP kinase (ERK1 and ERK2) with anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. EGF stimulated transient tyrosine phosphorylation of ERK1 and ERK2. Compared with the cells containing the vector alone, a higher level of phosphotyrosine was observed for the cells overexpressing the native PTP2C, while a lower level was obtained with cells expressing the mutant PTP2C. At basal level, neither significant gel shift nor tyrosine phosphorylation was detected, suggesting that the basal MBP kinase activity at zero time (see Fig. 4B) was probably due to protein kinases other than MAP kinase. Additional experiments indicated that the altered PTP2C expression had essentially no effect on the dose response of 293 cells to EGF and autophosphorylation of the EGF receptor upon stimulation (data not shown).Figure 5:Gel mobility shift (A) and tyrosine phosphorylation of MAP kinase (B).
