To understand the mechanism of interaction of CETP with HDL, we studied the binding of pure recombinant CETP to l-palmitoyl-2-oleoylphosphatidylcho-line (POPC)/apoA-I discoidal particles. Separating bound from free CETP using native gradient gel electrophoresis, complexes of CETP with 10-nm hydrodynamic diameter discoidal particles migrated with a diameter of 12–16 nm, compared with ∼7.5 nm for CETP. At lower ratios of CETP to discs, CETP bound to discs without displacement of apoA-I. CETP alone was unable to generate discoidal complexes. Cross-linking and fluorescence resonance energy transfer experiments indicated that CETP bound to discs as monomers. Cross-linking of CETP to apoA-I in discs suggested proximity of apoA-I and CETP. By negative-stain electron microscopy, discoidal complexes containing CETP and CETP monoclonal antibody showed localization of antibody molecules to the disc edge, suggesting that CETP was bound to the disc edge. The binding of CETP to discs of different composition or size was studied. Discs (10-nm Stokes diameter) prepared with either apoA-I or apoA-II had a similar Kd (120 nm). Inclusion of 1 mol % cholesteryl oléate, 5 mol % cholesterol, or 6 mol % phosphatidylinositol increased the binding affinity of CETP 3–10 times (20–30 run). In comparison, plasma HDL3 had a Kd of ∼450 nM. For POPC/apoA-I discs, 10-nm discs bound CETP with much higher affinity than smaller 7.8-nm discs (Kd = 1–2 µm). 7.7-nm hydrodynamic diameter POPC/apoA-I spherical particles containing either triolein or cholesteryl oleate in their core bound CETP with higher affinity (Kd = 50–100 nm) than 7.8-nm POPC/apoA-I discs. Thus, CETP appears to bind to the perimeter of discoidal particles, possibly in a process in which flexible segments in apoA-I or apoA-II accommodate CETP at the disc edge. The binding of CETP to HDL is markedly influenced by overall particle size and shape and by lipid composition, and the increased binding affinity for cholesterol- and cholesteryl ester-containing discs suggests a higher affinity of CETP for nascent than mature HDL. Human plasma cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) 1The abbreviations used are: CETP, cholesteryl ester transfer protein; HDL, high density lipoprotein(s); CE, cholesteryl ester(s); LDL, low density lipoprotein(s); POPC, l-palmitoyl-2-oleoylphosphatidylcho-line; CO, cholesteryl oleate; PI, phosphatidylinositol; BS3, bis(sulfosuccinimidyl) suberate; DMS, dimethyl suberimidate; GGE, gradient gel electrophoresis; BSA, bovine serum albumin; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; PAGE, Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; TR-CETP, tetra-methylrhodamine-labeled CETP; F-CETP, fluorescein-labeled CETP; mAb, monoclonal antibody. exchanges a variety of lipids (cholesteryl esters, triglycerides, and phospholipids) between lipoproteins. In human plasma, most of CETP is bound to high density lipoproteins (HDL) due to the high molar concentration and higher affinity of HDL for CETP relative to other lipoproteins. CETP's main effect on HDL is to exchange HDL cholesteryl esters (CE) with triglycerides in other lipoproteins. As this CE is the product of the esterification of tissue-derived cholesterol, its transfer to very low and low density lipoproteins (LDL) by CETP is an important step in the reverse transport of cholesterol to the liver (1Tall A.R. J. Lipid Res. 1993; 34: 1255-1274Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). HDL exists in several subclasses distinguishable by shape, density, and lipid and apolipoprotein content. Most plasma HDL are spherical particles, consisting of a shell of cholesterol, phospholipids, and apolipoproteins (A-I, A-II, E, and Cs) and a core of neutral lipids (CE and triglycerides) (2Eisenberg S. J. Lipid Res. 1984; 25: 1017-1058Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Sphere-shaped HDL originate from disc-shaped HDL particles that consist of phospholipid-cholesterol bilayers lined at the edges with apoA-I. Upon lecithinxholesterol acyltransferase action, these discoidal particles accumulate CE and acquire the spherical shape seen in mature HDL (3Jonas A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1084: 205-220Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). Discoidal HDL may also arise as surface remnants of very low density lipoprotein or chylomicron lipolysis (4Musliner T.A. Long M.D. Forte T.M. Nichols A.V. Gong E.L. Blanche P.J. Krauss R.M. J. Lipid Res. 1991; 32: 917-933Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). There is also evidence that apoA-I dissociated from HDL particles can combine with phospholipids and cholesterol to form discs (5Clay M.A. Newnham H.H. Forte T.M. Barter P.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1124: 52-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar, 6Tall A.R. Small D.M. Nature. 1977; 265: 163-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar) and that discoidal particles may also be secreted from the liver (7Hamilton R.L. Williams M.C. Fielding C.J. Havel R.J. J. Clin. Invest. 1976; 58: 667-680Crossref PubMed Scopus (313) Google Scholar, 8Johnson F.L. Babiak J. Rudel L.L. J. Lipid Res. 1986; 27: 537-548Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and small intestine (9Green P.H. Tall A.R. Glickman R.M. J. Clin. Invest. 1978; 61: 528-534Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar). Particles with pre-beta electrophoretic mobility and composition similar to discoidal HDL have been reported to be the initial plasma recipient of cellular cholesterol (11Castro G.R. Fielding C. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 25-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (564) Google Scholar) and to bind CETP (12Francone O.L. Gurakar A. Fielding C. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 7066-7072Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Marcel Y.L. McPherson R. Hogue M. Czarnecka H. Zawadzki Z. Weech P.K. Whitlock M.E. Tall A.R. Milne R.W. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 85: 10-17Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar). The interaction of CETP with lipoproteins is mediated by both hydrophobic and ionic interactions (14Morton R.E. Zilversmit D.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 11992-11995Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Nishida H.I. Arai H. Nishida T. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16352-16360Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CETP has a higher affinity for negatively charged particles, and because of this, the incorporation of lipolysis-derived fatty acids in lipoproteins enhances the binding of CETP and increases the ability of these particles to serve as substrates for CE transfer (16Sammett D. Tall A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 6687-6697Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Cholesterol content also appears to be important in CETP-lipoprotein interactions as HDL with higher levels of free cholesterol has lower levels of triglyceride transferred into it by CETP, probably because cholesterol modulates neutral lipid availability on the lipoprotein surface (17Morton R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 12235-12241Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). There is indirect evidence that the protein component of HDL also determines CETP binding because, in plasma, CETP was found to be preferentially associated with HDL containing only apoA-I rather than apoA-I/apoA-II particles (18Moulin P. Cheung M.C. Bruce C. Zhong S. Cocke T. Richardson H. Tall A.R. J. Lipid. Res. 1994; 35: 793-802Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In transgenic mice, more CETP is associated with HDL containing human apoA-I than with HDL containing mouse apoA-I (19Hayek T. Chajek-Shaul T. Walsh A. Agellon L.B. Moulin P. Tall A.R. Breslow J.L. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 505-510Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar), again pointing to the importance of the apolipoproteins. However, it is not clear from such studies whether the increased binding is due to a higher affinity of CETP for specific apolipoproteins or whether they impart properties to an HDL particle (e.g. size, charge, and lipid composition) that favor the binding of CETP. Since plasma HDL comprises many species, we sought to understand the determinants of CETP binding to HDL by studying recombinant HDL particles of defined composition. In this study, we examined the interaction of purified CETP with particles whose properties have been described in detail previously (20Sparks D.L. Phillips M.C. Lund-Katz S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 25830-25838Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Sparks D.L. Lund-Katz S. Phillips M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267 (and references therein): 25839-25847Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22Sparks D.L. Davidson W.S. Lund-Katz S. Phillips M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23250-23257Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Davidson W.S. Sparks D.L. Lund-Katz S. Phillips M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8859-8865Google Scholar). We also undertook this study to examine the possibility that CETP forms a dimer on the surface of HDL. Purified CETP forms self-associated species (24Hesler C.B. Swenson T.L. Tall A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 2275-2282Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and at high concentrations, it displays an apparent molecular weight that is double its native size (25Takahashi K. Jiang X.-C. Sakai N. Yamashita S. Hirano K. Bujo H. Hiroyuki Y. Kusunoki J. Miura T. Kussie P. Matsuzawa Y. Saito Y. Tall A. J. Clin. Invest. 1993; 92: 2060-2064Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). There is evidence for CETP dimerization in the secretory pathway as coexpression of wild-type CETP and a low activity structural variant (either an alternatively spliced or a mutant form) leads to decreased specific activity in the culture medium (25Takahashi K. Jiang X.-C. Sakai N. Yamashita S. Hirano K. Bujo H. Hiroyuki Y. Kusunoki J. Miura T. Kussie P. Matsuzawa Y. Saito Y. Tall A. J. Clin. Invest. 1993; 92: 2060-2064Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar, 26Quinet E. Yang T.P. Marinos C. Tall A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16891-16894Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Two aspects of CETP binding to HDL have been studied. First, focusing on 80:1 mol/mol POPC/apoA-I discoidal particles (20Sparks D.L. Phillips M.C. Lund-Katz S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 25830-25838Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Sparks D.L. Lund-Katz S. Phillips M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267 (and references therein): 25839-25847Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we looked at the mechanism of CETP binding. We investigated whether CETP can displace apoA-I from discs, whether CETP alone can form discs, where on the particle it binds, and whether it forms a dimer. Second, we examined how binding to HDL is modulated by HDL size, apolipoprotein and lipid composition, and charge and whether there is a specific interaction with the apolipoprotein. l-Palmitoyl-2-oleoylphosphatidylcholine (POPC), dimyristoylphosphatidylcholine, cholesteryl oleate (CO), cholesteryl linoleate, phosphatidylinositol (PI), triolein, egg phosphatidylcholine, and cholesterol were from Sigma; bis(sulfosuccinimidyl) suberate (BS3) and dimethyl suberimidate (DMS) were from Pierce; and [cholesteryl-1,2,6,7–3H]cholesteryl oleate was from DuPont NEN. The succinimidyl esters of 5-(or 6-)-carboxytetramethylrhodamine and carboxyfiuorescein were from Molecular Probes, Inc. CETP was purified from a stably transfected line of Chinese hamster cells grown in a bioreactor as described previously (25Takahashi K. Jiang X.-C. Sakai N. Yamashita S. Hirano K. Bujo H. Hiroyuki Y. Kusunoki J. Miura T. Kussie P. Matsuzawa Y. Saito Y. Tall A. J. Clin. Invest. 1993; 92: 2060-2064Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). Apolipoproteins A-I and A-II were purified from human HDL and used to prepare discoidal recombinant HDL by the cholate removal method, followed by purification by gel filtration (20Sparks D.L. Phillips M.C. Lund-Katz S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 25830-25838Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Davidson W.S. Sparks D.L. Lund-Katz S. Phillips M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8859-8865Google Scholar). Spherical recombinant HDL particles were prepared by co-sonication of the lipids with apoA-I, followed by reisolation by ultracentrifugation as described (23Davidson W.S. Sparks D.L. Lund-Katz S. Phillips M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8859-8865Google Scholar). [3H]CO-labeled LDL and [3H]CO-labeled HDL were prepared as described (14Morton R.E. Zilversmit D.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 11992-11995Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Sammett D. Tall A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 6687-6697Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CE transfer assays were performed by incubating CETP with labeled donor and unlabeled acceptor lipoprotein in 50 mm Tris, 150 mm NaCl, 2 mm EDTA, pH 7.5 (TSE); then the acceptor was separated from the donor by either precipitation (27Tall A.R. Granot E. Brocia R. Tabas I. Hesler C.B. Williams K. Denke M. J. Clin. Invest. 1987; 79: 1217-1225Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar) or ultracentrifugal flotation. Binding assays were performed by incubating mixtures of CETP and recombinant HDL in 50 µl of TSE and then analyzing them by native gradient gel electrophoresis (GGE). All incubation mixtures included 30 µg of BSA to minimize the adsorption of CETP to the gel matrix. The 4–30% gels were run in a Tris borate buffer, pH 8.3, in a Hoefer 600 electrophoresis system at 600 V for 16 h at ∼10 °C and then electroblotted to nitrocellulose at a current of 0.3 A for 16 h. The blots were blocked in 5% nonfat Carnation milk in TSE-T (0.1% Tween 20 in TSE) for 1 h, washed with TSE-T, incubated with the primary antibody in TSE-T for 1 h, washed, incubated with horseradish peroxidase-coupled secondary antibody, and then developed with a chemiluminescence detection system (Amersham Corp. or DuPont NEN). In some experiments, the antibody was stripped off the blot and then reprobed with another antibody. Stripping was performed by incubating the membrane in 100 mm 2-mercaptoethanol, 2% SDS, 62.5 mm Tris, pH 6.8, at 50 °C for 30 min with agitation and then washing it twice in TSE-T. For cross-linking experiments, CETP and discoidal particles were combined in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 150 mm NaCl, 10 mm sodium phosphate, pH 7.4) and incubated for 30 min at 37 °C; 0.1 volume of a BS3 stock in PBS was added to give the indicated concentration and incubated for 30 min at room temperature; and then glycine was added to 7 mm to stop the reaction. The samples were analyzed by either SDS-PAGE or GGE. In some experiments, a dimethyl suberimidate stock in 1 m triethylamine buffer, pH 9.7, was used as the cross-linking agent. Negative-stain electron microscopy was done using a Jeol JEM-1200 EX II electron microscope. Samples were incubated in 10 mm Tris, 1 mm EDTA, pH 7.5, for 30 min at 37 °C; mixed with an equal volume of 2% sodium phosphotungstate, pH 7.5; and then placed on the surface of a lacey Formvar/carbon-coated grid (Electron Microscopy Sciences). After 30 s, the excess liquid was blotted, the rest was allowed to dry, and the grid was examined within 1 h. The structures on the EM grids were assessed by one of the authors (A. T.) who did not know the identity of the samples. For fluorescence resonance energy transfer measurements, CETP was coupled to succinimidyl esters of either 5-(or 6-)-carboxytetramethylrhodamine or carboxyfiuorescein. CETP (100 µg) in 90 µl of PBS was mixed with 10 µl of 1 m sodium borate buffer, pH 9.3. The dye was rapidly dissolved in dry dimethylformamide to a final concentration of 10 mm, and 5 µl of this was added to the protein solution. The mixture was incubated at room temperature for 2 h and then run over a Sephadex G-50 column (equilibrated with PBS) to separate unincorporated dye. CETP conjugated with either dye (TR-CETP and F-CETP, respectively) had dye/protein molar ratios of ∼0.8. Both preparations were active in a transfer assay. To prevent loss of activity, the preparations of modified CETP were stored in 0.2 mg/ml BSA. Fluorescence measurements were done in an SLM-AMINCO 8000C spectrofluorometer. During fluorescence measurements, the photomultiplier tube was cooled to minimize electronic noise, samples were scanned five times at 2-nm intervals, and the spectra were averaged. Spectra were corrected for dilution effects caused by sample addition, and control spectra of samples without dye-conjugated CETP were subtracted. All measurements were made at room temperature. The diameter of a globular CETP molecule was calculated to be ∼50 A from the molecular mass of ∼53 kDa predicted from CETP's primary sequence (28Drayna D.A. Jarnagin A.S. McLean J. Henzel W. Kohr W. Fielding C. Lawn R. Nature. 1987; 327: 632-634Crossref PubMed Scopus (302) Google Scholar) and using a typical density of 1.4 g/ml. Thus, in calculating the expected size of a putative CETP dimer, we assumed the intersubunit distance of a CETP dimer to be 50 Á. The theoretical efficiency (E) of fluorescence energy transfer for this system can be calculated from the following formula (29Lakowicz J.R. Principles of Fluorescence Spectroscopy. Plenum Pres, New York1983Crossref Google Scholar): E = Roe/(Ro6 + r6), where Ro is the Forster distance for the pair of dyes used and equals 50 A (30Johnson D.A. Voet J.G. Taylor P. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 5717-5725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and r is the distance between them. For r = 50 Å, the efficiency would be 50%. Given that the dye/protein ratio was ∼0.8 for both preparations, only in 64% of potential dimers would both CETP molecules have a dye molecule, and only half of these (32%) would have two different dyes. Thus, the expected maximal energy transfer in this system due to the 50% efficiency is 16%. To understand the nature of CETP·HDL complexes, we studied the interaction of purified recombinant CETP with POPC/apoA-I discoidal particles. Binding assays were performed by incubating CETP and recombinant HDL, followed by electrophoresis on native gradient gels and immunoblotting with CETP mAb (TP2) (Fig. 1). Free CETP migrates primarily as a major band at 7.5 nm. The faint diffuse signal at higher molecular masses probably represents nonspecific interaction with the gel matrix since it was minimized by the addition of albumin (Fig. 1). Other interpretations are less likely; CETP contains only 1 mol of bound phospholipid/mol of CETP (41Wang S. Kussie P. Deng L. Tall A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 612-618Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar), and self-associated species (dimers and trimers) would have appeared as discrete bands. As shown by Coomassie Blue protein staining, the POPC/apoA-I discs were predominantly a single species 10 nm in diameter (lane 7). Following incubation of discs with CETP, the CETP signal was seen at higher molecular masses, representing binding to the discs. With increasing disc concentrations (lanes 2–6), the CETP signal moved to progressively higher apparent molecular masses, reaching a limiting size of ∼12–16 nm. We interpret the broadness of the bands at lower disc concentrations to arise either from heterogeneity of complexes or from partial dissociation of CETP·HDL complexes during electrophoresis. The large limiting size of these complexes suggests a major increase in hydrodynamic radius when discs bind CETP. The presence of CETP in large complexes could indicate that the discs have been transformed as a result of CETP activity. To assess this possibility, the binding of CETP to discs was studied as a function of CETP concentration and incubation time, and the distribution of both CETP and apoA-I was determined following native gel electrophoresis. When the concentration of CETP was varied, CETP was incorporated primarily into large complexes of 12–16 nm at lower concentrations (Fig. 2A, lanes 2 and 3), but also gave rise to smaller complexes and free CETP at higher concentrations (lanes 4–6). The distribution of apoA-I was determined in the same experiment (Fig. 2B). The POPC/apoA-I discs alone gave rise to an apoA-I band of 9–11 nm (lane 1). At a lower CETP concentration, the distribution of apoA-I was not appreciably changed (lane 2). A separate higher band of CETP·apoA-I complexes is not seen because less than one-tenth of the apoA-I mass is in complexes with CETP. At higher CETP concentrations, an appreciable part of apoA-I is seen in complexes of similar size to CETP (i.e. 12–16 nm). In addition, lower migrating species of apoA-I appear, probably representing smaller discs, and only at the highest CETP concentration do small apoA-I-containing species appear, running below albumin (lane 6). In time course experiments, 1 µg of apoA-I in discs was incubated with 100 ng of CETP for 0–100 min (data not shown). At short incubation times, CETP was incorporated into complexes of 12–16 nm, without any appreciable change in apoA-I distribution. Prolonged incubation favored the formation of small apoA-I-containing species as seen in Fig. 2B (lane 6). The results suggest that complexes formed with brief incubation times (0–30 min) and at lower amounts of CETP (30–100 ng/1 µg of POPC/apoA-I discs) represent direct binding of CETP to discs. At high CETP concentration and longer incubation times, disc reorganization may occur, producing smaller complexes and release of apoA-I. To investigate whether the reorganization of the discs we observed at high CETP/disc ratios is due to CETP combining with phospholipids to form CETP-lipid complexes, we examined CETP's ability to form discoidal complexes by incubating it with POPC by the cholate removal method (20Sparks D.L. Phillips M.C. Lund-Katz S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 25830-25838Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Under conditions that lead to the formation of POPC/apoA-I discoidal complexes, the POPC/CETP mixture appeared opalescent, and analysis by native GGE indicated the presence of protein in particles larger than 20 nm in diameter, suggesting the formation of liposomes to which CETP binds (data not shown). We also examined CETP's ability to form discoidal complexes by incubating it with dimyristoylphosphatidylcholine multilamellar liposomes (Fig. 3). Apolipoproteins such as apoA-I readily form discoidal complexes in these assays as indicated by a clearing of turbidity. However, CETP had no effect, indicating lack of complex formation. In contrast, apoA-I readily formed complexes in the same assay. These results indicate that unlike apolipoproteins, CETP lacks the ability to form discoidal complexes on its own. Rather, it binds to phospholipid-apolipoprotein complexes that have already been formed. The large changes in hydrodynamic radius that result from binding of CETP to POPC/apoA-I discs suggested that CETP might be binding to discs as a dimer (Fig. 1). This was evaluated by chemical cross-linking studies using BS3 (Fig. 4) and DMS (Fig. 5). CETP incubated by itself in solution at physiological concentrations (∼2 µg/ml) (13Marcel Y.L. McPherson R. Hogue M. Czarnecka H. Zawadzki Z. Weech P.K. Whitlock M.E. Tall A.R. Milne R.W. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 85: 10-17Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar) with either DMS or BS3 cross-links to itself only to a negligible extent (Fig. 4, lanes 1–4; and Fig. 5, lanes 4–6). At high concentrations of CETP (200 µg/ml), the protein does cross-link to itself to form dimers, trimers, and tetramers (data not shown). CETP at ∼2 µg/ml incubated with apoHDL does not form higher molecular mass species (Fig. 5), indicating that CETP does not cross-link to apoA-I or apoA-II under these conditions. Similar results were obtained by cross-linking CETP in the presence of purified apoA-I (data not shown). When discoidal particles at physiological concentrations of apoA-I (∼1.5 mg/ml) are reacted with BS3, apoA-I is cross-linked to form two bands migrating at 60 and 75 kDa (Fig. 4, lanes 13–16). These bands represent two forms of cross-linked apoA-I dimers (31Rye K.-A. J. CETP cross-linked in the presence of discs produces one ∼100-kDa band at 40 µm BS3 and a faint ∼150-kDa band at higher BS3 concentrations (Fig. 4, lanes 6–8). The same bands contained apoA-I (lanes 10–12). Since these bands containing apoA-I and CETP were not visualized in preparations of CETP alone or discs alone, they represent cross-linked species of CETP and apoA-I, probably CETP cross-linked to 1 and 2 molecules of apoA-I. 2The reason the apparent sizes of these bands are slightly larger than the sum of the molecular masses of their components (∼67 kDa for CETP and 38.5 kDa for apoA-I) may be due partly to the addition of multiple cross-linker molecules that reacted monovalently with the proteins and partly to the inability of SDS molecules to bind to the intramolecularly cross-linked proteins to the same extent as to unreacted proteins. A CETP-containing band that migrates slightly faster than the monomelic form of CETP appears at high levels of cross-linking, probably indicating an intramolecularly cross-linked form of the protein that is unable to be unfolded by SDS. Similar cross-linked species were seen by using DMS and could be visualized with CETP mAb (Fig. 5, lanes 8, 9, 11, and 12) and with apoA-I antiserum (data not shown), indicating cross-linking of CETP to apoA-I. The interpretation that the two higher molecular mass cross-linked species represent CETP·apoA-I complexes was supported in further experiments in which CETP was cross-linked to discs, immunoprecipitated with CETP mAb (TP2-Sepha-rose), and then analyzed by Western blotting with CETP and apoA-I antibodies: the immunoprecipitated cross-linked species contained both CETP and apoA-I (data not shown). To assess the possibility that the 150-kDa band might contain CETP dimer in addition to CETP-(apoA-I)2 complexes, we compared by densitometric analysis the intensity of the band at this position with the intensity of the band corresponding to the CETP·apoA-I band (∼100 kDa). Since the formation of a cross-linked CETP dimer is a bimolecular reaction, while the formation of a CETP(apoA-I)2 complex is a trimolecular reaction, at the lower cross-linker concentrations, CETP dimer formation should be favored over CETP(apoA-I)2 formation. However, in Fig. 4, the ratio of the CETP signal to apoA-I signal in the 150-kDa band did not change with BS3 concentration and remained at 0.5 ± 0.2, while the same ratio for the 115-kDa band was 1.2 ± 0.2. This suggests that the 150-kDa species consists predominantly of CETP(apoA-I)2 complexes. This result also confirms the native gel binding experiments that show CETP binding to discs conta

Activation of the TAL1 (or SCL) gene, originally identified through its involvement by a recurrent chromosomal translocation, is the most frequent molecular lesion recognized in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The protein products of this gene contain the basic-helix-loop-helix motif characteristic of a large family of transcription factors that bind to the canonical DNA sequence CANNTG as protein heterodimers. TAL1 expression by erythroid cells in vivo and in chemical-induced erythroleukemia cell lines in vitro suggested the gene might regulate aspects of erythroid differentiation. Since the terminal events of erythropoiesis are controlled by the glycoprotein hormone erythropoietin (Epo), we investigated whether the expression or activity of the TAL1 gene and its protein products were affected by Epo in splenic erythroblasts from mice infected with an anemia-inducing strain of Friend virus (FVA cells). Epo elicited a rapid, dose-related increase in TAL1 mRNA by increasing transcription of the gene and stabilizing one of its mRNAs. An Epo-inducible TAL1 DNA binding activity was identified in FVA cell nuclear extracts that subsequently decayed despite accumulating mRNA and protein. Induction of DNA binding activity was associated temporally with Epo-induced phosphorylation of nuclear TAL1 protein. These results indicate that Epo acts at both transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels on the TAL1 locus in Friend virus-induced erythroblasts and establish a link between Epo signaling mechanisms and a member of a family of transcription factors involved in the differentiation of diverse cell lineages. Activation of the TAL1 (or SCL) gene, originally identified through its involvement by a recurrent chromosomal translocation, is the most frequent molecular lesion recognized in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The protein products of this gene contain the basic-helix-loop-helix motif characteristic of a large family of transcription factors that bind to the canonical DNA sequence CANNTG as protein heterodimers. TAL1 expression by erythroid cells in vivo and in chemical-induced erythroleukemia cell lines in vitro suggested the gene might regulate aspects of erythroid differentiation. Since the terminal events of erythropoiesis are controlled by the glycoprotein hormone erythropoietin (Epo), we investigated whether the expression or activity of the TAL1 gene and its protein products were affected by Epo in splenic erythroblasts from mice infected with an anemia-inducing strain of Friend virus (FVA cells). Epo elicited a rapid, dose-related increase in TAL1 mRNA by increasing transcription of the gene and stabilizing one of its mRNAs. An Epo-inducible TAL1 DNA binding activity was identified in FVA cell nuclear extracts that subsequently decayed despite accumulating mRNA and protein. Induction of DNA binding activity was associated temporally with Epo-induced phosphorylation of nuclear TAL1 protein. These results indicate that Epo acts at both transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels on the TAL1 locus in Friend virus-induced erythroblasts and establish a link between Epo signaling mechanisms and a member of a family of transcription factors involved in the differentiation of diverse cell lineages. Since the terminal events of erythropoiesis are controlled by the glycoprotein hormone erythropoietin (Epo), these observations suggested that the expression of the TAL1 gene or the activity of its protein products might be regulated by this growth factor. To analyze the effects of Epo on TAL1 mRNA and protein expression we have used erythroblasts purified from the spleens of mice infected with an anemia-inducing strain of Friend virus (FVA cells). In contrast to established MEL lines, these cells show an absolute dependence on Epo for their initial survival in culture and undergo apoptosis if the growth factor is withheld (28Koury M.J. Bondurant M.C. Science. 1990; 248: 378-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (719) Google Scholar). In the presence of Epo, FVA cells complete a full program of differentiation over a period of 48–60 h, including nuclear extrusion with the formation of reticulocytes (29Koury M.J. Sawyer S.T. Bondurant M.C. J. Cell. Physiol. 1982; 121: 526-532Crossref Scopus (98) Google Scholar). This cell system has been extensively characterized with regard to Epo's effects on hemoglobin synthesis (30Bondurant M.C. Lind R.N. Koury M.J. Ferguson M.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1985; 5: 675-683Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), cytoskeletal maturation (31Koury S.T. Koury M.J. Bondurant M.C. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 109: 3005-3013Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar), and programmed cell death (28Koury M.J. Bondurant M.C. Science. 1990; 248: 378-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (719) Google Scholar), and represents an excellent model of normal erythroid differentiation. Our experiments indicate that sequential activating and inhibitory influences, operating at both transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels, act on the TAL1 locus in Epo-stimulated erythroblasts. Furthermore, they establish a link between signaling by this hematopoietic growth factor and a family of transcription factors many of whose members have been shown to specify cell fate. CD2F1 mice of 8–12 weeks of age were given 104 spleen focus-forming units of an anemia-inducing strain of Friend virus by tail vein injection. Sawyer S.T. Bondurant M.C. J. Cell. Physiol. 1982; 121: 526-532Crossref Scopus (98) Google Scholar). A dose-dependent increase in TAL1 mRNA was noted over the range of Epo concentrations observed in response to anemia (0.16–2 units/ml), with near-maximal responses obtained at concentrations greater than 1 unit/ml (not shown). Science. 1990; 248: 378-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (719) Google Scholar) precluded their being cultured under these conditions for longer periods. The increase in TAL1 message observed in Epo-treated FVA cell cultures did not reflect a general change in RNAs encoding transcription factors. Steady state levels of mRNA for GATA-1, expressed in many of the same cell types as TAL1, did not increase for at least 2–4 h of culture and that of the related HLH gene LYL-1 was not affected by Epo addition (not shown). The effect of Epo on TAL1 transcription was analyzed in nuclear run-off studies (Fig. 3). Consistent with the results of Northern blot analysis, transcription of the TAL1 gene was detected in FVA cells at the initiation of culture. In Epo-treated cells, TAL1 transcription increased a mean 2.3-fold within 1 h following the addition of growth factor and remained above the initial level for at least 4 h. No effect of Epo was seen on actin transcription in the first 4 h of culture, consistent with previous measurements of actin mRNA levels in Epo-treated FVA cells during this period (33Wickrema A. Bondurant M.C. Krantz S.B. Blood. 1991; 78: 2269-2275Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). These results indicate that Epo-stimulated accumulation of TAL1 message results in part from an increase in transcription of the gene. To determine whether the Epo-induced increase in steady state levels of TAL1 mRNAs also reflected any change in their stability, TAL1 message was measured by Northern blot analysis in cultures treated with actinomycin D at a concentration previously determined to inhibit transcription (33Wickrema A. Bondurant M.C. Krantz S.B. Blood. 1991; 78: 2269-2275Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The two major species of TAL1 mRNA, which diverge in their 3′ untranslated regions and utilize different polyadenylation sites (42Begley C.G. Visvader J. Green A.R. Aplan P.D. Metcalf D. Kirsch I.R. Gough N.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 869-873Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar), were found to have different half-lives. Treatment of FVA cells with Epo (2 units/ml) for 2 h significantly affected the slope of the decay curve of the 5.0-kb TAL1 message (p < 0.05), resulting in a prolongation in the calculated half-life from approximately 2 to 3.5 h (Fig. 4). The stability of the 3.7-kb message was unaltered by Epo treatment, with the calculated half-life remaining approximately 1 h in both the presence and absence of Epo. Thus, RNA stabilization also contributes to Epo-induced accumulation of TALI mRNA in Friend virus-induced erythroblasts. O-Sulfation at C-3 of N-sulfated GlcN units concludes polymer modification and the formation of antithrombin binding regions in the biosynthesis of heparin/heparan sulfate. The resulting GlcNSO3(3-OSO3) units are largely restricted to heparin chains with high affinity for antithrombin (HA heparin). Low affinity (LA) heparin fails to serve as a substrate in the 3-O-sulfotransferase reaction yet contains potential 3-O-sulfate acceptor sites (Kusche, M., Torri, G., Casu, B., and Lindahl, U. (1990) J. Biol. Chem. 265, 7292–7300), as verified in the present study using a novel sequencing procedure. O-Desulfated, re-N-sulfated LA heparin, as well as an octasaccharide fraction isolated after heparinase I digestion of LA heparin, both yielded labeled HA components following incubation with solubilized mouse mastocytoma microsomal enzymes and [35S]adenosine 3′-phosphate 5′phosphosulfate (PAPS), suggesting that the 3-O-sulfotransferase may be inhibited by sulfated saccharide sequences outside the 3-O-sulfate acceptor region. Indeed, the addition of LA heparin precluded enzymatic 3-O-sulfation of a synthetic pentasaccharide substrate. The Km for the pentasaccharide was determined to ~be 6 μΜ. Incubations of mixed pentasaccharide substrate and saccharide inhibitors revealed Ki values for intact LA heparin and for a heparin octasaccharide fraction of ~1.3 and ~0.7 μΜ, respectively. Inhibition experiments with selectively desulfated heparin indicated that both IdoA 2-O-sulfate and GlcN 6-O-sulfate groups contributed to the inhibition of the 3-O-sulfotransferase. By contrast, chondroitin sulfate or dermatan sulfate showed no significant inhibitory activity. It is proposed that the regulation of GlcN 3-O-sulfation during biosynthesis of heparin/heparan sulfate depends on the topological organization of the membrane-bound enzyme machinery in the intact cell. Apart from the 3-O-sulfate group, no apparent qualitative structural differences between HA- and LA heparin/heparan sulfate have been found.Heparin and heparan sulfate are synthesized as proteoglycans that consist of multiple polysaccharide chains attached to various distinct core protein species. The polymer initially formed has a simple structure of repeating -GlcA-GlcNAc-units. In the presence of PAPS, this polysaccharide is carried through a series of modification reactions which involves N-deacetylation and N-sulfation of GlcNAc units, C-5-epimerization of GlcA to IdoA residues, and finally incorporation of O-sulfate groups at various positions (18Kusche M. Bäckström G. Riesenfeld J. Petitou M. Choay J. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 15474-15484Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Since the reactions are generally incomplete, variable proportions of the disaccharide units are only partially modified, as reflected by the structural heterogeneity typical of the mature polysaccharide chains. The selection of target units in the various reactions is partially controlled by the substrate specificities of the corresponding enzymes but is also influenced by other, yet poorly defined factors.The biosynthesis of the AT binding region has been the subject of a number of studies. Kusche et al. (18Kusche M. Bäckström G. Riesenfeld J. Petitou M. Choay J. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 15474-15484Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) proposed, using oligosaccharide sulfate acceptors, that incorporation of the critical GlcN 3-O-sulfate group concludes the biosynthetic process, adding the final modification to a saccharide sequence already endowed with all other structural components required for AT binding. The sequence of hexuronic acid units within the 3-O-sulfate acceptor structure, unit 3, a GlcA, and unit 5, an IdoA residue (Fig. 1), was found to be essential for 3-O-sulfation and generation of a functional AT binding region (19Kusche M. Oscarsson L.-G. Reynertson R. Rodén L. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 7400-7409Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Analysis of LA heparin suggested the presence of saccharide structures predicted to serve as an acceptor sequence for the 3-O-sulfotransferase; yet incubation of LA heparin with solubilized mastocytoma microsomal sulfotransferases, in the presence of [35S]PAPS, failed to produce any radiolabeled HA components (17Kusche M. Torri G. Casu B. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 7292-7300Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The results of the present study suggest that the inability of the 3-O-sulfotransferase to act on LA heparin was due to strong inhibition of the enzyme by sulfated saccharide sequences other than the 3-O-sulfate acceptor site.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES MaterialsA microsomal fractions was prepared from a transplantable mouse mastocytoma (20Furth J. Res. 1976; 8: 859-867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar).MethodsIncubations of Saccharides with Microsomal 3-O-Sulfotransferase—Heparin-related saccharides were tested as acceptors for GlcN 3-O-sulfate groups by incubation with detergent-solubilized mouse mastocytoma microsomal proteins in the presence of [35S]PAPS. Incubation mixtures contained, in a total volume of 100 μl, 0.05 M HEPES (pH 7.4), the amounts of saccharide indicated, 1–2 mg of microsomal protein, 25 μCi of [35S]PAPS, 1 mm unlabeled PAPS, 10 mm MnCl2, 10 mm MgCl2, 5 mm CaCl2, 3.5 μΜ NaF, and 0.3% Triton X-100. Deviations from these standard conditions will be indicated as required. The reaction mixtures were incubated at 37 °C for 1 h, during which period the synthetic pentasaccharide substrate (at 20 μΜ; essentially substrate saturation) was 3-O-35S-sulfated at a constant rate (data not shown). The incubations were then heated at 100 °C for 5 min, and denatured protein was removed by centrifugation. Labeled saccharide products in the supernatant with high affinity for AT were detected by affinity chromatography on a 3-ml column of AT-Sepharose. The sample was applied in 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), 0.5 M NaCl, and the column was then thoroughly washed with the same buffer before elution of HA components with buffered 2 M NaCl (stepwise elution procedure). Effluent fractions of ~2 ml were analyzed for 35S by liquid scintillation counting. Alternatively, the column was equilibrated with 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), 50 mm NaCl before application of the sample, and was then washed with at least 3 bed volumes of the same buffer and eluted with a linear salt gradient (total volume, 80 ml) extending from 50 mm to 3 M buffered NaCl (gradient elution procedure). Occasionally, the remaining [35S]PAPS was removed before affinity chromatography by passing the sample through a PD-10 column (Pharmacia) equilibrated with 0.2 M NH4HCO3, followed by lyophilization of the excluded fraction. In some experiments, the 3-O-35S-sulfated pentasaccharide product was detected by gel chromatography on a column (1 × 190 cm) of Sephadex G-50 (superfine grade) in 1 M NaCl.Degradation of Heparin—Deaminative cleavage of heparin by treatment with HNO2 at pH 1.5 (cleavage at N-sulfated GlcN units) was performed as described (32Shively J.E. Conrad H.E. Biochemistry. 1976; 15: 3932-3942Crossref PubMed Scopus (664) Google Scholar). Even numbered heparin oligosaccharides were generated by partial deaminative cleavage, reduction of the products with NaBH4, and separation by gel chromatography (33Pejler G. Lindahl U. Larm O. Scholander E. Sandgren E. Lundblad A. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 5197-5201Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).Heparin oligosaccharides were also obtained by controlled, limited digestion with heparinase I (34Linhardt R.J. Turnbull J.E. Wang H.M. Loganathan D. Gallagher J.T. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 2611-2617Crossref PubMed Scopus (243) Google Scholar). A sample (10 mg) of LA heparin was incubated, in a total volume of 0.5 ml, with 32 mIU (20 Sigma units) of enzyme and 1 mg of bovine serum albumin in 5 mm NaH2PO4, 200 mm NaCl (pH 7.0). The reaction was monitored by removing aliquots and measuring A232 nm after appropriate dilution in 30 mm HCl. After incubation at 30 °C for 11 h, an additional 8 mIU of heparinase was added, and incubation was continued for 3 more h to reach ~50% completion of the digestion. The reaction mixture was boiled for 2 min, centrifuged to remove denatured proteins, and separated by gel chromatography on a (1 × 190 cm) column of Sephadex G-50, equilibrated with 1 M NaCl. Effluent fractions were analyzed for hexuronic acid and fractions contributing to an octasaccharide peak were combined, concentrated, and desalted by passage through a column of Sephadex G-15 in 0.2 M NH4HCO3, followed by lyophilization.Sequence Analysis of Heparin—A procedure was developed to determine the sequence of monosaccharide residues in heparin, toward the reducing end of the chain starting from an N-acetylated GlcN unit (see scheme in Fig. 2). Heparin (5 mg) was subjected to limited cleavage by treatment with 10 μl of deamination reagent (56 mg of NaNO2/ml of H2O) in a total volume of 2 ml of H2O acidified to pH 1.5 with H2SO4. After 3 h at 2 °C the reaction mixture was neutralized with Na2CO3 and was then reduced with 1 mCi of NaB3H4 (5–15 Ci/mmol; DuPont NEN). Labeled saccharides were recovered after passage through Sephadex G-15 (4Thunberg L. Bäckström G. Lindahl U. Carbohydr. Res. 1982; 100: 393-410Crossref PubMed Scopus (370) Google Scholar) and were then separated by gel chromatography on a (1 × 190 cm) column of Sephadex G-50, eluted with 1 m NaCl. Oligosaccharides larger than tetrasaccharides were combined, desalted (passage through Sephadex G-15), and N-deacetylated by hydrazinolysis (6 × 106 cpm of 3H-labeled saccharides and 2.5 mg of hydrazine sulfate in 250 μl of 70% hydrazine, 30% H2O; 100 °C; 2 h) (35Guo Y. Conrad H.E. Anal. Biochem. 1989; 176: 96-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). The products were passed through a PD-10 column in 0.2 μ NH4HCO3, lyophilized, and were then cleaved at N-unsubstituted GlcN units by high pH deamination (500 μl of 5.6 M NaNO2, 200 μl of 0.4 M acetic acid, pH 4.5; room temperature; 10 min). The resultant labeled oligosaccharides were again separated by gel chromatography on Sephadex G-50, eluted with 1 M NaCl. Di- and tetrasaccharides were pooled and desalted. The disaccharides were directly analyzed by anion-exchange HPLC as described below. The tetrasaccharides were cleaved by low pH deamination, and the released 3H-labeled disaccharides were recovered and identified. For further information see “Results.”Fig. 2Strategy employed to define saccharide sequences in a heparin chain, toward the reducing terminus from N-acetylated GlcN units. The initial sequence (top) represents a heparin chain composed of hexuronic acid units (circles), N-sulfated GlcN units (filled squares) and a single N-acetylated GlcN unit (stippled square); the reducing terminus is to the right. Partial deaminative cleavage of glucosaminidic bonds of N-sulfated GlcN units (reaction with HNO2 at pH 1.5), followed by reduction of the products with NaB3H4, results in the formation of a series of oligosaccharides with reducing terminal [3H]aManR units (striped arrowheads). Hexasaccharides and larger fragments are recovered by gel chromatography and are then N-deacetylated by hydrazinolysis and cleaved at the site of the resultant N-unsubstituted GlcN unit by treatment with HNO2 at pH 4.5. The released, N-sulfated oligosaccharides are separated with regard to size, and the tetrasaccharides and larger oligosaccharides are further degraded by exhaustive low pH deamination. Identification of the 3H-labeled disaccharides thus formed will reveal the structures of the corresponding disaccharide units in the native polymer.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Additional Analytical Methods—3H-Labeled HexA-aManR disaccharides were separated by anion-exchange HPLC on a Partisil-10 SAX column (Whatman) (17Kusche M. Torri G. Casu B. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 7292-7300Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar); effluent radioactivity was quantified either by a radio flow detector (17Kusche M. Biochem. 1962; 4: 330-334Crossref PubMed Scopus (5138) Google Scholar), arbitrarily assuming a 33% hexuronic acid content, an Mr of 15,000 for all polysaccharide preparations, and an Mr of 300 for the average monosaccharide unit.RESULTSThe incitement to the present study was the previous finding that solubilized mastocytoma microsomal sulfotransferases could catalyze GlcN 3-O-sulfation of oligosaccharide acceptors (18Kusche M. Bäckström G. Riesenfeld J. Petitou M. Choay J. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 15474-15484Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) but were unable to convert LA- into HA heparin (17Kusche M. Torri G. Casu B. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 7292-7300Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This failure could be due to the lack of the appropriate acceptor structure in LA heparin, as claimed by Linhardt et al. (37Linhardt R.J. Wang H. Loganathan D. Bae J.-H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 2380-2387Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Alternatively, 3-O-sulfation might be restricted by inhibitory, as yet unidentified, structural elements present in the polysaccharide chain. Each of these possibilities was evaluated in the present study.Occurrence of a Potential 3-O-Sulfate Acceptor Site in LA heparin—Our current view of the structure of the AT binding region in heparin (and in heparan sulfate) is illustrated in Fig. 1. Two structural variants have been identified within the native, functional binding region, i.e. the N-substituent of unit 2, which may be either an acetyl or a sulfate group, and the O-substituent at C6 of unit 4, either a hydrogen atom or a sulfate group (7Lindahl U. Thunberg L. Bäekström G. Riesenfeld J. Nordling K. Björk I. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 12368-12376Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Moreover, when the GlcN unit 2 is N-acetylated, the IdoA unit 1 (outside the actual binding region) appears predominantly to lack an O-sulfate group at C-2, whereas an N-sulfated unit 2 is preceded by an O-sulfated unit 1.The occurrence of potential 3-O-sulfate acceptor sites in LA heparin was previously investigated by analysis of deamination products generated by treatment with nitrous acid at pH 1.5 (17Kusche M. Torri G. Casu B. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 7292-7300Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Under these conditions glycosidic bonds of N-sulfated GlcN units are cleaved, along with conversion of the amino sugars to terminal 2,5-anhydro-mannose (subsequently reduced to aManR) units, whereas N-acetylated GlcN units are resistant. Deamination of LA heparin (from pig intestinal mucosa) yielded the tetrasaccharide, IdoA-GlcNAc(6-OSO3)-GleA-aManR(±6-OSO3), corresponding to units 1–4 in Fig. 1, in amounts approaching 1 mol/mol of polysaccharide chain. This tetrasaccharide thus would express the distinguishing structural features of the AT binding region, except for the 3-O-sulfate group. It was proposed that LA heparin contains appreciable proportions of nonutilized 3-O-sulfate acceptor sites, such that the structural difference between HA and LA heparin would primarily be restricted to the presence or absence of this particular sulfate group.The disaccharide unit 5–6 in the AT binding region has the same structure, -IdoA(2-OSO3)-GlcNSO3(6-OSO3)-, as the most abundant disaccharide unit in heparin, and it was therefore tacitly assumed to occupy the corresponding position also in LA heparin (17Kusche M. Torri G. Casu B. Lindahl U. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 7292-7300Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To test this assumption we have adopted a novel sequencing strategy (see “Methods”), aimed at identifying disaccharide units that are located at defined distances toward the reducing end from a potentially cleavable reference site. The method, which should have general applicability, is schematically outlined in Fig. 2. The heparin chain is first subjected to partial (essentially random) deaminative cleavage at N-sulfated GlcN units, and the resultant anhydromannose residues are reduced with NaB3H4 to [3H]aManR units. Following the removal of low molecular weight labeled oligosaccharides by gel chromatography (not indicated in Fig. 2), the labeled oligo/polymers are N-deacetylated by hydrazinolysis, and the products are treated with nitrous acid at pH 4.5. Under these conditions cleavage occurs exclusively at N-unsubstituted GlcN units, N-sulfated units being resistant, such that the labeled aManR units of the oligosaccharides now released will correspond to N- sulfated GlcN units at defined positions in relation to the N-acetylated residues of the intact polysaccharide. After N-deacetylation of unit 2, the labeled disaccharide formed on high pH deamination thus will directly identify units 3–4 (Fig. 2). The labeled tetra- and hexasaccharides should be cleaved at N-sulfated GlcN residues (low pH deamination) to release the terminal, 3H-labeled, disaccharide units, which will correspond to units 5–6 and 7–8, respectively.The application of this method to the sequencing of LA heparin is illustrated in Fig. 3, Fig. 4. Limited low pH deamination of LA heparin (5 mg) followed by reduction of the products with NaB3H4 yielded ~65 × 106 cpm of 3H-labeled oligosaccharides. The di- and tetrasaccharides, together 39% of the incorporated label, were separated from higher oligosaccharides by gel chromatography (data not shown) and discarded. The latter components (61% of total 3H initially incorporated) were N-deacetylated by hydrazinolysis and were then deaminated at pH 3.9, resulting in a series of new, smaller oligosaccharides that were separated by gel chromatography (Fig. 3). The new disaccharide fraction thus obtained from LA heparin (13% of initial 3H incorporated), predicted to contain the disaccharide unit adjacent to the N-acetylated GlcN residue in the intact structure (units 3–4 in Fig. 2), was separated further by anion-exchange HPLC (Fig. 4A). A major peak of GlcA-aManR(6-OSO3) was observed, in accord with prediction, thus validating the method. In addition, however, the same sample contained significant amounts (~2.3% of initial 3H incorporated) of the disulfated disaccharide, IdoA(2-OSO3)-aManR(6-OSO3), derived from the predominant disaccharide unit of heparin (38Bienkowski M.J. Conrad H.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 356-365Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This finding was unexpected, since IdoA units do not occur bound at C-4 to N-acetylated GlcN residues (due to the substrate specificity of the GlcA C-5-epimerase (39Jacobsson I. Lindahl U. Jensen J.W. Rodén L. Prihar H. Feingold D.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 1056-1063Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar)). In search for an explanation, the initial, end group-labeled oligosaccharides (≥six saccharides; 61% of initial 3H incorporated) were subjected to high pH deamination without previous N-deacetylation. Labeled low molecular weight oligosaccharides were again released, albeit in smaller amounts than obtained with the chemically N-deacetylated starting material. Anion-exchange HPLC of the disaccharide fraction yielded IdoA(2-OSO3)aManR(6-OSO3) as the only labeled component present in significant amounts (data not shown), correspon

Activation of the membrane-associated NADPH oxidase of neutrophils requires several cytosolic factors including p47phox, p67phox and p21roc2. We compared NADPH oxidase activity with the membrane translocation of p47phox, p67phox, and p21rac2. In a cell-free system, GTPγS stimulated translocation of p47phox and p67phox to the plasma membrane only in the presence of arachidonate, and this translocation correlated with NADPH oxidase activity of the reisolated plasma membranes (R = 0.94 and 0.97, respectively). In contrast, GTPγS-stimulated p21rac2 translocation with or without arachidonate, and the extent of translocation did not correlate with oxidase activity (R = 0.17). Neutrophil cytoplasts were used to relate membrane translocation of p47phox, p67phox and p21rac2 to membrane oxidase activity in response to the inflammatory agonists. Whereas N-formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine stimulated equimolar, transient membrane translocation of p47phox and p67phox which kinetically paralleled NADPH oxidase activity, relatively little p21rac2 translocated (moles of p47phox/p21rac2 = 16.6). Moreover, although phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate stimulated both the stable translocation of p47phox and p67phox and sustained NADPH oxidase activity, it did not stimulate p21rac2 translocation. From these data we conclude that membrane translocation of p21rac2 does not regulate NADPH oxidase activity stoichiometrically. Neutrophils and other phagocytic cells have the capacity to generate superoxide anion (O2⨪) and related toxic oxygen species that are critical to host defense against microorganisms and play a role in autoimmune tissue damage. The multimeric enzyme responsible for O2⨪ production, NADPH oxidase, is latent in resting neutrophils. Upon stimulation with a variety of inflammatory agonists, an active oxidase complex is transiently assembled at the plasma/phagolysosome membrane (1Morel F. Doussiere J. Vignais P.V. Eur. J. Biochem. 1991; 201: 523-546Crossref PubMed Scopus (526) Google Scholar). Studies of patients with the X-linked form of chronic granulomatous disease characterized by a complete absence of neutrophil NADPH oxidase permitted the identification of the first component of the oxidase, cytochrome b558 (2Segal A.W. Jones O.T.G. Webster D. Allison A.C. Lancet. 1978; ii: 446-449Abstract Scopus (119) Google Scholar), a heterodimeric glycoprotein intrinsic to neutrophil plasma membrane (PM). 1The abbreviations used are: PM, plasma membrane; CS, cytosol; GTPγS, guanosine 5′-O-(3-thiotriphosphate); GDPβS, guanyl-5′-yl thio-phosphate; GMP-PNP, guanyl-5′-yl imidodiphosphate; ATPγS, adenosine 5′-O-(3-thiotriphosphate); PMA, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate; GDI, GDP dissociation inhibitors; AFC, N-acetyl-S-trares,trans-farnesyl-l-cysteine; AGGC, N-acetyl-S-all trares-geranylgeranyl-l-cysteine. Yeung C.L. Katkin J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14256-14260Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Chem. 1993; 268: 8624-8631Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 25Abo A. Webb M.R. Grogan A. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1994; 298: 585-591Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar), cofactors required for NADPH oxidase activation. p21rac2 is a member of the ras superfamily of GTPases that regulate a wide variety of cellular processes by cycling between a GDP-bound inactive and a GTP-bound active state (26Bourne H.R. Sanders D.A. McCormick F. Nature. 1991; 349: 117-127Crossref PubMed Scopus (2694) Google Scholar). Like all ras-related proteins, p21rac2 is post-translationally processed by C-terminal prenylation, proteolysis, and carboxyl methylation that targets it to membranes (27Clarke S. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 355-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (795) Google Scholar). However, members of the rho and rab families of ras-related proteins can remain soluble after post-translational modification by association with regulatory proteins known as GDP dissociation inhibitors (GDI). Moreover, the partition of members of this class of ras-related proteins between membranes and GDI appears to depend on the guanine nucleotide bound (28Isomura M. Kikuchi A. Ohga N. Takai Y. Oncogene. 1991; 6: 119-124PubMed Google Scholar, 29Soldati T. Riederer M.A. Pfeffer S.R. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 425-434Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). The two cytosolic rac proteins purified as activators of the NADPH oxidase, p21rac1 from guinea pig macrophages (30Abo A. Pick E. Hall A. Totty N. Teahan C.G. Segal A.W. Nature. 1992; 353: 668-670Crossref Scopus (766) Google Scholar) and p21rac2 from human neutrophils (31Knaus U.G. Heyworth P.G. Evans T. Curnutte J.T. Bokoch G.M. Science. 1991; 254: 1512-1515Crossref PubMed Scopus (544) Google Scholar) were both found to be complexed with rhoGDI. These properties make p21rac2 an attractive candidate for the factor that regulates NADPH oxidase assembly at the neutrophil PM by translocation from the CS. We previously reported that in a cell-free system, GTPγS stimulated membrane translocation of neutrophil p21rac2, but not rhoGDI, under conditions in which GTPγS also stimulated carboxyl methylation of p21rac2 (32Philips M.R. Pillinger M.H. Staud R. Volker C. Rosenfeld M.G. Weissmann G. Stock J.B. Science. 1993; 259: 977-980Crossref PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar). Using a cell-free system and enucleate neutrophil cytoplasts, we have now tested the hypothesis that translocation of p21rac2 from CS to PM regulates NADPH oxidase activity by promoting stoichiometric assembly of the oxidase complex. We found that p21rac2 translocation is independent of stimulated carboxyl methylation and is neither necessary nor sufficient for NADPH oxidase activation. Preliminary reports of these results have been presented (33Philips M.R. Feoktistov A.S. Pillinger M.H. Weissmann G. Clin. Res. 1993; 41 (abstr.): 322AGoogle Scholar, 34Philips M.R. Feoktistov A.S. Ficoll 70 was from Pharmacia Biotech Inc. Pyrogen-free dextran (molecular mass 100–200 kDa) was from U. S. Biochemical Corp. Ultrapure sucrose, 125I-protein A and 125I-protein G were purchased from ICN Biochemicals. fMLP was purchased from Vega Biochemicals, and PMA was from Calbiochem. N-Acetyl-S-all trans-geranylgeranyl-L-cysteine (AGGC) and N-acetyl-S-trans,trans-farnesyl-L-cysteine (AFC) were synthesized and purified as described (35Volker C. Miller R.A. Stock J.B. Methods. 1990; 1: 283-287Crossref Scopus (24) Google Scholar). GTP, GDPβS, GTPγS, GMP-PNP, and ATPγS were from Boehringer Mannheim. Affinity-purified rabbit antipeptide antisera specific to p21rac1, p21rac2, p22rhoA, p22rhoB, p21CDC42hs. and p21rap1 were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. A monoclonal antibody that recognizes p21rap1, 142–24E5, was purchased from Microbiological Associates, Inc. Antipeptide rabbit antisera specific to rhoGDI was provided by Alan Hall (University College, London, UK), and a monoclonal anti-p22rhoA (36Lang P. Gesbert F. Thiberge J.M. Troalen F. Dutartre H. Chavrier P. Bertoglio J. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1993; 196: 1522-1528Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar) was provided by Jacques Bertoglio (Universite Paris-Sud, Chatenay Malabry, France). Affinity-purified goat antisera to recombinant p47phox and p67phox was provided by Harry Malech (NIAID, Bethesda, MD). Tris-glycine precast polyacrylamide gels were purchased from NOVEX Inc., and nitrocellulose filters were from Schleicher & Schuell. X-Omat AR film was from Eastman Kodak. Neutrophils were isolated from heparinized venous blood of normal volunteers by Ficoll/Hypaque (Accu-Prep) centrifugation followed by dextran sedimentation and hypotonic lysis of residual erythrocytes as described previously (37Boyum A. Scand. J. Clin. Lab. Invest. 1968; 21: 77-78PubMed Google Scholar). Neutrophils were maintained in cell buffer (150 mm NaCl, 5 mm KOH, 1.3 mm CaCl2, 1.2 mm MgCl2, 10 mm HEPES, pH 7.4). Neutrophil subcellular fractions (CS, PM, and specific granules) were produced by nitrogen cavitation followed by discontinuous sucrose density centrifugation as we have described (38Philips M.R. Abramson S.B. Kolasinski S.L. Haines K.A. Weissmann G. Rosenfeld M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 1289-1298Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Human erythrocyte membranes were prepared as described previously (39Dodge J.T. Mitchell C. Hanahan D.J. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1963; 100: 119-130Crossref PubMed Scopus (3636) Google Scholar). Neutrophil CS was dialyzed overnight against 20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, containing 10 kallikrein inactivating units of aprotinin/ml to reduce potassium concentrations (100 meq in cavitate) to permit SDS-poly-acrylamide gel electrophoresis. Membranes were washed and suspended in 20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, containing 100 kallikrein inactivating units of aprotinin/ml (TA buffer). All subcellular fractions were stored in aliquots at –70 °C until use, and all thawed CS was centrifuged at 100,000 × g immediately prior to use in translocation assays. Cytoplasts were prepared from cytochalasin b-treated neutrophils by discontinuous Ficoll 70 (12.5%, 16%, and 25%) centrifugation at 37 °C as described by Roos et al. (40Roos D. Voetman A.A. Meerhof C.J. J. Cell Biol. 1983; 97: 368-377Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar). Cytoplasts were washed and maintained in cell buffer supplemented with 5 mm glucose (CBG) and used immediately. The viability of each preparation of cytoplasts was confirmed with an assay of fMLP-stimulated O2⨪ production. Neutrophil subcellular fractions were analyzed by 14% Tris-glycine SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and electroblotted onto nitrocellulose in 10 mm sodium bicarbonate, 3 mm sodium carbonate, pH 9.9. Nitrocellulose was blocked with 5% non-fat dry milk in phosphate-buffered saline, 0.3% Tween 20, 0.02% NaN3 (PBS/T/Az buffer). The blots were probed with antisera in PBS/T/Az (1:200 for all anti-ras-related protein antisera and monoclonal antibodies, 1:500 for anti-p47phox and anti-p67phox antisera, and 1:10,000 for anti-rhoGDI antiserum) overnight at 4 °C, washed five times, and then incubated with 3–5 × 106 cpm/ml 125I-protein A (rabbit primary antisera) or 126I-protein G (goat primary antisera) for 2 h at 4 °C. When murine monoclonal antibodies were used, a polyclonal rabbit anti-mouse antiserum was used as an intermediary reagent before incubation with 125I-protein A. The nitrocellulose was washed five times, and the immunodetected proteins were visualized by autoradiography (1–3 day exposures) and quantitated by Phosphorlmager (Molecular Dynamics model 400A). The cell-free translocation assay was performed with and without reisolation of PM over discontinuous sucrose gradients. In the latter, 100 µg of centrifuged CS was combined with 25 µg of membranes and added to TA buffer prewarmed to 37 °C with or without GTPγS, arachidonate, or other reagents, for a final volume of 25 µl. After 1 min or longer, the reaction was stopped with 100 µl of ice-cold TA buffer, and the soluble and particulate fractions were separated by centrifugation (150,000 × g for 10 min) in a TL-100 (Beckman Instruments) tabletop ultracentrifuge using a TLA-100.3 rotor. The supernatants were collected, concentrated to 15 µl by vacuum centrifugation, and analyzed by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and immunoblot alongside the particulate pellet that was resuspended by sonication in SDS sample buffer. A similar procedure was followed when PM was reisolated over sucrose density gradients except 400 µg of CS was combined with 100 µg of PM in a final volume of 100 µl. After incubation at 37 °C for 1 min, the reaction was stopped with an equal volume of ice-cold TA buffer, and the mixture was layered over a 200-µl methylene blue-stained 15%/300-µl 50% discontinuous sucrose gradient in 0.7-ml UltraClear tubes (Beckman Instruments) and centrifuged at 200,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C in an SW-55 rotor (Beckman Instruments). CS was collected as the colorless fluid floating on the blue 15% sucrose, and PM was reisolated from the 15%/50% sucrose interface. One-quarter of the CS was reduced to 15 µl by vacuum centrifugation and analyzed by immunoblot beside one-quarter of the reisolated PM. Translocation was quantitated by phosphorimage analysis of the immunoblots and expressed as the percent of the total (CS + PM) cytosolic oxidase factor detected in the particulate or reisolated PM fraction. Another quarter of the reisolated PM was split in half and added to each of two cuvettes containing 0.25 ml of prewarmed (37 °C) 10 mm sodium phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, with 130 mm NaCl, 340 mm sucrose, 0.9 mg/ml ferricytochrome c, and 100 µg/ml NADPH, one of which also contained 10 µg/ml superoxide dismutase (reference cuvette). The NADPH oxidase activity of the reisolated PM was measured as the slope of the change in absorbance at 551 nm in a dual beam spectrophotometer (Beckman Instruments) using the extinction coefficient 15.15 nm ferricytochrome c reduced/ΔA661 and expressed per mg of membrane protein as determined by the Pierce BCA assay. Neutrophils were treated with fMLP, PMA, or buffer alone prior to subcellular fractionation as described above. CS and PM was analyzed for p21rac2, p47phox, and p67phox by immunoblot and Phosphorlmager analysis. Cytoplasts (8 × 108/ml) were prewarmed in 300 µl of CBG for 5 min prior to addition of fMLP (100 nm), PMA (1 µg/ml), or CBG alone. At various times poststimulation, 50-µl aliquots were removed to 150 µl of ice-cold TA containing 1.33 mm EGTA and 6.65 mm MgCl2 and immediately disrupted with three 1-s pulses from a probe sonicator. Homogenates were loaded onto 15%/50% discontinuous sucrose gradients and processed as described above for reisolation of PM in the cell-free assay. One-tenth of the CS (2.4 × 106 cytoplast equivalents) was analyzed for p21rac2, p47phox, and p67phox by immunoblot alongside one-half of the cytoplast-derived PM (1.2 × 107 cytoplast eq). The content of each cytosolic oxidase component in the CS and PM was measured by Phosphorlmager, and the percent associated with the PM normalizing for cytoplast equivalents was determined. One-half of the cytoplast-derived PM without addition of CS, GTPγS, or arachidonate was used to assay cell-free NADPH oxidase activity as described above for reisolated neutrophil PM. Immunoblot analysis of neutrophil subcellular fractions generated by nitrogen cavitation and discontinuous sucrose density centrifugation revealed that 99 ± 1% of p21rac2 was cytosolic. When 25 µg of PM and 100 µg of CS (4-fold the original PM:CS protein ratio of the subcellular fractions; PM:CS = 0.07 ± 0.01) were incubated together at 37 °C for 1 min and then separated by centrifugation (150,000 × g), 18 ± 1% of p21rac2 was recovered in the pellet. In the presence of 100 µm GTPγS, the proportion of p21rac2 found in the pellet increased to 66 ± 4% (Fig. 1). Both the baseline and GTPγS-stimulated association of p21rac2 with the 150,000 × g pellet was dependent on the PM (Fig. LA). In contrast, a portion of both cytosolic p47phox and p67phox was recovered in the 150,000 × g pellet in the absence of PM (Fig. 1A). GTPγS augmented the insoluble portion of p47phox and p67phox. Thus, whereas this simple cell-free system was not reliable for reporting membrane association of p47phox and p67phox, it detected a GTPγS-stimulated increase in the association of neutrophil cytosolic p21rac2 with isolated PM and therefore reliably reported membrane translocation of activated p21rac2. Another nonhydrolyzable analog of GTP, GMP-PNP, stimulated p21rac2 translocation, although to a lesser extent than GTPγS (Table I). GTP at the same concentration (100 µm) was 29% as effective as GTPγS in stimulating p21rac2 translocation. Increasing the concentration of GTP 10-fold did not increase the extent of translocation. Neither GDPβS nor ATPγS had any activity (Table I). GTPγS-stimulated membrane translocation of p21rac2 was rapid (complete by 1 min) and stable for at least 1 h (Fig. 1B). Because membrane association of p21rac2 increased slightly over 1 h at 37 °C in the absence of GTPγS and because NADPH oxidase activation in intact cells and in cell-free systems is rapid (<1 min), all subsequent analysis of cell-free membrane translocation was performed with a 1-min incubation.Table IThe effects of nucleotides on p21rac2 membrane associationNucleotidePercent membrane-associatedNone27 ± 4GTPγS72 ± 6GMP-PNP60 ± 9GTP40 ± 5GDPβS32 ± 7ATPγS24 ± 5 Open table in a new tab Because, in addition to membrane translocation of p21rac2, GTPγS stimulated α-carboxyl methylesterification of the same protein under similar conditions (32Philips M.R. Pillinger M.H. Staud R. Volker C. Rosenfeld M.G. Weissmann G. Stock J.B. Science. 1993; 259: 977-980Crossref PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar), we determined whether stimulated carboxyl methylation is required for membrane translocation. Neither the prenylcysteine-directed carboxyl methyltransferase inhibitors AFC and AGGC nor the general methyltransferase inhibitor S-adenosyl-l-homocysteine had any effect on the GTPγS-stimulated membrane translocation of p21rac2 (Table II). Neither did excess (100 µm) methyl donor, S-adenosyl-l-methionine, affect p21rac2 translocation. Open table in a new tab To determine whether GTPγS-stimulated membrane translocation was specific to neutrophil p21rac2, the CS:PM distributions of three other ras-related proteins and the accessory protein rhoGDI were determined in the absence or presence of 100 µm GTPγS (Fig. 2). Like p21rac2, two other members of the rho family of ras-related proteins, p22rac1 and p21CDC42hs, were predominantly cytosolic in neutrophils. GTPγS stimulated membrane translocation of both p22rac1 and p21CDC42hs to an extent similar to that observed for p21rac2. rhoGDI was found exclusively in the CS in the absence or presence of GTPγS. In contrast, p21rap1, a protein in the ras family that has been reported to be physically associated with cytochrome b668 of the neutrophil oxidase (41Quinn M.T. Parkos C.A. Walker L. Orkin S.H. Dinauer M.C. Jesaitis A.J. Nature. 1989; 342: 198-200Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar), was found in both PM and specific granule membranes but not CS (38Philips M.R. Abramson S.B. Kolasinski S.L. Haines K.A. Weissmann G. Rosenfeld M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 1289-1298Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). GTPγS did not affect the subcellular localization of p21rap1 in the cell-free assay. Thus, GTPyS-stimulated membrane translocation is a property shared by several members of the rho family of ras-related proteins in neutrophils. We next determined whether GTPγS-stimulated p21rac2 translocation was specific to neutrophil-derived membranes. The membranes of neutrophil-specific granules function as an intracellular store of intrinsic PM proteins such as cytochrome b558 (42Borregaard N. Heiple J.M. Simons E.R. Clark R.A. J. Cell Biol. 1983; 97: 52-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (653) Google Scholar) because within seconds following an inflammatory stimulus specific granule membranes are added to the PM through the process of degranulation. Like PM, neutrophil-specific granule membranes supported GTPγS-stimulated membrane translocation of p21rac2 (Fig. 3). In contrast, although 20 ± 1% of neutrophil cytosolic p21rac2 became associated with human erythrocyte membranes after 1 min at 37 °C, there was no increase in this association in the presence of GTPγS. Thus, neutrophil plasma and specific granule membranes contain a factor that promoted GTPγS-stimulated membrane translocation of p21rac2. Since GTPγS-stimulated p21rac2 translocation under conditions of high (5 mM) Mg2+ (not shown) as well as low Mg2+ (dialyzed CS plus PM without exogenous Mg2+, FIG. 1, FIG. 2, FIG. 3, FIG. 4), it is likely that a guanine nucleotide exchange factor is required.FIG. 4Cell-free NADPH oxidase activity of reisolated PM correlates with membrane translocation of p47phox and pG7phox but not p21rac2 or p21rhoA. The reisolated PM was assayed for NADPH oxidase activity (○, ●) as the superoxide dismutase-inhibitable reduction of ferricytochrome c without further addition of anything except NADPH (left ordinates). The reisolated PM and CS were assayed for p47phox (A), p67phox (B), p21rac2 (C), and p21rhoA (II) by immunoblots quantitated by Phosphorlmager analysis. Results are expressed as mean ± S.E. of five (A and B) or four (C and D) experiments. The kinetic properties of sulfate transport mediated by the anion exchangers AE1 and AE2 have been examined. Microsomes isolated from HEK cells transiently overexpressing either protein were reconstituted in unilamellar, 200–600-nm diameter proteoliposomes. Transport mediated by the exchangers was monitored by loading the reconstituted proteoliposomes with the slowly transportable anion SO42- using [35S]SO42- as a tracer and performing [35S]SO42-/SO42- exchange. The following data suggest that ΑE1 and AE2 have been functionally reconstituted: (i) the rate of SO42- transport in AE1 and ΑE2 containing proteoliposomes was 10–20 times higher than in proteoliposomes derived from control microsomes; (il) the transport of SO42- was strongly dependent on the presence of a trans anion; and (iii) the anion exchanger inhibitors, 4,4′-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate (DIDS) and 4,4′-dinitrostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate (DNDS) totally abolished SO42- transport. Furthermore, DIDS inhibits SO42- transport only when occluded inside the vesicles, indicating a uniform, asymmetrical, inside-out orientation of the reconstituted exchangers. The Ki values of the stilbene disulfonate compound DNDS were 2.5 and 4 μΜ for AE1 and AE2, respectively, suggesting that the two exchangers possess similar high affinity sites for stilbene compounds. Both AE1 and AE2 showed the same steep pH dependence of sulfate transport, which was maximal at pH 5.5 and reduced to less than 10% (of the value at pH 5.5) at pH 8.5, suggesting that an acidic residue shared by AE1 and AE2 participates in the pH regulation of sulfate transport.
