Int. Rev. Cytol. 1990; 123: 177-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar). The most extensively studied member of the family is AE1 (band 3), which is abundantly expressed in the erythrocyte plasma membrane (2Jennings M.L. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Chem. 1989; 18: 397-430Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). Erythrocyte anion exchange serves to increase the capacity for plasma CO2 transport by exchanging HCO42- generated by intracellular carbonic anhydrase for extracellular Cl− (3Knauf P.A. Andreoli T. Hoffman J.F. Schultz S.G. Fanenstil D.D. Membrane Transport Disorders. 2nd Ed. Plenum Publishing Corp, New York1986: 191-220Google Scholar). The nonerythroid anion exchanger, AE2, is expressed in lymphoid, fibroblastic, and epithelial cells (4Alper S.L. Kopito R.R. Libresco S.M. Lodish H.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17092-17099Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5Kudrycki K.E. Newman P.R. Schull G.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 462-471Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), where it is presumed to participate in the regulation of intracellular chloride concentration, pH, and volume. In addition, specialized AEs play key roles in acid-base balance in bone (6Green J. Yamaguchi D.T. Kleeman C.R. Muallem S. J. Gen. Physiol. 1990; 95: 121-145Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar), gastric acid secretion (7Muallem S. Burnham C. Blissard D. Berglindh T. Sachs G. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 6641-6653Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), cerebral spinal fluid production (8Saito Y. Wright E.M. J. Physiol. (Lond.). 1983; 336: 635-648Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar), and the regulation of chloride activity in cardiac muscle (9Vaughan-Jones R.D. J. Physiol. (Lond.). 1979; 295: 111-137Crossref Scopus (117) Google Scholar). anion exchanger 4,4′-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate 4,4′-dinitrostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate human embryonic kidney 2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid 4-acetamido-4′-isothiocyanostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid dihydro-4,4′-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate anion exchanger 4,4′-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate 4,4′-dinitrostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate human embryonic kidney 2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid 4-acetamido-4′-isothiocyanostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid dihydro-4,4′-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate In addition to monovalent anion exchange, band 3 can catalyze the exchange of the divalent anion, sulfate, at a 100–1000 times slower rate relative to chloride (10Milanick M.A. Gunn R.B. Am. J. Physiol. 1984; 247: C247-C259Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Sulfate transport is steeply pH-dependent in that the rate of transport is maximal at a pH value of ~5 and is reduced to less than 10% at pH 8 and above (10Milanick M.A. Gunn R.B. Am. J. Physiol. 1984; 247: C247-C259Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Milanick M.A. Gunn R.B. J. Gen. Physiol. 1982; 79: 87-113Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). The slow rate and strong pH dependence of SO42- transport have been reconciled as reflecting a requirement for binding and cotransport of a proton that accompanies SO42- movement (12Jennings M.L. J. Membr. Biol. 1976; 28: 187-205Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). Thus, cotransport of sulfate and proton preserves the monovalent nature of transport and explains the steep pH dependence of the process (10Milanick M.A. Gunn R.B. Am. J. Physiol. 1984; 247: C247-C259Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 13Gunn R.B. Gerlach E. Moser K. Deutch E. Wilmans W. Erythrocytes, Thrombocytes, Leukocytes. Thieme, Stuttgart1973: 77-79Google Scholar). Although measurement of sulfate transport has served as an important tool in studying transport kinetics, the anion binding site, and regulation of anion transport, little is known about sulfate transport in the related nonerythroid exchanger, AE2. A hallmark of the anion exchangers is their sensitivity to disulfonic stilbene derivatives. Although the affinity constant of various stilbene disulfonate compounds for band 3 is firmly established, the affinity constant of the stilbene compound DIDS has been reported to vary over 300-fold between two nonerythroid anion exchangers, AE2 and AE3 (14Lee B.S. Gunn R.B. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 11448-11454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), suggesting differences in the stilbene disulfonate binding sites between AE1 and AE2 (14Lee B.S. Gunn R.B. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 11448-11454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Alternatively, the difference in the DIDS apparent affinity may arise from different densities of the exchangers in various expression systems or the complex nature of covalent and noncovalent binding of the most frequently used inhibitor DIDS (15Cabantchik Z.I. Greger R. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 31: C803-C827Crossref Google Scholar, 16Frohlich O. J. Membr. Biol. 1982; 65: 111-123Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). It has been shown recently that AE1 and AE2 can be overexpressed in human embryonic kidney 293 (HEK) cells (14Lee B.S. Gunn R.B. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 11448-11454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). When expressed in these cells, a significant portion of AE2 acquires mature oligosaccharides and is functionally detectable at the plasma membrane. In contrast, AE1 expression is restricted in these cells to the endoplasmic reticulum (17Ruetz S. Lindsey A.E. Ward C. Kopito R.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 37-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). Therefore, comparison between sulfate transport mediated by AE1 and AE2 cannot be performed on intact cells. In addition, populations of vesicles containing AE1 or AE2 in crude microsomes from transfected HEK cells are heterogeneous in size, lipid composition, sidedness, and ionic permeability (18Darnell J. Lodish H. Baltimore D. Molecular Cell Biology. Scientific American Books, New York1990: 489-578Google Scholar), thereby complicating functional comparison between the two exchangers using crude microsomes. In the present study, we describe a reconstitution method to assess and compare the functional properties of sulfate transport mediated by AE1 and AE2. We have used this system to determine stilbene disulfonate affinity and pH dependence of sulfate transport mediated by these two anion exchangers. Expression of Anion Exchangers in Cultured Cells—Murine anion exchanger cDNAs were cloned into the expression vector pRBG4 and expressed in HEK 293 cells, a human embryonic kidney cell line transformed with human adenovirus type 5 DNA (14Lee B.S. Gunn R.B. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 11448-11454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Cells were grown and transfected in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum and maintained in humidified incubators at 37 °C and 5% CO2. Anion exchangers were expressed by transient transfection of HEK cells as described previously (17Ruetz S. Lindsey A.E. Ward C. Kopito R.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 37-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar), except that calcium phosphate-precipitated plasmids were added at 16 μg/150-mm tissue culture plate. After 48 h, cells were harvested. Microsome Preparation—Unless otherwise stated, all steps were carried out at 0–4 °C. Medium was removed from 5–10 culture dishes (150 mm), and the cells were scraped using a plastic cell scraper and resuspended in 3 ml of wash buffer (140 mM NaCl, 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5) for each plate. Cells in the wash buffer were pooled and centrifuged at 1500 rpm (551 × g) for 10 min in a H-6000A Sorvall rotor. The resulting pellet was resuspended in 20–40 ml of wash buffer, and the cells were centrifuged at 1000 rpm (291 × g) for 10 min. The cellular pellet was resuspended in 10–20 ml of swelling buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, supplemented with 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and incubated on ice for 20 min. The suspension was then subjected to centrifugation at 4000 rpm (4660 × g) for 5 min. The resulting pellet was resuspended in 10–20 ml of swelling buffer, homogenized with 50 strokes using a 5-ml glass Dounce homogenizer, and sonicated twice for 1 s each using a cylindrically shaped bath sonicator, G112SPIT (Laboratory Supplies Co.), that was operated at 80 × 103 cycles/s at 300 watts. Sucrose solution was then added from a 70% w/v stock to achieve a final concentration of 10% w/v. The nuclear fraction was removed by centrifugation at 1200 rpm (400 × g) for 5 min, and then the supernatant was centrifuged at 3700 rpm (4100 × g) for 5 min. The resulting supernatant was supplemented with 50 mm KCl and 10 mm HEPES-KOH, pH 7.4. This mixture was centrifuged at 35,000 rpm (140 × 103 × g) in a Beckman Ti45 rotor for 50 min, and the final microsomal pellet was resuspended in a buffer containing 7% sucrose w/v, 25 mm KCl, 1 mm MgCl2, 15 mM HEPES-KOH, pH 7.5. Crude microsomes derived from ten 150-mm plates were resuspended in 0.5–1.2 ml at a protein concentration of about 1 mg/ml, homogenized using a 2-ml tight Teflon glass homogenizer, and immediately frozen and kept in liquid nitrogen for up to 60 days. Reconstitution of the Anion Exchanger—Unless otherwise stated all steps were carried out at 0–4 °C. Crude microsomes (40–80 μg of protein in 40–80 μl) were mixed with a 50-fold excess (w/w) of sonicated soybean asolectin (Sigma) in standard sulfate buffer (20 mm Na2SO4, 10 mM MES-KOH, pH 6.0, and 2 mm MgSO4) with 70 μCi of [35S]Na2SO4 (1050–1600 Ci/mmol, DuPont NEN) in a final volume of 0.5–1 ml in the presence or absence of 300 μΜ DIDS. The reconstitution mixture was subjected to one cycle of rapid freezing in liquid nitrogen and thawing at room temperature, followed by five successive 1-s sonication cycles using a cylindrically shaped bath sonicator, G112SPIT (Laboratory Supplies Co.), operated at 80 × 103 cycles/s. To remove tracer not trapped inside the proteoliposomes and to exchange to the desired extravesicular buffer, the sample was centrifuged through a prechilled 10-ml semi-dried Sephadex G-50 fine (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) column at 1200 rpm (400 × g) for 5 min in a H-6000A Sorvall rotor. The columns were semi-dried by centrifugation for 3 min at 900 rpm (200 × g) in the same rotor. Prior to the semi-dry process, the resin was preswollen in boiling water for 2 h, degassed, and then equilibrated with at least 2 column volumes of desired buffer lacking the isotopic tracer. Sulfate Transport Assays—[35S]SO42- transport was initiated by transferring the proteoliposomes to a 30 ºC water bath and terminated by passing 50–100-μl aliquots through Dowex 1 (Bio-Rad) anion exchange columns that were converted into a formate form and packed into 1.5-ml Pasteur pipettes as described in Ref. 19Gasko O.D. Knowls A.F. Sherzer H.G. Suolinna E.M. Racker E. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 57-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar. Loading of the sample was followed by washing with 1.5 ml of ice-cold isoosmolar sucrose solution. Recoveries of the anion exchanger after the Sephadex spin and Dowex columns were determined by immunoblot to be 85–95% (data not shown). Time 0 of each reaction was determined by passing ice-cold proteoliposomes on the Dowex column. Different preparations show sulfate efflux specific activity that ranged from 150 to 450 × 103 cpm of [36S]SO42-−/mg of protein × min at 20 mm SO42-, pH 6, for AE1 and AE2. For sulfate influx experiments, proteoliposomes were formed in the standard sulfate buffer as described above with non-radioactive sulfate. Transport was initiated by adding 70–100 μCi of [35S]SO42- to 1 ml of proteoliposomes and passing the proteoliposomes through a 3-ml Dowex column. The transport data represent an average of at least three independent experiments each performed in triplicate. pH Dependence of Sulfate Efflux—Proteoliposomes were formed as described above and passed through a spin-down column, equilibrated with standard sulfate buffer in which 10 mm MES was replaced by 10 mM MES and 10 mm HEPES brought to the desired pH with KOH. To avoid a formation of a ΔpH across the proteoliposomes, 10 μΜ nigericin (Sigma) and 5 μΜ carbonyl cyanide p-(trifluoromethoxy)phenylhydrazone (Sigma) were added prior to the passage of the proteoliposomes on the semi-dry spin column, and sulfate flux experiments were performed as described above. The dissipation of ΔpH was verified by spectrofluorimetric analysis of intracellular pH in proteoliposomes reconstituted in the presence of 2′,7′-bis(carboxyethyl)-5,6-carboxyfluorescein (20Thomas J.A. Buchsbaum R.N. Zimniak A. Racker E. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 2210-2218Crossref PubMed Scopus (1765) Google Scholar). Electron Microscopy of AE Proteoliposomes—For electron microscopy, a drop of reconstituted vesicle suspension was applied to a Formvar-coated grid made hydrophilic by glow discharge. After 30 s, most of the liquid was absorbed at the periphery of the grid using a filter paper; the remaining sample was air-dried at room temperature for 30 min and subsequently by vacuum for 10–15 min. This fixation treatment was used in order to avoid any staining solution-induced artifact, that is the formation of multilamellar vesicles. Finally, the monolayer of reconstituted vesicles was negatively stained with 0.5% uranyl acetate for 30 s. Excess staining solution was absorbed at the periphery of the grid using filter paper. Samples were viewed and photographed using a Philips 410 electron microscope under 1.2 × 104 magnification. Miscellaneous Determinations—SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and immunoblot processing were performed as described in Ref. 17Ruetz S. Lindsey A.E. Ward C. Kopito R.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 37-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar. Protein concentration was determined with bicinchoninic acid reagent (Sigma) in the presence of 0.5% SDS using bovine serum albumin as a standard. The Marquardt-Levenberg least squares regression algorithm was used to fit the data to nonlinear equations using Kaleidagraph software (Synergy Software) for sulfate dependence and linear fit for the Dixon plot analysis. Sulfate Transport by Reconstituted Anion Exchangers—Crude microsomes prepared from HEK 293 cells transfected with ΑΕ1, AE2 cDNA, or vector alone were reconstituted into soybean phospholipids by a modified freeze-and-thaw procedure. The AE1 proteoliposomes as visualized by electron microscopy were round and unilamellar (Fig. 1). More than 80% of the proteoliposomes had diameters in the range of 150–400 nm as determined by measurement of 250 randomly selected vesicles. AE2 and control proteoliposomes showed a similar shape and size distribution (not shown). Equilibrium sulfate exchange in these proteoliposomes was measured by monitoring [35S]SO42- efflux (Fig. 2A) or influx (Fig. 2B) mediated by the anion exchangers. Sulfate efflux from proteoliposomes reconstituted with membranes from vector-transfected cells (Fig. 2A) was low, corresponding to an initial rate of 28 × 103 cpm mg−1 min−1. Similar low rates were observed from pure (proteinfree) liposomes assayed under identical conditions (not shown). In contrast, proteoliposomes reconstituted with AE1 or AE2 microsomes showed a markedly enhanced [35S]SO42- efflux, reaching equilibrium at ~60 min. The initial rates of [35S]SO42- efflux for AE1 and AE2 proteoliposomes were 238 and 384 × 103 cpm mg−1 min−1, respectively. These rates are 9–15-fold faster than those observed in control liposomes, suggesting that most if not all the sulfate efflux is mediated by the anion exchanger. To further characterize the capacity of AE-reconstituted proteoliposomes to mediate sulfate exchange, sulfate influx was assayed under steady-state conditions (Fig. 2B). Proteoliposomes were loaded with non-isotopic 20 mm sulfate buffer and mixed into an isoosmolar sulfate solution with [35S]SO42- tracer. Proteoliposomes reconstituted with AE1 or AE2 showed an influx of 7 and 8 nmol of SO42-/mg of protein min−1, respectively. In contrast, proteoliposomes derived from vector-transfected cells showed a sulfate influx rate that is at least 10 times slower.Fig. 2Sulfate transport mediated by ΑΕ1 and AE2. A, sulfate content as a function of time from proteoliposomes reconstituted from cells transfected with AE1 (squares), AE2 (circles), or vector (diamonds). B, sulfate uptake in proteoliposomes reconstituted from cells transfected with AE1 (squares), AE2 (circles), or vector (diamonds). Symbols and error bars represent the mean ± S.D. of 3 and 4 flux measurements performed on different cell preparations, in triplicate for the efflux and the influx measurements, respectively. The specific activities for the sulfate influx measurements for AE1 and AE2 were 350 ± 40 and 402 ± 47 cpm of [35S]SO42- mg−1 protein min−1, respectively.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Inhibition of AE1 and AE2 Transport by Disulfonic Stilbenes—Disulfonic stilbenes such as DIDS are potent inhibitors of ΑΕ1-mediated anion exchange in erythrocytes (21Passow H. Rev. Physiol. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1986; 103: 62-203Google Scholar), where they react with AE1 exclusively from the extracytoplasmic side (22Kaplan J.H. Skoran K. Fasold H. Passow H. FEBS Lett. 1976; 62: 182-185Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). We took advantage of these properties to further characterize sulfate transport in reconstituted proteoliposomes and to probe the membrane orientation of the reconstituted protein. DIDS was either occluded within the proteoliposomes during reconstitution or added to the extravesicular side after membrane resealing. As shown in Fig. 3, DIDS inhibits AE1 (Fig. 3A) or AE2 (Fig. 3B)-mediated [35S]SO42- efflux only when occluded inside the proteoliposomes, indicating a predominantly inside-out orientation of the reconstituted anion exchangers. Inhibition of the anion exchanger by DIDS may involve both covalent and noncovalent interactions that complicate the evaluation of Ki (21Passow H. Rev. Physiol. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1986; 103: 62-203Google Scholar). Therefore we used DNDS, a disulfonic stilbene that interacts with AE1 in a strictly noncovalent manner (16Frohlich O. J. Membr. Biol. 1982; 65: 111-123Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 4, A and B, DNDS was effective in inhibiting more than 90% of AE1 and AE2 activity. The Ki for DNDS inhibition, derived from Dixon analysis (Fig. 4, A and B, inset), was 2.5 and 4 μΜ for AE1 and AE2, respectively. These values are similar to the Ki value of 2 μΜ previously described for erythrocyte band 3 (23Barzilay M. Ship S. Cabantchik Z.I. Membr. Biochem. 1979; 2: 227-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar), suggesting that the stilbene binding site is preserved during heterologous expression and reconstitution and is conserved between AE1 and AE2.Fig. 4Inhibition of ΑΕ1 and ΑΕ2 by DNDS. ΑΕ1 (A) and AE2 (B) proteoliposomes were prepared with the indicated concentrations of DNDS. Insets show a Dixon plot analysis of the data. Symbols represent the mean of 4 flux measurements, each performed on different cell preparations in triplicate for AE1 and AE2. The specific activities for sulfate efflux were 175 ± 21 and 223 ± 12 × 10s cpm of [35S]SO42- mg−1 protein min 1 for AE1 and AE2, respectively.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) trans Anion Concentration Dependence of [35S]SO42- Efflux Mediated by the Anion Exchangers—An important prediction of exchange-only transport systems is the dependence of transport on the trans anion. Exchange-only transport should be stimulated in a saturable manner by increasing the trans substrate concentration, while keeping the cis concentration constant (24Krupka R.M. J. Membr. Biol. 1989; 109: 159-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). To investigate whether this property is preserved in our reconstitution system, proteoliposomes were loaded with 60 mm sulfate buffer, while the extravesicular concentration was varied between 0 and 60 mm sulfate. To maintain isoosmolarity, the “spectator” anion (i.e. non-transportable) gluconate was used to replace sulfate on the trans side. As shown in Fig. 5, DIDS-sensitive sulfate efflux from the proteoliposomes was abolished in the absence of external sulfate, demonstrating that sulfate efflux from the reconstituted proteoliposomes was dependent on the presence of a transportable trans anion. Stimulation of transport was saturatable with apparent Km values of 9.2 ± 2.3 and 10.2 ± 1.7 mm for AE1 and AE2, respectively. Proton Activation of [35S]SO42- Efflux—We investigated the pH dependence of sulfate transport mediated by AE1 and AE2 proteoliposomes. As shown in Fig. 6, transport by both anion exchangers was maximal at pH 5.5 and dropped sharply to below 10% at pH 8.5. The striking similarity between AE1 and AE2 pH dependence suggests the participation of the same titratable group(s) on AE1 and AE2. The ability to measure the binding and transport of divalent anions mediated by the erythroid anion exchanger band 3 have provided important insight into the nature of the binding sites for anions and inhibitors and the mechanism of anion transport and selectivity (2Jennings M.L. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Chem. 1989; 18: 397-430Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). Although sulfate transport mediated by AE1 and AE2 has been demonstrated to occur in crude microsomes derived from cells expressing the transporters (17Ruetz S. Lindsey A.E. Ward C. Kopito R.R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 37-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar), little is known about kinetic parameters that underlie this process. The difficulties in assessing these parameters may arise from distribution of the anion exchangers in at least two organelles: the endoplasmic reticulum and the plasma membrane. Microsomes derived from these organelles differ in lipid composition, size, and permeability properties (18Darnell J. Lodish H. Baltimore D. Molecular Cell Biology. Scientific American Books, New York1990: 489-578Google Scholar). The reconstitution of heterologously expressed anion exchangers permits the assessment of kinetic parameters under similar conditions and membrane composition. In the present work, we have established a reconstitution system to investigate sulfate transport mediated by the anion exchangers AE1 and AE2 expressed in heterologous cells and reconstituted into proteoliposomes. That the anion exchangers have been functionally reconstituted is corroborated by the following observations. First, the rate of [35S]SO42- efflux from proteoliposomes reconstituted with AE-containing microsomes was at least 9-fold faster than that from proteoliposomes reconstituted with microsomes derived from vector-transfected cell and from pure liposomes. Second, this enhanced [36S]SO42- efflux was sensitive to inhibition by stilbene disulfonate compounds. Third, [35S]SO42- efflux mediated by both AE1 and AE2 was strongly dependent on trans-sulfate concentration, with a Km between 6 and 10 mm sulfate at pH 6.0. An important question to address is whether the reconstituted anion exchangers have a specific activity comparable with that of the erythroid AE1. By subtracting the nonspecific flux of sulfate into the control proteoliposomes from the initial rate of sulfate uptake by AE-containing proteoliposomes (Fig. 2B), we estimated an influx rate of 7 and 8 nmol of sulfate mg−1 protein min−1 for AE1 and AE2, respectively, at 30 °C and pH 6. Based on an abundance of 0.4% w/w of AE1 and AE2 protein in the crude microsomes, estimated by an immunoblot comparison of ΑΕ1, AE2, and erythrocyte band 3 2J. Casey, personal communication. and assuming 100% incorporation into the proteoliposomes during reconstitution, the specific activity of AE1 and AE2 is estimated to be between 1750 and 2000 nmol sulfate mg−1 protein min−1, respectively. These values compare favorably with those of Schnell et al. (25Schnell K.F. Gerhardt S. Schoppe-Fredenburg A. J. Membr. Biol. 1977; 30: 319-350Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar), who estimated the maximal specific activity of erythrocyte band 3 (corrected to pH 6 and 30 °C) to be approximately 2600 nmol sulfate mg−1 protein min−1. These estimated specific activities of recombinant AE1 and AE2 also compare favorably with detergent-purified erythrocyte AE1 reconstituted into lipid proteoliposomes (26Lukacovic M.F. Feinstein M.B. Sha'afi R.I. Perrie S. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 3145-3151Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Taken together, our data suggest that AE1 and AE2 reconstituted into proteoliposomes are fully functional. Disulfonic stilbene compounds have been shown to inhibit anion exchangers of various cells and tissues with widely different affinities (27Aronson P.S. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1989; 51: 419-441Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 28Hopfer U. Liedtke C.M. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1987; 49: 51-67Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 29Karniski L.P. Aronson P.S. Am. J. Physiol. 1987; 253: F513-F521PubMed Google Scholar, 30Reinertsen K.V. Tonnessen T.I. Jacobsen J. Sandvig K. Olsnes S. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 11117-11125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, AE2 and AE3 heterologously expressed in HEK 293 cells showed susceptibility to reversible inhibition by DIDS that varied over a 300-fold range (14Lee B.S. Gunn R.B. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 11448-11454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), while AE2 expressed in Xenopus oocytes showed a IC50 of about 400 μΜ for DNDS (31Humphreys B.D. Jiang L. Chernova M.N. Alper S.L. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; 36: C1295-C1307Crossref Google Scholar), which is considerably higher than the 0.2–5 μΜ value described for erythroid AE1. These observations suggested the existence of structural differences in the stilbene disulfonate binding site among the anion exchangers (14Lee B.S. Gunn R.B. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 11448-11454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The existence of structural differences in the stilbene disulfonate binding site has been further supported by the demonstration that mutating mouse AE1 lysine 869 to methionine, which is naturally occurring in mouse and human AE2, reduced the affinity to DNDS by 10-fold (32Wood P.G. Müller H. Sovak M. Passow H. J. Membr. Biol. 1992; 127: 139-148Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). This result can be interpreted to mean that the different amino acids at position 869 are at the least partially responsible for the observed difference in the affinity of DNDS for AE1 and AE2. This interpretation, however, needs to be further substantiated by the reverse mutation whereby AE2 methionine 869 is replaced by a lysine. Whether this reverse mutation would enhance the affinity of DNDS for AE2 by 10-fold cannot be predicted o priori. Furthermore, a double mutant with substitutions at both lysine 869 and lysine 558, the latter of which is conserved among all anion exchangers hitherto identified, resulted in a synergistic reduction of DNDS inhibitory capacity by about 80-fold. This result suggested that residues shared by AE1 and AE2 have a role in high affinity stilbene disulfonate binding, and further studies comparing the role of AE2 residues, such as methionine 869, in binding stilbene compounds are still required. On the other hand, the differences in stilbene disulfonate binding sites may stem from differences in membrane composition (e.g. lipid composition, charge) or surface densities of the expressed anion exchangers (15Cabantchik Z.I. Greger R. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 31: C803-C827Crossref Google Scholar). The possibility that the difference in the inhibitory capacity of stilbene disulfonate compounds for AE1 and AE2 depends on the expressing host cell rather than on structural differences in the inhibitor binding site is supported by a comparison of the anion exchangers expressed in different cell types. The IC50 of H2 DIDS for AE2 expressed in HEK 293 cells in the absence of Cl− was approximately 142 μΜ, while the IC50 and Ki of DIDS inhibition of AE2 expressed in SF-9 insect cells and Xenopus oocytes are 5 and 0.5 μΜ, respectively (31Humphreys B.D. Jiang L. Chernova M.N. Alper S.L. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; 36: C1295-C1307Crossref Google Scholar, 33He X. Wu X. Knauf P.A. Tabak L.A. Melvin J.E. Am. J. Physiol. 1993; 264: C1075-C1079Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Even more striking is the observation that, while in K562 cells, which endogenously express AE2, the IC50 for DNDS inhibition is 23 μΜ, the IC50 for H2DIDS and DNDS for AE2 expressed in Xenopus oocytes is approximately 0.5 and 400 μΜ, respectively. Moreover, AE2 expressed in oocytes has a lower sensitivity to other stilbene compounds such as SITS and 4,4′-diaminostilbene-2,2′-disulfonate (31Humphreys B.D. Jiang L. Chernova M.N. Alper S.L. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; 36: C1295-C1307Crossref Google Scholar). Taken together, such vast differences in the affinity of stilbene compounds for the same anion exchanger expressed in different cells may exceed the actual difference in affinity of stilbene compounds for different anion exchangers expressed in the same host cell. It has been suggested that the density of the anion exchanger, the presence of the glycocalyx, and the composition and charge of membrane may affect stilbene disulfonate affinity for the anion exchangers (15Cabantchik Z.I. Greger R. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 31: C803-C827Crossref Google Scholar). Unfortunately, little is known about the individual role of each factor. Reconstitution of band 3 into liposomes, while maintaining a similar exchange rate to native band 3, reduced the IC50 for DNDS by about 6-fold, indicating that a change in the lipid environment or the density of the anion exchanger reduced the affinity of DNDS inhibition (34Kohne W. Haest C.W.M. Deutike B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1981; 229: 547-556Google Scholar). Another factor that may play a role in changing the apparent affinity of stilbene disulfonates is the presence of an abundantly expressed membrane protein not related to the anion exchanger but possessing a high affinity for stilbene disulfonate. One such protein is aminopeptidase A, a major protein in kidney microsomes that binds with high affinity to SITS Affi-Gel resin (35See H. Reithmeier R.A.F. Biochem. J. 1990; 271: 147-155Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The apparent Ki in this study of DNDS is 2.5 and 4 μΜ for AE1 and AE2, respectively, and is comparable with an apparent Ki value of approximately 2 μΜ for DNDS inhibition of SO42-/SO42- exchange mediated by band 3 measured in red blood cells (23Barzilay M. Ship S. Cabantchik Z.I. Membr. Biochem. 1979; 2: 227-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). Therefore, our data indicate that AE1 and AE2 share a similar, if not identical, binding site for stilbene disulfonate compounds. The striking similarity of the pH dependence of sulfate transport mediated by AE1 and AE2 strongly suggests that a conserved site has a key role in the pH regulation of sulfate transport. Furthermore, the steep pH dependence for both anion exchangers suggests the participation of an acidic group in the process of AE-mediated divalent anion transport. The latter notion is in agreement with a pH-titratable site for sulfate transport on erythrocyte AE1 (11Milanick M.A. Gunn R.B. J. Gen. Physiol. 1982; 79: 87-113Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 13Gunn R.B. Gerlach E. Moser K. Deutch E. Wilmans W. Erythrocytes, Thrombocytes, Leukocytes. Thieme, Stuttgart1973: 77-79Google Scholar). Unfortunately our data do not permit accurate determination of the pKa value for this titratable group on AE2, as the proteoliposomes became leaky at pH values below 5.0. The use of reconstituted proteoliposomes described here offers several advantages over the use of crude microsomes: homogeneity of size and orientation, low permeability to anions, and the ability to rapidly exchange solution using the dry spin process. Thus, reconstitution by freeze-and-thaw may have widespread applications for measuring the activity of other heterologously expressed transporters. The availability of transport assays for both divalent and monovalent anions and our ability to express site-directed mutants will permit future studies aimed at dissecting the role of specific residues that participate or regulate anion transport. Studies are under way to determine which residues participate in or regulate ion binding and transport as well as pH sensitivity. We thank Drs. Joe Casey and Paul Quinton for critical reading of the manuscript and helpful discussions. Thanks to Fran Thomas for help with the electron microscopy. We are grateful to Lex Bunten for patience and expert help with the preparation of the manuscript.

Skeletal muscle glycogen phosphorylase b binds to sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) membranes with a dissociation constant of 1.7 ± 0.6 mg of phosphorylase/ml at 25°C at physiological pH and ionic strength. Raising the temperature to 37°C produced a 2-3-fold decrease in the dissociation constant. The SR membranes could bind up to 1.1 ± 0.1 mg of glycogen phosphorylase b/mg of SR protein, whereas liposomes prepared with endogenous SR lipids and reconstituted Ca2+-ATPase were unable to bind glycogen phosphorylase. Binding of glycogen phosphorylase b to SR membranes is accompanied by inhibition of its activity in the presence of AMP. The Vmax for glycogen phosphorylase b associated with SR membranes is 40 ± 5% of that for purified glycogen phosphorylase and shows a decreased affinity for its allosteric activators, AMP and IMP. These kinetic effects are also observed with purified glycogen phosphorylase b when starch or α-amylose is used as substrate instead of glycogen. Treatment of SR membranes with α-amylase produced dissociation of glycogen phosphorylase b from the SR membranes. Thus, linear polysaccharide fragments of glycogen bound to the SR membranes are likely mediating the binding of glycogen phosphorylase b to these membranes. Raising the temperature to 37°C produced a 2-3-fold decrease in the dissociation constant. The SR membranes could bind up to 1.1 ± 0.1 mg of glycogen phosphorylase b/mg of SR protein, whereas liposomes prepared with endogenous SR lipids and reconstituted Ca2+-ATPase were unable to bind glycogen phosphorylase. Binding of glycogen phosphorylase b to SR membranes is accompanied by inhibition of its activity in the presence of AMP. The Vmax for glycogen phosphorylase b associated with SR membranes is 40 ± 5% of that for purified glycogen phosphorylase and shows a decreased affinity for its allosteric activators, AMP and IMP. These kinetic effects are also observed with purified glycogen phosphorylase b when starch or α-amylose is used as substrate instead of glycogen. Treatment of SR membranes with α-amylase produced dissociation of glycogen phosphorylase b from the SR membranes. Thus, linear polysaccharide fragments of glycogen bound to the SR membranes are likely mediating the binding of glycogen phosphorylase b to these membranes. Glycogen phosphorylase (phosphorylase, EC 2.4.1.1) plays an important role in controlling glycogen metabolism and in the cell is found associated with glycogenolytic particles (Meyer et al., 1970Meyer F. Heilmeyer Jr., L.M.G. Haschke R.H. Fischer E.H. J. Biol. We have shown that binding of purified phosphorylase to the SR membrane leads to partial loss of its catalytic activity and that the phosphorylated form of phosphorylase (phosphorylase a) binds with much lower affinity to SR membranes than the dephosphorylated form (phosphorylase b) (Cuenda et al., 1991Cuenda A. Centeno F. Gutiérrez-Merino C. FEBS Lett. 1991; 283: 273-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). In addition, phosphorylase b can be dissociated from SR membranes by simple dilution and upon dissociation is fully active, thus showing that this is a reversible process (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). sarcoplasmic reticulum 2-{[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]amino}ethanesulfonic acid 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid pyridoxal 5’-phosphate. Glycogen mediates the association of phosphorylase with the SR-glycogenolytic particle complex because digestion with α-amylase largely decreases the amount of enzyme bound to this complex (Meyer et al., 1970Meyer F. Heilmeyer Jr., L.M.G. Haschke R.H. Fischer E.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1970; 245: 6642-6648Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Wanson and Drochmans, 1972Wanson J.C. Drochmans P. J. Cell Biol. 1972; 54: 206-224Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Interestingly, it has been found that glycogen associated with SR membranes is less branched compared with glycogen particles (Wanson and Drochmans, 1968Wanson J.C. Drochmans P. J. Cell Biol. 1968; 38: 130-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar), but the functional and physiological role of this observation is not known. Recent results obtained in our laboratory support the view that the association of glycogen phosphorolysis with SR membranes in skeletal muscle cells can produce low amounts of ATP in the vicinity of these membranes, which support Ca2+ transport into the SR (Cuenda et al., 1993Cuenda A. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. de Meis L. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1993; 196: 1127-1132Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). Because of the importance that these findings may have in regulating muscle bioenergetics, we have studied the association of phosphorylase with SR membranes under experimental conditions approaching normal physiological conditions (concentrations of phosphorylase and of SR membranes, pH, temperature, ionic strength, and the allosteric activators of phosphorylase b, AMP and IMP). In addition, we have investigated the kinetic properties of phosphorylase b present in SR membranes prepared from skeletal muscle and the effect of phosphorylase b on the Ca2+ pump of SR membranes. Phosphorylase b and SR membranes were prepared from rabbit (New Zealand White) back and hind leg skeletal muscle as described (Gutiérrez-Merino et al., 1980Gutiérrez-Merino C. Garcia-Blanco F. Pocovi M. Menéndez M. Laynez J. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1980; 87: 1483-1490Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, Gutiérrez-Merino et al., 1989Gutiérrez-Merino C. Molina A. Escudero B. Diez A. Laynez J. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 3398-3406Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). SR membranes were fractionated into heavy and light fragments following the method of Meissner, 1984Meissner G. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 2365-2374Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, Meissner, 1986Meissner G. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 6300-6306Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Based on the SDS gel electrophoretic pattern (Laemmli, 1970Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 277: 680-685Crossref Scopus (207227) Google Scholar), phosphorylase b was found to be >98% pure and did not show a detectable AMP deaminase activity (measured with 100 μg of protein/ml). Ca2+-ATPase (EC 3.6.1.38) was purified from SR membranes as described (Gutiérrez-Merino, 1987Gutiérrez-Merino C. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1987; 252: 303-314Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar) and reconstituted with egg lecithin or with lipids extracted from SR membranes as described by Mata and Gutiérrez-Merino, 1985Mata A.M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1985; 133: 176-182Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar using 1 mg of lipid/mg of protein. The protein concentration was determined using the method of Lowry et al., 1951Lowry O.H. Rosebrough N.J. Farr A.L. Randall R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar with bovine serum albumin as a standard and, in the case of phosphorylase b, also spectrophotometrically using a molar absorption coefficient at 280 nm of ε = 1.29 × 105M-1 cm-1 at pH 6.9 (Buc et al., 1971Buc M.H. Ullman A. Goldberg M. Buc H. Biochimie (Paris). 1971; 53: 283-289Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). The glycogen concentration of SR membranes was measured using the phenol sulfuric method (Dubois et al., 1956Dubois M. Giles K.A. Hamilton J.K. Rebers P.A. Smith F. Anal. Chem. 1956; 28: 350-356Crossref Scopus (40876) Google Scholar) with glycogen as a standard and was found to be on average 32 ± 10 μg of glycogen/mg of membrane protein (n = 10). The phosphorylase activity was measured in the direction of both glycogen synthesis and degradation as described by Cuenda et al., 1991Cuenda A. Centeno F. Gutiérrez-Merino C. FEBS Lett. 1991; 283: 273-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar. In the synthesis mode, the assay medium contained 10 mM glucose 1-phosphate, 0.45 g/liter glycogen, 0.1 mM AMP, 1 mM EGTA, 150 mM KCl, 10 mM TES (pH 7.4) or 10 mM MES (pH 6.0), and 0.1 mg/ml purified phosphorylase b. The inorganic phosphate released was determined following the method of Fiske and Fiske and SubbaRow, 1925Fiske C.H. SubbaRow Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1925; 66: 375-400Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar as described by Leloir and Cardini, 1957Leloir L.F. Cardini C.E. Methods Enzymol. 1957; 3: 843-844Google Scholar. Unless stated otherwise, the initial activity in the direction of glycogen synthesis was measured after a 1-min reaction. The phosphorylase activity in the direction of glycogen phosphorolysis was measured in the following assay medium: 12 mM H2PO4K, 10 mM magnesium acetate, 0.63 mM NADP+, 50 mM imidazole (pH 6.9), 1 mM AMP, 0.45 g/liter glycogen, 25 μg of phosphoglucomutase, and 15 μg of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase plus purified phosphorylase b (≤1 μg/ml) or SR membranes (30-50 μg of protein/ml). Each data point of phosphorylase activity in the figures is the average of triplicate experiments done with at least three different preparations of phosphorylase b or of SR membranes, and the error bars shown are the standard errors (n ≥ 9). When needed, the concentration of glucose 1-phosphate in the medium used for phosphorylase activity was measured from the increase in absorbance at 340 nm after the addition of 0.63 mM NADP+, 25 μg of phosphoglucomutase, and 15 μg of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase by interpolation in the calibration line obtained with solutions of known concentrations of glucose 1-phosphate. The Ca2+-ATPase activity was measured at 25°C using the coupled enzyme system pyruvate kinase/lactate dehydrogenase (Warren et al., 1974Warren G.B. Toon P.A. Birdsall N.J.M. Lee A.G. Metcalfe J.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1974; 78: 795-799Google Scholar) as described (Gutiérrez-Merino et al., 1989Gutiérrez-Merino C. Molina A. Escudero B. Diez A. Laynez J. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 3398-3406Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar; Cuenda et al., 1990Cuenda A. Henao F. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Eur. J. Biochem. 1990; 194: 663-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar), with the following assay medium: 100 mM TES (pH 7.4), 0.1 M KCl, 0.1 mM CaCl2, 5 mM MgCl2, 35 μg of pyruvate kinase, 30 μg of lactate dehydrogenase, 0.25 mM NADH, 0.42 mM phosphoenolpyruvate, and 2.5 mM ATP. On average, the Ca2+-dependent ATPase activity of our preparations assayed in the presence of calcimycin (0.1 μg/μg of protein) ranged from 3 to 5 μmol of ATP hydrolyzed per min/mg of protein. The Ca2+-independent ATPase activity was measured in the presence of 3.5 mM EGTA and was <10% of total uncoupled ATPase activity. The steady-state level of calcium accumulation was monitored using arsenazo III as a metallochromic dye as described (Fernéndez-Salguero et al., 1990Fernéndez-Salguero P. Henao F. Laynez J. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1990; 1022: 33-40Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). The AMP deaminase and phosphoglucomutase activities of SR membrane preparations were determined from measurements of the AMP concentrations at different times as described (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). On average, the AMP deaminase and phosphoglucomutase activities of our SR membrane preparations were found to be (1.12 ± 0.55) × 10-2 and (0.86 ± 0.33) × 10-3μmol of product/min/mg of membrane protein (n = 10), respectively. The correction of the effect of the AMP deaminase activity on the activity of phosphorylase b in the presence of SR membranes was done as follows. The decrease in AMP concentration and the increase in IMP concentration at every SR concentration at the given time of incubation were measured. By making use of the saturation curves for the phosphorylase activity induced by AMP and IMP, determined under the same experimental conditions, the loss of activity due to partial desaturation of AMP or IMP (1 - Y) was corrected using the following relationship: activitycorrected = activitymeasured× (1/Y). Pyridoxal 5’-phosphate (PLP) was resolved from phosphorylase following the method of Strausbauch et al., 1967Strausbauch P.H. Kent A.B. Hedrick J.L. Fischer E.H. Methods Enzymol. 1967; 11: 671-675Crossref Scopus (34) Google Scholar with minor modifications, and PLP was taken as a measurement of phosphorylase content of SR membranes because no other proteins in the SR membranes contain PLP (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Briefly, to resolve PLP from phosphorylase, the enzyme was treated with 0.6 M perchloric acid for 30 min at 30°C with mild stirring, and the sample was centrifuged for 30 min at 15,000 × g. The concentration of PLP in the supernatant was determined using absorbance measurements at 410 nm of the PLP-phenylhydrazone derivative (ε = 3 × 104M-1 cm-1). Essentially, 1 volume of sample was mixed with 0.05 volume of 2% phenylhydrazine in 5 M NH2SO4 and then allowed to stand for 30 min before taking absorbance readings. The absorbance of samples of reconstituted Ca2+-ATPase with endogenous SR lipids treated as described above was used as the blank value in measurements of phosphorylase bound to SR membranes and was found to be <0.005 A at 410 nm (20 nmol of PLP gives an absorbance reading of 0.110 ± 0.005 A). Bovine serum albumin, AMP, ATP, α-amylose, PLP, phosphoenolpyruvate, EGTA, phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, β-mercaptoethanol, sodium dodecyl sulfate, Sephadex G-50, glucose 1-phosphate, glucose 6-phosphate, Trizma (Tris base), and TES were obtained from Sigma. Glycogen, NADH, NADP+, calcimycin, α-amylase, pyruvate kinase (200 IU), lactate dehydrogenase (550 IU), phosphoglucomutase (200 IU), and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (350 IU) were purchased from Boehringer Mannheim. Starch (70-80% amylopectin and 20-30%α-amylose) and all other chemicals used in this study were obtained from Merck. The activity of purified phosphorylase b is inhibited when the enzyme is incubated with SR membranes at 25°C (Cuenda et al., 1991Cuenda A. Centeno F. Gutiérrez-Merino C. FEBS Lett. 1991; 283: 273-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). The inhibition is fully reversed by dilution of the phosphorylase b/SR membrane mixture, thus showing that it is a reversible process. This excluded the possibility that the inhibition could be due to irreversible processes, such as proteolysis and/or denaturation of phosphorylase b. Increasing the temperature of the incubation medium from 25 to 37°C enhances the inhibition of purified phosphorylase b by SR membranes (Fig. 1A). This result indicates that the inhibition of phosphorylase b activity by SR membranes is stronger at physiological temperatures than at 25°C. In addition, the inhibition appears to be insensitive to physiological pH changes (6.0 and 7.4) (Fig. 1B). This inhibition is specific for SR membranes because neither incubation with liposomes from egg lecithin or from SR lipids nor incubation with plasma membrane vesicles from erythrocytes produces a significant inhibition of phosphorylase b activity (Cuenda et al., 1991Cuenda A. Centeno F. Gutiérrez-Merino C. FEBS Lett. 1991; 283: 273-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar).2 2A. Cuenda, M. Nogues, F. Henao, and C. Gutiérrez-Merino, unpublished results. The Ca2+,Mg2+-ATPase is the major protein component of the SR membrane, accounting for 70-80% of total SR protein (Andersen, 1989Andersen J.P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1989; 988: 47-72Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). However, preincubation of SR membranes with purified phosphorylase b (up to 8 mg/ml) had no effect on the Ca2+-ATPase activity, on Ca2+ binding to SR membranes, or on Ca2+ uptake by these membranes at pH 7 (data not shown). This and the lack of inhibition of phosphorylase b by incubation with Ca2+-ATPase reconstituted in egg lecithin (data not shown) suggest that interaction of phosphorylase b with another component(s) of the SR membrane should be producing the observed inhibition of its activity. Fig. 2 shows that the extent of inhibition of purified phosphorylase b by SR membranes is dependent on the time of incubation of SR membranes with the assay medium not containing AMP, prior to the addition of purified phosphorylase b. The time taken to achieve 50% inhibition (t) is linearly dependent on the concentration of SR membranes in the reaction medium (Fig. 2, inset). This inhibition is dependent on the presence of glucose 1-phosphate since if it is omitted from the incubation medium, no time-dependent inhibition of phosphorylase b activity was observed in the presence of up to 4 mg of SR protein/ml. Withdrawal of any other of the components of the incubation medium did not significantly alter the time course of inhibition shown in Fig. 2. The inhibition of phosphorylase b activity by preincubation of SR membranes with the assay medium cannot be explained in terms of glucose 1-phosphate depletion because the concentration of glucose 1-phosphate only decreased from 10 to 9.9 mM after a 120-min incubation with SR membranes (2 mg of protein/ml), a decrease that would account for <5% inhibition. In addition, this time-dependent inhibition was also observed in the presence of saturating concentrations (30 mM) of glucose 1-phosphate. A small amount of phosphoglucomutase activity is associated with the SR membranes (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Since glucose 6-phosphate is a well known allosteric inhibitor of phosphorylase b (Graves and Wang, 1972Graves D.J. Wang J.H. Boyer P.D. The Enzymes. 3rd Ed. Vol. 7. Academic Press, New York1972: 435-482Google Scholar), we considered the possibility that this time-dependent inhibition could be due to glucose 6-phosphate production from glucose 1-phosphate. As shown in Fig. 2, production of glucose 6-phosphate cannot account for the time-dependent inhibition observed. Despite the absence of AMP in the reaction medium used in the incubation of SR membranes, there is a low but significant phosphorylase activity in the direction of glycogen synthesis ((0.40 ± 0.02) × 10-3μmol/min/mg of SR protein (n = 10)). Taking into account that the SR membrane preparations used in this study contain <0.1 mg of phosphorylase b/mg of SR protein (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar; see below), this activity is close to that reported elsewhere for purified phosphorylase b in the absence of AMP, 0.1 IU (Madsen and Shechosky, 1967Madsen N.B. Shechosky S. J. Biol. Chem. 1967; 242: 3301-3307Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The polysaccharide synthesized by phosphorylase b activity is linear (Graves and Wang, 1972Graves D.J. Wang J.H. Boyer P.D. The Enzymes. 3rd Ed. Vol. 7. Academic Press, New York1972: 435-482Google Scholar), and the spectral characteristics of the complex of the polysaccharide synthesized by SR membranes with I2 confirmed this point and the lack of glycogen branching activity in these membranes (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). The preparations of SR membranes contain glycogen (see “Materials and Methods” and Wanson and Drochmans, 1972Wanson J.C. Drochmans P. J. Cell Biol. 1972; 54: 206-224Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Since treatment with α-amylase dissociates endogenous phosphorylase b from SR membranes (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar), we considered the possibility that inhibition of purified phosphorylase b by SR membranes could be due to interaction with linear polysaccharide fragments associated with these membranes. The kinetic properties of purified phosphorylase b with starch and α-amylose as substrates support this hypothesis. Fig. 3A shows that for purified phosphorylase b, the Kmvalues obtained with glycogen, starch, and α-amylose are approximately the same. However, the Vmax values for purified phosphorylase b with starch (16 ± 2 IU) and with α-amylose (7 ± 1 IU) were much lower than the Vmax that we obtained with glycogen (28 ± 3 IU). In addition, the K0.5(AMP) values with starch and α-amylose as substrates obtained from Hill plots of the data of Fig. 3B (170 ± 20 and 220 ± 20 μM, respectively) are severalfold higher than the K0.5(AMP) with glycogen as substrate (30 ± 5 μM) (Fig. 3B and Table I).Table IKinetic constants for substrates and ligands of phosphorylase Open table in a new tab The SR preparations used in this study have a phosphorylase activity in the presence of 1 mM AMP between 0.3 and 0.75 μmol of glucose 1-phosphate released per min/mg of SR membrane protein. At least 95% of this activity is in the unphosphorylated b form since this activity depends on the presence of AMP (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). The content of phosphorylase in these membranes was measured as described under “Materials and Methods” by assaying the content of PLP and also by using polyclonal antibodies against phosphorylase. The values obtained ranged from 0.03 to 0.1 mg of phosphorylase/mg of membrane protein. Therefore, we obtained a specific Vmax at 30°C and pH 6.9 for phosphorylase b bound to SR membranes of 12 ± 6 IU (n = 14). This Vmax is clearly lower than that for soluble and purified enzyme (25-30 IU) and close to the Vmax obtained using starch as substrate instead of glycogen (Fig. 3A). If the inhibition of phosphorylase b activity by SR membranes is due to the use of low branched polysaccharide associated with SR membranes instead of glycogen as substrate, the dependence of the activity on AMP concentration should be altered (see above). Fig. 4 and Table I show that the activation by AMP and IMP of the phosphorylase b activity associated with SR membranes is shifted to higher nucleotide concentrations. The apparent K0.5(AMP) was 100 ± 10 μM for phosphorylase b associated with SR membranes. This is ~3-fold higher than that obtained for the purified enzyme (30 ± 5 μM) with glycogen as substrate (Fig. 4A), and it is closer to the K0.5(AMP) with starch as substrate, 170 ± 20 μM (Fig. 3B). The slope of the Hill plot of the dependence of the activity on AMP concentration was 1.7-1.8 and therefore shows characteristics of positive cooperativity in the activation process, like purified phosphorylase b (Morange et al., 1976Morange M. Garcia-Blanco F. Vanderbunder B. Buc H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1976; 65: 553-563Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Similar results were obtained from the analysis of the activation by IMP of phosphorylase b bound to SR membranes (Fig. 4B). Table I shows that association of phosphorylase b with SR membranes had no effect on the Kmvalues for Pi and glycogen and on the Kifor glucose 6-phosphate. If AMP causes the dissociation of phosphorylase b from the SR membranes, this can account for the apparent lack of effect of SR membranes on these kinetic parameters since they were obtained under saturating concentrations of AMP. Therefore, we measured the dissociation constant for purified phosphorylase b from SR membranes in the absence and presence of AMP, and the results obtained are presented below. SR membranes (2 mg of protein/ml) were incubated with different concentrations of purified phosphorylase b (0.5-15 mg/ml) at 25°C in 10 mM TES/KOH (pH 7.4), 0.1 M KCl. After a 15-min incubation, SR membranes were pelleted by centrifugation at 35,000 × g for 90 min at 25°C. In control experiments, we demonstrated that SR membranes were completely pelleted by this procedure because no significant Ca2+-ATPase activity was measured in the supernatant. Furthermore, purified phosphorylase b under these conditions remained in the supernatant, as shown by the fact that the phosphorylase activity in the supernatant was identical before and after centrifugation in the absence of added SR membranes. The concentration of phosphorylase b in the supernatant (free phosphorylase b) was determined by measuring the concentration of PLP as described under “Materials and Methods.” The concentration of phosphorylase b bound to the membrane was calculated as the difference between total and free phosphorylase b. Identical values were obtained by directly measuring the concentration of PLP in the membrane pellet. Scatchard plots of the results obtained in a typical experimental series are presented in Fig. 5. The scatter of the data at low phosphorylase b concentrations is likely due to the variation in the content of phosphorylase in the SR membrane preparations used in these experiments (from 0.03 to 0.1 mg of phosphorylase/mg of total SR protein). It can be readily observed that the data demonstrate that the binding of phosphorylase b to SR membranes shows, at most, weak positive cooperativity. Fig. 5 illustrates that an SR membrane concentration of 2 mg of protein/ml can bind up to 2.0-2.5 mg of phosphorylase/ml and that the endogenous content of phosphorylase in our SR preparations accounts for only 3-10% of the maximum binding capacity of SR membranes. From the results shown in Fig. 5, a Kdof 1.7 ± 0.6 mg of phosphorylase b/ml was obtained, a value that is well below the phosphorylase concentration in skeletal muscle cells (~10 mg/ml) (Fischer et al., 1978Fischer E.H. Alaba J.O. Brantigan D.L. Kerrick W.G.L. Malencik D.A. Moeschler H.J. Picton C. Pocinwong S. Li C.H. Proceedings of the International Symposium on Proteins, Taipei, Taiwan, March 6-8, 1978. Academic Press, New York1978: 133Google Scholar). This Kdis close to the concentration of SR membranes producing 50% of the maximum inhibition of phosphorylase activity in titrations of purified phosphorylase b with SR membranes (Fig. 1A). It is noteworthy that the inhibition of phosphorylase b by light, heavy, and unfractionated SR membranes was found to be the same within experimental error (data not shown). Fig. 5 shows that in the presence of saturating AMP concentration (1 mM), the dissociation constant for phosphorylase b from SR membranes is ~3-fold higher than the one obtained in its absence. Therefore, if inhibition of phosphorylase b is a consequence of its binding to SR membranes, it can be predicted that the Kiobtained from titrations of the activity of purified phosphorylase b with SR membranes should be dependent on the concentration of AMP. Plotted in Fig. 6 are the results obtained from these titrations in the presence of the following AMP concentrations: 0.05, 0.1, and 0.5 mM, which produced endogenous phosphorylase activities of SR membranes of ~25, 50, and 95% of the Vmax at saturation by AMP, respectively (Fig. 4). An ~3-fold increase in the Kiis produced when the AMP concentration is raised from 0.05 to 0.5 mM, in good agreement with the conclusions derived from the Scatchard plots in Fig. 5. Fig. 5 also shows that in the presence of AMP, the SR membranes can bind at saturation approximately twice the amount of phosphorylase b than in the absence of AMP. This latter result can be simply rationalized taking into account that AMP shifts the dimer ⇌ tetramer equilibrium toward the tetramer of phosphorylase b (Merino et al., 1976Merino C. Garca-Blanco F. Laynez J. FEBS Lett. 1976; 67: 9-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The association of phosphorylase b with SR membranes is reversible, and upon dissociation, phosphorylase is fully active (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar), suggesting that SR membranes can act as a phosphorylase b reservoir in skeletal muscle cells. The results presented in this paper support this hypothesis since the dissociation constant (Kd) for phosphorylase b from the SR membranes determined in this study at 25°C at physiological pH and ionic strength is 1.7 ± 0.6 mg of phosphorylase b/ml. A 2-3-fold decrease in the Kdis produced by raising the temperature from 25 to 37°C. Owing to the high content of phosphorylase in skeletal muscle cells (~10 mg/ml) (Fischer et al., 1978Fischer E.H. Alaba J.O. Brantigan D.L. Kerrick W.G.L. Malencik D.A. Moeschler H.J. Picton C. Pocinwong S. Li C.H. Proceedings of the International Symposium on Proteins, Taipei, Taiwan, March 6-8, 1978. Academic Press, New York1978: 133Google Scholar; Varsanyi and Heilmeyer, 1981Varsanyi M. Heilmeyer Jr., L.M.G. FEBS Lett. 1981; 131: 223-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar) and to the large membrane network of SR in these cells (>1.5 mg of protein/ml) (MacLennan, 1970MacLennan D. J. Biol. Chem. 1970; 245: 4508-4518Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), it can be estimated that a large fraction of phosphorylase b must be bound to SR membranes in vivo. The conversion of phosphorylase b to a produces dissociation of fully active phosphorylase from SR membranes since phosphorylase a binds ~10-fold more weakly than phosphorylase b (Cuenda et al., 1991Cuenda A. Centeno F. Gutiérrez-Merino C. FEBS Lett. 1991; 283: 273-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). In addition, we show in this study that the association constant for phosphorylase b with SR membranes is 3-fold lower in the presence of AMP, the allosteric activator of phosphorylase b, which produces a conformational change in this enzyme close to that observed upon phosphorylation (Barford et al., 1991Barford D. Hu S.H. Johnson L.N. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 218: 233-260Crossref PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar). On the basis of in vivo concentrations of relevant metabolites, it has been estimated that in normal skeletal muscle during contraction, ~10-14% of total phosphorylase activity can be attributed to the allosteric activation of this enzyme by AMP (Busby and Radda, 1976Busby S.J.W. Radda G.K. Curr. Top. Cell. Regul. 1976; 10: 89-160Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). It is noteworthy, however, that the effect of compartmentation of phosphorylase was not taken into account when doing these calculations. The results reported in this paper show that binding of phosphorylase b to SR membranes produces inhibition of the activity of this enzyme and a severalfold increase in the K0.5 of activation by AMP and IMP. As a result, the allosteric activation of phosphorylase b in vivo by nucleotides (AMP and IMP) must be lower than previously assumed, at least by a factor of 2. Thus, the association of phosphorylase with SR membranes will result in a more efficient cutoff of glycogenolysis after muscle contraction ceases. The association of AMP deaminase with SR membranes (Cuenda et al., 1994Cuenda A. Henao F. Nogues M. Gutiérrez-Merino C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1194: 35-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) should also contribute to this end since this will result in even further decreases in the local AMP concentration near phosphorylase b bound to SR membranes. Inhibition of phosphorylase b was produced by SR membranes, but not by other membrane preparations, such as erythrocyte membranes, or by liposomes prepared from lipids extracted from these membranes (Cuenda et al., 1991Cuenda A. Centeno F. Gutiérrez-Merino C. FEBS Lett. 1991; 283: 273-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar; data not shown). Therefore, the inhibition of phosphorylase b by SR membranes must be caused by its interaction with a non-lipid component of SR membranes. In spite of the high content of Ca2+-ATPase in SR membranes, purified Ca2+-ATPase reconstituted with egg lecithin or endogenous SR lipids failed to produce inhibition of phosphorylase (data not shown). SR membrane preparations contain 32 ± 10 μg of glycogen/mg of protein, enriched in linear polysaccharide fragments with respect to glycogen purified from skeletal muscle (see “Materials and Methods” and Wanson and Drochmans, 1968Wanson J.C. Drochmans P. J. Cell Biol. 1968; 38: 130-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). It is likely that this glycogen is tightly bound to the glycogen-targeting subunit of protein phosphatase-1, PP1G, a protein component of the SR membranes (Hubbard and Cohen, 1993Hubbard M.J. Cohen P. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1993; 18: 172-177Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). Because treatment of SR membranes with α-amylase promotes dissociation of phosphorylase b from the SR membrane (Wanson and Drochmans, 1972Wanson J.C. Drochmans P. J. Cell Biol. 1972; 54: 206-224Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar; this paper), we considered the possibility that the inhibition of phosphorylase is a consequence of binding to linear polysaccharide fragments tightly associated with SR membranes. This hypothesis is supported by the following experimental results reported in this paper. 1) The inhibition of the activity of purified phosphorylase b by SR membranes is strongly potentiated by incubation of SR membranes in a medium containing all the components required for polysaccharide synthesis by the phosphorylase associated with these membranes. In addition, the spectral characteristics of the I2-polysaccharide complex showed that the polysaccharide synthesized is an α-amylose type. 2) The Vmax for purified phosphorylase b with α-amylose as substrate (7 ± 1 IU) is only 25% of the Vmax with glycogen (28 ± 3 IU). With starch, the Vmax (16 ± 2 IU) is about half the Vmax with glycogen, and it is close to the activity obtained for phosphorylase b associated with SR membrane preparations (12 ± 6 IU). 3) Endogenous phosphorylase b associated with SR membranes has a K0.5(AMP) severalfold higher than that for purified phosphorylase b with glycogen as substrate. This is also seen with purified phosphorylase b when α-amylose or starch is used as substrate instead of glycogen. The simplest hypothesis of how phosphorylase b binds to the SR membranes in vitro is that it initially associates with glycogen particles on the membrane, which act as anchoring points until new binding sites are formed by the elongation of the polysaccharide. Light scattering studies show that the SR membranes preferentially associate with low branched polysaccharides,2 and this is consistent with the fact that glycogen associated with the SR membranes has long end chains with a mean length of 16-18 glucose units (Wanson and Drochmans, 1968Wanson J.C. Drochmans P. J. Cell Biol. 1968; 38: 130-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Since the Vmax for phosphorylase b is much lower when α-amylose is used as substrate instead of glycogen, binding to the SR membranes results in a high level of inhibition of phosphorylase activity measured in the presence of glycogen. From the results obtained with purified phosphorylase b and α-amylose as substrate, a maximum inhibition of 75-80% should be expected after a long preincubation of the SR membranes with the assay medium, which allows for a large elongation (through α-1,4-glycosidic bonds) of the end chains of the glycogen associated with the SR membranes. The maximum inhibition experimentally measured (80-90%) is in good agreement with this prediction. Neither the Ca2+ dependence nor the Vmax for the Ca2+ pumping activity of SR membranes mediated by the Ca2+-ATPase is altered by this association. Values were obtained from titrations with glycogen, Pi, AMP, or IMP at 30°C in 10 mM magnesium acetate, 0.63 mM NADP+, 50 mM imidazole (pH 6.9), 25 μg of phosphoglucomutase, and 15 μg of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase plus phosphorylase b (1 μg/ml) or SR membranes (30-50 μg of protein/ml). We gratefully acknowledge Dr. Dario Alessi for critical reading of the manuscript and suggestions.

An uncharacterized minor transient product, observed in our earlier studies of substrate turnover by the E48Q mutant of Rhodospirillum rubrum ribulose-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (Lee, E. H., Harpel, M. R., Chen, Y.-R., and Hartman, F. C.(1993) J. Biol. Chem. 268, 26583-26591), becomes a major product when it is trapped and stabilized with borate as an additive to the reaction mixture. Chemical characterization establishes this novel product as D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose 1,5-bisphosphate, thereby demonstrating oxidation of the C-3 hydroxyl of D-ribulose 1,5-bisphosphate to a carbonyl. As the formation of the novel oxidation product is oxygen-dependent and generates hydrogen peroxide, its precursor must be a peroxy derivative of ribulose bisphosphate. Thus, discovery of the dicarbonyl bisphosphate lends direct support to the long standing, but heretofore unproven, postulate that the normal pathway for oxidative cleavage of ribulose bisphosphate by the wild-type enzyme entails a peroxy intermediate. Our results also suggest that stabilization of the peroxy intermediate by the wild-type enzyme promotes carbon-carbon scission as opposed to elimination of hydrogen peroxide.
