H., Harpel, M. R., Chen, Y.-R., and Hartman, F. C.(1993) J. Biol. Chem. 268, 26583-26591), becomes a major product when it is trapped and stabilized with borate as an additive to the reaction mixture. Chemical characterization establishes this novel product as D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose 1,5-bisphosphate, thereby demonstrating oxidation of the C-3 hydroxyl of D-ribulose 1,5-bisphosphate to a carbonyl. As the formation of the novel oxidation product is oxygen-dependent and generates hydrogen peroxide, its precursor must be a peroxy derivative of ribulose bisphosphate. Thus, discovery of the dicarbonyl bisphosphate lends direct support to the long standing, but heretofore unproven, postulate that the normal pathway for oxidative cleavage of ribulose bisphosphate by the wild-type enzyme entails a peroxy intermediate. Our results also suggest that stabilization of the peroxy intermediate by the wild-type enzyme promotes carbon-carbon scission as opposed to elimination of hydrogen peroxide. INTRODUCTIONBecause of its inherent inefficiency and its dual activities of biosynthetic carboxylation and biodegradative oxygenation of RuBP1, 1The abbreviations used are: RuBPD-ribulose 1,5-bisphosphatePGA3-phospho-D-glyceratePGyc2-phosphoglycolateRubiscoD-ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenaseXuBPD-xylulose 1,5-bisphosphateBicineN,N-bis(2-hydroxyethyl)glycine. D-ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (EC 4.1.1.39) is viewed as a fulcrum of biomass yields (see Ref. 1Hartman F.C. Harpel M.R. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 197-234Crossref PubMed Google Scholar for a review of Rubisco). Catalytic turnover of RuBP by Rubisco involves several unstable intermediates (Fig. 1): the 2,3-enediolate of RuBP (I), 2-carboxyl-3-ketoarabinitol 1,5-bisphosphate (and its hydrate) (II, III), and the C2 carbanion of PGA (VI) all in the carboxylation pathway and the same enediolate (I) and a putative C-2 peroxy derivative of RuBP (and its hydrate) (IV, V) in the oxygenation pathway. Questions then arise as to how the enzyme mitigates decomposition of labile intermediates and ensures normal throughput of substrate. We are attempting to address these questions by use of site-directed mutagenesis to probe potentially relevant structural elements as suggested by the x-ray structure (2Schneider G. Lindqvist Y. Brändén C.-I. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 1992; 21: 119-143Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). One such structural element is a mobile segment of the N-terminal domain of the interfacial active site, which includes the catalytically facilitative residue Glu-48. In this report, we show that the E48Q mutant of the Rhodospirillum rubrum enzyme, although severely impaired in carboxylase activity, catalyzes the oxidation of RuBP to D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose 1,5-bisphosphate. As a signature of the corresponding peroxy derivative of RuBP, this novel dicarbonyl product provides the most direct evidence to date for a peroxy intermediate in the normal oxygenase pathway as first invoked in pioneering studies of Lorimer et al.(3Lorimer G.H. Andrews T.J. Tolbert N.E. Biochemistry. 1973; 12: 18-23Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar).EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESCommon laboratory reagents and biological materials were procured at the highest level of purity readily available. [1-3H]RuBP and [5-3H]RuBP were synthesized from commercial [2-3H]glucose and [6-3H]glucose, respectively, by a published procedure (4Kuehn G.D. Hsu T.-C. Biochem. J. 1978; 175: 909-912Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). The E48Q mutant of R. rubrum Rubisco was isolated from transformed Escherichia coli MV1190 as described earlier (5Lee E.H. Harpel M.R. Chen Y.-R. Hartman F.C. J. Biol Chem. 1993; 268: 26583-26591Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and was homogeneous, as judged by Coomassie Blue staining of SDS-polyacrylamide gels. The concentration of the mutant protein was based on the extinction coefficient at 280 nm of the wild-type enzyme (A of 1.2 for 1 mg/ml) (6Schloss J.V. Phares E.F. Long M.V. Norton I.L. Stringer C.D. Hartman F.C. Methods Enzymol. 1982; 90: 522-528Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar).Analyses of turnover products derived from [1-3H]RuBP or [5-3H]RuBP followed the published anion-exchange method (7Harpel M.R. Lee E.H. Hartman F.C. Anal. Biochem. 1993; 209: 367-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). Detailed reaction conditions are provided in the figure and table legends. Except where noted, all reactions were carried out at room temperature and included air-saturated concentrations of O2 (255 μM).RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONThe active sites of Rubisco are interfacial (8Larimer F.W. Lee E.H. Mural R.J. Soper T.S. Hartman F.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 15327-15329Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), being comprised of the β/α-barrel domain from one subunit and the N-terminal domain of the adjacent identical subunit (9Andersson I. Knight S. Schneider G. Lindqvist Y. Lundqvist T. Brändén C.-I. Lorimer G.H. Nature. 1989; 337: 229-234Crossref Scopus (187) Google Scholar). During catalysis, the active sites are apparently occluded by flexible segments (loop 6 from the β/α-barrel domain and helix B from the N-terminal domain) that extend over the mouth of the barrel and approach each other. In this closed conformation, visualized directly in the three-dimensional structure of the exchange-resistant complex of activated enzyme and the reaction-intermediate analogue 2-carboxyarabinitol 1,5-bisphosphate, active-site Lys-329 (located at the apex of loop 6) and active-site Glu-48 (located at the C-terminal end of helix B) engage in intersubunit electrostatic interaction (10Knight S. Andersson I. Brändén C.-I. J. Mol. Biol. 1990; 215: 113-160Crossref PubMed Scopus (278) Google Scholar).We have used site-directed mutagenesis to assess the roles of the intersubunit salt bridge and the residues therein (5Lee E.H. Harpel M.R. Chen Y.-R. Hartman F.C. J. Biol Chem. 1993; 268: 26583-26591Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Harpel M.R. Hartman F.C. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 5553-5561Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), as well as loop 6 per se(12Larson E.M. Larimer F.W. Hartman F.C. Biochemistry. 1995; 34 (in press)Google Scholar), in intermediate stabilization and control of ligand ingress to and egress from the active site. Prior characterization (5Lee E.H. Harpel M.R. Chen Y.-R. Hartman F.C. J. Biol Chem. 1993; 268: 26583-26591Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) of the E48Q mutant showed that Glu-48 enhances the carboxylation rate by 200-fold and that disruption of the salt bridge decreases the carboxylation/oxygenation partitioning ratio and leads to extensive misprotonation of the intermediate enediolate at C-3 to form XuBP, a poor alternate substrate for Rubisco. Whereas this error occurs only once per 400 turnovers with the native spinach enzyme (13Edmondson D.L. Kane H.J. Andrews T.J. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 62-66Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar) and is undetectable with the wild-type R. rubrum enzyme (5Lee E.H. Harpel M.R. Chen Y.-R. Hartman F.C. J. Biol Chem. 1993; 268: 26583-26591Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), misprotonation and carboxylation of the enediolate occur at similar rates with the E48Q mutant. In addition to XuBP, an uncharacterized minor side product (denoted unknown in Fig. 2) was also formed during turnover of RuBP by E48Q.Figure 2:Anion-exchange chromatographic analyses of radioactive products generated from [1-3H]RuBP by E48Q. [1-3H]RuBP (250 μM) and E48Q (1 mg/ml) were incubated in 0.5 ml of pH 8.0 buffer (50 mM Bicine, 66 mM NaHCO3, 10 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM 2-mercaptoethanol, and 2% glycerol). At 30 s (panel A), 10 min (panel B), and 60 min (panel C), 100-μl aliquots of the reaction mixture were quenched with 1% (w/v) SDS, deproteinated (Amicon Centricon-10 filters), and chromatographed at pH 8.0 on a MonoQ anion exchanger (Pharmacia Biotech Inc. HR5/5, 5 × 50 mm) with a gradient (depicted only in panel A) of NH4Cl containing a fixed concentration of 10 mM sodium borate. Radioactivity was monitored continuously by flow-through radiometric detection (IN/US β-RAM). Ƭ values were calculated from the ratio of radioactive peak areas for PGA and PGyc (corresponding to the kinetic partitioning between carboxylation and oxygenation) according to the relationship, Ƭ = (vc/v0)/([CO2]/[O2]) (14Laing W.A. Ogren W.L. Hageman R.H. Plant Physiol. 1974; 54: 678-685Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Panel D depicts an identical, 60-min reaction mixture (100 μl), except for the inclusion of 80 mM borate. Analysis of a third reaction mixture (300 μl) (30 min), which was identical to that shown in panel D but freed of oxygen by inclusion of protocatechuate and protocatechuate 3,4-dioxygenase (7Harpel M.R. Lee E.H. Hartman F.C. Anal. Biochem. 1993; 209: 367-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar), is shown in panel E. Unk, unknown.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Curiously, the carboxylation/oxygenation partitioning ratio (VcK0/VcKƬ) (14Laing W.A. Ogren W.L. Hageman R.H. Plant Physiol. 1974; 54: 678-685Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) declines during progression of [1-3H]RuBP utilization by E48Q. For example, the Ƭ value provided by the [3-3H]PGA/[2-3H]PGyc ratio declines from 2.0 at early stages of RuBP utilization to 0.3 at completion, with PGA and PGyc as the sole end products (Fig. 2, A-C). By contrast, the Ƭ value of the wild-type enzyme is about 11 (7Harpel M.R. Lee E.H. Hartman F.C. Anal. Biochem. 1993; 209: 367-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 15Jordan D.B. Ogren W.L. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1983; 227: 425-433Crossref PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar) and is independent of the extent of RuBP turnover. Thus, a transient product (XuBP or the unknown) must be partitioned differently than RuBP by the mutant enzyme. Since XuBP and RuBP should yield the same enediolate, the unknown presumably accounts for the Ƭ dependence on the extent of RuBP turnover. This contention is supported by inclusion of borate in the reaction mixture, thereby trapping the unknown and retarding its subsequent processing (Fig. 2D). Under these conditions, 35% of the input RuBP is converted to the unknown, and the Ƭ value is raised to 1.6 (i.e. disproportionately less PGyc is formed when processing of the unknown is blocked). The unknown is not formed in the absence of oxygen (Fig. 2E).Its late elution position from the anion-exchange column, in conjunction with the oxygen requirement for its formation, indicated that the unknown might be an oxidized analogue of RuBP with both phosphate groups intact. A compound fitting this description is D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose-1,5-bisphosphate. Such a dicarbonyl bisphosphate should undergo oxidative cleavage by hydrogen peroxide to form PGyc and PGA, condensation with o-phenylenediamine to form a dioxime, and reduction with sodium borohydride to form ribitol bisphosphate, arabinitol bisphosphate, and xylitol bisphosphate in molar ratios of 1:2:1 (Fig. 3). Purified unknown (Fig. 4), derived from [1-3H]RuBP, was subjected to each of these chemical treatments, and the resulting products were identified by anion-exchange chromatography. As predicted, cleavage of the unknown with hydrogen peroxide gave PGyc as the only labeled product (Fig. 4B), condensation with o-phenylenediamine gave complete conversion to a less acidic compound (Fig. 4C), and borohydride reduction gave an approximate 1:2:1 mixture of the three pentitol bisphosphates (Fig. 4D). These experiments were repeated with purified unknown derived from [5-3H]RuBP. Chromatographic profiles were identical to those shown in Fig. 4 with the exception of PGA rather than PGyc as the only labeled product of oxidative cleavage (data not shown). We conclude that the unknown is D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose-1,5-bisphosphate and stress that neither the corresponding 2,4-pentodiulose nor any of the pentulose isomers would exhibit the observed chemical properties.Figure 3:Predicted reactions of D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose 1,5-bisphosphate with hydrogen peroxide, o-phenylenediamine, or sodium borohydride.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Figure 4:Characterization of D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose 1,5-bisphosphate. The dicarbonyl bisphosphate (55 μmol) was isolated by MonoQ chromatography of a reaction mixture consisting of [1-3H]RuBP and E48Q as described in the legend for Fig. 2D. Rechromatography on MonoQ of a portion of the isolated material demonstrates its purity (panel A). Another portion of the isolated material (7 μM) was treated with 1 M hydrogen peroxide in 10 mM sodium borate (pH 8.0) for 1 h. The reaction mixture was quenched with 9 volumes of H2O followed by the addition of 2,000 units of catalase. Following deproteination, the sample was chromatographed (panel B). A third portion of the dicarbonyl bisphosphate (4 μM) in 50 mM Bicine (pH 8.0) was incubated with 100 mMo-phenylenediamine for 1 h prior to chromatography (panel C). A fourth portion of the dicarbonyl bisphosphate (7 μM) was treated at 2°C with 10 mM NaBH4 for 15 min in a pH 8.0 buffer containing 50 mM Bicine, 85 mM NaCl, 120 mM NH4Cl, 10 mM MgCl2, 66 mM NaHCO3, and 1 mM EDTA and chromatographed subsequent to the addition of glucose (20 mM) to consume excess borohydride (panel D); peak assignments are based on standards (7Harpel M.R. Lee E.H. Hartman F.C. Anal. Biochem. 1993; 209: 367-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). A fifth portion of the dicarbonyl bisphosphate (7.8 μM) was incubated with E48Q (1 mg/ml) for 24 h in the pH 8.0 Bicine buffer described in the legend for Fig. 2, quenched with 1% (w/v) SDS, deproteinated, and chromatographed (panel E). Unk, unknown.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)In our earlier study (5Lee E.H. Harpel M.R. Chen Y.-R. Hartman F.C. J. Biol Chem. 1993; 268: 26583-26591Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we tentatively (and erroneously) identified this compound as 3-ketoarabinitol 1,5-bisphosphate, which would be formed by misprotonation of the enediolate at C-2 and has indeed been reported as a minor product with wild-type spinach Rubisco (16Zhu G. Jensen R.G. Plant Physiol. 1991; 97: 1354-1358Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Our misidentification was based on borohydride reduction in which arabinitol 1,5-bisphosphate was the only significant product. The reduction was carried out at pH 8.0 in 120 mM NH4Cl containing 10 mM sodium borate, i.e. the solvent composition for the compound as eluted from the MonoQ column. We have confirmed that reduction of D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose 1,5-bisphosphate under these conditions yields arabinitol 1,5-bisphosphate almost exclusively. In contrast, at higher ionic strengths as used in the present study and described in the legend for Fig. 4D, the reduction leads to the statistically predicted ratio of the three pentitol bisphosphates. We conclude that at relatively low ionic strengths complexation of borate by the dicarbonyl compound results in stereoselective borohydride reduction.The formation of PGA and PGyc as the sole end products of RuBP turnover by E48Q and the disproportionate increase in labeled PGyc (from [1-3H]RuBP as substrate) as turnover progresses prompt the deductions that D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose-1,5-bisphosphate must serve as an alternate substrate for the mutant enzyme and that PGyc must be a product. Incubation of the isolated [1-3H]dicarbonyl bisphosphate with E48Q indeed gives PGyc as the only labeled product (Fig. 4E), whereas turnover of the isolated [5-3H]dicarbonyl bisphosphate identifies PGA as the other cleavage product (data not shown). Although we have not studied the enzyme-catalyzed turnover of the dicarbonyl bisphosphate in detail, the process is oxygen-dependent (data not shown) and thus appears similar to oxidative cleavage of the compound by hydrogen peroxide.Oxidation of RuBP by molecular oxygen to form a 2,3-pentodiulose can only occur via a C-2 peroxy intermediate (Fig. 5), identical to that proposed in the normal oxygenase pathway of Rubisco catalysis leading to PGA and PGyc (3Lorimer G.H. Andrews T.J. Tolbert N.E. Biochemistry. 1973; 12: 18-23Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). Although this earlier postulate was chemically sound and was supported by the appearance in PGyc of one atom of oxygen derived from molecular oxygen and also supported by 17O-EPR (17Brändén R. Nilsson T. Styring S. Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 4378-4382Crossref Scopus (15) Google Scholar), proof has been lacking due to inherent instability of the putative intermediate. Our discovery of D-glycero-2,3-pentodiulose 1,5-bisphosphate provides a direct signature of the oxygenase intermediate and thus confirms the proposed pathway for oxidative cleavage of RuBP by Rubisco. Our studies also illustrate alternate fates for the peroxy intermediate: carbon-carbon scission as promoted by wild-type enzyme or elimination of hydrogen peroxide as promoted by E48Q. Formation of hydrogen peroxide concomitant with the dicarbonyl bisphosphate has been verified by use of peroxidase and catalase (Table I). Thus, the demonstrated chemistry is reminiscent of flavin hydroperoxides, which dissociate to hydrogen peroxide and oxidized flavin (see Ref. 18Massey V. J. Biol. After 1 h, one-third of each reaction mixture was mixed with an equal volume of 2 M sodium acetate to lower the pH to 5.4 and then assayed for peroxide; the remainder of each reaction mixture was quenched with 1% (w/v) SDS, deproteinated, and chromatographed. Histochemical study indicated that the posterior pituitary possesses numerous microvesicles (MVs) containing synaptophysin, a marker protein specific for brain synaptic vesicles (Navone, F., Di Gioia, G., Jahn, R., Browning, M., Greengard, P., and De Camilli, P. (1989) J. Cell Biol. 109, 3425–2433). By monitoring cross-reactivity with anti-synaptophysin antibody, the MVs were highly purified from bovine posterior pituitaries by a combination of differential and sucrose density gradient centrifugations. The purified MVs had an average diameter of about 60 nm and were associated with synaptophysin as revealed by immunoelectron microscopy. The vesicles contained ATPase activity partially sensitive to bafilomycin A1 and to vanadate. The membrane fraction immunoisolated with anti-synaptophysin antibody also exhibited similar ATPase activity. The two ATPases could be purified separately; the vanadate-sensitive enzyme was identified as a 115-kDa polypeptide immunochemically similar to chromaffin granule P-ATPase (forming phosphoenzyme intermediate), and the bafilomycin A1-sensitive ATPase showed essentially the same properties as those of vacuolar type H+-ATPases. Upon addition of ATP, the MVs formed an electrochemical gradient of protons and took up norepinephrine in a reserpine-sensitive manner, indicating the presence of secondary monoamine transporter coupled with vacuolar type H+-ATPase. No uptake of L-glutamate, γ-aminobutyrate, glycine, or acetylcholine was observed. The identification of MVs as organelles responsible for storage of monoamines is important for understanding the physiological function of the posterior pituitary. Histochemical study indicated that the posterior pituitary possesses numerous microvesicles (MVs) containing synaptophysin, a marker protein specific for brain synaptic vesicles (Navone, F., Di Gioia, G., Jahn, R., Browning, M., Greengard, P., and De Camilli, P. (1989) J. Cell Biol. 109, 3425–2433). By monitoring cross-reactivity with anti-synaptophysin antibody, the MVs were highly purified from bovine posterior pituitaries by a combination of differential and sucrose density gradient centrifugations. The purified MVs had an average diameter of about 60 nm and were associated with synaptophysin as revealed by immunoelectron microscopy. The vesicles contained ATPase activity partially sensitive to bafilomycin A1 and to vanadate. The membrane fraction immunoisolated with anti-synaptophysin antibody also exhibited similar ATPase activity. The two ATPases could be purified separately; the vanadate-sensitive enzyme was identified as a 115-kDa polypeptide immunochemically similar to chromaffin granule P-ATPase (forming phosphoenzyme intermediate), and the bafilomycin A1-sensitive ATPase showed essentially the same properties as those of vacuolar type H+-ATPases. Upon addition of ATP, the MVs formed an electrochemical gradient of protons and took up norepinephrine in a reserpine-sensitive manner, indicating the presence of secondary monoamine transporter coupled with vacuolar type H+-ATPase. No uptake of L-glutamate, γ-aminobutyrate, glycine, or acetylcholine was observed. The identification of MVs as organelles responsible for storage of monoamines is important for understanding the physiological function of the posterior pituitary. The posterior pituitary contains nerve endings of hypothalamic neurons. Two kinds of vesicles have been identified in the nerve endings: dense-cored secretory granules with diameters of 100–300 nm (neurosecretory granules) and microvesicles (MVs) 1The abbreviations used are: MV, synaptophysin-containing microvesicle; C12E9, polyoxylethylene 9-laurylether; GABA, γ-aminobutyrate; MES, 2(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid; MOPS, morpholinepropanesulfonic acid; NE, norepinephrine; [3H]NE, DL-[7–3H]norepinephrine; P-ATPase, ATPase forming phosphorylated intermediate; Tricine, N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylglycine; V-ATPase, vacuolar H+-ATPase; V1, an extrinsic sector of V-ATPase; SCH28080, 2-methyl-8(phenylmethoxyl)imidazo(1′-2α)pyridene-3-acetonitrile.1The abbreviations used are: MV, synaptophysin-containing microvesicle; C12E9, polyoxylethylene 9-laurylether; GABA, γ-aminobutyrate; MES, 2(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid; MOPS, morpholinepropanesulfonic acid; NE, norepinephrine; [3H]NE, DL-[7–3H]norepinephrine; P-ATPase, ATPase forming phosphorylated intermediate; Tricine, N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylglycine; V-ATPase, vacuolar H+-ATPase; V1, an extrinsic sector of V-ATPase; SCH28080, 2-methyl-8(phenylmethoxyl)imidazo(1′-2α)pyridene-3-acetonitrile. with average diameters of about 60 nm (1Tweedle C.D. Prog. Brain Res. 1983; 60: 259-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The neurosecretory granules are responsible for storage and secretion of peptide hormones into the blood stream (2Russell J.T. Curr. Top. Membr. Transp. 1987; 31: 277-312Crossref Scopus (9) Google Scholar) and have an acidic internal pH (3Russell J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 9496-9507Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4Scherman D. Nordmann J. Henry J-P. Biochemistry. 1982; 21: 687-694Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) maintained by vacuolar H+-ATPase (V-ATPase) (5Moriyama Y. Futai M. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 9165-9169Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The microvesicles were first postulated to be vesicles formed during membrane recycling of neurosecretory granules fused with plasma membranes upon exocytosis (6Gerschenfeld H.M. Tramezzani J.H. de Robertis E. Endocrinology. 1960; 66: 741-762Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Later, their morphological similarities to brain synaptic vesicles were reported (7Douglas W.W. Nagasawa J. Schulz R. Mem. Soc. Endocrinol. 1970; 19: 353-377Google Scholar, 8Broadwell R.D. Cataldo A.M. Balin B.J. J. Comp. Neurol. 1984; 228: 155-167Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 9Nordmann J.J. Morris J.F. Nature. 1976; 261: 723-725Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 10Morris J.F. Nordmann J.J. Neuroscience. 1980; 5: 639-649Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). More recently, Navone et al. (11Navone F. Di Gioia G. Jahn R. Browning M. Greengard P. De Camilli P. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 109: 3425-3433Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) in histochemical studies demonstrated the presence of synaptic vesicle proteins (i.e. synapsin I and synaptophysin) in microvesicles. Furthermore, Walch-Solimena et al. (12Walch-Solimena C. Takei K. Marek K.L. Midyett K. Sudhof T.C. De Camilli P. Jahn R. J. Neurosci. 1993; 13: 3895-3903Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) found synaptotagmin in these vesicles. These results suggest that the microvesicles have proteins necessary for exocytosis and may be involved in a novel type of neurosecretion. However, the detailed properties of these vesicles are unknown, because they could not be purified previously for biochemical studies. In this study, we established a procedure for isolating microvesicles from bovine posterior pituitary and found that these vesicles accumulate norepinephrine depending on an electrochemical proton gradient established by V-ATPase. Interestingly, these microvesicles did not accumulate other transmitters such as L-glutamate or GABA, in contrast to synaptic vesicles prepared from a brain homogenate. These studies indicate that microvesicles participate in storage and secretion of NE from the posterior pituitary. [3H]NE (24.7 Ci/mmol), l-[3H]glutamate (17.25 Ci/mmol), [3H]GABA (36.8 Ci/mmol), [3H]glycine (22.5 Ci/mmol), [14C]acetylcholine (3.6 mCi/mmol), 125I-protein A (0.5 mCi/mg protein) and 126I-antimouse IgG (87.7 Ci/ml), and [γ-32P]ATP (30 Ci/mmol) were purchased from DuPont NEN, Amersham Corp., or ICN-Biochemicals. Other chemicals used in this study were of the highest grade commercially available. Phosphatidylserine, ouabain, and SCH28080 were obtained from Avanti Polar Lipids, Sigma, and Dr. George Sachs, respectively. V-ATPase and vanadate-sensitive ATPase were purified from bovine adrenal chromaffin granules (13Moriyama Y. Nelson N. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 9175-9180Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 14Moriyama Y. Nelson N. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 8521-8527Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Antibodies against V-ATPase subunits, vanadate-sensitive ATPase, and rat mitochondrial Fl-ATPase were raised by injecting the individual proteins into albino rabbits. Monoclonal antibody against synaptophysin was prepared as described previously (15Obata K. Nishiya H. Fujita S.C. Shirao T. Inoue H. Uchizono K. Brain Res. 1986; 375: 37-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). All steps for purifications of MVs and ATPases were carried out at 4 °C. Twenty bovine posterior pituitaries were kept in ice and used within a few hours after their isolation at a local slaughterhouse. They were washed twice, suspended in 50 ml of SME buffer (20 mit MOPS-Tris (pH 7.0) containing 0.3 m sucrose, 5 mm EDTA, 5 ng/ml leupeptin, and 5 µg/ml pepstatin A), and homogenized by a few strokes of a Dounce homogenizer. The homogenate was centrifuged at 1,000 × g for 10 min, and the supernatant was centrifuged at 17,000 × g for 15 min. The resultant pellet (light mitochondrial fraction) was washed once and suspended in SME buffer (5 ml), and an aliquot of 1 ml was applied to a continuous sucrose density gradient (8 ml of 0.4–2 m sucrose containing 5 µg/ml pepstatin A and leupeptin). After centrifugation at 78,000 × g for 3 h, three distinct bands were obtained: upper (white), middle (brown), and bottom (white) bands containing vesicles with synaptophysin, mitochondria, and neurosecretory granules, respectively. The upper band was collected (about 3 ml in total) and rapidly diluted into 150 ml of 5 mm MOPS-Tris (pH 7.0) containing 5 µg/ml pepstatin A and leupeptin. The solution was kept on ice for 30 min and centrifuged at 17,000 × g for 15 min. The supernatant was carefully withdrawn by pipette and recentrifuged at 140,000 × g for 1 h. The transparent pellet (crude MV fraction) was suspended in SME buffer, diluted 1.5-fold with distilled water (total volume, about 1 ml), applied to a second sucrose gradient (4 ml of 0.3–1.0 m sucrose containing protease inhibitors), and centrifuged at 140,000 × g for 2 h. The upper band was collected, diluted with SME buffer, and centrifuged at 140,000 × g for 1 h. The pellet (purified MVs) was suspended in SME and stored at –70 °C until use. The MV fraction (2.5 mg protein/ml; 2 ml) was supplemented with 1% C12E9, incubated for 5 min, and centrifuged at 200,000 × g for 40 min. The supernatant was diluted 2-fold with 10 mm MES-Tricine buffer (pH 7.0) containing 5 mm monothioglycerol and 0.1% C12E9 (buffer A). Solid ammonium sulfate was added to the supernatant to 20% saturation, and the mixture was centrifuged at 200,000 × g for 15 min. The fluffy white precipitate rich in V-ATPase was suspended in buffer A, and 1 ml of the suspension was applied to a continuous glycerol density gradient (5 ml, 10–30%) in buffer A. After centrifugation at 330,000 × g for 5 h, fractions containing V-ATPase were pooled and stored at –70 °C. The 20% ammonium sulfate supernatant was mixed with solid ammonium sulfate to give 40% saturation and centrifuged at 250,000 × g for 20 min. The supernatant was brought to 50% saturation of ammonium sulfate and centrifuged at 250,000 × g for 20 min. The floating precipitate, rich in vanadate-sensitive ATPase, was suspended in buffer A (about 1 mg of protein/ml) and stored at –70 °C. MVs (about 40 µg of protein) were suspended in 0.5 ml of 20 mm MOPS-Tris (pH 7.0) containing 0.2 m sucrose, 0.1 m KCl, 2 mm magnesium acetate, and 5 mm ATP-Tris. The uptake of [3H]NE into MVs was assayed at 30 °C by adding 5 µm [3H]NE (2 µCi). Aliquots (150 µl) were taken at intervals and applied to 0.45-µm Millipore filters (type HA). Their radioactivities were counted in a liquid scintillation counter after extensive washing (16Moriyama Y. Maeda M. Futai M. J. Biochem. 1990; 108: 689-693Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Uptakes of other radiolabeled transmitters (0.1 mm) were assayed essentially by the same procedures as described above except that KCl concentration was reduced to 4 mm for glutamate uptake. Conventional and immunoelectron microscopy (17Tokuyasu K.T. Histochem. J. 1989; 21: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (359) Google Scholar) and other procedures (18Moriyama Y. Nelson N. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 18445-18450Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) were as described previously. Cross-reactivity with anti-synaptophysin antibody was used in preparation of MVs from bovine posterior pituitaries. The final preparation showed 18-fold enrichment of MVs over the post-nuclear supernatant with about 50% recovery (about 1 mg of protein from 20 pituitaries) (Table I). The key purification step was the first sucrose gradient centrifugation in which MVs were clearly separated from neurosecretory granules (Fig. 1): MVs contained synaptophysin but not neurophysin (a marker protein for neurosecretory granules). The purified MVs were small vesicles with an average diameter of about 60 nm (Fig. 2A) and were recognized by anti-synaptophysin antibody (Fig. 2B). The purified MV fraction contained essentially no vasopressin, F0F1-ATPase, N-acetyl-β-d-glucosaminidase, or adenosine monophosphatase (Table I). Cytochrome b561, which is a membrane component of neurosecretory granules (12Walch-Solimena C. Takei K. Marek K.L. Midyett K. Sudhof T.C. De Camilli P. Jahn R. J. Neurosci. 1993; 13: 3895-3903Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), was not detectable immunologically (data not shown). Consistent with the presence of V-ATPase, about half of the ATPase activity in the purified MV fraction was inhibited by bafilomycin A1 (70 nM), a specific inhibitor of V-ATPase (19Bowman E-J. Siebers A. Altendorf K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 7972-7976Crossref PubMed Scopus (1589) Google Scholar) (Fig. 3A, MVs). Furthermore, about 60% of the ATPase activity in the purified MV fraction was inhibited by vanadate (0.1 min), an inhibitor for P-ATPase (20O'Neal S.G. Rhoads D.B. Racker E. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1979; 89: 845-850Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar), and the ATPase activity was inhibited almost completely by bafilomycin A1 plus vanadate. These results suggested that two kinds of ATPase (V-ATPase and vanadate-sensitive ATPase) are present in the vesicles. Both ATPases were also detectable in MVs precipitated with anti-synaptophysin antibody (Table II).Table IIATPase activity in the immunoprecipitatet MVs fractionAdditionATPase activitymilliunits/assayNone1.19Bafilomycin A1 (75 nm)0.65Vanadate (0.5 mm)0.72Bafilomycin + vanadate0.23 Open table in a new tab After solubilization of MV membrane proteins with C12E9, the V-ATPase and vanadate-sensitive ATPase could be separated by ammonium sulfate fractionation; V-ATPase was mainly recovered at 20% ammonium sulfate saturation, and vanadate-sensitive ATPase was mainly recovered at 40–50% saturation (Fig. 3A). The vanadate-sensitive ATPase activity was co-purified with a 115-kDa polypeptide that was recognized by antibody against P-ATPase from chromaffin granules (Fig. 3B). The purified vanadate-sensitive ATPase (40–50% ammonium sulfate fraction) was inhibited 81, 63, and 95% by N-ethylmaleimide (1 mm), calcium chloride (0.5 mm), and sodium fluoride 150 µm), respectively. Furthermore, phosphatidylserine (10 µg/ml) stimulated the ATPase activity 2-fold. However, bafilomycin A, (10 µm), ouabain (0.2 mm), or SCH28080 (0.1 mm) had no effect. These properties of the ATPase from MVs were different from those of known ion-translocating P-ATPases but were similar to those of chromaffin granule P-ATPase (14Moriyama Y. Nelson N. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 8521-8527Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Moriyama Y. Nelson N. Maeda M. Futai M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 286: 252-256Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). The V-ATPase in MVs was purified further by glycerol density gradient centrifugation. The final preparation exhibited a specific activity of 0.58 unit/mg of protein, which was about 4.5-fold higher than that of the membrane vesicles. The purified V-ATPase had essentially the same properties as V-ATPases from various mammalian sources (data not shown). A minor but interesting difference was that the apparent molecular size of the accessory subunit I of MVs (110 kDa) was slightly lower than that of a counterpart of chromaffin granules (115 kDa) (13Moriyama Y. Nelson N. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 9175-9180Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This may be due to the different degree of glycosylation of the subunit, since the subunit I polypeptide is a glycoprotein (22Nelson N. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1989; 21: 553-571Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 23Forgac M. Physiol. Rev. 1992; 69: 765-796Crossref Scopus (479) Google Scholar). Another possibility is that it is an isoform similar to the yeast subunit (24Manolson M.F. Wu B. Proteau D. Taillon B.E. Roberts B.T. Hoyt M.A. Jones E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 14064-14074Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The physiological function of V-ATPase is to establish an electrochemical gradient of protons across membranes for various organellar functions such as active transport of transmitters and protein degradation (22Nelson N. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1989; 21: 553-571Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 23Forgac M. Physiol. Rev. 1992; 69: 765-796Crossref Scopus (479) Google Scholar, 25Kanner B.I. Schuldiner S. CRC Crit. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 22: 1-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar). As in other organelles, the V-ATPase in MVs could form both a pH gradient (acidic inside) and a membrane potential (positive inside) upon addition of ATP (Fig 4, A and B, respectively); ATP-dependent fluorescence quenchings of acridine orange and oxonol-V were completely inhibited by the addition of bafilomycin A1, N-ethylmaleimide, or proton conductors such as 3,5-di-tert-butyl-4-hydroxybenzylidene malononitrile (1 µm) but insensitive to vanadate (0.5 mm), oligomycin (5 µg), azide (0.5 mm), and ouabain (0.5 mm). These results also confirmed that the electrochemical gradient was established by V-ATPase, but not by other ATPases such as vanadate-sensitive ATPase described above. We then investigated whether various transmitters are taken up by MVs coupled with V-ATPase. The MVs accumulated [3H]NE dependent on ATP, and this uptake was inhibited by bafilomycin A1, 3,5-di-tert-butyl-4-hydroxybenzylidene malononitrile, and reserpine (Fig. 5A), indicating that [3H]NE was taken up by the vesicular monoamine transporter, which was driven by an electrochemical gradient of protons established by V-ATPase. Other monoamines such as dopamine and serotonin were also taken up by MVs in a similar manner (not shown). The properties and the kinetics of the transport were comparable with those of monoamine transport in synaptic vesicles and chromaffin granules (25Kanner B.I. Schuldiner S. CRC Crit. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 22: 1-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar). Unlike synaptic vesicles prepared from brain, however, no detectable uptake of l-glutamate, GABA, glycine, or acetylcholine by MVs was observed (Fig. 5, B-F), suggesting the absence of transporters for these transmitters. Brain vesicles are from various neurons and, therefore, showed mixed transport activities of various neurotransmitters (25Kanner B.I. Schuldiner S. CRC Crit. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 22: 1-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar). Synaptophysin-containing microvesicles in various neuroendocrine cells such as adrenal chromaffin and pancreatic β cells have been identified histochemically (11Navone F. Di Gioia G. Jahn R. Browning M. Greengard P. De Camilli P. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 109: 3425-3433Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar, 27Annaert W.G. Llona I. Backer A.C. Jacob W.A. De Potter W.P. J. Neurochem. 1993; 60: 1746-1754Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 28Sudhof T. Jahn R. Neuron. 1991; 6: 665-677Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (431) Google Scholar). The detailed physiological function(s) of these vesicles has not been studied mainly because the vesicles could not be isolated; preparation of pure vesicles is essential to characterize their membrane proteins and transport and storage activities. In this study, we established for the first time a procedure for preparation of such vesicles (MVs) from posterior pituitary. Our simple method results in reasonably good recovery of MVs and can be applied to the purifications of similar microvesicles from other endocrine cells. The purified MVs were slightly larger than synaptic vesicles. Immunoblotting experiments indicated that the purified MV fraction contained synapsin I, synaptotagmin, synaptobrevin, marker proteins for synaptic vesicles (28Sudhof T. Jahn R. Neuron. 1991; 6: 665-677Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (431) Google Scholar), and also N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive fusion protein (29Tagaya M. Wilson D.W. Brunner M. Arango N. Rothman J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 2662-2666Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) (data not shown). These results confirmed previous histochemical studies (11Navone F. Di Gioia G. Jahn R. Browning M. Greengard P. De Camilli P. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 109: 3425-3433Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) and supported the idea that MVs possess proteins for vesicular transport. The presence of V-ATPase and vesicular monoamine transporter clearly indicated that MVs possess a system for storage of monoamines. Taken together, these results strongly suggested that MVs are responsible for secretion of monoamines from nerve endings in the posterior pituitary. MV-mediated secretion is a novel system of neurosecretion. Further studies on the mechanism of fusion of MVs with plasma membrane and exocytosis of monoamines will be important for understanding the physiological function of the posterior pituitary. Comparative studies on neurosecretory granules and MVs will also be fruitful because these are distinct organelles as discussed previously (9Nordmann J.J. Morris J.F. A. 1993; 90: 5317-5321Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar)). The GABA accumulated in β cells is extruded from the cells and modulated glucagon secretion from α cells (31Rorsman P. We suggest that microvesicles in endocrine cells are organelles having similar function to synaptic vesicles. We thank Dr. Nathan Nelson (Roche Institute of Molecular Biology, Nutley, NJ), Prof. K. Sobue (Osaka University), and Dr. M. Tagaya (Tokyo College of Pharmacy) for providing antibody against cytochrome b561, synapsin I, and NSF, respectively.

Addition of dithiothreitol (DTT) to the culture medium of Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells blocks transport of newly synthesized gp80 (clusterin, apolipoprotein J), a soluble marker protein for apical exocytosis in this epithelial cell line. In cells treated with DTT during pulse labeling, gp80 is retained in the endoplasmic reticulum. After removal of the reducing agent, gp80 is posttranslationally oxidized and secreted at the apical surface of MDCK cell monolayers. This demonstrates that when folded and oxidized posttranslationally, gp80 can acquire a conformation that exhibits sorting signals for vectorial targeting. In the continuous presence of DTT, the transepithelial electrical resistance of filter-grown monolayers is maintained for several hours, indicating the presence of functionally intact tight junctions. Under the same conditions, transport competent forms of gp80 mature within the Golgi complex and are secreted predominantly at the apical surface of MDCK monolayers. Furthermore, another secretory protein, the osteopontin-derived 20-kDa polypeptide, is targeted to the apical plasma membrane domain in the continuous presence of DTT. These results suggest that the apical sorting machinery in MDCK cells functions independent of the redox state of the secretory pathway.

The modular ligand-binding domains of steroid receptors have been widely used to generate protein chimeras that are ligand dependent for activity. In a similar manner, we generated a series of conditionally active JunD and c-Fos proteins by fusing their carboxyl (COOH)-terminal ends with a COOH-terminal fragment of the human estrogen receptor (ER) that contains the ligand-binding domain. JunD-ER (DER) and Fos-ER (FER) chimeras with an intact leucine zipper and basic region exhibit hormone-dependent activation of activator protein-1-directed transcription in transient expression assays. One of these fusions, DER, has been examined in detail to determine its mechanism of action. Results from immunoprecipitation experiments with extracts from DER and Fos transfected cells demonstrate that Fos and DER readily form heterodimer complexes. Surprisingly, the formation of Fos:DER heterodimers, and possibly DER homodimers, is estrogen-independent. However, gel shift assays clearly demonstrate that DNA binding to AP1 sites by Fos:DER heterodimers or DER homodimers is estrogen-dependent. Moreover, in the absence of estrogen, the DER protein is an effective inhibitor of Fos-mediated transactivation, and this effect is reversed by the presence of estrogen. Our results indicate that the DER protein is a direct, hormone-reversible inhibitor of Fos and that estrogen controls the conditional positive or dominant negative activities of DER at the level of DNA binding to AP1 sites. Accordingly, clonally derived fibroblast cell lines that stably express the DER protein exhibit reduced entry into the S phase of the cell cycle when quiescent cells are serum stimulated in the absence of estrogen. This is in contrast to the estrogen-treated controls. These results support the hypothesis that AP1 is important for cell cycle progression and provide a unique approach for examining the role of AP1 in this process. Members of the Jun and Fos families of oncoproteins are the essential components of the dimeric transcription factor activator protein-1 (API). 1The abbreviations used are: AP1, activator protein-1; GR, glucocorticoid receptor; ER, estrogen receptor; WT, wild type; PCR, polymerase chain reaction; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyl transferase; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; FBS, fetal bovine serum; TR, thyroid hormone receptor; RAR, retinoic acid receptor. The three members of the jun gene family, c-jun, junB, and junD, all undergo similar, but not identical, regulation and encode proteins that share a high degree of amino acid sequence identity (1Vogt P.K. Bos T.J. Adv. Cancer Res. 1990; 55: 2-36Google Scholar). They are also similar in their interaction with c-Fos and Fos-related proteins (2Nakabeppu Y. Ryder K. Nathans D. Cell. 1988; 55: 907-915Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (531) Google Scholar). Jun:Jun or Jun:Fos dimer complexes bind to DNA at AP1 sites and regulate the expression of target genes. Since jun and fos family members are rapidly induced in response to extracellular growth signals, they are classified as immediate early response genes. Expression of these two gene families is an integral part of a well-orchestrated cascade of events leading to cellular proliferation (1 and 3, and references therein). Since Jun proteins are important participants in the cellular growth response, further studies analyzing the direct effects of these proteins on gene expression and cell growth would be greatly facilitated by a well characterized inducible expression system. One approach for creating an inducible system focuses on placing the activity of a protein under the control of the ligand-binding domain of a steroid hormone receptor such as the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) or the estrogen receptor (ER). Steroid receptor fusion proteins have been created with proteins such as E1A (4Picard D. Salser S.J. Yamamoto K.R. Cell. 1988; 54: 1073-1080Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (294) Google Scholar), c-Myc (5Eilers M. Picard D. Yamamoto K.R. Bishop J.M. Nature. 1989; 340: 66-68Crossref PubMed Scopus (390) Google Scholar), the CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein (6Umek R.M. Friedman A.D. McKnight S.L. Science. 1991; 251: 288-292Crossref PubMed Scopus (573) Google Scholar), MyoD (7Hollenberg S.M. Cheng P.F. Weintraub H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 8028-8032Crossref PubMed Scopus (175) Google Scholar), p53 (8Roemer K. Friedman T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1993; 90: 9252-9256Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar), and c-Fos (9Superti-Furga G. Bergers G. Picard D. Busslinger M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 5114-5118Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 10Schuermann M. Hennig G. Muller R. Oncogene. 1993; 8: 2781-2790PubMed Google Scholar). In each of these cases, the fusion protein appeared to be devoid of biological activity when expressed in cells in the absence of hormone, whereas its appropriate wild type (WT) function was restored in the presence of hormone. We explored the possibility that the activities of WT and mutated Jun proteins could be regulated post-translationally by fusion with the ER. A JunD chimeric molecule was created by appending a truncated human ER sequence to its 3′ end resulting in the JunD-ER (DER) fusion. Analysis of the DER fusion protein shows that it is estrogen dependent for the activation of transcription from AP1 reporter constructs. In addition, a detailed analysis of the mechanism by which estrogen regulates the DER protein was performed. The chimera forms heterodimers with WT Fos proteins but does not readily form heterodimers with WT Jun proteins. However, neither the weak interactions between DER and WT Jun nor the strong interactions between DER and Fos are regulated by estrogen. In contrast, DNA binding by DER homodimers or DER:Fos heterodimers is completely estrogen-dependent. Because of this novel mechanism of action, the DER fusion protein is an effective dominant negative protein that complexes with Fos and reversibly inhibits its DNA binding activity. In addition, cell clones that stably express the DER protein exhibit a reduced capacity to enter S phase from a growth arrested state in the absence of estrogen, a result that is consistent with the hypothesis that AP1 is important for normal cell cycle progression. While a number of recombinant chimeras between steroid receptors and various proteins have been described previously, the mechanisms by which hormone controls the activities of these chimeric proteins have been largely unexplored. This is the first report to examine in detail the mechanism of hormone-dependent regulation of an ER fusion protein. Our results, which show that these ER chimeras are not necessarily physiologically inert in the unliganded state, have important implications for other studies that have similarly employed the estrogen receptor. Indeed, we suggest that this approach may be generally useful for developing hormone-regulated dominant negative proteins, particularly in cases where the WT polypeptides normally form heterotypic complexes with other proteins. The Bluescript plasmid (pBS(KS), Stratagene) containing the 475/ junD hybrid cDNA (pBS.junD), as constructed by Nakabeppu et al. (2Nakabeppu Y. Ryder K. Nathans D. Cell. 1988; 55: 907-915Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (531) Google Scholar), was used to generate the deletion and fusion gene constructions. The basic region deletion mutant deleted the coding sequence for a stretch of 26 amino acids immediately preceding the leucine zipper (amino acids 258 through 281). The sequences 5′ and 3′ to this region were joined by an artificially created AflIII site as the result of two separate PCR (polymerase chain reaction) products. The introduced AflIII site did not insert or change any amino acids across this junction. The transactivation domain deletion mutant deleted the coding sequence for amino acids 2 through 158. This clone was generated in a two-step process. The first step deleted the coding sequence for amino acids 93 through 158. To accomplish this a 340-base pair HindIII-BstYI fragment (with the BstYI 5′ overhang rendered blunt with Klenow) was excised from pBS.junD. This fragment was ligated to a 3.4-kilobase fragment of pBS.junD cut with HindIII and SfiI, in which the SfiI end was rendered blunt using T4 DNA polymerase. The blunt-end ligation between SfiI and BstYI created a BamHI site at the deletion junction. This clone was then used in the second step to delete an NcoI/BamHI fragment to remove amino acids 2 through 93. In this process two additional amino acids were inserted between amino acids 1 and 158 which are an asparagine and proline. To create the junD-estrogen receptor fusion gene, pBS.junD was used as the template to create a PCR product which replaced the terminal TGA with a BglII site. This clone, pBS.junD3′Bgl, was then used to excise a 1-kilobase XhoI and BglII fragment with the BglII 5′ overhang filled in with Klenow. The ER portion of the fusion was prepared by excising a 1-kilobaseb fragment from pBS.HE14 (11Kumar V. Green S. Staub A. Chambon P. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2231-2236Crossref PubMed Scopus (407) Google Scholar) digested with SacI and partially with NcoI. The NcoI 5′ overhang was rendered blunt with Klenow. The junD and ER fragments were then ligated into Bluescript digested with XhoI and SacI. A block of nine amino acids was inserted fortuitously during the cloning process that linked the coding sequences of these two polypeptides: RSIPPWIDP. From each deletion mutant, DAB2 and DΔTA, an XhoI-HincII fragment was excised and used to replace the corresponding junD sequences in the DER clone. All of the above constructs were initially cloned into the Bluescript vector and checked via sequencing to ensure the fidelity of the PCR products and deletion junctions. All sequencing reactions were performed using a modification of the dideoxy chain termination reaction of Sanger et al. (12Sanger F. Nicklen S. Coulson A.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1977; 74: 5463-5467Crossref PubMed Scopus (52668) Google Scholar) according to the specifications of the manufacturer of the Sequenase sequencing kit (U. S. Biochemical Corp., Cleveland, OH). For DNA transfections, a reporter plasmid containing a single AP1 site linked to the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) gene driven by the thymidine kinase promoter (AP1/tkCAT) was used. The above deletion mutants and ER fusions were cloned into the pMT2 (13Bontron D.R. Handin R.I. Kaufman R.J. Wasley L.C. Orr E.C. Mitsock L.M. Ewenstein B. Loscalzo J. Ginsburg B. Orkin S.H. Nature. 1986; 324: 270-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar) and LNCX (14Miller A.D. Rosman G.J. BioTechniques. 1989; 7: 980-990PubMed Google Scholar) eukaryotic expression vectors to examine the effects of the various constructs following transient introduction into cells. Either the plasmid pCH110 or RSV-βGAL, which encode the β-galactosidase gene, was used as an internal control for transfection efficiency. The F9 embryonal carcinoma cell line was routinely maintained by culturing in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) which was supplemented with 7.5% fetal bovine serum (FBS). Cells were plated to be 50–60% confluent at the time of transfection. Transfections were performed in 60-mm dishes via the standard calcium phosphate technique or in 6-well plates using the lipofectamine reagent (Life Technologies, Inc.). The latter was used as per the manufacturer's instructions after determining that 5 µl of the lipofectamine reagent/one well of a 6-well plate was optimal for these cells under our culture conditions. F9 cells grown on 60-mm dishes were transfected with the AP1/tkCAT reporter plasmid (2 µg), the β-galactosidase plasmid pCH110 (1.5 µg), and 4.5 µg of the pMT2 expression plasmid by the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method. Lipofectamine transfections into cells grown in 6-well plates used the following DNA concentrations: 0.4 µg of AP1/tkCAT reporter plasmid, 0.4 µg of RSV-β-GAL plasmid, and 1.5 µg of pMT2 or LNCX expression plasmid. In those experiments where estrogen effects were examined, the transfection media was DMEM (without phenol red; Life Technologies, Inc.) supplemented with 10% charcoal-treated calf serum (15Stanley E.R. Palmer R.E. Sohn U. Cell. 1977; 10: 35-44Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar). This media was used after the requisite incubation of the DNA-lipofectamine mix with the cells. More recent experiments have shown that 10% FBS can also be used with no effect on the estrogen inducibility of specific constructs. To test the hormonal regulation of the various constructs, β-estradiol (Sigma) was added to the transfection media at 10–6 m final concentration from a stock solution of 10–2 or 10–3 m prepared in ethanol. Estrogen minus wells or plates received the comparable amount of ethanol alone. Cells were harvested 24 h (lipofectamine mediated) or 48 h (calcium phosphate mediated) after the transfection. Extracts were then prepared via a standard freeze-thaw method and analyzed for β-galactosidase and CAT activities where appropriate. The COS cell line was routinely maintained by culturing in the same conditions as the F9 cells. Cells were plated in 100-mm dishes to be approximately 70% confluent at the time of transfection. Transfections using the pMT2 expression plasmids were performed via the standard calcium phosphate technique or the DEAE-dextran procedure as follows. After washing the cells twice in DMEM without serum, 6 ml of DMEM (no serum) containing 400 µg of DEAE-dextran/ml and 200 ng each test DNA/ml was added to each dish and incubated for 3 h at 37 °C. After one wash with DMEM, 6 ml of DMEM containing 2.5% FBS and 100 µm chloroquin was added for an additional incubation of 3 h at 37 °C. After this second incubation, the cells were washed in DMEM and replated in DMEM (no phenol red) containing 10% FBS and where appropriate 10–6 m β-estradiol. Cells were harvested 48–72 h later. Whole cell extracts of transfected COS cells for gel shift analyses were prepared by a freeze-thaw method after the cells were resuspended in a binding buffer containing 20 mm HEPES, pH 8, 0.4 m potassium chloride, 2 mm dithiothreitol, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. To the cleared supernatant (10,000 × g in a microcentrifuge), glycerol was added to a 20% final concentration, and the extracts were stored at –70 °C. Extracts were checked by Western analysis for appropriate protein expression from the transgene. The Rat1A fibroblast cell line was routinely maintained by culturing in the same conditions as F9 cells. Rat1A transformants expressing the DER fusion protein from the LNCX expression vector were selected in DMEM (phenol red-free) containing 10% FBS, 10–6 m estrogen, and 400 µg of G418 (Life Technologies, Inc.) per ml. To establish cell lines, G418-resistant colonies were pooled, clones were selected by limiting dilution, and screened by immunofluorescence using the ER-LH1 antibody (Novacastra Laboratories Ltd.) to select clones that expressed various levels of the DER protein. The DER positive clones are routinely maintained in DMEM (phenol red-free) containing FBS and G418, as above, and estrogen at 5 × 10–7 m. Approximately 48 h after the transfection, cells were labeled for 1 h with [35S]methionine (ICN, Trans-label) at a concentration of 100 µCi/ml in DMEM (minus methionine and cysteine) containing 5% dialyzed FBS. The labeled cells were collected and stored as a pellet at –20 °C until extracts were prepared. Whole cell extracts were prepared as described by Harlow and Lane (16Harlow E. Lane D. Antibodies: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1988Google Scholar) by resuspending the cells in radioimmunoprecipitation assay buffer containing 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 TIU (trypsin inhibitor unit) aprotinin/ml, 10 µg of leupeptin/ml, and 10 mm Na2MoO4. The supernatant fraction was saved. Counts precipitable by trichloroacetic acid were determined, and the volume of extract to be precipitated was calculated based on transfection efficiency determined by a β-galactosidase assay. Immunoprecipitations of labeled cell extracts or in vitro products were done as described (16Harlow E. Lane D. Antibodies: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1988Google Scholar) after preclearing with preimmune sera and formalin-fixed Staphylococcus aureus cells (immunoprecipitin; Life Technologies, Inc.). Protein A-Sepharose (Sigma) was used to collect the immune complex. Precipitated antigen was separated on a 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel and radioactivity was measured by a Fujix Bio-Imaging analyzer (BAS1000 Mac). The β-galactosidase assay was performed by adding half of the extract to a buffer containing 0.1 m NaPO4, 0.01 m KCl, 1 mm MgSO4, 0.045 m 2-mercaptoethanol, and 4 mg 2-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyrano-side/ml. This was a timed reaction and stopped with 1 m Na2CO3 when a yellow color was observed. The absorbance at 420 nm was determined for each sample and was used to calculate β-galactosidase units per hour (A420 × 1000/time (h)). CAT activity in the extracts was determined in a continuous assay which measured the accumulation over time of radioactive chloramphenicol partitioning into a water-immiscible fluor, as detected in a scintillation counter (17Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). Counting was started after overlaying the reaction mix with scintillation fluid. Several cycles were counted at 20–30-min intervals to obtain quantitative kinetic data. The reaction rates were determined by linear regression and data are stored and analyzed with the Cricket Graph software (Cricket Software, Inc.) Corrected CAT activities were obtained by adjusting the observed activities according to the level of β-galactosidase. The CAT activities for the WT junD and test constructs are divided by the CAT activity value obtained with the pMT2 or LNCX expression construct alone. This value is the induction ratio. Recombinant plasmids, in pBS(KS), containing the complete coding sequence were used to prepare in vitro transcribed RNAs as per the manufacturer's instructions (Stratagene). The concentration of the RNA was determined by absorbance, and routinely 2 µg of RNA were used to prepare the in vitro translated product as per the manufacturer's instructions (Promega). [35S]Methionine (ICN, Trans-label) was used to label the in vitro products. A small portion of each reaction was analyzed by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis to check for protein integrity and approximate concentration. For association studies, volumes of reticulocyte lysates (1–4 µl) representing equal amounts of protein were mixed, incubated for 0.5 h at 37 °C, and then immediately diluted with radioimmunoprecipitation assay buffer (18Kovary K. Bravo R. Mol. Cell Biol. 1991; 11: 2451-2459Crossref PubMed Scopus (294) Google Scholar). The complexes were isolated by immunoprecipitation using the appropriate antibody. Rabbit antisera specific for the COOH terminus of JunD (653), the NH2 terminus of JunD (183), and Fos (64) were previously prepared 2K. Ryder, unpublished data. and a mouse monoclonal antibody specific for the estrogen receptor (Novocastra Laboratories, Ltd., clone NCL-ER-LH1) were used for immunoprecipitations and supershift experiments. A mouse monoclonal anti-β-galactosidase antibody (Promega) was also used in the supershift experiments. Jun:Fos heterodimers of in vitro translated products (1–5 µl) were allowed to form at 37 °C for 15 min in 20 µl of the DNA binding buffer of Brown et al. (19Brown P.H. Alani R. Preis L.H. Szabo E. Birrer M.J. Oncogene. 1993; 8: 877-886PubMed Google Scholar). Prior to adding the probe, the samples were incubated with 300 ng of salmon sperm DNA. The samples were then incubated at room temperature for 15–20 min with a 1-µl aliquot (0.093 pmol) of a 32P-end-labeled double-stranded oligonucleotide containing a single AP1 consensus sequence: 5′-CGGTATCGATAAGCTATGACT-CATCCGGGG-3′. This oligonucleotide was end-labeled with T4 polynucleotide kinase (Life Technologies, Inc.) in a kinase reaction using [γ-32P]ATP (17Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). After heat inactivating the kinase, a 3-fold molar excess of the complementary strand was added, heated to 85 °C for 10 min, and annealed by slow cooling to room temperature. The unincorporated radioactivity was removed as per the manufacturer's directions after loading the sample to a Bio-Spin column (Bio-Rad). Gel shift analyses of COS cell transfectants were performed similarly. A 4-µl volume of each whole cell extract was added to 20 µl of the above binding buffer without sodium chloride. Salmon sperm DNA was added to the reaction mix at a final concentration of 0.5–1.0 µg/reaction and incubated 15–20 min at room temperature. A 1-µ1 aliquot (0.093 pmol) of the same 32P-labeled oligonucleotide probe was added and incubated at room temperature for 15 min. The reaction mixes of both types of samples were then loaded and run on a 5% non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel (29.5 parts acrylamide/1 part Bis-acrylamide) in 0.25 × TBE buffer (1 × TBE is 89 mm Tris base, 89 mm boric acid, 2.5 mm EDTA). After electrophoresis, gels were dried and exposed to x-ray film. If antibodies were used, whole cell extracts and antibodies were preincubated for 1 h in binding buffer on ice (20Bossy-Wetzel E. Bravo R. Hanahan D. Genes & Dev. 1992; 6: 2340-2351Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar) prior to adding the labeled oligonucleotide probe. Radioactivity in the shifted bands was measured by a Fujix Bio-Imaging analyzer (BAS1000 Mac). Cells were collected at indicated times after growth arrest or serum stimulation and resuspended at approximately 107 cells/ml in a sodium citrate buffer containing dimethyl sulfoxide (21Vindelov L.L. Christensen I.J. Nissen N.I. Cytometry. 1983; 3: 323-327Crossref PubMed Scopus (1603) Google Scholar). Cells were routinely stored at –20 °C at this point until stained. A detergent-trypsin method was used to prepare nuclei from 1–2 × 106 cells and stain DNA with propidium iodide for flow cytometric analysis as described by Vindelov et al. (21Vindelov L.L. Christensen I.J. Nissen N.I. Cytometry. 1983; 3: 323-327Crossref PubMed Scopus (1603) Google Scholar). Fluorescence intensity in the cell nucleus was measured with a FACScan (Becton Dickinson). For each sample, 10,000 cells were acquired using the CELLQuest software program (Becton Dickinson) and analyzed with the MacCycle curve-fitting program for DNA content and cell cycle analysis (Phoenix Flow Systems, Inc.). A conditionally active JunD protein (DER) was created by joining in frame a truncated human ER sequence (11, HE14) that encodes the ligand-binding and hormone-inducible transactivation domains with the 3′ end of junD. In addition, two junD genes coding for mutant proteins containing deletions of the DNA binding basic region (DAB2) or the transactivation domain (DATA) were constructed. These mutants are comparable to those previously described with c-Jun and shown to be dominant negative molecules (19Brown P.H. Alani R. Preis L.H. Szabo E. Birrer M.J. Oncogene. 1993; 8: 877-886PubMed Google Scholar, 22Brown P.H. Chen T.K. Birrer M.J. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 791-799PubMed Google Scholar, 23Ransone L.J. Vivader J. Wamsley P. Verma I.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 3806-3810Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Fusions analogous to DER were generated with these deletion mutants resulting in DΔB2.ER and DΔTA.ER. A schematic representation of the WT, deletion mutants, and fusion proteins is shown in Fig. 1, A and B. The genes encoding these proteins were cloned into both prokaryotic and eukaryotic expression vectors for in vitro and in vivo analyses, respectively. Prior to the introduction of these constructs into tissue culture cells, the deletion mutants and fusion proteins were assessed for their interaction with Fos and subsequent DNA binding activity as compared to WT JunD. JunD and c-Fos polypeptides, as well as the mutant and fusion proteins, were expressed separately via an in vitro transcription-translation system, allowed to interact under conditions appropriate to form Jun:Fos dimers (18Kovary K. Bravo R. Mol. Cell Biol. 1991; 11: 2451-2459Crossref PubMed Scopus (294) Google Scholar), and then immunoprecipitated with a Fos-specific antibody (Fig. 2A). While the Fos antibody was unable to precipitate any of the Jun proteins alone (data not shown), the results in Fig. 2A show that in the presence of Fos, JunD and the deletion mutants coprecipitated with the 58-kDa Fos polypeptide (lanes 1–3). Since the in vitro translation reactions of the ER polypeptides did not yield as much protein as with JunD and the deletion mutants, 3-fold less in vitro translated Fos was used in the immunoprecipitation reactions (Fig. 2A, lanes 4–7). Analyses of the fusion proteins show that they also coprecipitated with the Fos polypeptide (Fig. 2A, lanes 4–6). In each of these cases, approximately 50% of the JunD deletion mutants or chimeras formed dimers with Fos, which is comparable to the percent of WT JunD that complexed with Fos. In contrast, the 35-kDa truncated ER polypeptide did not coprecipitate with Fos (HE-14; Fig. 2A, lane 7). After immunoprecipitation with the Fos-specific antibody, the truncated ER protein was, however, detected in the supernatant with an ER-specific antibody (data not shown). To examine the DNA binding activity of the JunD deletion and fusion proteins in the presence of Fos, aliquots of the various Jun:Fos dimers shown in Fig. 2A were allowed to interact with a radiolabeled oligonucleotide (30-mer) containing the consensus sequence of the API-binding site. Fig. 2B shows gel mobility shift results for the analyzed proteins. In vitro translated WT c-Jun (lane 2) and JunD (lane 3), the DER fusion (lane 6), and the TA deletion proteins (lanes 5 and 8) all bind and retard the labeled oligonucleotide, presumably through the formation of heterodimers with c-Fos. DNA binding by these complexes does not require added estrogen in vitro. It is important to note that this result is consistent with previous data which show that in vitro expressed steroid receptors bind DNA in a ligand-independent fashion, even though they are ligand dependent for DNA binding in vivo. In general, the various proteins show similar binding, with the possible exception of the DΔTA.ER fusion which seems to exhibit less binding. The reason for this observation is not obvious and has not been explored. In contrast, those proteins containing a deletion of the basic region (DΔB2 and DΔB2.ER), although capable of interacting with Fos, are devoid of DNA binding activity (lanes 4 and 7, Fig. 2B). Neither Fos alone nor the truncated ER in combination with Fos shows DNA binding (Fig. 2B, compare lanes 9 and 10 with lane 1). The data shown in Fig. 2, which examined the mutant and fusion proteins in vitro, predict that within a cell all of these proteins should interact with Fos nearly as well as WT JunD, bind to an AP1 site to some extent (except for those containing a basic region deletion), and possibly transactivate a gene containing an API-binding site. To examine API-directed transactivation, the altered JunD molecules and WT JunD were transiently expressed in F9 embryonal carcinoma cells. These cells are typically chosen for their low, but not undetectable, level of endogenous AP1 activity (9Superti-Furga G. Bergers G. Picard D. Busslinger M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 5114-5118Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar). 3M. K. Francis, unpublished observations. Transactivation by the ER chimeras and their WT or deletion mutant counterparts wa

The identification of membrane-inserted segments of pore-forming soluble proteins is crucial to understanding the action of these proteins at the molecular level. A distinct member of this class of proteins is α-toxin, a 293-amino acid-long 33-kDa hemolytic toxin secreted by Staphylococcus aureus that can form pores in both artificial and natural membranes. We have studied the interaction of α-toxin with single bilayer vesicles prepared from asolectin using a hydrophobic photoactivable reagent, 2-[3H]diazofluorene ([3H]DAF) (Pradhan, D., and Lala, A. K. (1987) J. Biol. Chem. 262, 8242–8251). This reagent readily partitions into the membrane hydrophobic core and on photolysis labels the lipid and protein segments that penetrate the membrane. Current models on the mode of action of α-toxin indicate that, on interaction with membranes, α-toxin forms an oligomer, which represents the active pore. In keeping with these models, we observe that [3H]DAF photolabels the membrane-bound α-toxin oligomer. Cyanogen bromide fragmentation of [3H]DAF-labeled α-toxin gave several fragments, which were subjected to Edman degradation. We could thus sequence residues 1–19, 35–60, 114–139, 198–231, and 235–258. Radioactive analysis and phenylthiohydantoin-derivative analysis during sequencing permitted analysis of DAF insertion sites. The results obtained indicated that the N and C termini (residues 235–258) have been extensively labeled. The putative pore-forming glycine-rich central hinge region was poorly labeled, indicating that the apposing side of the lumen of the pore does not form the lipid-protein interface. The DAF labeling pattern indicated that the major structural motif in membrane-bound α-toxin was largely β-sheet.
