Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 5475-5479Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar). These pores are large in size, and diameters of 1–2 nm have been reported (8Fussle R. Bhakdi S. Sziegoleit A. Tranum-Jensen J. Kranz T. Wellensiek H.J. J. Cell Biol. 1981; 91: 83-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (258) Google Scholar, 12Menestrina G. J. Membr. Biol. 1986; 90: 177-190Crossref PubMed Scopus (288) Google Scholar). The current models suggest that, in any membrane type, α-toxin binds to the membrane as a monomer, which on lateral diffusion oligomerizes to a 200-kDa hexamer, which represents the active pore (8Fussle R. Bhakdi S. Sziegoleit A. Tranum-Jensen J. Kranz T. Wellensiek H.J. J. Cell Biol. 1981; 91: 83-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (258) Google Scholar, 14Bhakdi S. Fussle R. Tranum-Jensen J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 5475-5479Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 15Bhakdi S. Tranum-Jensen J. Microbiol. Rev. 1991; 55: 733-751Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, recent reports indicate that the oligomer formed is a heptamer (16Gouaux J.E. Braha O. Hobaugh M.R. Song L. Cheley S. Shustak C. Bayley H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12828-12831Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). Based on mutation and other studies involving proteolysis, it has been proposed that the assembly of the α-toxin pore involves separation of two rigid domains that are separated by a glycine-rich loop region located around the middle of the molecule (17Tobkes N. Wallace B.A. Bayley H. Biochemistry. 1985; 24: 1915-1920Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar, 18Walker B. Krishnasastry M. Zorn L. Bayley H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21782-21786Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). On binding to membranes, α-toxin undergoes a conformational change resulting in the formation of amphiphilic rods, which then aggregate to form the active pore. More recent mutation studies suggest the involvement of the glycine-rich loop region in lining the membrane pore (19Walker B. Krishnasastry M. Bayley H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 5285-5292Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Walker B. Kasianowicz J. Krishnasastry M. Bayley H. Protein Eng. 1994; 7: 655-662Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). While these studies have certainly helped in understanding the mode of action of α-toxin, we are still far from understanding it at the molecular level. Direct structural approaches have also met with limited success. Thus, despite the availability of reasonable quantities of the purified toxin, it has not been possible to obtain the three-dimensional structure of α-toxin. In the absence of the solution structure, it has been a formidable challenge to determine the structure of the membrane-bound pore. Electron microscopy was used in the past to obtain structural information on membrane-bound α-toxin, and these early studies indicated an annular structure with a stain-filled center (14Bhakdi S. Fussle R. Tranum-Jensen J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 5475-5479Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 21Freer J.H. Arbuthnott J.P. Bernheimer A.W. J. Bacteriol. 1968; 95: 1153-1168Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Even current studies involving image analysis of the electron micrograph have yielded structural information at very low resolutions and at best provide information on the oligomeric state of membrane-bound α-toxin (22Olofsson A. Kavéus U. Hacksell I. Thelestam M. Hebert H. J. Mol. Biol. 1990; 214: 299-306Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 23Olofsson A. Kavéus U. Thelestam M. Hebert H. J. Ultrastruct. Mol. Struct. Res. 1988; 100: 194-200Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). The identification of peptide segments of α-toxin that interact with the membrane, amino acid residues involved in subunit-subunit contact, and residues that line the pore is of considerable importance to understanding the mode of action of α-toxin at the molecular level. Hydrophobic photolabeling using apolar reagents can be used to establish the insertion of protein toxins in membranes and to identify protein segments that interact with the membrane hydrophobic core (24Montecucco C. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 165: 347-357Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). This approach involves the use of hydrophobic or ampiphilic photoactivable reagents that can easily partition into the membrane. On photolysis, they generate highly reactive intermediates like a carbene or a nitrene, which readily insert into any bond, including a C-H bond, in neighboring molecules. Thus, a membrane hydrophobic core reagent can photolabel the lipid and protein components embedded in the hydrophobic core (25Brunner J. Methods Enzymol. 1989; 172: 628-686Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). In brief, the approach provides a direct method for establishing the peptide segments of a membrane-bound protein (24Montecucco C. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 165: 347-357Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar, 25Brunner J. Methods Enzymol. 1989; 172: 628-686Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 26Brunner J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1993; 62: 483-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (438) Google Scholar). We have used a carbene-based photoactivable reagent, [3H]DAF, to study the interaction of α-toxin with single bilayer vesicles. [3H]DAF is an apolar photoactivable reagent that readily partitions into the membrane hydrophobic core and labels the lipid and protein segments that span the membrane. [3H]DAF has been used to photolabel the erythrocyte glucose transporter (27Lala A.K. Batliwala H.F. Bhat S. Pure Appl. Chem. 1990; 62: 1453-1456Crossref Scopus (4) Google Scholar, 28Lala A.K. Bhat S. Biotechnol. Appl. Biochem. 1990; 12: 586-594PubMed Google Scholar) and more recently to evaluate hydrophobic exposure, in the molten globule state of soluble proteins like α-lactalbumin (29Lala A.K. Kaul P. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 19914-19918Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We report here a characterization of the photoincorporation of [3H]DAF in membrane-bound α-toxin and show that it labels α-toxin in the pore-forming oligomeric state. Analysis of DAF insertion sites in α-toxin by proteolysis and peptide sequencing shows that parts of the N- and C-terminal segments are associated with lipids. The photolabeling pattern indicates that a β-sheet structure is the dominant motif in membrane-bound α-toxin. All reagents used were of the highest commercial grade purity available. Spectral grade water was obtained using Milli-Q Plus (Millipore Corp., Bedford, MA). Calcein and asolectin were purchased from Sigma. Asolectin (mixed soybean phospholipids) was further purified by the procedure of Kagawa and Racker (30Kagawa Y.L. Racker E. J. Biol. Chem. 1971; 246: 5477-5487Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar) and stored as a chloroform solution at –20 °C. The concentration of the stock solution was determined by phosphate assay (31Ames B.N. Dubin D.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1960; 235: 769-775Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). HPLC analysis was carried out on a Shimadzu LC-6A system. Tritiated fluorenone was obtained by catalytic tritium exchange of 2-iodofluoren-9-one (Board of Radiation and Isotope Technology, Bombay, India). The purity of the [3H]fluorenone was checked by reverse-phase HPLC on a Bio-Sil ODS-5S C18 column (4 × 250 mm) using methanol/water (80:20, v/v) as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 0.4 ml/min. Elution was monitored at 260 nm with an absorbance unit at full scale of 0.02. [3H]Fluorenone appeared at 13.78 min. In some of the batches received after tritium exchange, [3H]fluorenone was found to be contaminated with [3H]fluorenol (8.72 min) and [3H]fluorene (28.43 min). In such cases, the crude [3H]fluorenone was purified by HPLC. The purified [3H]fluorenone was reinjected onto the Cl8 column to confirm its homogeneity. The specific activity was estimated from the radioactivity and area associated with the [3H]fluorenone peak. The concentration of [3H]fluorenone was determined from the peak area using a standard curve prepared using unlabeled fluorenone as the external standard. [3H]DAF was prepared from [3H]fluorenone according to the procedure reported earlier (32Pradhan D. Lala A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 8242-8251Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) with minor modifications. Samples of lyophilized α-toxin were a kind gift from Dr. S. Bhakdi (Institute of Medical Microbiology, University of Mainz, Mainz, Federal Republic of Germany). The toxin was found to be a single band as analyzed by 15% SDS-PAGE according to the procedure of Laemmli (33Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (205531) Google Scholar). Concentrations of α-toxin were estimated either by monitoring the absorbance at 280 nm, using an extinction coefficient of 1.1 for a 1 mg/ml solution (6Harshman S. Sugg N. Cassidy P. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 165: 3-7Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar), or on the basis of protein assay (34Lowry O.H. Rosebrough N.J. Farr A.L. Randall R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). All experiments were done at 23 °C unless specified otherwise. The standard buffer used in all experiments was 10 mm Tris buffer containing 100 mm NaCl, pH 7.0, unless specified otherwise. Liposome Preparation—Small unilamellar vesicles were prepared from asolectin. Asolectin (5 µmol) was dried onto the walls of a test tube. The thin film was dried under high vacuum for 8 h. To this film was added 1 ml of degassed standard buffer, which was then vortexed. The suspension was sonicated twice for 6 min at 4 °C using a Branson B-30 sonicator fitted with a microtip. The resulting clear solution was spun at 15,000 rpm (15,850 × g) to pellet any titanium particles shed from the microtip during sonication. The vesicles were freshly prepared for all experiments. Calcein Release Assay—1 ml of 100 mm calcein in 50 mm NaCl, adjusted to pH just above 7.0 when the calcein entirely dissolved, was added to the dried asolectin (5 µmol) film and vortexed for 5 min. The resulting preparation was sonicated twice for 6 min at 4 °C. Part (1 µmol of lipid) of the sonicated suspension was loaded onto a Sephadex G-50 column (1 × 40 cm), equilibrated in standard Tris buffer, and eluted in the same buffer at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. The calcein-entrapped vesicles eluted in the void volume, which corresponded to a volume of 3 ml. The liposome concentration was estimated by measuring the lipid phosphorus content (31Ames B.N. Dubin D.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1960; 235: 769-775Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The final phosphate concentration was 0.33 µmol/ml. The release of calcein on addition of α-toxin was monitored using a Shimadzu Model RF-540 spectrofluorometer. Calcein-loaded vesicles (16.9 nmol) were added to 2 ml of standard Tris buffer in a cuvette of 1-cm path length. The excitation wavelength was set at 494 nm, and the emission wavelength at 520 nm. A 10-nm slit was used for both excitation and emission monochromators. The fluorescence intensity of the vesicle preparation in the buffer was taken as the zero reading. 100% calcein release was obtained by the addition of 20 µl of 5% Triton X-100. α-Toxin was added to the vesicle preparation, and calcein release was monitored as a function of time. The experiment was done for increasing α-toxin concentrations. The percent calcein release was expressed as follows: % calcein release = ((It – I0)/(If – I0)) × 100, where I0 is the fluorescence before the addition of the toxin, It is the fluorescence observed after the addition of the toxin, and If is the total fluorescence of calcein after the addition of Triton X-100. Photolabeling of α-Toxin in Vesicles with [3H]DAF—Photolabeling of α-toxin in asolectin vesicles with [3H]DAF was carried out on an analytical scale as well as on preparative scales. The specific activity of [3H]DAF ranged from 1.035 to 8.25 Ci/mmol, and [3H]DAF was stored as a 0.5–1 mm stock solution in ethanol at –20 °C. In a general procedure for photolabeling experiments, a few microliters of ethanolic solution of [3H]DAF (3–10 µCi) were added to asolectin vesicles (60.6 µm final lipid concentration) prepared in standard Tris buffer and incubated for 10 min in the dark. The total alcohol concentration never exceeded 2% (v/v) of the total buffer volume. The final concentration of [3H]DAF was 12 µm. α-Toxin (200 µg/ml) was then added and incubated for 60 min. At the end of 1 h, the tubes were photolyzed for 3 min using a Rayonet Minireactor (RMR-500) equipped with four 3000-Å lamps. In a control experiment, the sample containing α-toxin incubated with [3H]DAF-bearing vesicles was not photolyzed. Unreacted [3H]DAF, if any, was destroyed by the addition of glacial acetic acid to a final concentration of 1 m. The photolabeled samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE directly for the experiments carried out on a small scale i.e. sample volumes below 100 µl. SDS-PAGE was carried according to the procedure of Laemmli (33Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (205531) Google Scholar) on a slab gel electrophoresis unit. In photolabeling experiments carried out on a larger scale (sample volumes of 4–5 ml, 1–2 mg of α-toxin), the photolabeled toxin was delipidated by chloroform/methanol (2:1, v/v) extraction twice. The aqueous layer was then dialyzed in water to remove salts and lyophilized. The sample was subjected to SDS-PAGE as before. The gel was then stained in Coomassie Blue and destained in a destaining solution containing 10% acetic acid and 40% methanol in water. The gel was photographed and sliced into 2-mm pieces. The sliced gel pieces were digested in 100 µl of 30% H2O2 at 60 °C for 8 h. The solubilized gel was counted in a toluene-based scintillation mixture (0.4% diphenyloxazole, 0.025% 1,4-bis[2-(4-methyl-5-phenyloxazolyl)]benzene, 7.2% Bio-Solv as an aqueous solubilizer) using a liquid scintillation counter (Model Rackbeta 1217, LKB, Uppsala). To analyze the aggregation state of α-toxin photolabeled in asolectin vesicles with [3H]DAF, the sample, after photolysis, was directly electrophoresed on a 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel essentially according to the procedure of Laemmli (33Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (205531) Google Scholar), except that we did not boil the sample in sample buffer containing 2% SDS and 5% 2-mercapto-ethanol. After staining with Coomassie Blue and destaining, the gel was scanned using a gel scanner (Model 1312, Isco Inc., Lincoln, NE). The region around the Coomassie Blue-stained bands were sliced into 2-mm pieces, solubilized in H2O2, and subjected to counting. Electroblotting of CNBr Fragments of Photolabeled α-Toxin—Photolabeled peptides from the CNBr digest of α-toxin photolabeled with [3H]DAF in vesicles were separated on a 16.5% Tris/Tricine gel and immediately electroblotted onto a PVDF membrane (Problott, Applied Biosystems Inc.) using a semidry blotting apparatus (Novablot, LKB) according to the procedure of Mozdzanowski and Speicher (35Mozdzanowski J. Speicher D.W. Anal. Biochem. 1992; 207: 11-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). The transfer buffer contained 12.5 mm Tris, 96 mm glycine containing 0.1% SDS, and 10% MeOH. After electroblotting, the PVDF membranes were washed thoroughly with water to remove Tris and glycine and then stained for 1 min in 0.5% Coomassie Blue and destained in 50% MeOH/H2O. The radioactive bands were excised for sequencing. N-terminal Sequencing of Photolabeled a-Toxin and Its CNBr Fragments—Automated Edman degradation of radiolabeled peptides was carried out using gas-phase protein sequencers (Shimadzu Model PSQ-1 or Applied Biosystems Model 477A. both equipped with an on-line HPLC). For sequence analysis, the photolabeled toxin and the HPLC fractions were loaded onto a Polybrene-coated glass fiber disc, while the CNBr fragments were loaded as PVDF blots. The photolabeled toxin and its CNBr fragments were subjected to automated Edman degradation in the Shimadzu protein sequencer. For each sequencing cycle, 60% of the fraction collected was analyzed in an on-line PTH analyzer for PTH-derivative release, while the remaining 40% was counted for 3H release, pmol release and the radioactivity data were normalized to 100%. Sequence analysis of the HPLC fraction was done in an Applied Biosystems protein sequencer with an on-line PTH analyzer. 33% of the fraction collected after every sequencing cycle was injected into the PTH analyzer for PTH-derivative release, while the remaining 67% was counted for 3H release. Repetitive yields were calculated by performing nonlinear regression analysis of the data fitted to the equation M = I0·Rn, where M is the observed release at each cycle, I0 is the initial yield, R is the repetitive yield, and n is the cycle number. With the main objective of this work being the identification of membrane-interacting domains of α-toxin, it was important to ensure the functional integrity of the system being used for studying interaction of α-toxin with membranes. We used single bilayer vesicles prepared from negatively charged lipid, asolectin, as a source of membrane preparation. We then studied the release of vesicle-entrapped calcein by α-toxin as an indicator of toxin-induced pore formation. Calcein is a concentration-dependent self-quenching dye (36Allen T.M. Cleland L.G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1980; 597: 418-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (425) Google Scholar) that provides a convenient membrane leakage assay (37Forti S. Menestrina G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1989; 181: 767-773Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). The addition of a membrane lytic agent to calcein-loaded vesicles leads to the release of calcein to the outer medium. The resulting dilution of calcein leads to an increase in fluorescence. At toxin concentrations >27 µg/ml, calcein release was seen to be >50%. The calcein release experiments clearly indicated the pore-forming ability of α-toxin in the asolectin vesicle system used here. Photolabeling of Membrane-bound a-Toxin with [3H]DAF—In the hydrophobic photolabeling experiments, [3H]DAF was first partitioned into the hydrophobic core of asolectin vesicles prepared in 10 mM Tris, 100 mM NaCl, pH 7. These DAF-bearing vesicles were then incubated with α-toxin in the dark, and the resulting preparation was photolyzed. The lipid and α-toxin concentrations corresponding to preparations that induced maximum calcein leakage in the experiments described above were used in the initial photolabeling experiments. Basically, these experiments were conducted with vesicle/toxin preparations made under conditions identical to those used for carrying out calcein leakage experiments. Briefly, the hydrophobic photoactivable reagent [3H]DAF with a specific activity of 1.035 Ci/mmol was partitioned into asolectin vesicles by adding an alcoholic solution of [3H]DAF to asolectin vesicles so that the final concentration of alcohol was <2% (v/v). This preparation was then incubated for 10 min in the dark. α-Toxin was added to the vesicles so that the final concentration of α-toxin was 1 µm. It was then incubated for 1 h in the dark and photolyzed for 3 min using four UV lamps that cut off light below 300 nm. The crude photolysate was extracted with chloroform/methanol (2:1) to remove lipid and photorearrangement products of DAF and dialyzed. The bulk of the counts (>90%) was found to be associated with the organic layer. This is not surprising as membrane hydrophobic core photolabeling experiments using [3H]DAF and other photoactivable reagents in the past have shown major labeling of lipids relative to proteins (32Pradhan D. Lala A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 8242-8251Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The aqueous layer left after delipidation was then subjected to SDS-PAGE. Staining with Coomassie Blue gave a very faint band, indicating that most of the α-toxin had been lost during processing. In another experiment, the chloroform/methanol extraction step was not carried out, and the sample after photolysis was concentrated and directly subjected to SDS-PAGE. In such experiments, the photolabeled lipid and photorearrangement products of DAF run at the dye front on SDS-PAGE (32Pradhan D. Lala A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 8242-8251Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and by allowing the tracking dye to run a little beyond the end of the gel, such products can be removed. Similar observations on the movement of photorearrangement products, resulting from use of aryl azide-based photoactivable reagents, to the dye front on SDS-PAGE have been made by others (38Kochi S.K. Martin L. Schiavo G. Mock M. Cabiaux V. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 2604-2609Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). The gel was then stained with Coomassie Blue, sliced, solubilized, and counted for radioactivity. In this case, a band corresponding to α-toxin could be seen, but was diffused. The high salt concentration in the buffer used in the calcein leakage and photolabeling experiments became still higher during sample concentration (2 ml) to a reasonable volume to carry out SDS-PAGE. Attempts to remove salt by dialysis before SDS-PAGE were sometimes successful, but often led to loss of α-toxin. Radioactive analysis indicated labeling of α-toxin with [3H]DAF, but the counts were barely above the background level. The photolabeling experiments were then carried out with [3H]DAF of higher specific activity (4.84 Ci/mmol) in low sample volumes. Analysis by SDS-PAGE (Fig. 1) indicated photolabeling of α-toxin with [3H]DAF as the bulk of the radioactivity was found to be associated with the α-toxin band. As mentioned above, the radioactivity observed at the tracking dye front at the end of the gel corresponds to the photolabeled phospholipid and photorearrangement products of DAF. In a control experiment in which the sample was not subjected to photolysis, SDS-PAGE analysis indicated that no radioactivity was associated with the α-toxin band (Fig. 1). These results indicate that labeling of α-toxin with [3H]DAF is photoinduced. Subsequent experiments indicated that for detection of [3H]DAF-labeled α-toxin by SDS-PAGE, the specific activity of [3H]DAF should be at least 3 Ci/mmol. Further experiments were thus conducted with [3H]DAF with a specific activity of >3 Ci/mmol. After establishing analytical conditions for α-toxin photolabeling, we tried to standardize conditions for preparative photolabeling to isolate [3H]DAF-labeled α-toxin and to subject it to subsequent analysis. In these preparative scale experiments, the α-toxin concentration used was 200 µg/ml (6.06 µm), with the rest of the conditions being similar to those of the analytical experiments. Typically, these experiments used 1–1.5 mg of α-toxin. Unlike in the analytical experiments, in the preparative experiments, we decided to remove the bulk of the counts associated with lipid and photorearrangement products of DAF by delipidation before processing the [3H]DAF-labeled α-toxin. Montecucco C. Papini E. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 14978-14984Abstract Full Text PDF Pu

Elements of the mouse Immunoglobulin γ2a gene, near the membrane-specific poly(A) addition site, were inserted into a heterologous location in either a synthetic mouse γ2b gene or a gpt/SV40 chimeric gene and then assayed for their ability to terminate RNA polymerase II transcription in isolated nuclei of transfected myeloma cells. The intact γ2a membrane-specific 3’-untranslated region, with its potential stem loop forming sequences and poly(A) site, is able to efficiently terminate transcription in the absence of the downstream region in which transcription normally terminates (term). Termination efficiency in the presence of the termination fragment decreases either when sequences specifying a potential stem/loop, upstream of the poly(A) region, are interrupted or when the stronger membrane poly(A) site is substituted with a weaker, secretory-specific poly(A) site. We therefore conclude that the γ2a membrane-specific untranslated region plays a major role in specifying downstream termination. We further conclude that the immunoglobulin γ2a, membrane-specific, 3’-untranslated region can function in the context of the gpt gene, driven by an SV40 promoter, to terminate transcription in a poly(A) site dependent fashion. DNA constructs consisting of various segments from the γ2a heavy chain gene membrane-specific 3’-UT and 3’-flanking regions, including the region where γ2a transcription normally terminates, were inserted into a γ2b heavy chain gene which had been deleted for the sec poly(A) site. Using nuclei of mouse myeloma cell lines stably transfected with these constructs, we find that the γ2a membrane untranslated region itself is the most important part of the transcription termination signal. When γ2a membrane UT sequences were inserted into a chimeric gpt/SV40 gene of pSV2gpt, transcription termination was further shown to be induced even with a heterologous promoter and gene, indicating that the sequences have a mode of action independent of the Ig gene. The rate of use of the membrane site was influenced not only by the presence of the unusual sequence elements upstream of the poly(A) site, but also by the poly(A) site itself. The ability of RNA polymerase II to transcribe through the various inserted putative terminator elements in the Igγ gene was assayed in nuclear run-on experiments on stably transfected cell lines. A γ2b heavy chain gene construct deleted for its first poly(A) site and containing no inserted putative transcription termination element, pMPC11 Oli Sac-Kpn, construct A, supports the transcription of the regions downstream from the inserted 24-bp oligonucleotide polylinker at levels nearly equal to transcription of the upstream constant region-encoding exons (Fig. 2A, 3-7% termination; Table I). Insertion of a 2.2-kb fragment of heterologous γ phage DNA into the polylinker, in pMPC11γ, construct B, only slightly increases termination prior to transcription of the downstream probes 6/7 region with most RNA polymerase II molecules traversing the γ DNA as indicated by the strong hybridization to probes 6 and 7 (Fig. 2B, 12-17% termination). Appropriate sense strand cRNA controls, which were designed to detect opposite strand transcription, were included in each nuclear run-on assay (e.g.Fig. 2, probes 2’, 3’, and 6’). In all the experiments there was little or no opposite strand transcription as indicated by the low or absent hybridization to the opposite orientation probes. Hybridization of 32P-labeled nuclear RNA from untransfected J558L cells to probes 1-4 and 6-8 was less than 3% of that seen in the cells transfected with the intact MPC11 gene (data not shown). Table ITable IRelative termination efficiencies of inserted putative termination elements in IgG gene constructs Open table in a new tab Insertion of a 2.2-kb fragment of the γ2a gene 3’ end containing the previously identified region where γ2a transcription normally terminates (term) as well as the γ2a membrane poly(A) signal/site and upstream set of stem loop-specifying GA/CT repeat elements (SL) plus (GT)15 in the 3’-UT was able to act as a very efficient termination element in this system. As seen in Fig. 2C, insertion of this whole element in pMPC11 p(A)m(SL) + term, Table I, construct C, caused a 93-97% decrease in transcription of downstream regions as assayed in isolated transfectant nuclei. The effect of the γ2a region appears to be specific, since the absence of an insert or the presence of a heterologous DNA insert failed to cause termination (Fig. 2, A and B). The probe 5 region contains repetitive DNA elements which are responsible for the high signal obtained so it was subsequently omitted from the analyses. Hybridization of run-on RNA from nuclei of pMPC11 2ap(A)m(SL) + term transformants to probes 6 and 7 was very minimal, indicating that, as we had determined by sequence comparisons, the γ2a and γ2b gene elements are sufficiently diverged to allow for our analyses with these probes. The insertion of the 750-bp region in which γ2a transcription normally terminates (term) with no other upstream γ2a sequences into the γ2b gene (pMPC11 2a term alone) leads to significant read-through of the termination region into the probe 6/7 region (Fig. 3 and Table I, construct D), indicating that the region in which γ2a transcription terminates normally fails to efficiently stop Pol II on its own. The construct pMPC11 2ap(A)m(SL) alone, construct E, contains the γ2a 3’-UT with stem/loop structure and mb poly(A) sites. The data in Fig. 3 and Table I show, somewhat surprisingly, that the γ2a mb 3’-UT and poly(A) region acts as an extremely efficient transcriptional terminator in our constructs. Indeed, transcription has decreased by 72% over the downstream probe 6 region and by 92% over the probe 7 region, relative to transcription of the upstream probe 2 (CH3 exon) region. The ability of the γ2a membrane 3’-UT and poly(A) region to terminate transcription on its own and the inefficiency of the region of termination alone (term) in specifying Pol II stopping indicates a major role for the γ 2a mb 3’-UT and poly(A) region in specifying downstream termination. To test the potential role of the GA repeat motifs in specifying transcription termination, we inserted into the γ2b gene a fragment starting 30 bp upstream of the (CT)23 element of the γ2a membrane 3’-UT region and containing the downstream termination region, but lacking the GA repeat motifs upstream, creating pMPC11 2ap(A)m + term, construct F in Table I. As shown in Fig. 4, this construct was still able to cause specific transcription termination, but at a reduced efficiency (see Table I) in the nuclear run on assay. Therefore, the stem/loop may be an important determinant of the efficiency with which the membrane 3’-UT is able to halt the polymerase molecule. To determine whether another poly(A) region could act as a functional substitute and whether the strength of the poly(A) site played a role in termination, we inserted the γ2b sec poly(A) region together with the downstream γ2a termination region into pMPC11 Oli Sac-Kpn to create pMPC11 2bp(A)s + term, construct G. We have previously shown this Ig secretory-specific poly(A) site to be almost 10 times weaker at directing polyadenylation than the membrane-specific sites when both are placed in competition with the same downstream element (35Lassman C.R. Matis S. Hall B.L. Toppmeyer D.L. Milcarek C. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 1251-1260PubMed Google Scholar, 38Lassman C.R. Milcarek C. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 2578-2585PubMed Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 4, and summarized in Table I, this insert is able to cause 56-64% transcription termination. So the secretory-specific poly(A) site + term is more efficient than the γ2a term region alone, but was not able to terminate transcription as efficiently as the intact γ2a membrane poly(A) region alone or pMPC11 2a poly(A)m(SL) + term. We conclude that stronger poly(A) sites cause more efficient termination than weaker sites. We conclude further that the term region has the effect of increasing termination in conjunction with the sec poly(A) site, since the sec poly(A) site has been previously shown to cause little or no termination on its own (Table I and Ref. 1Flaspohler J.A. Milcarek C. J. Immunol. 1990; 144: 2802-2810PubMed Google Scholar). The expected size or sizes of the transcripts from each of the constructs is shown in Fig. 5. Cytoplasmic, poly(A) containing RNA was isolated, run on denaturing formaldehyde:agarose gels, blotted to membranes, and hybridized with a 32P-labeled probe for the VH domain of the Ig gene. As shown in Fig. 5, the recipient cell line, J558L, produces no endogenous cytoplasmic RNA capable of hybridizing with the VH-specific probe, whereas hybridization of the same blot with a glycerol aldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase probe shows that RNA was present (data not shown). We therefore conclude that the sizes of the cytoplasmic RNAs produced from cells tranfected with constructs A, B, C, D, and E were consistent with the results we had obtained from the transcription run-on studies. Transfectants with constructs F and G produce primarily the shorter of the two predicted species, indicating little use of the second poly(A) site in the transcript. We assume that the virtual absence of the larger predicted mRNA species in construct G (pMPC11 2b(A)s+ term) where 40% of the molecules should read through the second poly(A) site, indicates that either insertion of the termination region in the CH3 to M1 intron interferes with splicing or the first poly(A) site is able to compete for the polyadenylation machinery of the cell because of its promoter proximal location and the large distance between the sites. The amounts of poly(A)-containing cytoplasmic mRNA detected by the VH probe varied not only from construct to construct, but also from transfectant to transfectant with the same construct (data not shown). We have previously shown that between individual stable transfectants, even with the same Ig construct, the amount of exogeneous Ig heavy chain mRNA, as a percentage of total RNA in that cell, can vary from 5 to 50% of the level seen in a normal plasma cell (31Kobrin B.J. Milcarek C. Morrison S.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1986; 6: 1687-1697Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). We assume that this variation is a function of the position of insertion of the exogenously added Ig gene. Therefore, conclusions about the relative abundance of the cytoplasmic poly(A) containing RNAs between constructs is not informative. In these constructs the gpt gene is driven by the SV40 promoter:enhancer elements. Construct AX2 contains the entire GA/CT stem/loop, (GT)15 element and the membrane-specific poly(A) encoding region. Construct XX contains only the (CT)23 portion, (GT)15 and poly(A) region of AX2. In AX2ΔpA the SphI to PvuII fragment containing the two membrane-specific poly(A) site was removed from AX2. Construct SphX contains the poly(A) site and the region 3’ of it from AX2, but lacks the GA/CT and GT regions entirely. We used transient transfections where it is possible to detect more transcription signal from the large number of input molecules. The gpt signal in these experiments was roughly 5% of that seen with an internal β-actin control. The results from the run-on assays, performed on nuclei of cells which had been transfected with the indicated constructs, are shown in Fig. 6, B and C, and summarized in Table II. The run-on probe 12 spans the region from +988 to +1228 downstream of the inserted membrane-specific poly(A) site.Table IIRelative termination efficiencies of inserted γ2aIg elements in gpt constructs Open table in a new tab From the analysis of the results in Table II, we conclude that the regions upstream of and including the membrane poly(A) site can function in the gpt gene, driven by the SV40 promoter, to cause transcription termination. We observe that deletion of the poly(A) site, as in AX2ΔpA, causes a decrease in termination efficiency, yet the membrane-specific poly(A) site alone is insufficient to cause termination in SphX. Therefore, the interaction of the region upstream of the membrane poly(A) site plus the region surrounding the A2UA3 element itself are necessary and sufficient for efficient termination and function independently of the Ig promoter. Cytoplasmic poly(A)-containing RNA was isolated from the J558L transfectants, size-fractionated on denaturing RNA gels, blotted to membranes, and hybridized with a 32P-labeled, antisense probe for the body of the gpt message, i.e. probe 9, see Fig. 6A. The predicted sizes of the gpt RNAs are listed in Table II. As shown in Fig. 7, in cells transfected with AX2 and XX, the most abundant gpt/Ig RNA species were the ones corresponding to use of the first, γ2a, membrane poly(A) site. In accordance with the transcription termination data, very little of the RNA ending with the downstream (SV40 early, vector) poly(A) site was observed. In cells transfected with AX2ΔpA, gpt/Ig RNA, with a size corresponding to use of the downstream vector poly(A), was the major species observed, consistent with the run-on data. However, there was also a gpt/Ig RNA species of 2.15 kb. We hypothesize that this RNA may arises from a AATAA sequence about 35 nt downstream of the start of the AX2 insert. Some of this RNA is also observed in a few of the AX2 transfectants with an intact stem/loop and poly(A) site, see lanes 3 and 4, Fig. 7. Since little transcription termination was occurring just beyond the second poly(A) site, we had expected to see only the longer gpt/Ig RNA (2.8 kb) species in the transfectants with SphX. Those are observed, but, in addition, we saw a species whose size (2.2 kb) is consistent with the use of the first (membrane) poly(A) site. We conclude that the “first come first served” model of poly(A) site choice (38Lassman C.R. Milcarek C. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 2578-2585PubMed Google Scholar) is operating in this construct. We show that the Ig heavy chain γ2a membrane poly(A) region, which contains an upstream GA/CT element, a (GT)15 element and two tandem poly(A) signal/sites, each with their own downstream GT-rich elements, is capable of specifying very efficient transcription termination in two different types of constructs. We see 72-92% termination in a construct driven by the homologous Ig promoter and 65% termination in a construct where it is driven by the SV40 promoter. The distance of the termination event relative to the γ2a membrane poly(A) site is over a range of 320-1470 nt, analogous to most eucaryotic genes thus far studied where the poly(A) to termination event distance is approximately 1000 nt. The Igγ2a membrane poly(A) site could therefore serve as a moderately sized (approximately 600 nt) cassette for gene expression studies where an efficient poly(A) site:terminator is required. Disruption of the GA/CT potential stem loop in the γ2a membrane 3’-UT in the construct pMPC11 2ap(A)m + term, construct F, while still allowing fairly efficient termination, increases the level of read-through transcription relative to constructs C or E. The same is true in the comparison of constructs XX and AX2 in Table II. The formation of an RNA stem loop 95 nt upstream of the membrane poly(A) site could enhance termination by directly increasing membrane poly(A) site utilization through sequestering of polyadenylation factors and/or pausing the RNA polymerase II elongation complex. In this model polyadenylation and termination could be linked and increasing membrane poly(A) site utilization inherently would lead to increasing transcription termination. Alternatively, the RNA stem loop may increase termination efficiency directly through slowing or stalling polymerase II and/or providing a site where a putative “antitermination factor” is lost or a “termination factor” is bound to the elongation complex. This eucaryotic element bears a striking resemblance to the procaryotic factor independent terminators for RNA polymerase where the polymerase stalls at a stem loop structure in the RNA. A nuclear factor binding site has been located just upstream (8Law A. Kuwabard M. Briskin M. Fasel N. Hermanson G. Sigman D. Wall R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 4: 9160-9164Crossref Scopus (15) Google Scholar) of the μ membrane poly(A) site and has been proposed as a nucleation site for termination factor binding. The region upstream of the μ membrane poly(A) site has also been reported to stall or pause polymerase II elongation through interaction with DNA repetitive elements in the vicinity of the μ membrane poly(A) site and mediate termination (2Galli G. Guise J.W. McDevitt M.A. Tucker P.W. Nevins J.R. Genes & Dev. 1987; 1: 471-481Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 3Guise J.W. Lim P.L. Yuan D. Tucker P.W. J. Immunol. 1988; 140: 3988-3994PubMed Google Scholar). The presence of a (GT)15 element, also upstream of the γ2a membrane poly(A) site, is intriguing, since GT-rich elements are found downstream of many poly(A) sites. The (GT)15 element may have a role in enhancing the strength of the membrane specific poly(A) site. The ability of the γ2a termination region to cause only 40% transcription termination on its own mirrors the inefficiency of the mouse β major globin gene termination region in specifying termination when inserted into the adenovirus E1A gene (20Falck-Pedersen E. Logan J. Shenk T. Darnell Jr., J.E. The γ2a termination region may contribute to termination by possessing a sequence which facilitates polymerase II pausing and/or disengagement as directed by upstream sequence elements. When we compare the termination in probe 6 for constructs labeled D, G, F, and C we see a progressive increase in termination efficiency (from 40-56% to 76-97%, see Table II). This progression seems to parallel an increase in the “strength” of the poly(A) sites involved. We previously measured the amount of steady state cytoplasmic RNA in J558L cells transfected with different constructs in which the membrane or secretory-specific poly(A) regions were put in a cis-competition with an identical downstream SV40 early poly(A) site (35Lassman C.R. Matis S. Hall B.L. Toppmeyer D.L. Milcarek C. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 1251-1260PubMed Google Scholar). The myeloma cells containing the γ2b secretory poly(A) region produced cytoplasmic RNA in which the sec poly(A)-terminated molecules were three times as abundant as the SV40 poly(A)-terminated molecules. Cells transfected with γ2a membrane poly(A) region constructs with only the (CT)23 half of the potential stem/loop sequences produced RNA in which the mb-terminated molecules were 26 times as abundant as the SV40-terminated molecules (35Lassman C.R. Matis S. Hall B.L. Toppmeyer D.L. Milcarek C. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 1251-1260PubMed Google Scholar). The cells transfected with the full GA:CT sequence element of the 2a mb untranslated region produced RNA in which the mb-terminated molecules were 89 times as abundant as the SV40-terminated molecules (41Hall B.L. Sequence and Secondary Structure of the Murine Immunoglobulin 2a Membrane 3’-Untranslated Region. 1989; (Ph.D. thesis, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA)Google Scholar). So, by the criteria of stable mRNA produced, the membrane poly(A) site is much stronger than the sec site. Likewise, we and others have also shown that the μ membrane site is stronger than the μ secretory site as assayed in various constructs (2Galli G. Guise J.W. McDevitt M.A. Tucker P.W. Nevins J.R. Genes & Dev. 1987; 1: 471-481Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 3Guise J.W. Lim P.L. Yuan D. Tucker P.W. J. Immunol. 1988; 140: 3988-3994PubMed Google Scholar, 26Edwalds-Gilbert G. Biol. 1989; 9: 726-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). In the absence of any known poly(A) site, the term alone construct (construct D), termination falls to 40%. We conclude that a poly(A) site is required for efficient termination, and the stronger the site, the more active the process becomes. This conclusion is confirmed by the lack of termination in the construct AX2ΔpA. A functional poly(A) site has been shown to be mandatory for termination of polymerase II transcripts both in cells and nuclear extracts (20Falck-Pedersen E. Logan J. Shenk T. Darnell Jr., J.E. Cell. 1985; 40: 897-905Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 21Whitelaw E. Proudfoot N. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2915-2922Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar, 22Logan J. Falck-Pedersen E. Darnell J.E. Shenk T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8306-8310Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar, 23Lanoix J. Acheson N.H. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 2515-2522Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 24Connelly S. Manley J.L. Genes & Dev. 1988; 2: 440-452Crossref PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar, 25Miralles V.J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1991; 19: 3593-3599Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar). It is intriguing to speculate whether poly(A) site “strength” in other polymerase II gene products is a true reflection of the polyadenylation/cleavage efficiency of the sequence itself or is more a function of the ability of that site to promote termination which then facilitates mature 3’ end formation. The stronger membrane Igμ poly(A) site terminates transcription more efficiently than the weaker secretory-specific Igμ site in an adenovirus hybrid construct (26Edwalds-Gilbert G. Prescott J. Falck-Pedersen E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 3472-3480Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Transcription termination and poly(A) site strength are clearly interrelated, perhaps not directly through cleavage and polyadenylation itself, but through assembly or disassembly of an elongation complex. Transmembrane disposition of the NH2-terminal third of the Na,K-ATPase α subunit was studied using an experimental approach that involved in vitro endoplasmic reticulum membrane insertion of chimeras. These chimeras consisted of four truncated amino-terminal segments of the α subunit linked at amino acid residues 126, 179, 313, and 439 to chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT), a reporter protein, that contains a consensus sequence for N-linked glycosylation. The fusion sites were located after one of the four hydrophobic segments (H1-H4). The results showed that the chimeras in which the α subunit was truncated at positions 126 and 313 were glycosylated, and the glycosylated peptides were protected by membranes from proteolysis. However, the other two chimeras were not glycosylated and the inserted peptides were digested by protease into fragments which did not immunoprecipitate with anti-CAT. These results clearly demonstrate that hydrophobic segments H1 and H3 function as signal/anchor type II, and H2 and H4 function as halt transfer signals. Furthermore, membrane insertion of the NH2-terminal third of Na,K-ATPase α subunit is achieved by a series of alternate signal/anchor type II and halt transfer sequences. Transmembrane disposition of the NH2-terminal third of the Na,K-ATPase α subunit was studied using an experimental approach that involved in vitro endoplasmic reticulum membrane insertion of chimeras. These chimeras consisted of four truncated amino-terminal segments of the α subunit linked at amino acid residues 126, 179, 313, and 439 to chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT), a reporter protein, that contains a consensus sequence for N-linked glycosylation. The fusion sites were located after one of the four hydrophobic segments (H1-H4). The results showed that the chimeras in which the α subunit was truncated at positions 126 and 313 were glycosylated, and the glycosylated peptides were protected by membranes from proteolysis. However, the other two chimeras were not glycosylated and the inserted peptides were digested by protease into fragments which did not immunoprecipitate with anti-CAT. These results clearly demonstrate that hydrophobic segments H1 and H3 function as signal/anchor type II, and H2 and H4 function as halt transfer signals. Furthermore, membrane insertion of the NH2-terminal third of Na,K-ATPase α subunit is achieved by a series of alternate signal/anchor type II and halt transfer sequences. Na,K-ATPase of animal cells is an integral plasma membrane protein which plays an important role in maintaining the characteristic ionic composition of cytoplasm and in generating electro-chemical gradients necessary for normal cell function (see reviews by Jorgensen and Andersen, 1988Jorgensen P.L. Andersen J.P. J. Membr. Biol. 1988; 103: 95-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (268) Google Scholar and Skou and Esmann, 1992Skou J.C. Esmann M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 988: 185-220Google Scholar). The enzyme consists of two noncovalently linked subunits in an equimolar ratio (Brotherus et al., 1983Brotherus J.R. Moller J.V. Jorgensen P.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1983; 731: 290-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar): a larger nonglycosylated α subunit (about 100 kDa), and a glycosylated β subunit (about 55 kDa) (Glynn, 1985Glynn I.M. Martonosi N.Y. The Enzyme of Biological Membranes. Plenum Publishing Corp., New York1985: 35-114Google Scholar; Jorgensen, 1982Jorgensen P.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 694: 27-68Crossref PubMed Scopus (369) Google Scholar), both of which are transmembrane proteins (see review by Ovchinnikov, 1987Ovchinnikov Y.A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1987; 12: 434-438Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (27) Google Scholar). The complete amino acid sequence of the Na,K-ATPase α subunit has been deduced from the nucleotide sequence of cDNA cloned from various sources (Shull et al., 1986Shull G.E. Lane L.K. Lingrel J.B. Nature. 1986; 321: 429-431Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar; Kawakami et al., 1985Kawakami K. Noguchi S. Noda M. Takahashi H. Ohta T. Kawamura M. Nojima H. Nagano K. Hirose T. Inayama S. Hayashida H. Miyata T. Numa S. Nature. 1985; 316: 733-736Crossref PubMed Scopus (237) Google Scholar, Kawakami et al., 1986Kawakami K. Ohta T. Nojima H. Nagano K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1986; 100: 389-397Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar; Noguchi et al., 1986Noguchi S. Noda M. Takahashi H. Kawakami K. FEBS Lett. 1986; 196: 315-320Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar; Hara et al., 1987Hara Y. Urayama O. Kawakami T. Ohta T. Nagano K. Nakao M. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1987; 102: 43-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). The hydropathy analysis has shown that the α subunit has eight to ten hydrophobic segments. Four segments (H1-H4) are present in the NH2-terminal third, and the rest of four to six segments are present in the COOH-terminal third. Orientation of the first four hydrophobic segments in the lipid bilayer has been investigated by a variety of approaches, including immunochemical methods (Farley et al., 1986Farley R.A. Ochoa G.T. Kudrow A. Am. J. Physiol. 1986; 250: C896-C906Crossref PubMed Google Scholar; Ball and Loftice, 1987Ball Jr., W.J. Loftice C.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1987; 916: 100-111Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar; Felsenfeld and Sweadner, 1988Felsenfeld D.P. Sweadner K.J. J. Biol. Cell Biol. 1990; 68: 1262-1267Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar; Arystarkhova et al., 1992Arystarkhova E. Gasparian M. Modyanov N.N. Sweadner K.J. J. Biol. Modyanov N.N. FEBS Lett. 1987; 217: 269-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar), site-specific labeling (Jorgensen et al., 1982Jorgensen P.L. Karlish S.J.D. Gitler C. J. Biol. These results demonstrated that the NH2 terminus is exposed on the cytoplasmic side of the membrane and that the predicted four hydrophobic segments appear to be transmembrane domain. Recently Homareda et al., 1989Homareda H. Kawakami K. Nagano K. Matsui H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 5742-5745Crossref PubMed Google Scholar constructed truncated α subunits containing two adjacent hydrophobic segments (H1 and H2, H3 and H4, or H5 and H6) and examined if these truncated peptides were inserted into dog pancreas microsomal membranes in N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive fashion using a rabbit reticulocyte lysate translation system. Their results have shown that at least two insertion signals are present within the four hydrophobic segments in the NH2-terminal third. In the present paper, we describe the studies on the transmembrane disposition of the NH2-terminal third of α subunit using an experimental strategy based on the topogenic properties of the four hydrophobic segments H1-H4. In this approach, a reporter protein chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT)1 1The abbreviations used are: CATchloramphenicol acetyltransferaseDTTdithiothreitolEndo Hendoglycosidase HPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisERendoplasmic reticulum. that has a consensus N-linked glycosylation site is linked sequentially in frame after each hydrophobic segment in four truncated α subunits of different lengths. CAT is chosen since it is a cytosolic protein and does not contain either insertion or halt transfer sequences. It can therefore be used as a faithful COOH-terminal reporter protein (Lipp and Dobberstein, 1986Lipp J. Dobberstein B. Cell. 1986; 46: 1103-1112Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar, Lipp and Dobberstein, 1988Lipp J. Dobberstein B. J. Cell Biol. 1988; 106: 1813-1820Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). The chimeras are designed such that topogenic properties of hydrophobic segments can be examined sequentially in the native context. Signal/anchor and halt transfer sequences are identified by characterization of their COOH-terminal flanking sequence with respect to the membrane. Two properties, occurrence of N-linked glycosylation and membrane protection of the reporter protein from proteolysis, are used as the marker for the luminal disposition. The results, therefore, will provide information on both the orientation (with respect to the membrane) and the function (an insertion signal, a halt transfer signal or topogenically inactive element) of each hydrophobic segment in the native context. chloramphenicol acetyltransferase dithiothreitol endoglycosidase H polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis endoplasmic reticulum. Restriction enzymes, SP6 RNA polymerase, DNA polymerase I (Klenow enzyme), T4 DNA ligase, T4 polynucleotide kinase, RNasin, Taq DNA polymerase, m7G(5’)ppp(5’)G, and calf intestinal alkaline phosphatase were obtained from either Boehringer Mannheim or Life Technologies, Inc. Tetracaine, phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, trypsin, chymotrypsin, and Trasylol (aprotinin) were obtained from Sigma. The Geneclean kit was purchased from BIO 101. Reticulocyte lysate and dog pancreas microsomal membranes were obtained from Promega Corp. (Madison, WI). [35S]Methionine was obtained from DuPont NEN. Rabbit antibody against CAT was obtained from 5 Prime → 3 Prime Inc. (Boulder, CO). Plasmids pGEM-3Z and pCAT basic were obtained from Promega Corp., and pT7/T3 19R was obtained from Life Technologies, Inc. Okayama-Berg vector containing an entire coding region of rat brain Na,K-ATPase α-1 subunit was supplied by Dr. Y. Hara (Tokyo Dental Medical School, Tokyo). All cDNA constructs (pN-1, pN-2, pN-3, and pN-4) encoding the fusion proteins of the truncated Na,K-ATPase α subunit and CAT as a reporter protein were derived from two plasmids: pF1 in which the entire coding region of α-1 subunit was engineered into a plasmid pT7/T3 19R, and pCAT, in which the entire coding region of CAT was engineered into a plasmid pGEM-3Z. cDNA constructs pX-1, pX-2, pX-3, and pX-4 were constructed from an in vivo and in vitro expression vector containing rat growth hormone cDNA (pSG5rGH) and one of the pN-1, pN-2, pN-3, and pN-4. The α-1 subunit cDNA, engineered from Okayama-Berg vector into pT7/T3 19R vector, contained about 200 nucleotides in 5’ end-noncoding region. When the mRNA from the cDNA was translated in a rabbit reticulocyte lysate system the translation efficiency was very poor probably due to the long stretch of GC pairs preceding the initiation codon. To improve the in vitro translation efficiency, a new 45-mer oligonucleotide, AGCTTGATATCGATAACTGAATAGCTGCAGGACGATCGCCATGGG, was designed according to Kozak's rule (Kozak, 1987Kozak M. J. Mol. Biol. 1987; 196: 947-950Crossref PubMed Scopus (985) Google Scholar) and engineered just before the initiator codon of the α subunit by ligating the annealed oligomers, the NcoI/SacI fragment from plasmid Okayama-Berg α1 and the plasmid pT7/T3 19R cut with HindIII and NcoI. The entire coding region of the CAT gene obtained by cutting a plasmid pCAT basic with HindIII and NlaIV was ligated into the plasmid pGEM-3Z cut with HindIII and HincII. The 404-base pair fragment obtained by cutting a plasmid pF I with PstI and RsaI was ligated into the plasmid pCAT that had been cut with PstI and HincII. A plasmid pF 1 was linearized by NspV digestion, and its protruding ends were filled in with Klenow enzyme. The linearized, blunt-ended pF 1 was then ligated to 8-mer SalI linkers, and the ligated sample was digested with PstI and SalI. A 535-base pair PstI/SalI fragment thus obtained was inserted into the plasmid pCAT that had been cut with PstI and SalI. A plasmid pF 1 was digested with XhoI, and the protruding ends were filled in with Klenow enzyme. After digestion with PstI, an approximately 0.97-kilobase pair fragment was isolated and inserted into the plasmid pCAT that had been cut with PstI and HincII. A plasmid pF 1 was linearized with AflII, and its protruding ends were filled in with Klenow enzyme. After digestion with PstI, a fragment of about 1.35 kilobase pair was isolated and inserted into the plasmid pCAT that had been cut with PstI and HincII. A fragment containing one of four hydrophobic segments (H1, H2, H3, or H4) and CAT was made by polymerase chain reaction using their corresponding linearized plasmid pN-1, pN-2, pN-3, or pN-4 as the template and two oligonucleotides described below. The polymerase chain reaction product was digested with NaeI (pX-1 and pX-2) or PmlI (pX-3 and pX-4) and BamHI and then ligated to the plasmid pSG5rGH that had been cut with Eco47III and BamHI. The NH2-terminal side oligonucleotides (oligonucleotides 1, 2, 3, and 4) and the COOH-terminal side oligonucleotide (oligonucleotide C) are: oligonucleotide 1 for pX-1, ATTCCGGCAGCTGTT; oligonucleotide 2 for pX-2, GATGAGCTCTGCCGGCTGTACCTCGGGGTCGTGGC; oligonucleotide 3 for pX-3, GATGAGCTCGCACGTGTCATCCACCTCATCACGGG; oligonucleotide 4 for pX-4, TGATGAGCTCGCACGTGCTGTCATCTTCCTCATTGG; oligonucleotide C, CCATGGCTCGAGCTTAAG. That all constructs encoding chimeras were ligated in frame has been confirmed by DNA sequencing, size of the primary translation products, and immunoreactivity of the primary translation products to anti-CAT antibody. Microsomes were prepared from canine pancreas as described by Walter and Blobel, 1983Walter P. Blobel G. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 96: 84-93Crossref PubMed Scopus (470) Google Scholar. Occasionally microsomal membranes were obtained from Promega Corp. The plasmids pN-1, pN-2, pN-3, and pN-4 and pX-1, pX-2, pX-3, and pX-4 were cut with SmaI and BamHI, respectively, and the linearized DNAs were purified with a Geneclean kit. A 45 μl of transcription reaction mixture contains 5 μg of linearized plasmid DNA, 80 mM HEPES-KOH (pH 7.5), 16 mM MgCl2, 2 mM spermidine, 40 mM DTT, 1 unit/μl RNasin, 25 μg/ml bovine serum albumin, 0.5 μM cap analog (m7G(5’)ppp(5’)G), and 50 units of SP6 RNA polymerase (for pN-1, pN-2, pN-3, and pN-4) or T7 RNA polymerase (for pX-1, pX-2, pX-3, and pX-4). After the mixture was incubated for 10 min at 40°C, 5 μl of nucleotide mixture (0.5 mM each of ATP, CTP, UTP, and GTP) was added and incubated again at 40°C for 1 h. Then, in order to obtain the maximal amount of the transcripts, 50 units of RNA polymerase were added, and the reaction mixture was incubated at 40°C for an additional hour. The transcripts were then purified with phenol/chloroform extraction, followed by ethanol precipitation, and the pellets were dissolved in 50 μl of diethyl pyrocarbonate-treated water. The translation reaction was carried out as described in the Promega's technical manual. Briefly, a 20-μl translation mixture contains 14 μl of reticulocyte lysate, 1.6 μl of 10 mCi/ml [35S]methionine, 20 μM each of the other 19 amino acids, 20 units of RNasin, and 68 mM KOAc (endogenous amount of KOAc, 78 mM, contained in the lysate was not included). The reaction mixture was incubated at 30°C for 90 min in the presence or absence of microsomal membranes (5 A260 units/ml of translation reaction). Immediately after the incubation was over, the translation mixture was chilled on ice and diluted with high salt buffer (500 mM KOAc, 3 mM Mg(OAc)2, 50 mM triethanolamine (pH 7.5), and 1 mM DTT) to 100 μl. The diluted sample was incubated on ice for an additional 10 min and overlaid onto a 100-μl cushion containing 0.5 M sucrose, 500 mM KOAc, 50 mM triethanolamine, 3 mM Mg(OAc)2, and 1 mM DDT. The step gradient was centrifuged at 60,000 rpm for 150 min in the 100.3 rotor of the Beckman centrifuge TL-100. The top 125 μl was collected as the supernatant fraction, the rest of the sucrose cushion was discarded, and the pellet (microsomal fraction) was gently washed once with high salt buffer. The supernatant fractions (see the previous paragraph) or the translation products synthesized in the absence of membranes were mixed with 1.7 volume of saturated ammonium sulfate solution. Trasylol was added to a final concentration of 2 μg/ml. The mixture was incubated on ice for 30 min and centrifuged at 4°C for 4 min. The resultant pellets were suspended in a small volume of 5% trichloroacetic acid and centrifuged at 4°C for 4 min in an Eppendorf centrifuge. The pellets were suspended in a small volume of 0.1 M Tris-HCl (pH 9.2), 2% SDS, and 50 mM DTT. The suspension was incubated for 30 min at 55°C and then analyzed in 12.5% SDS-PAGE. The microsomal membranes isolated from the translation mixture as described earlier were dissolved in a 30 μl 1% SDS solution containing 50 mM DTT, incubated for 3 min in boiling water, followed by addition of an equal volume of 0.2 M sodium citrate buffer (pH 5.5) containing 0.2 μg/ml Trasylol. The samples were then equally divided into two parts: one part was supplemented with 3 μl of 1 mU/μl Endo H and to the other 3 μl of water was added. Both samples were incubated at 37°C overnight. After addition of 33 μl of the sample loading buffer (0.1 M Tris-HCl pH 9.2, 50 mM DTT and 10% glycerol) the samples were incubated in boiling water for 3 min and analyzed in 12.5% SDS-PAGE. Microsomal membranes isolated from the translation mixture were suspended in 40 μl of dilution buffer (2.5% Triton X-100, 190 mM NaCl, 6 mM EDTA, 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4)) containing 0.1 μg/ml Trasylol. 10 μl of 20% SDS solution was added, and the sample was incubated in boiling water for 4 min. After the sample was chilled to about 4°C, 4 volumes of cold dilution buffer and then 4 μl of antiserum against CAT were added. The samples were processed as described by Anderson and Blobel, 1983Anderson D.J. Blobel G. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 96: 111-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar. For immunoprecipitation of the translation products synthesized in the absence of microsomal membranes, immunoprecipitation was conducted after the endogenous globins were removed by addition of saturated ammonium sulfate, as described before. Translation mixture was diluted with 3 volumes of 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 100 mM NaCl, and incubated in the presence of 3 mM tetracaine hydrochloride at room temperature for 10 min to stabilize the microsomal membranes. Freshly prepared stock solutions of trypsin and chymotrypsin were added to a final concentration of 100 μg/ml each in the presence or absence of 1% Triton X-100. Proteolytic digestion was carried out at room temperature for 30 min and terminated by the addition of Trasylol (at a final concentration of 2 μg/ml) and phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (at a final concentration of 3 mM). The reaction mixture was then supplemented with KOAc to a final concentration of 400 mM and overlaid onto 100 μl of 0.5 M sucrose/0.5 M KOAc cushion. The step gradient was centrifuged at 60,000 rpm for 15 min in the 100.3 rotor of the Beckman centrifuge TL-100. The membrane pellets were washed once with 50 μl of high salt buffer solution and analyzed in SDS-PAGE after incubation in boiling water for 5 min in the presence of sample loading buffer. As shown in the hydropathy plot (Fig. 1), the NH2-terminal third of the Na,K-ATPase α subunit contains four hydrophobic segments. They are located at residues Leu91-Ile112 (H1), Leu125-Gln145 (H2), Phe286-Leu308 (H3), and Ala315-Ala343 (H4). The topogenic nature of these hydrophobic segments was examined using in vitro insertion into endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of chimeras that were expressed by the cDNA constructs pN-1, pN-2, pN-3 and pN-4. These constructs contained one or more hydrophobic segments sequentially in their native context. As described in the Introduction, two criteria, occurrence of N-linked glycosylation of the reporter protein and membrane protection of the reporter protein from proteolysis, were used as markers for the luminal location of the ligation site. When the mRNA transcribed from pN-1 was translated in a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in the absence of microsomal membranes, the immunoprecipitates with anti-CAT antibody contained a single band with molecular mass of 39 kDa, which corresponds to the size of the primary translation product of the fusion protein N-1 (Fig. 2, lane 1). Translation in the presence of microsomal membranes yielded two major proteins with molecular masses of about 42 and 39 kDa (Fig. 2, lane 2). This 39-kDa protein was slightly larger than the primary translation product in lane 1, which suggested that the 39-kDa protein was not the primary translation product but the glycosylated fusion protein N-1 that was initiated from an internal methionine, Met27. This is supported by Endo H digestion results discussed below. The 42-kDa protein comprised about 60% of the total immunoprecipitates. The immunoprecipitates also contained a smaller protein (about 36 kDa) as a minor product. Since an internal methionine residue is located at the 32nd amino acid from the NH2 terminus (see Fig. 1), the minor protein may be the unglycosylated fusion protein N-1 that was initiated by the internal methionine. When the immunoprecipitates shown in lane 2 were digested with Endo H, the two major proteins shifted quantitatively from 42 and 39 kDa to 39 and 36 kDa, respectively (lane 3). This 36-kDa protein migrated exactly at the same speed as the minor protein in lane 2, strongly supporting that the 39-kDa protein in lane 2 was the glycosylated fusion protein N-2 initiated by Met27 Therefore, the glycosylated form comprised more than 80% of the newly synthesized fusion proteins. This high efficiency of translocation of the fusion protein N-1 initiated by the hydrophobic segment H1 allowed us to examine the topogenic properties of its downstream hydrophobic segments in an in vitro translation/translocation system. To examine whether the hydrophobic segment H1 functions as an anchor signal, the fusion protein N-1, which was synthesized in the presence of microsomes, was digested with trypsin and chymotrypsin in the presence or absence of Triton X-100. The membrane-protected fragments were recovered by immunoprecipitation with anti-CAT antibody. In this experiment, if H1 functioned as an anchor signal, 95 NH2-terminal flanking residues of H1 would remain untranslocated in the cytoplasmic side of the membrane and would be cleaved by proteases in the absence of Triton X-100. Therefore, the size of a peptide that is protected by membranes from proteolysis will be smaller by about 10 kDa than the control fusion protein N-1. As shown in Fig. 3, lane 2, one fragment whose molecular mass was about 30 kDa was recovered by immunoprecipitation when digested in the absence of Triton X-100. As no fragments were recovered upon digesting in the presence of Triton X-100 (Fig. 3, lane 3), it is reasonable to conclude that the fragment recovered was a membrane protected one. These results clearly demonstrated that the hydrophobic segment H1 functioned as an insertion signal as well as an anchor of the inserted signal sequence and also confirmed that the NH2-terminal flanking region of the H1 is located in the cytoplasmic side of the membrane. Upon translation of the plasmid pN-2 transcript in a reticulocyte lysate without addition of microsomes, a major protein with molecular mass of about 51 kDa was recovered by immunoprecipitation with anti-CAT antibody (Fig. 2, lane 4). This size corresponds to that of the unglycosylated fusion protein N-2. A minor band (about 48 kDa) was also recovered. This protein was probably an unglycosylated fusion protein N-2 that was initiated by the internal Met27. The molecular mass difference between the major and minor proteins was about 3 kDa, which corresponds to the size of the peptide between Met-5 and Met27. When the pN-2 transcripts were translated in the presence of microsomes, a 51-kDa protein was recovered as a major product (Fig. 2, lane 5). This product had the same apparent molecular mass as those obtained in the absence of microsomes (compare the sizes of the major bands in lanes 4 and 5), which strongly indicated that the fusion protein N-2 was not glycosylated. As predicted, the apparent molecular mass of this band did not shift down by Endo H treatment (the data are not shown here). Since the CAT protein was linked to an amino acid residue in the COOH-terminal flanking region of H2, the result showed that the translocation which was initiated by H1 was halted by H2, and consequently the CAT protein remained in the cytoplasmic side of membranes as illustrated in Fig. 2, bottom. These results were further supported by proteolysis experiments. Fig. 3, lane 5, showed that no membrane-protected fragments were recovered by immunoprecipitation upon digestion with proteases. The immunoprecipitates from the translation of pN-3 transcript in the absence of microsomes contained a major band with molecular mass of about 59 kDa (Fig. 2, lane 6), which is the size of an unglycosylated fusion protein N-3. A minor band (about 56 kDa) might be an unglycosylated fusion protein that was initiated by an internal methionine. Translation in the presence of microsomes yielded an additional band with molecular mass of about 62 kDa (Fig. 2, lane 7). The larger band, however, shifted its molecular mass to 59 kDa by Endo H treatment (Fig. 2, lane 8), which confirmed that the shift was due to deglycosylation of the N-linked sugar moiety. Since hydrophobic segment H3 was linked to an amino acid residue in the COOH-terminal flanking region of H3, the results demonstrated that the second round of translocation of the N-3 peptide was initiated by H3, and the following CAT protein was translocated into the ER lumen where it was glycosylated. To confirm if the hydrophobic segment H3 functions also as an anchor signal, the translation mixture performed in the presence of microsomes was digested with trypsin and chymotrypsin, and the digested sample was subjected to immunoprecipitation with anti-CAT antibody. As predicted, only one fragment (about 29 kDa) was recovered by the immunoprecipitation (Fig. 3, lane 8), and no fragments were recovered upon proteolysis in the presence of Triton X-100 (Fig. 3, lane 9). This verified that the 29-kDa band was the membrane-protected fragment, and the results confirmed that the hydrophobic segment H3 functioned as a signal/anchor type II. Translation of the plasmid pN-4 transcript carried out in a reticulocyte lysate without addition of microsomal membranes produced a major band with molecular mass of about 70 kDa (Fig. 2, lane 9), which corresponds to the unglycosylated form of the fusion protein N-4. Translation performed in the presence of microsomes produced also a 70-kDa protein (Fig. 2, lane 10). This result indicated that the H4 halted the translocation of its downstream peptide containing CAT protein, and therefore, the CAT protein remained in the cytoplasmic side of the membranes. To ascertain that the CAT protein remained untranslocated, the translation mixture of the pN-4 transcript, carried out in the presence of microsomes, was digested with trypsin and chymotrypsin, and the digested sample was subjected to immunoprecipitation with anti-CAT antibody. No fragments were recovered (Fig. 3, lane 11). Thus, protease digestion experiments demonstrated that the CAT protein remained in the cytoplasmic side of membranes and was digested by exogenously added proteases. Figure 2:, Figure 3: have shown that hydrophobic segments H2 and H4 function as halt transfer signal in the native context. In order to examine whether the topogenic nature of H2 and H4 is intrinsic and whether H1 and H3 are also capable of halting translocation, we chose a rat growth hormone signal sequence and constructed plasmids pX-1, pX-2, pX-3, and pX-4. These plasmids encoded fusion proteins consisting of the NH2-terminal 66 amino acid residues (including a cleavable signal sequence) of rat growth hormone and one of the hydrophobic segments (H1, H2, H3, and H4) linked at its COOH-terminal flanking region to the CAT protein. As a control, plasmid pX-c was constructed. This plasmid encoded a chimera consisting of NH2-terminal 66 amino acid residues of rat growth hormone and CAT protein only. In this experiment, the topogenic nature of each hydrophobic segment was characterized by occurrence of N-linked glycosylation of the reporter protein and complete protection by membranes from proteolysis, as shown schematically in Fig. 4B. The transcripts of plasmids pX-c, pX-1, pX-2, pX-3, and pX-4 were translated in a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in the presence and absence of microsomes. An aliquot of the translation mixture was immunoprecipitated with anti-CAT antibody, and the resulting precipitates were digested with Endo H. Other aliquots were digested with trypsin and chymotrypsin in the presence or absence of Triton X-100, and membrane-protected fragments were recovered by immunoprecipitation with anti-CAT antibody. The results are summarized in Fig. 4A. The primary translation product of the control chimera X-c gave a single band with a molecular mass of about 33 kDa (X-c, lane 1). The product obtained in the presence of microsomes also gave a single band with a molecular mass of about 33 kDa (X-c, lane 2); however, the molecular mass of this protein was shifted to about 30 kDa by Endo H digestion (X-c, lane 3). After digestion of the translation product with trypsin and chymotrypsin, a 33-kDa protein was recovered by immunoprecipitation (X-c, lane 4), but the translocated protein was digested into undetectable fragments by immunoprecipitation when digested in the presence of Triton X-100 (X-c, lane 5). These results show that, as expected, the cleavable signal sequence of rat growth hormone did very efficiently initiate translocation of the control chimera, and almost all of the translocated proteins were glycosylated and fully protected by membranes from proteolysis. The primary translation products of the plasmids pX-1, pX-2, pX-3, and pX-4 were about 37, 44, 37, and 47 kDa, respectively (Fig. 4A), and the translation products carried out in the presence of microsomes were about 34, 41, 34, and 44 kDa, respectively. These sizes were not changed by Endo H treatment (Fig. 4A), suggesting that all four chimeric proteins were inserted into membranes where their signal sequences were cleaved and further translocation of their downstream peptides was halted by the hydrophobic segments. Therefore the CAT protein remained in the cytoplasmic side of the membranes. When these translation products were digested with trypsin and chymotrypsin, no fragments were recovered by immunoprecipitation with anti-CAT antibody, which proved that the CAT protein remained in the cytosol and was digested by exogenously added proteases (Fig. 4). Thus, the data have clearly demonstrated that all four hydrophobic segments in the NH2-terminal third of α subunit have halt transfer signal function when they are in a different context and therefore their nature seems to be intrinsic. In addition, these experiments further confirmed that hydrophobic segments H2 and H4 are transmembrane domains. We report here the topogenesis of the NH2-terminal third of the α subunit examined by using in vitro ER membrane insertion of two different groups of chimeras. The first group of chimeras encoded fusion proteins consisting of different lengths of truncated α subunit with one or more hydrophobic segments located sequentially in the native context and CAT protein as a reporter protein. The second group encoded fusion proteins consisting of NH2-terminal 66 amino acid residues (including a cleavable signal sequence) of rat growth hormone, one of the H1, H2, H3, or H4 sequences, and CAT protein. Our data demonstrated that the membrane insertion of the NH2-terminal third of α subunit was initiated by H1 which functioned as a signal/anchor type II and was achieved by the downstream hydrophobic segments, which acted alternately as halt transfer (H2), insertion (H3), and halt transfer (H4) signals. The data also demonstrated that H1 and H3 were capable of halting translocation of their downstream peptides and that halt transfer function shown by all four hydrophobic segments seemed to be intrinsic. Homareda et al., 1989Homareda H. Kawakami K. Nagano K. Matsui H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 5742-5745Crossref PubMed Google Scholar used in vitro ER membrane insertion of truncated α subunits that contain two adjacent hydrophobic segments such as H1 and H2 or H3 and H4 to examine which of the hydrophobic segments function as an insertion signal. Since the truncated polypeptides that were inserted into microsomal membranes in an N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive fashion were resistant to alkali extraction, Homareda et al., 1989Homareda H. Kawakami K. Nagano K. Matsui H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 5742-5745Crossref PubMed Google Scholar have suggested that at least two insertion signals were present in the NH2-terminal third of the α subunit. The present data confirm the existence of two insertion signals in the NH2-terminal third and furthermore demonstrate that H1 and H3 function as a signal/anchor type II. The number of transmembrane domains in the NH2-terminal third of α subunit established here is in agreement with those reported previously (Jorgensen, 1982Jorgensen P.L. Biochim. Biophys.
